webTitle: England to get salaries tied to results in elastic bands

fields.headline: England to get salaries tied to results in elastic bands
fields.trailText: The salaries of England's leading players will be performance-related next season, the England and Wales Cricket Board chief executive Tim Lamb revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The salaries of England's leading players will be performance-related next season, the England and Wales Cricket Board chief executive Tim Lamb revealed yesterday.

In advance of the announcement on March 1 of England's soon-to-be centrally contracted players Lamb said: "A significant proportion of the remuneration package will be performance-related.

"In addition to a basic salary there is an attractive additional amount which will recognise team performances. This is over and above the sponsors' win money."

Up to 16 players can be named next week, though it is likely that only around 12 will be given six-month contracts there and then. Nasser Hussain will be one, of course, as will Michael Atherton, Alec Stewart, Michael Vaughan, Andrew Flintoff, Andrew Caddick and Darren Gough. After that it gets more difficult. Hussain is known to admire the talents of Graham Thorpe and Dean Headley, so they may clamber aboard, and an evangelical gleam enters the eye of the coach Duncan Fletcher when Graeme Hick's name crops up. Then there is Mark Ramprakash and the rich promise of Stephen Harmison and Chris Schofield to consider.

Lamb added: "This will enable us to manage and control the activities of players more effectively than in the past." In truth, however, it reflects a further hardening of attitudes in the search for success.

He also revealed that the counties would be paid about £50,000 compensation for each player contracted to the ECB. There will be three pay bands, according to age and experience. "It will be possible for players to move from one band to another," he said. "It will also be possible to move within a particular band, within the financial perimeters of each band." Elastic bands, in other words.

The ECB has budgeted about £750,000 to pay for the enterprise, over and above what it is already paying. Because England are not due to play a home one-day international until the second week of July the list will be, essentially, a Test-based party.

The concept of a crack, elite Australia-style squad of players who will attend camps and specialised coaching clinics is basically an attractive one, especially as the gap between the domestic and international game continues to widen.

A closer look, however, throws up a number of worries. This could well turn out to be just another prop in the long-running sitcom, like Ronnie Barker's fast-closing till in Open All Hours.

It will be divisive for one thing. Some good players will miss out and resent it. It also pushes the selectors into a corner; they are being asked to decide this week who will appear in the first Test against Zimbabwe early in the summer.

The counties would also accuse the board of wasting money if it picks a small squad now and chooses more than 25 players through the summer, which it has done in the past.

The chairman of selectors David Graveney said yesterday: "We must respect the sen sitivities of the counties. The worst-case scenario is to choose one group of people for central contracts and another group to play Zimbabwe."

In other words, the selectors have to make up their minds now and be consistent. Perhaps that is not entirely a bad thing.

 Shoaib Akhtar will lead Nottighamshire's attack from late May, as soon as Pakistan's tour of West Indies is over.

"I have been given verbal confirmation by General Zia, chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, that Shoaib will be released at the end of May and will be available to us for the rest of the summer," said Stuart Foster, Nottinghamshire's cricket committee chairman. "We are grateful to Chris [Cairns, who was on stand-by as a replacement] but Shoaib was always our first choice.

"He has continually stressed his commitment to play at Trent Bridge and we are looking forward to bringing him here. Now we can get on with planning for the season."

webTitle: Sunderland find new identity as The Black Cats

fields.headline: Sunderland find new identity as The Black Cats
fields.trailText: It's Mackems no more. Sunderland supporters have voted out the club's nickname in favour of The Black Cats.
fields.body:
Sunderland will be hoping their luck takes a turn for the better after supporters voted for the club to be known in future as The Black Cats, ending a three-year wait for an official nickname.

The Black Cats won 48% of the 10,000 votes cast by fans through the club's official magazine, the Legion of Light, and the official website, beating The Mackems, with 37%, into second place.

Sunderland, known as The Rokermen when they played at Roker Park, have not had an official nickname since they moved to the Stadium of Light in 1997. They are the last Premiership team to acquire one.

The choice of The Black Cats is not a superstitious move, however, to put the club's faltering season back on track, but originates from the 18th century when a battery of guns protecting the mouth of the River Wear bore the name.

The club launched the campaign to find a nickname in December and fans were offered a choice of five alternatives; The Black Cats also proved more popular than The Light Brigade, The Miners and The SOLs.

Bob Murray, Sunderland's chairman, said yesterday that he was keen to make sure everyone was aware of the new name.

"We now need to work out the logo to ensure that we don't slip back into the position where we had several nicknames doing the rounds," he said. "Before this vote if someone from another part of the country or overseas had contacted the club asking for the club nickname we were unable to give a straight answer. From now on we can take pride in being The Black Cats, knowing that our supporters have chosen the name."

The first new Black Cat could be Don Hutchison, the Everton's captain who is expected to move to Sunderland this week. The Scottish international midfielder has been courted by the Wearside club for the past two months and Everton's FA Cup quarter-final defeat by Aston Villa on Sunday is likely to prompt an official bid from Peter Reid.

However, if Sunderland's manager believes the 28-year-old will be offloaded cheaply as part of the Merseyside club's economy drive he will be disappointed. Smith will demand at least £3m for a player who cost just £1m when he was signed two years ago from Sheffield United.

Hutchison, who will be available on a Bosman-inspired free transfer in 15 months' time, has been attempting to negotiate - without success - a new long-term contract for the past six weeks.

Hutchison's fellow Scot and Goodison Park team-mate John Collins, 32, will also be on the move shortly. Although he still has more than two years of a £26,000-a-week contract to run, the former Monaco player is expected to return to France at the end of the season.

webTitle: Heskey up front and very personal

fields.headline: Heskey up front and very personal
fields.standfirst: Soft-spoken striker is likely to partner Alan Shearer against Argentina
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan intimated his intention to play Emile Heskey alongside Alan Shearer against Argentina.
fields.body:
Emile Heskey speaks in a whisper and with polite vacuity. Is this really the strong, powerful, lean and hungry striker many are saying could be the perfect England partner for Alan Shearer?

Looks are obviously deceptive. Heskey in person comes across more like a cuddly bear than the prowling tiger that Kevin Keegan hopes will add bite to his team's Euro 2000 attack in the continuing absence of Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen.

Long-term injuries to Liverpool's forward pair have promoted the Leicester front-man up the England pecking order to the point where he is expected to start his first international against the mighty Argentina at Wembley tomorrow night.

In fact, so strong was Keegan's desire to look at how the 6ft 1in striker plays alongside Shearer that he even over-ruled Martin O'Neill's request to stand Heskey down from international duty and keep him fresh and injury-free for Leicester's Worthington Cup final on Sunday.

The England manager is running out of credible options up front and it is Heskey's turn to show what he can do.

It would be too simplistic simply to say that Heskey is present because he can impersonate Duncan Ferguson, with whom Shearer has struck up such a productive partnership at Newcastle.

Ferguson is a better player for sure. But certainly the England captain will welcome the presence alongside him of someone who can share the battling element of the striker's role, while Heskey also has the pace and strength to equip himself well, even if his first touch still leaves something to be desired and his goalscoring is a bit thin - just seven goals this season for Leicester.

When asked if it was a simple question of Shearer needing a big man alongside him, Keegan was not quite sure. "Bearing in mind Duncan Ferguson, Shearer and Heskey is a combination we haven't looked at," he said. "We have looked at pretty much all the others. There is a possibility if he does not start he will play some part in the game.

"I think he has earned that right by the way he has trained with us and the way he has come on with us. You could argue that he has not scored many goals for Leicester but we had that argument with Alan Shearer earlier in the season. I just think he gives us some really nice options."

With only four England appearances as a substitute behind him, it will certainly be one hell of a baptism if the 22-year-old Heskey does start tomorrow night.

It would also represent another highlight in a memorable two weeks which began with Leicester's disgraced flight home from La Manga following the fire-extinguisher incident and will end on Sunday in the heat of a second Wembley appearance in five days.

As for whether Heskey himself is ready to take on Argentina, judge for yourself. His answers to a series of questions on the subject yesterday were hardly illuminating.

"Obviously I want to go out there and score goals but whether I take my chances or not I will always go out there and I want to score."

And later: "I just have to go out and try and perform. We will have to wait and see if I can perform with Alan Shearer."

The fact that Liverpool are reported to have already agreed to buy Heskey at the end of the season proves that Gérard Houllier for one has belief in the player's potential. Tomorrow night will provide an interesting test of that judgment.

webTitle: Excuse us, can we have our footballers back?

fields.headline: Excuse us, can we have our footballers back?
fields.trailText: Some of Nigeria's footballers will have an awful lot of explaining to do over the next few days as mystery continues to surround their sluggish returns to their European club sides more than a week after losing on penalties to Cameroon in the African Nations Cup final.
fields.body:
Perhaps it was the pain of defeat that caused them to go into hiding, or maybe it was just a rare chance to spend a few days at home with family and friends and relax in the sunshine.

Whatever the reasons, some of Nigeria's footballers will have an awful lot of explaining to do over the next few days as mystery continues to surround their sluggish returns to their European club sides more than a week after losing on penalties to Cameroon in the African Nations Cup final.

The way was led by Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro, who could teach David Beckham a thing or two about going Awol. The Nigerian defender was supposed to report back for training last Tuesday and was even named in the squad for the FA Cup tie against Gillingham on Sunday.

The club claim they have not received any explanations as to why he has not returned to west London but depending on who you talk to Babayaro has either become stranded in his native northern Nigeria because of ethnic violence or cannot leave the country because of serious illness.

Babayaro's guardian claimed yesterday that the player was unable to leave his hometown of Kaduna because of violence between Muslims and Christians which has resulted in two deaths.

Alhaji Sabo Babayaro said: "He has been delayed because of the rioting. He was supposed to leave today for Lagos on his way back to London. But as I speak to you now Celestine is trapped."

However, the Nigerian high commission in London, which maintains close contacts with Nigerian footballers in Britain, has a different explanation. It says Babayaro is trapped on doctor's orders.

"He has malaria and is in quarantine," said a spokesman. "I spoke to his sister and she told me that Celestine is not well and has been put into quarantine by the doctor. He will not be allowed out of the country until he has recovered.

"Celestine's sister said that he will be back very soon and he is resting. We have told Chelsea that he has malaria but we couldn't give a definite date as to when he will return."

Chelsea are to report the matter to Fifa and have warned that he faces disciplinary action when he returns.

The Luton Town centre-half Efetobore Sodje had been given a definite date of last Tuesday to return to the Bedfordshire club but instead, according to club officials, Sodje strolled into the club yesterday morning without explaining adequately where he had been or why he had returned so late.

To rub further salt into Luton's wound, Sodje had in fact been released for international duty two weeks earlier than Nigerian players from the Premiership because he was not even sure he was going to make it into the final squad of 22. When he did make it, he failed to inform the club, who only found out via his wife.

A bemused Lennie Lawrence, the Luton manager, yesterday fined and disciplined Sodje and placed him on the transfer list.

At least two other Nigerian players at clubs on the continent, Jay-Jay Okocha of Paris Saint-Germain and Borussia Dortmund's Victor Ikpeba, are reported to have failed to return, although neither club could confirm this yesterday, while two other clubs are anxiously awaiting the return of their players, fingers crossed.

The Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu and Milan's Taribo West have both been given extra leave to visit relatives in Nigeria. "We are expecting Kanu back sometime this week," said a spokesman for Arsenal, who did not have a fixture last weekend. "It's not as if he's late. There's no reason to be worried, as yet." Milan are adopting a similar line, particularly as West is not currently in the first team.

Meanwhile, the Nigerians themselves have a more pragmatic view of their players' actions. "I can't see what all the fuss is about," said the Nigerian high commission spokesman. "The players were very upset at losing the final and many have not been home for a while."

webTitle: Dutch declare war on Euro 2000 black market

fields.headline: Dutch declare war on Euro 2000 black market
fields.trailText: The parliament in the Netherlands will today debate a bill to criminalise black-market ticket sales there in readiness for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
The parliament in the Netherlands will today debate a bill to criminalise black-market ticket sales there in readiness for Euro 2000.

The proposal, a direct result of lobbying by the organisers of Euro 2000, will be introduced by two members of the lower house. Its passing on to the statute book is considered vital to help maintain security at the 16-team tournament, which kicks off on June 10.

Organisers feel an unpoliceable black market would only serve to encourage ticketless fans and hooligans to travel to the Netherlands and buy tickets locally. "It would undermine our entire security system," a spokesman said.

Belgium, the co-hosts, already has laws making black-market ticket sales illegal.

However the Dutch interior and justice ministries have expressed reservations about any legislation, saying measures to tackle black-market trade are impractical and would place further pressure on police.

All 1.2m Euro 2000 tickets have been sold to individuals, with none being allocated to travel agencies to offer in deals which often take little account of segregation guidelines.

 British Airways yesterday averted a public relations disaster when the Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy persuaded the national carrier to reinstate his squad's afternoon Heathrow flight to Luxembourg for tomorrow's friendly with the Grand Duchy.

BA had initially cancelled the scheduled flight as there was a technical fault with the aircraft only for Northern Ireland officials to demand that another plane be found. The party were eventually airborne one hour and 40 minutes late.

"A few of us got involved and just put it to them that this was an international match," said McIlroy. "Everything had been arranged and it wasn't on that they cancelled the flight. Obviously they had to bow under our pressure because for British Airways to do what they did was terrible."

Leeds United's Stephen McPhail has pulled out of the Ireland squad to play the Czech Republic with a hamstring injury. The midfielder, who missed Sunday's defeat by Manchester United, had been expected to win a first cap in the Lansdowne Road friendly.

 The Wales manager Mark Hughes yesterday announced the end of his international career after winning 72 caps, the first of which came in 1984 when he scored the only goal against England. "I won't be involved in the World Cup games so there's no point."

fields.headline: Burns becomes a Bhoy again
fields.trailText: With their supporters clamouring for a return to more "traditional" values, Celtic last night unveiled a stalwart from the recent past as a partial solution to their coaching vacancies; the former manager Tommy Burns will return until the end of the season.
fields.body:
With their supporters clamouring for a return to more "traditional" values, Celtic last night unveiled a stalwart from the recent past as a partial solution to their coaching vacancies; the former manager Tommy Burns will return until the end of the season.

Burns, who managed Celtic from 1994-97 before departing by mutual consent after failing to wrest the league title from Rangers' grasp, will assume the role of assistant head coach for the remainder of this campaign.

However, Kenny Dalglish the director of football operations, stressed that Burns is not in the frame to succeed the deposed John Barnes as head coach. So the search continues, although Dalglish hinted at the weekend that he may remain in charge of team affairs until the summer.

 The Coventry City striker Noel Whelan has been transfer-listed after talks on a new contract broke down yesterday. With 15 months of his current deal remaining, the club have decided to cash in now rather than lose the player under the Bosman ruling.

The success of the Robbie Keane-Cédric Roussel partnership this season has curtailed Whelan's first-team opportunities. Aston Villa and Derby County have both been linked with the 25-year-old.

 ITV will screen live the FA Cup semi-final between Bolton Wanderers and Aston Villa on April 2, while Sky Sports will cover the Newcastle United v Chelsea semi-final on April 9.

However, Kenny Dalglish the director of football operations, stressed that Burns is not in the frame to succeed the deposed John Barnes as head coach. So the search continues, although Dalglish hinted at the weekend that he may remain in charge of team affairs until the summer.  The Coventry City striker Noel Whelan has been transfer-listed after talks on a new contract broke down yesterday. With 15 months of his current deal remaining, the club have decided to cash in now rather than lose the player under the Bosman ruling. The success of the Robbie Keane-Cédric Roussel partnership this season has curtailed Whelan's first-team opportunities. Aston Villa and Derby County have both been linked with the 25-year-old.  ITV will screen live the FA Cup semi-final between Bolton Wanderers and Aston Villa on April 2, while Sky Sports will cover the Newcastle United v Chelsea semi-final on April 9.

webTitle: Beckham goes fromzero to Keegan's hero...

fields.headline: Beckham goes fromzero to Keegan's hero...
fields.standfirst: England v Argentina United's playmaker put at centre stage with orders to control tomorrow's Wembley rematch
fields.trailText: David Beckham will tomorrow night be given a chance to pack up the weekend's troubles in his old kitbag and demonstrate that he has a marshal's baton hidden in a spare knapsack. Kevin Keegan wants Beckham to run England's game against Argentina with the authority of Johnny Haynes, Trevor Brooking, Paul Gascoigne or, indeed, another Keegan.
fields.body:
David Beckham will tomorrow night be given a chance to pack up the weekend's troubles in his old kitbag and demonstrate that he has a marshal's baton hidden in a spare knapsack. Kevin Keegan wants Beckham to run England's game against Argentina with the authority of Johnny Haynes, Trevor Brooking, Paul Gascoigne or, indeed, another Keegan.

This is the England coach's response to the rumpus at Manchester United which led Sir Alex Ferguson to drop Beckham for Sunday's crucial Premiership match at Leeds after he had failed to turn up for training two days earlier.

Beckham's agent said he had stayed at home in Hertfordshire with his Spice Girl wife Victoria on Friday because their baby son had a chill. Now the 24-year-old United player is being asked to prove that he can stop England catching a cold tomorrow evening in the face of formidable opposition.

While nobody can seriously doubt Beckham's ability as one of the best crossers of a ball in the modern game he has yet to show that he has the strength of personality to command a match in the manner Keegan will require tomorrow night. His two celebrated sendings-off, against Argentina in France 98 and Necaxa in the recent World Club Championship, have not enhanced his image as a cool manipulator of big occasions.

Typically Keegan stressed the positive side of Beckham when this doubt was raised yesterday. "I think a lot of people underestimate him because they don't know him," he said. "You pick up the bits that you read and build up an image that I don't think fits the guy.

"I've spent a lot of time with him, talking with him, working with him and watching him train. I see a very determined character who loves playing football, and that is what you need at the top level.

"I've never had a problem with David Beckham," Keegan continued. "Because, in the past, I've said he was a model professional people almost turned it against him but I use those words again today. He is a model professional when help has been there."

Clearly Keegan is hoping that Beckham, fresh and fit after a weekend of unforeseen inactivity, will relish the task he will be given against Argentina. "I think it is a chance to see him in a different position," the England coach explained.

Argentina are particularly strong in central midfield. Beckham can expect to encounter not only Diego Simeone, his old sparring partner from the second phase of the 1998 World Cup in St Etienne, but possibly Ariel Ortega, Javier Zanetti and the best of the bunch, Juan Veron.

Keegan, who will announce his side today, could use Paul Ince and Paul Scholes to support Beckham, with Kieron Dyer and Jason Wilcox on the flanks. But to do this the England coach would have to switch to a back three of, say, Martin Keown, Gareth Southgate and Sol Campbell.

Alternatively he could use Scholes to augment Shearer up front, leaving Emile Heskey, who is certain to take some part in the match, on the bench, and play Gareth Barry on the left side of a back four. Whatever happens, an isolated exercise in England's preparations for the European Championship has now become the most crucial test of faith yet in Beckham's future as a prime influence in international affairs.

After England's previous match, when despite winning their Euro 2000 play-off with Scotland the players were booed by the Wembley crowd having lost lamely 1-0 in the return leg, Keegan stressed the need for better passing and movement. "In the second Scotland game we looked like a team that had just not quite found the right formula," he admitted.

Beckham, therefore, will have to be as much a catalyst tomorrow evening as was Alan Ball for Alf Ramsey in the 1966 World Cup. Keegan has invited Ball to join England's preparations this week. "I think that with people like this around it can only do good for the players," he said. Just so long as nobody remembers that Ball was once sent off in a World Cup qualifier for trying to throttle a Pole.

Tomorrow then, for both Beckham and the England side as a whole, it is going to be a matter of kill or cure against opponents reckoned by Keegan to be the second best in the world after Brazil. "David Beckham will not decide whether we beat Argentina or whether we win Euro 2000," he warned. But Keegan is about to put Beckham under the international microscope all the same.

England (possible, 3-5-2): Seaman ; Keown (both Arsenal), Southgate (Aston Villa), Campbell (Tottenham); Dyer (Newcastle), Beckham (Man Utd), Ince (Middlesbrough), Scholes (Man Utd), Wilcox (Leeds); Shearer (Newcastle), Heskey (Leicester).

webTitle: ...but the spin may not wash with Ferguson

fields.headline: ...but the spin may not wash with Ferguson
fields.trailText: David Beckham's advisers claimed yesterday that he had "been given no reason whatsoever" for being banished from training and dropped from Manchester United's first-team after incurring the wrath of his manager Sir Alex Ferguson.
fields.body:
David Beckham's advisers claimed yesterday that he had "been given no reason whatsoever" for being banished from training and dropped from Manchester United's first-team after incurring the wrath of his manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

As Beckham attempted to focus on England's game against Argentina tomorrow, the London-based public relations company employed to promote his image was anxious to portray the player as victim.

Beckham's spokeswoman Caroline McAteer said her client had been culpable of nothing more than being a responsible parent after giving United notice of his plans to miss training on Friday because his baby boy Brooklyn had fallen ill during the night.

"At 3am David called out a doctor who diagnosed Brooklyn had a touch of gastro-enteritis. He let the club know and you would have thought it was a valid excuse," she said. "Then, when he turned up for training on Saturday Ferguson told him to leave. Obviously he was not played [at Leeds] on Sunday but he has been given no reason whatsoever." It is believed, however, that he gave United only 20 minutes' notice of his decision to miss training.

Beckham's faltering relationship with Ferguson was described as "near unworkable" by an informed source yesterday, while several senior United players are understood to have warned their colleague about the potentially damaging effect his millionaire lifestyle could have on his playing career.

His omission at Elland Road shows that Ferguson is no longer willing to tolerate the 24-year-old leading his dual life between Old Trafford and the Hertfordshire home he shares with his pop-star wife Victoria Adams, although his advisers are adamant he is not seeking a move. Ferguson was refusing to discuss the situation yesterday, reiterating his view that it was an internal matter.

Beckham's use of PR spinners from The Outside Organisation is more in keeping with the pop industry and is likely to serve only to inflame his manager. Ferguson is renowned for his efforts to keep matters in-house and will not be impressed to have his authority challenged by a company 200 miles away.

Ferguson does not tolerate his employees bringing bad publicity to the club and anyone who does not abide by his stringent regulations is usually left in the wilderness; Beckham will have some further explaining to do when he returns to the club's training complex in Carrington later this week.

 Manchester United's captain Roy Keane has said that he and his team-mates "went too far" when they chased the referee Andy d'Urso after he awarded Middlesbrough a penalty at Old Trafford 3 weeks ago. "It won't be happening again," Keane said. "I know I should have been setting a better example."

webTitle: Basque politician killed by Spanish car bomb

fields.headline: Basque politician killed by Spanish car bomb
fields.trailText: A car bomb exploded this afternoon near the seat of the Basque regional government in Vitoria, Spain, killing a leading political opponent of Basque separatism and his bodyguard.
fields.body:
A car bomb exploded this afternoon near the seat of the Basque regional government in Vitoria, Spain, killing a leading political opponent of Basque separatism and his bodyguard.

The explosion occurred shortly after 4:30 pm local time on a university campus about 200 meters from the headquarters of the president of the Basque government as officials were inside holding a press conference.

Spanish television showed footage of a bloodied body lying on a grassy area of the campus. Police later confirmed that the fatalities were Fernando Buesa, leader of the Alava provincial chapter of the Basque socialist party, and a policeman serving as his bodyguard.

Basque separatists ETA were immediately blamed for the killing by Spanish interior minister Jaime Mayor Oreja.

People in Spain and the Basque region "must understand the macabre lesson ETA is trying to teach us," Mayor Oreja told reporters.

ETA announced in December it was ending a 14-month-old cease-fire and warned it would resume attacks.

The organization, which has killed nearly 800 people since 1968, was blamed for a car bomb blast in Madrid on January 21 in which an army colonel was killed.

Although most of its victims have been security force members, in recent years ETA has begun targeting members of Spain's governing Popular Party and the leading opposition Socialist party, to which Buesa belonged.

Tuesday's attack came as Spain gears up for general elections on March 12.

Buesa's party opposes Basque separatism and favors instead the current system of broad Basque autonomy granted by the Spanish constitution.

The regional government is controlled by the moderate Basque Nationalist Party, which says it supports Basque independence but opposes ETA's violent methods.

Buesa was walking near his home with his bodyguard when the bomb detonated.

He was among some 10,000 people who took part in an anti-ETA demonstration on Saturday in the nearby Basque city of San Sebastian.

webTitle: England v Argentina: players to watch

fields.headline: England v Argentina: players to watch
fields.trailText: Gabriel Batistuta
fields.body:
Gabriel Batistuta

Born: Santa Fe 1/2/69

Clubs: Newell's Old Boys, River Plate, Boca Juniors, Fiorentina

Batigol needs little introduction. He has been scoring goals at the very top for years. During his last trip to Wembley he ended Arsenal's Champions League campaign with a rasping shot past a hapless David Seaman.

The Fiorentina star, coveted by big clubs around the globe, is lethal with either foot and has supreme aerial power. He was on target from the penalty spot, in the sixth minute, against England in France 98 and scored in the penalty shoot-out.

Batistuta scored his 50th international goal in the friendly against Colombia in October, which Argentina won 2-1, but that was only his second for his country since the World Cup.

Hernan Crespo

Born: Florida, Argentina 5/7/7

Clubs: River Plate, Parma

The striker leading Parma's assault on Italy's Serie A is also trying to cement his place in the national team as Batistuta's strike-partner.

A cunning and skilful player, he barely featured in France 98, coming on as a second-half substitute against England in the second round before seeing his penalty saved by David Seaman in the shoot-out.

Crespo moved from River Plate to Parma in 1996 and has continued to mature, finding the net regularly for his club. He scored 16 in Serie A last season and is among the top marksmen this season.

Juan Sebastian Veron

Born: Buenos Aires 9/3/75

Clubs: Estudiantes, Boca Juniors, Sampdoria, Parma, Lazio

A tireless midfield dynamo who was arguably Argentina's player of the World Cup in 1998.

He was the driving force of the team and remains a vital cog in the machine. Veron, known in his homeland as La Brujita, which means little witch, moved from Parma to Lazio in July for £18m.

He offers energy and aggression in the midfield, married to skill, vision and an eye for the spectacular goal.

Diego Simeone

Born: 28/4/70

Clubs: Velez Sarsfield, Pisa, Sevilla, Atletico Madrid, Inter, Lazio

Midfield hardman Simeone will always be remembered in England as the player involved in the incident which led to the dismissal of David Beckham in St Etienne in June 1998.

While on the ground Beckham flicked his heel at Simeone who tumbled to the ground in mock-agony. The pair clashed again last season when Manchester United overcame Inter on the way to their Champions League success. Simeone, who moved to Lazio in the summer for £7m, is an experienced campaigner.

His link-up with countryman Veron at Lazio has added grit and guile to the club which was pipped to the Italian title last season by AC Milan.

fields.headline: Is ignorance bliss?
fields.standfirst: Should college admissions staff see candidates' other Ucas choices?  Donald MacLeod and  Lee Elliot Major  on a hot debate
fields.trailText: Should college admissions staff see candidates' other Ucas choices? Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major on a hot debate
fields.body:
Proposals to make the university admissions system fairer to students are being warmly backed by schools. The Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (Ucas) is expected to change its arrangements to prevent admissions officers from seeing applicants' other choices - so-called "blind decision-making".

At present all six of an applicant's choices are seen by each institution when he or she is considered for a place, and schools and further education colleges are convinced that this has led to some candidates being treated unfairly.

Outstanding candidates for Oxford or Cambridge have been rejected by other universities and ended up without offers, while some admissions tutors at prestigious universities are said to reject candidates who include "safety" choices for courses that are easier to get onto. Sixth formers are usually advised to make all their choices look consistent by applying for similar courses in case admissions officers think they are not committed.

Higher education institutions have always stoutly denied unfairness, but last year Sir Martin Harris, president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, called for the introduction of blind decision-making to reassure schools.

"It will be a real step forward," said John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads' Association. "A whole range of problems have arisen quite unnecessarily because admissions tutors are seeing information that is none of their business."

Some admissions officers say seeing all a candidate's choices helps build up a useful picture. (They also want to see what rival universities are getting.) The changes will be discussed by admissions officers in April and are expected to be approved by Ucas directors in June, but would not be in place until the 2003 applications round.

Anthony McClaran, Ucas deputy chief executive, said change was technically possible. At present information on ethnic origins is withheld from tutors but given later to universities to help plan equal opportunities policies.

Figures for the next academic year show more students want to go to Leeds than any other university - there were 39,500 applications for degree courses, 500 more than last year. Nottingham saw degree applications up nearly 2,000, totalling 37,400 in 2000-01. The universities of Bristol and Manchester received 33,850 and 32,600 applications respectively, both down on figures for last year.

Assuming student numbers in universities will be broadly in line with last year, Bristol, though, emerges as the most oversubscribed institution among universities attracting high numbers of applications. There are approximately 11 applications for every student place at Bristol, compared to 9 at Nottingham and 7 at Leeds.

By far the biggest increase in applications was seen by the University of Central Lancashire, which attracted over 50% more than last year, bringing the total to just over 14,000 for undergraduate courses this year. This meteoric rise comes despite applications being down 2.6% nationally and down 4% in the north-west of England. A number of new popular degrees, including a course in forensic science, a new outdoor sports arena, as well as a recent TV marketing campaign are thought to have put Central Lancashire high on the wish lists.

Napier University, the University of Derby and Thames Valley University witnessed the largest falls in degree applications compared with last year, down 15%, 14% and 13.5% respectively. In total numbers, Liverpool, Ulster, Manchester and Southampton saw the biggest drops in applications, all at least 2,500 fewer than last year.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

webTitle: Britain 'low on crime but tough on sentencing'

fields.headline: Britain 'low on crime but tough on sentencing'
fields.standfirst: Home office study reveals fall in burglaries, violent crime and drug trafficking in England and Wales
fields.trailText: Crime fell by one per cent in 1998 in England and Wales, according to a new report comparing international figures.
fields.body:
Crime fell by one per cent in 1998 in England and Wales, according to a new report comparing international figures.

The home office study found that England and Wales had one of the lowest homicide rates in western Europe and that London had a below average rate. Domestic burglaries fell by 6% in England and Wales, compared with a 1% fall for the whole of Europe. Violent crime recorded by police across Europe rose by 2% but fell by 6% in England and Wales. And while drug trafficking increased across the continent, it fell by 9% in England and Wales.

The home office report looked at sentencing from nine council of Europe countries and found that England and Wales tended to sentence offenders to the longest terms of imprisonment. It also discovered that the prison population rate per capita was the highest for the whole of western Europe, with 126 prisoners per 100,000 head of general population. This rate was well below the USA, with 668 and Russia at 690.
fields.bodyText: Crime fell by one per cent in 1998 in England and Wales, according to a new report comparing international figures. The home office study found that England and Wales had one of the lowest homicide rates in western Europe and that London had a below average rate. Domestic burglaries fell by 6% in England and Wales, compared with a 1% fall for the whole of Europe. Violent crime recorded by police across Europe rose by 2% but fell by 6% in England and Wales. And while drug trafficking increased across the continent, it fell by 9% in England and Wales. The home office report looked at sentencing from nine council of Europe countries and found that England and Wales tended to sentence offenders to the longest terms of imprisonment. It also discovered that the prison population rate per capita was the highest for the whole of western Europe, with 126 prisoners per 100,000 head of general population. This rate was well below the USA, with 668 and Russia at 690.

fields.headline: The right to secrecy

fields.body:
This is in some ways a strange subject on which to give a lecture under the auspices of the British Institute of Human Rights. If one sees the Institute, a most admirable organisation, as operating in the territory defined by the European Convention on Human Rights, neither the secrecy nor the freedom of information comes within its scope. The convention majestically asserts the right to freedom of expression. And the judgements resulting from it have had important things to say about privacy, confidentiality, and many other limits on free speech. But it's of no help in any contest between citizen and government over the disclosure of official information. The freedom from official secrecy is not a human right, and nor is its protection.

All the same, it seems entirely proper to be launching a discussion under this roof about freedom of information. I am delighted to have been invited to do so. For in the government's eyes, certainly, their interest in this freedom is part of a package for which they make grand claims as constitutional reformers. The bill now going through parliament is an accompaniment to the Human Rights Act that is already law. It springs, as they would claim, from the same reformist spirit that has slaughtered the forces of conservatism in Scotland, in Wales, in the legal profession and also, we're supposed to believe, in the House of Lords. It is part of the making good of an agenda which this Institute, in broad terms, exists to support.

In my lecture, I have no intention of discussing the broad agenda. That's the last you'll hear of Scotland. I don't propose to deal in detail with the freedom of information legislation itself, though there are parts of it - and especially of its underlying philosophy - worth drawing attention to. My intention is to go beyond the Bill, and challenge some of the axioms that have tended to limit debate - even among those who most passionately want to see a freedom of information law enacted.

I contend that even if this Bill is passed, it will bring us nowhere near an acceptable frontier between secrecy and disclosure. Our debates, worthy though they have been - and far though they have taken things in the past two decades - are constipated by too many fixed assumptions that need to be dislodged. So tentative has the reform movement become, and so grateful is it meant to be for the offerings the Government has generously agreed to make, that we - who are part of this movement - have conceded too much of the ground that matters most: the ground at the heart of government, where the big decisions are made in secret, and where the very essence of the democratic compact is to be found. I argue that secrecy, though presented as essential to the making of good decisions, is more likely to be the accomplice of bad ones.

The right to secrecy is claimed by all governments at all times. It is, as has often been pointed out, a matter of power. In the British case, but not only the British, the hallowed tradition is that all official information should be secret unless admitted, exceptionally, to be suitable for disclosure. There never has been a right of access to government documents. In 1605 Francis Bacon wrote: "We see all governments as obscure and invisible". This, he thought, was how it should be, and he proved to be a durable prophet of his country's future practices. Although invisibility became impossible with the arrival of something like a free press, obscurity - studied, conscious, dissembling obscurity - survives, as a British governing philosophy, to this day.

Sweden enacted a Freedom of the Press Act in 1766, which continues to give citizens the right to inspect and reproduce official documents. In the United States, Congress passed the Freedom of Information Act in 1966 - strengthened in 1974 - to promote the disclosure of official information. But these are unusual cases of a voluntary recognition - one in the 18th century, the other in the 20th - that absolute official secrecy conflicted with the public interest. In sixties America, which is our main model for these things, the public right to know was asserted partly because power in Washington is dispersed. The executive branch was up against Congresses, both in '66 and '74, that did not trust it. The appetite for absolute power is nothing like so easily sustainable there as in London. All the same, this was a signal surrender. Even though the American law has been hedged around by exemptions, it does still mean it is much easier to find out about aspects of contemporary British government in Washington than in London: as my Guardian colleague, David Hencke, regularly shows.

London, however, has not entirely failed to take an interest in more openness. People not in government have seen that more freedom of information would be a handy weapon of oppositionism. Openness, though never previously a part of the British governing culture, has been the promise of several recent opposition parties. The earliest one I can trace is in the manifesto of the 1970 Conservatives, where Ted Heath promised to eliminate "unnecessary secrecy" concerning the working of government. This wasn't a promise of freedom of information, merely a hint in favour of the far more paternalistic, aspirational and undemanding mantra of open government. But it had seldom been said before. There were similar vague mutterings by other oppositions during the 1970s, but no serious work was done - and nothing whatever, of course, was done about such inconsequential aspirations when the party in question got into power. For power, as I say, was what it was all about.

The first party to carry the issue to a new level was the predecessor of the present government, the last manifestation of what we now know as Old Labour. The longer Labour stayed in opposition, the more dedicated it became to the notion that the entire culture of government had to change. Power, the nectar of which it had been deprived for so long, would finally be diluted when this period in the wilderness was over. When it supped once more from the cup, it would transfer significant amounts of public information into the public realm and create a right to know. The proof of the extent of this shift of mind-set was striking: a fully drafted Freedom of Information law, worked-over clause by clause, ready to go if Labour won the 1992 election, and grandly pledged by Neil Kinnock as the first piece of legislation he would then enact.

Well - chance would be a fine thing! Like much else, this pledge turned to ashes when John Major won the election. But it had, for me, a significant after-life - or rather, non-life. When, much later, I was interviewing Jack Straw about the present measure for which he is the responsible minister, he showed striking ignorance of this piece of history. His excuse for the long delay in producing his freedom of information Bill was that - unlike the Human Rights Bill, for example - no work had been done on it in opposition. But, I said to him, an entire statute lay fully worked out on somebody's shelf from six or seven years ago. Mr Straw had never heard of it. Was this the amnesia of a minister schooled to forget that anything good had ever come out of Old Labour? Or the negligence of one who actually did not want to hasten the work on his own bill, despite the fact that it was a major promise made by Tony Blair?

Before going on to take a look at what the Blair Government has done, or not done - what it should do, and does not want to do - to redefine the right to official secrecy, I should observe that secrecy is not maintained, or otherwise, only by law. It never has been sealed tight, whatever the law may say. We have lived through several governments that had no commitment to freedom of information which have nevertheless been involuntary exponents of it on a formidable scale. No government - until Mr Blair's - sought to impose itself with more absolute authority on politics than Margaret Thatcher's But no government, either, was more exposed to view. The most potent catalyst of openness is political disagreement. Under Mrs Thatcher it was the regular experience of people like me to meet a minister for lunch on Thursday whose exasperation with what had just happened in Cabinet drove him to give a blow-by-blow account, which duly appeared in next day's paper - a model exercise in informing the British people what was really going on.

Mr Blair, however, promised something better. In March 1996, he set out not just a few cautious proposals to keep the open government lobby quiet but what sounded like a complete philosophy of openness, designed, as he put it, to change "the relationship in politics today". It was an almost messianic performance. Openness was the key solution to just about everything wrong with a system that was, as he said, "about fifty, sixty, seventy years behind the actual feelings and sentiments of the broad majority of people." It was the cure for disaffection and disillusion. It met the aspirations of a vastly better educated people. Freedom of information, Mr Blair concluded, was the way to deliver "not just more open but more effective and efficient government." I want to come back to that last phrase later: it is, I believe, the heart of the matter.

In the beginning - those first heady six months of power - it looked as though something like this promise would be delivered. There was, of course, a battle. Whitehall soon identified its most trusted force for conservatism - the chief minister at the Home Office. But at that time, Mr Straw was ranged against a somewhat improbable radical: none other than the Lord Chancellor, who supervised the publication of a white paper which did import into government some of the perceptions gained in opposition, and in particular the sense that ministers should not be judges in their own cause on every occasion when their right to secrecy was contested. The sense that politicians were not necessarily the least self-interested upholders of the public good - already given remarkable acceptance in the apparatus of regulators and invigilators overseeing the conduct of MPs - was extended to the question of secrecy. A quasi-judicial commissioner, and not a minister, would determine the limits of the public's right to know.

The white paper was not a perfect fulfillment of the promises, but it went much further than any British government had gone before. To watch its subsequent dismembering was to witness, in clinical detail, the evolving of the New Labour personality, from opposition idealist into governmental cynic. The spectacle could be used as a graphic case-study not just of how governments change their minds - which they're quite entitled to do when they get to grips, say, with the realities of the health service or the tax system - but of how the mind-set of ministerialism itself soon infuses everything they do: the compelling need for power, the aversion to the possibility of embarrassment, and therefore the belief that the slightest risk of these imperatives being compromised, by losing control of information, must always be avoided.

So - the bill that is now before Parliament is a pale version of the white paper, as is, I am sure, well known to this audience.

It is not valueless. By creating a legal framework, it goes further than the mere code of practice on openness which the Major government introduced. It does, in general, require public authorities of many kinds to make information public, and obliges them to devise schemes whereby this publication can take place. Many public bodies - from nursery schools to parks authorities, from the British Transport Police to Passenger Transport Executives, from universities to parish councils - will be living under new obligations of openness, better enabling those who want to interrogate them to acquire the data needed to do so. For low-level bodies - and perhaps even for some more important ones, like the police - the regime of accountability may become more real.

But the measure is riddled with loopholes to protect the political power elite. Although it purports to create a right of access, it contains no clear presumption in favour of disclosure. In the many exempt categories it creates, it does require public authorities, in considering whether, exceptionally, to release information, to have regard for the possibility that the case for disclosure outweighs the case for exemption - but it does not assert that the public interest is in favour of disclosure unless there is good reason not to disclose. Nor is the Commissioner any longer empowered to override a public authority's, or minister's, decision on that matter. It remains the case, moreover, that if the already substantial barricades against disclosures that ministers do not want should turn out to be insufficient - if some crevice has been overlooked, through which some sensitive morsel might escape - a reserve power will exist for the minister, at his or her discretion, to block it by retrospective order.

The proposals have attracted much discussion in the relatively small circles that care about these things - which do not include to any serious extent, Her Majesty's Opposition. Perhaps they have not been there long enough! Under pressure, Mr Straw has made one or two concessions. The original Bill, for example, exempted as a category any information that might end up as relevant to an accident inquiry. The chance proximity of publication of the Bill with the Paddington rail disaster made this unreasonable exemption politically impossible to sustain in all its absolute rigour: there has been a very modest relaxation. Straw has also graciously withdrawn the extraordinary requirement, in the original Bill, that any authority from whom information was being demanded had the right to ask how this was going to be used and, if it didn't want the stuff to be actually published, to withhold it. There've been other small improvements.

At the core, however, there has been no change. The process of policy-making will still be exempt as a class of information, double-banked by further protection to be gained from contents-based exemption. Section 33 (1) exempts as a class all information on "the formulation or development of government policy", communications between ministers, cabinet papers, and all information related to the operation of a minister's private office. All this irrespective of any harm, still less any substantial harm, disclosure might do. Section 34 (2), as if that were not enough, creates an additional harm test, specifying information - just in case subsection 1 isn't restrictive enough - that in the opinion of the authority or ministers "would, or would be likely to, prejudice the maintenance of collective responsibility of ministers", or "inhibit the free and frank provision of advice".

fields.body:
In other words, here, at the heart of government, there is to be no reform. And this, in the conservative British way, is generally accepted as reasonable. It may be right to have a lot more open accountability for Camden Council or the University of London - in which their decision-making processes have to be revealed. But central government is another matter.

The objection to disclosures in this field often begins with caricature. It is couched in terms that make freedom of information sound self-evidently absurd, or patently a private rather than a public matter. "So you want to have the Cabinet minutes published tomorrow" is one familiar line of ridicule - designed at a stroke to dispose of the slightest possibility of publishing them within 30 years, the minimum limit for public records. Another familiar allegation is that the media, by pressing for such a regime of openness, are interested solely in serving their own purposes - as if there could not be anything except scuttlebutt and tabloid headlines to be gained from the exposure of public policy decisions being privately arrived at: either before they are made, or very soon afterwards.

There is something in the second of these objections - in that so few parts of the media have taken a serious interest in the freedom of information debate. It is quite striking how this measure, which bears directly on the service journalism can offer the citizen, has almost become the property of one newspaper - The Guardian - and is not seen as a matter of broad and genuine public concern. One might conclude from this that the only interest most newspapers and broadcasters have is indeed in what they can pruriently extract by way of instant scandal from whatever opportunities the final Act gives them. They excuse their indifference by deriding any chatterer who takes the issue seriously as being out of touch with what the great British public cares about.

Actually, nobody is saying that Cabinet minutes should be revealed tomorrow: and nobody with any sense would imagine that these issues are of concern only to the media. They are of serious relevance to the way government is done to all of us. And there is a serious case for a more liberal approach than virtually anyone in the political establishment is prepared to contemplate. I don't argue for instant publication of minutes. But I do contest the premise that all the best policy decisions are made behind a wall of secrecy protected for 30 years.

Let's consider this a little further. What we're asked to believe is that both ministers and officials - approaching, say, a long-term decision about health service rationing, or an instant response to the latest twist in the beef war with France - can only function at their best and wisest if arguments they privately make and advice they privately give can be relied on to stay secret until most of them are dead, or at any rate have long retired from the public service. In respect of officials especially, there's an unexamined assumption that free and frank advice would be impossible to submit unless its secrecy - barring unofficial leaks, of course - was guaranteed. This is a very old British rule, based on two traditional ideas: first, that officials are and must remain faceless people, who do not answer to the public; and second, that if they became associated with a particular piece of advice to one government, a successor government might put the mark of Cain on them. Their famous neutrality, in short, would be blown apart.

The case this makes against disclosure billows out more widely. Not merely the policy discussion and advice-giving must be suppressed, but also much of the factual data on which it is based. Though there is a lot of factual data in the public realm, this is by grace and favour of the government. It's seldom up to Parliament, and never imposed by law. Secrecy is the baseline, irrespective of the nature of the decision in question: the siting of a new motorway, the reform of child benefit, how to make green suburban land available to Walmart, what new aircraft to sell to Indonesia, whether to renew the British nuclear deterrent. The key preparations for all these decisions are kept secret for 30 years, partly to protect the sanctity of the civil service.

I think this is a poor reason. It's out of date. Civil servants are far more public people than they were. Many of them are hardened by the jousting they have to do with select committees on behalf of their ministers. Of course, their ministers remain supreme. The official will never break ranks with the party line. But nor would he be punished any more than he or she is already, if it became known in due course that they advised for rather than against the Newbury bypass. Civil servants are already far less of a faceless, all purpose mandarinate than they were 30 years ago. Mrs Thatcher moved them round at will and whim, constantly searching for people who were one of us. Mr Blair does the same thing.

The broader point about this secrecy applies to ministers as well as officials. Decisions made in private are not, by definition, the best decisions. They're quite likely to be the worst. They exclude any two-way dialogue between insiders and outsiders who might have much to contribute, for example, to the thinking about motorways - but can only do so if they're let in on all the data and discussions the Department of Transport is currently relying on. It was a very senior civil servant, and one of the old school - Robert Armstrong, formerly the secretary of the Cabinet - who once told me that, in many cases, if he knew the advice he was called on to give might soon be subject to public scrutiny, it would probably be more rigorously worked out. Lord Armstrong was, of course, an especially high-grade official. Less self-confident people would be more worried at this prospect. But what we have here is the glimmerings of an argument that most people are familiar with, but that British government has long been sheltered from adopting: that the more open your work is to scrutiny, the harder you will try to get it right.

I know the case against this. While policy is maturing, it's said, nobody should find themselves suddenly exposed as backing an opinion that may only be contingent. There must be space for people to disagree, before the compromises are struck which everyone then gets behind. Some decisions are so sensitive - when they involve genuine matters of national security, intelligence (for example in Northern Ireland), or relations with foreign powers - that the need for secrecy has to override the democratic case for public information.

On the other hand, even the most sensitive subjects can acquire a new perspective. I propose an example to make my point. I think it's just about perfect. Ten years ago, the holiest of all holy public information was what was quaintly known as Bank Rate. Not only were the government's interest-rate plans never discussed by ministers in public, they were outside the reach of the Cabinet - an entirely privy matter between the Chancellor and Prime Minister. It was unimaginable that interest-rate policy would be set other than in secret, and defended other than by the grand assertions of the almighty minister.

This was changed, first, when Kenneth Clarke became Chancellor. The Ken and Eddie show began, in which Mr Clarke and Eddie George, governor of the Bank, had regular meetings to discuss interest-rates, and the minutes of their meetings were published six weeks later. This was not a complete success. The Bank's opinion was set down much more clearly than the Treasury's, and the meeting concluded with a decision by the Chancellor - of which even his officials seldom had prior notice, and which Mr Clarke, rather characteristically, did not reason out so much as bluffly assert. Elements of political caprice, which typified the old regime, remained.

Now, that system has become more like a true, public Socratic dialogue, concluding with a decision that is drained both of secrecy and of caprice. The monthly meetings of the Monetary Policy Committee are preceded by informed public debate, in which members of the committee feel free to join. They take detailed and public soundings with representatives of every region and industry affected by their power. In place of political power, exercised in secret, we have technocrats reasoning out their decisions in public.

Why did this happen? And what has it produced? It happened because Mr Clarke and Mr George saw that the only way to build credibility for British economic decision-making after the calamity of being forced out of the ERM was by inventing more transparency for the deliberations of the Bank and Treasury. The world needed to see that at least some economic reasoning, subject to scrutiny and challenge, lay behind the political decision. Gordon Brown took it a large stride further, by renouncing any part in the decision - but insisting that the process should be more open still. And the result? On the old model, such daring would have been universally expected to produce chaos on the markets, horrendous speculation, and the national life-blood draining away. Instead, it has no critics. Not merely the transfer of the decision, but the immediate transparency that attends its making, are just about universally agreed to have transformed the monetary context of British economic policy.

Now - I'm not so daft as to argue from this that Cabinet committee minutes should be released a fortnight after the meetings. Though the interest-rate decision is hyper-sensitive, it is, in a sense, quite simple. It is singular, black-and-white and done on a monthly basis. Though it touches many other economic matters, the people who make it have a narrow brief, which doesn't include the whole breadth of economic policy. On the other hand, it's noticeable that the members are allowed publicly to disagree, without the house falling down or their collective decision being compromised. The advance into this fully publicised world attests to a belief in the public's greater maturity. The notion of public choices being publicly made, after informed public discussion and in the knowledge that each participant's contribution will become public property, sets an instructive precedent. It expresses a philosophy which could usefully be spread wider. This would lead to greater public understanding of the choices ministers face and - I believe - better ways of making them.

I'd like briefly to put up two suggestions.

First, as regards current policy-making, there really is no excuse - beyond a combination of idleness and control-freakery - for retaining in the realm of non-disclosure the factual and data-based material on which ministers are going to rest their difficult decision.

Statistics. Technical and scientific advice. The submissions of lobbyists. Descriptions of existing practices, and past advice, of departments. Assessments of previous failures. Even the official analysis of data relating to the policy decision that has to be taken. You can see how much this might stimulate inconvenient challenges from expert outsiders - whether on new motorways, or nuclear power, or rural subsidies, or the independence of general practitioners, or whatever is the issue of the moment But it also stands to reason that such an open process would diminish the opportunities for private deals and short-term political priorities to fly in the face of some longer-term public interest.

Personally, I would go further. I see no reason - beyond preserving the myth of government as the making of a single obvious choice on which all reasonable persons must agree - not to be more open about the difficulty of those choices. I agree with Lord Burns - formerly Terry Burns, permanent secretary at the Treasury - who told the Commons committee which took evidence on freedom of information, that there was "an enormous amount to be gained in exposing on a lot of difficult policy issues that there often is quite a fine line between the options that are concerned'. Jack Straw has used this as an argument against making a formal distinction in law between them. That is, of course, a big if. It might impose the beginnings of a presumption, where data were intermingled with advice, that disclosure was, all the same, more in the public interest than non-disclosure.

What Sir Douglas proposed in 1984 has so far been unthinkable to a reforming government in 2000.

Here is a real opportunity to give meaning to the notion of accountability. Without infringing on the desire for secrecy while decisions are being made, such a rule would acknowledge that open accountability for advice and decision-making is better transacted in the forum than the museum.

It would come as a terrible shock to the governing classes. It must be so wonderfully comforting to know that your follies, and duplicities, as well as your better moments, will be preserved from sight for pretty much the rest of your natural life. webTitle: Iran election: what the papers say on the web

fields.headline: Iran election: what the papers say on the web
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: In Iran
fields.body:
In Iran

Iranians have taken back their government
Despite lingering scepticism people are getting a feel for the political process. They have reached deep into their hearts and taken back their government. Friday 18 February 2000 represents another real turning point in Iran's political history, like May 23 1997, when people brought their popular president to office. Indeed, democracy has finally arrived. Dokhi Fassihian, The Iranian

People want change
The people indicated that they want certain changes resulting in a better life and prosperity by mostly opting for the reformist candidates. In short, the Friday election signalled the outset of a new era in Iran characterised by a better domestic situation as well as improved relations with the outside world. Teheran Times

In Israel

Election should pave way to rapprochement with US
The United States wants to return to Iran just as much as Iran wants to return to America's banks. Iran's new parliament, if the election results so far indicate what it will look like, has admittedly removed several major obstacles on the road to a conciliation between the two countries; the pace of progress along that road, however, will be determined by Khatami, in accordance with the latitude that he and the nation's supreme religious leader will agree upon.
Zvi Bar'el, Ha'aretz

In the US

Iran still a danger
It is not yet time for a softening of sanctions. A more politically open Iran will not necessarily become less of an international menace; ending state-sponsored terrorism does not appear high on the priority list of reformers, who are preoccupied with domestic projects. Though signs of an Iranian opening are sure to quicken the rush of European businesses to Teheran, the "soft" diplomacy and cultural exchanges of current US policy are more appropriate as Iran's struggle proceeds.
The Washington Post

webTitle: Utilities go for the one-stop shop

fields.headline: Utilities go for the one-stop shop
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: "Convergence billing"? Never heard of it? Coming to a flat-screen digital TV or WAP mobile phone in your home soon, and certainly within the next couple of years.
fields.body:
"Convergence billing"? Never heard of it? Coming to a flat-screen digital TV or WAP mobile phone in your home soon, and certainly within the next couple of years.

That is if you fancy being able to access every minute of the day via the web your single, combined bill for gas, electricity, fixed and mobile telephony and internet access charges - and, to cap it all, a bank statement showing whether you have enough funds to meet them.

A new joint venture between PowerGen, a relatively ageing generator whose shares have slumped badly in the last few months, and internet babe Affinity offering this mouthwatering, or stomach-turning, prospect was enough to put new life into electricity stocks yesterday. fields.headline: Large Emile, Big deal and Great fat hope
fields.trailText: READ THIS AND BENEFIT FROM WHAT IT TELLS YOU
fields.body:
READ THIS AND BENEFIT FROM WHAT IT TELLS YOU

Win £10k! with www.kamikazefootball.com, the new online footy game. Coming tomorrow - a unique offer from Kamikaze Football for subscribers to the Fiver.

A WISE CHOICE

Kelvin Koogan, the man with the future of English football in his hands - please don't cry - has named his team for England's "severe test" against Argentina at Wembley tomorrow. It's got Dennis Wise in it.

The selection of the little Chelsea firebrand will cause consternation among those who become sad and unhappy when England end the game with ten men or get involved in nineteen-man mass brawls which climax in a Benny Hill-style chase. But to be fair, he's only getting in ahead of Paul Ince, and the only reason Ince seems so benign these days is because nobody notices what's going on at Middlesbrough any more. "Paul Ince has played the last two games and I know what he can do. Dennis Wise hasn't played for a while and I have to have a look at him," explained Kelv, some rarely-heard sense spilling out of his over-optimistic mouth.

Kelv's had some other clever ideas as well. Nine-foot Leicester striker Emile Heskey gets his first start in an England shirt, and Kevin Phillips is expected to play at some point. The problem on the left looks to have been sorted too, with the solid and in-form Leeds winger Jason Wilcox giving the side some much-needed balance.

Finally, perhaps, proof that Koog has developed some tactical acumen to go with his renowned man-management skills? "I've said to Jason Wilcox I'm not expecting him to go out there and absolutely set the world on fire," Koog opined, spectacularly shooting Wilcox's confidence down in flames. What you lose on the managerial swings, you gain on the managerial roundabout, we suppose.

The team: Seaman, Dyer, Keown, Southgate, Campbell, Wilcox, Wise, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Heskey.

CHEER UP

Stuck in the office instead of the pub tomorrow night? Don't worry - there'll be live minute-by-minute coverage of England v Argentina at Football Unlimited. It's better than listening to Andy Gray bang on, in any case.

LET'S GET READY TO RUMBLE

The row between David Beckham and Alex Ferguson rumbles on and on. In fact, it has violently oscillated so much that it's broken free of its moorings, rumbled all the way out of Manchester United's training ground and crashed onto the pages of the Mirror, where an easy-to-read-and-to-laugh-at transcript of the petulant slanging match between the two has been printed for your leisure and pleasure.

As you'll no doubt know by now, Beckham turned up to training on Saturday having missed the previous day because his young child required some running repairs. He had phoned in with his excuse, but placate the Fergmeister it did not. And so, according to the Mirror, he met this volley of abuse upon his return:

F: "Where have you been?"
B: "The baby wasn't well and I had to look after him."
F: "Get your priorities right."
B: "I did. My family comes first."
F: "No! It should be United."
B: "**** off."
F: "No - you **** off. Get out of here."
B: "Big deal!"

Sources suggest this snatch of Wildean repartee has brought Beckham's dream stint at Old Trafford to a premature end - expect the bids to rain in this summer from every big club in Europe bar Leeds and Liverpool. But all is not lost if Becks really wants to stay at OT - stunning news has come in which proves Fergie is capable of forgiveness!

The United manager has revealed how he attempted to patch up the rift between him and ex-coach Brian Kidd by recently offering him a job with United youth. Hold on though... upon giving it some thought, and remembering where he'd left his temper, Ferg decided it was "not feasible" and swiftly withdrew the offer.

Ah well, never mind Becks... big deal, eh?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"A Beckham goal at any stage of the match will be particularly well received." - A spokesman for Coral being particularly patriotic? Nope, they've offered to refund all losing first-goalscorer bets if Becks scores against Argentina tomorrow. He's not hated so much that the bookies have to give him a safety net, is he?

A FISHY TALE

You don't always have to go to the ends of the earth to find love. But for Paul Gascoigne, the four corners of planet football are beckoning. Hot on the heels of old pal Gary 'Salt'n' Lineker's suggestion that Gazza might be happier playing football in the USA, Japan, or somewhere foreign, reassurance comes that England's great fat hope does indeed have a friend, albeit 12,000 miles away.

But who would want a rotund has-been with a broken arm? Step forward Bryan Robson's Antipodean equivalent, Eddie 'Dial-a-Crock Dundee' Krncevic of the Marconi Stallions. Gazza, with his penchant for the odd beer and kebab, "would be something very special for the Australian public," burped the Stallions boss as he swatted away flies from the barbie. "I don't think he'd be a problem here," said Krncevic, who 'made his name' playing for Belgian club Bruges. "It's more a question of finding a good fishing venue," he mused, flipping a burger. "If he could find a place on the Harbour with a little boat where he could fish, he'd be very content," concluded Krncevic, solving the wayward midfielder's problems at a stroke.

Marketing man Ross Musso, cracking tinnies by the fridge, agreed. "Paul's exciting. He's like Dennis Rodman," he waffled, surprisingly comparing Gazza to a cross-dressing, philandering basketball player who was hauled up before the courts and once kicked a cameraman in the groin.

Marconi have also been linked with Chelsea's Gianfranco Zola - "He's fascinating, like Des from Neighbours," enthused a source.

THE RUMOUR MILL

According to Opta Soccer, Aston Villa have emerged as front-runners in the race to sign PSV Eindhoven striker Luc Nilis.

Milan have joined Juventus, Roma and Manchester United in the chase for Spurs defender Sol Campbell.

NEWS IN BRIEF

A Scottish parliament committee today offered its backing to an ambitious bid for Scotland, Ireland and Wales to co-host the 2010 World Cup - despite Fifa dismissing it as a non-starter. Brian Monteith, Conservative MSP for Mid-Scotland and Fife, said: "It seems to me perfectly sensible the SFA initiate exploratory discussions to see if the matter can possibly be taken forward. I would leave it to them to decide if it is an appropriate plan. But at least exploratory discussions are worthwhile." But a Fifa spokesman said: "The 2002 World Cup is being co-hosted by Japan and South Korea but that was always intended to be a one-off situation that will not be repeated."

BBC Scotland has acquired the live rights to the next Old Firm game at Parkhead on Wednesday March 8.

Leeds youngster Matthew Jones is likely to be handed a full Wales debut tomorrow against Qatar. Expected line-up: Jones (Southampton), Delaney (Aston Villa), Coleman (Fulham), Page (Watford), Melville (Fulham), Robinson (Charlton), Speed (Newcastle), Jones (Leeds), Pembridge (Everton), Blake (Blackburn), Roberts (Wigan).

Portsmouth players Rory Allen and Aaron Flahavan have been fined £750 and ordered to pay £55 costs each after pleading guilty to a charge of behaviour likely to cause harassment, alarm and distress in an incident outside a TGI Friday restaurant in Fareham, Hampshire, last Friday. Allen and Flahavan have been fined two weeks' wages as a punishment by Portsmouth for the incident.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.25am)
Premiership schmemiership.

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.25am)
Watch Lazio get jolly cross as Milan are awarded about sixty penalties.

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (4.50am)
So this week you're interested. Well, Channel 5 doesn't want any fly-by-nights round here. It's not as if they need the viewing figures or anything.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm)
Like English football but two teams can still win it.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.15am)
McCaff sits in a studio with his mouth gaping open. Coffee goes in, nothing useful comes out.

Sky Sports 2: International Football - Live (7.30pm, 12.30am)
England and Argentina U-21s. Yes of course the one at 12.30am isn't live as well.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)
For those of you who want to know what the Sun's Striker cartoon would be like in real life.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
For those of you who want to know what the Sun's agony column would sound like in real life.
