fields.headline: La violencia xenófoba
fields.trailText: Beginners' Spanish
fields.body:
El pueblo de El Ejido, en Almería, ha sido escenario de violentos ataques xenófobos en España. A principios de febrero, los inmigrantes de Marruecos y Argelia fueron víctimas de amenazas y ataques. Las imágenes en televisión y en los periódicos eran alarmantes. En la comarca de El Ejido trabajan 20.000 inmigrantes.

En los campos de El Ejido crecen un millón de toneladas de hortalizas al año: pimientos, tomates, pepinos - que exportan a toda Europa. Las hortalizas se cultivan bajo inverna- deros de plástico. Se necesitan muchos agricultores para trabajar en las miles de hectáreas de invernaderos. Los inmigrantes trabajan por 4.500 pesetas al día. La mayoría vienen del Magreb, del norte de Africa. Las condiciones de vida de los inmigrantes son indignas. Los inmigrantes duermen en chabolas junto a los campos, a menudo sin agua y sin electricidad. El alcalde, Juan Enciso, del Partido Popular, dice que los magrebíes no deben entrar en el pueblo.

"Los inmigrantes vienen para ganar dinero y volver a su país. No tienen intención de integrarse porque no hay actitud de acogida", opina Armand, 18 años. "Es importante," añade, "buscar soluciones de inmediato. Si la población inmigrante y la población local viven separadas, los conflictos se repetirán". Daniel, 20 años, está de acuerdo. Propone integrar a los inmigrantes y sensibilizar a la sociedad.

Luis, 19 años, considera que la solución es no dejar entrar a inmigrantes ilegales. "Si hay cien empleos y doscientos inmigrantes, los que sobran lógicamente se dedican a robar. Los inmigrantes ilegales deben volver a su país". Gonzalo, 19 años, opina que la solución es la integración: "Los inmigrantes deben entrar a España con un contrato de trabajo bajo el brazo".

Glosario/Glossary

la acogida welcome
amenazar to threaten
bajo el brazo under their arm
una chabola hut
la comarca area
estar de acuerdo to agree
la hortaliza vegetable
un invernadero a greenhouse
el pepino cucumber
sembrar to sow
los que sobran those who are left over, ie. those without jobs

Propone integrar a los inmigrantes y sensibilizar a la sociedad. Luis, 19 años, considera que la solución es no dejar entrar a inmigrantes ilegales. "Si hay cien empleos y doscientos inmigrantes, los que sobran lógicamente se dedican a robar. Los inmigrantes ilegales deben volver a su país". Gonzalo, 19 años, opina que la solución es la integración: "Los inmigrantes deben entrar a España con un contrato de trabajo bajo el brazo". fields.headline: Razorfish backs Autonomy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Software manufacturer Autonomy Corporation's market value edged towards the $5bn (£3.12bn) level last night after Nasdaq-listed Razorfish became the latest company to back its technology.
fields.body:
Software manufacturer Autonomy Corporation's market value edged towards the $5bn (£3.12bn) level last night after Nasdaq-listed Razorfish became the latest company to back its technology.

Internet consultant Razorfish announced that its German division would be selling the Cambridge-based company's information personalisation technology to its corporate clients.

Autonomy hopes the agreement will eventually be extended to cover the American and other European markets in which Razorfish operates.

Razorfish clients will be able to personalise the news, data and advertising delivered to their customers on completion of the deal. The company says the technology will enable improved user brand loyalty and attract more traffic to sites.

Shares in Easdaq-listed Autonomy climbed $2.13 to $119.25, valuing it at $4.8bn.

webTitle: Perren guides Bulls into one-day final

fields.headline: Perren guides Bulls into one-day final
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Another precocious innings from Clinton Perren, who turns 25 today, guided the Queensland Bulls into the final of the one-day Mercantile Mutual Cup at the expense of the New South Wales Blues in Brisbane. Perren, who shone on his first-class debut earlier this season with 153, hit 86* as Queensland got home with three wickets and 22 balls to spare. NSW made 210 for 6 in their 50 overs, with Mark Higgs striking 74 off 71 balls.

New South Wales 210 for 6 in 50 overs
Queensland 214 for 7 in 46.2 overs
Queensland won by 3 wickets

Simon Katich was the hero in the other semi-final as Western Australia overcame South Australia by 29 runs at Perth. Katich, who will play for Durham this summer, scored 116 as WA registered 246 for 7. It would have been more but for an excellent spell of bowling from left-arm seamer Brett Swain. He removed both openers cheaply, including Justin Langer for 8, to finish with figures of 10-3-16-2. SA got off to a good start in reply, reaching 149 for 3 in the 31st over, but then lost 4 for 2 and never recovered, despite 85 from Darren Lehmann.

Western Australia 246 for 7 in 50 overs
South Australia 217 in 46.4 overs
Western Australia won by 29 runs

West Indies

Jamaican opener Chris Gayle blasted 168 as his side reached the final of the first-class Busta Cup - where they will meet the Leeward Islands - by virtue of their first-innings lead over Guyana at Sabina Park. Gayle made his runs out of a total of 348, although his colleagues struggled to come to terms with the spin of Neil McGarrell, who finished with 4-82. Shivnarine Chanderpaul hit 112 in reply, but 6-71 from Franklyn Rose limited Guyana to 242. Jamaica only needed to bat out the game to go through, and they duly closed on 192 for 6, Robert Samuels holding things together with 73*.

Jamaica 348 and 192 for 6 (Reon King 4-30)
Guyana 242
Drawn. Jamaica go through by virtue of their first-innings lead

South Africa

A career-best 150* from opener Willem Dry gave Griqualand West a rare victory, over Border, in the Standard Bank one-day competition. Dry faced just 140 balls, hitting nine fours and seven sixes, and putting on 166 for the first wicket with John Arthur (72). His innings, the highest by any Griquas player, allowed his side to close on 252 for 3; Makhaya Ntini took all three wickets. In reply, Border were looking good at 132 for 1 in the 26th over, but proceeded to lose nine wickets in 14 overs and were bowled out for 203, Adrian Swanepoel claiming a career-best 5-32.

Griqualand West 252 for 3 in 45 overs
Border 203 in 41 overs (Peterus Botha 70)
Griqualand West won by 49 runs

A century from Test discard Adam Bacher (112) was the basis of Gauteng's four-wicket win over Free State in Johannesburg. Gauteng were also indebted to a 46-ball 56 from Andrew Hall, who has now hit four half-centuries this season in his position as pinch-hitter. Earlier, Willem Smit struck 103*, while Gerard Brophy clubbed a quickfire 56* from just 30 balls, but it wasn't enough.

Free State 244 for 5 in 45 overs
Gauteng 247 for 6 in 43.4 overs
Gauteng won by 4 wickets

Another player with a famous father stole the headlines as Easterns pulled off a last-over victory over KwaZulu-Natal in Durban. Graeme Pollock, son of a more famous Graeme Pollock, smashed 51* off 52 balls at No.7 as Easterns sneaked home with three balls to spare in pursuit of 230. Ex-Test opener Andrew Hudson made 89 for Natal.

KwaZulu-Natal 229 for 6 in 45 overs
Easterns 232 for 7 in 44.3 overs
Easterns won by 3 wickets

In the other game played last Thursday, 73* from Martin van Jaarsveld took Northerns to a comfortable win against Western Province at Cape Town.

Western Province 174 in 44.3 overs
Northerns 177 for 4 in 41.1 overs
Northerns won by 6 wickets

There were three games played on Sunday. The highlight was a tight win for KwaZulu-Natal against Northerns at Centurion. Northerns made 219 for 5, thanks to 100* from Gerald Dros, but Natal pinched a win with three wickets and one ball to go.

Northerns 219 for 5 in 45 overs
KwaZulu-Natal 220 for 7 in 44.5 overs
KwaZulu-Natal won by 3 wickets

Wetsern Province were skittled for 102, with Hylton Ackerman's 16 the top score, as Eastern Province triumphed at Port Elizabeth. Former international Meyrick Pringle returned figures of 9-2-15-4. And Boland strengthened their position at the top of the table with a four-wicket win over close rivals Easterns at Paarl.

Eastern Province 186 for 8 in 45 overs
Western Province 102 in 36.2 overs
Eastern Province won by 84 runs

Easterns 171 in 45 overs
Boland 174 for 6 in 42.3 overs
Boland won by 4 wickets

Boland lead the table with 23 points from 6 games, followed by Easterns (15 from 5), Gauteng (14 from 4) and KwaZulu-Natal (13 from 4). North-West are bottom, behind Griqualand West.

India

Rahul Dravid was in the runs as reigning champions Karnataka saw off Rajasthan in the super league stage of the Ranji Trophy in Bangalore. Dravid, Kent's new overseas signing, followed a first-innings 71 with 149 as Karnataka, strengthened by the return of fellow Test players Javagal Srinath, Venkatesh Prasad and Anil Kumble, declared their second innings on 326 for 6. Rajasthan, dismissed by Sunil Joshi's left-arm spin (6-48) first time round, were set 359 for victory, but collapsed to 96 for 7, before 85 from No.9 Devendrapal Singh at least gave them respectability.

Karnataka 243 and 326 for 6 decl.
Rajasthan 211 and 219
Karnataka won by 139 runs

Saurav Ganguly was in the wickets in the other group A game, as Bengal narrowly failed to beat Delhi in Calcutta. Ganguly, opening the bowling, took 5-91 in Delhi's second innings to leave Bengal a target of 124 to win in 11 overs. They finished on 82 for 4, Ganguly making just 17. Earlier, three players fell in the nervous nineties: opener Akash Chopra hit 95 but ate up 328 balls in the process as Delhi crawled to 236 in 105.3 overs in their first innings. Then Nikhil Haldipur (92) and S Kalyani (90) helped Bengal to 374 for 8 declared.

Delhi 236 and 261
Bengal 374 for 8 decl. and 82 for 4
Drawn

There were runs galore in Delhi where Railways and Baroda did battle for first-innings supremacy on a pitch that had nothing in it for the bowlers. Railways opened with a massive 506, with centuries for Yere Goud (182) and S Wankhade (139); slow left-armer Valmik Buch toiled heroically for an analysis of 64-31-109-4. But Baroda then out-bored even that effort, and finished the match on 516 for 9. Opener Connor Williams made 123, and Himanshu Jadhav 109. In all, 1022 runs were made over four days for the loss of just 19 wickets.

Railways 506
Baroda 516 for 9
Drawn

Vangipurappu Laxman, one of the few Indian batting successes on their recent tour of Australia, struck 119 for Hyderabad in their group-B draw with visitors Bihar. Hyderabad ran up 440 for 8 declared, with Vanka Pratap registering 100*, in reply to Bihar's 381, in which three players got out in the eighties. One of them, Sunil Kumar (80), made 71* in the second innings as the game petered out.

Bihar 381 (Mihir Diwakar 86, Rajiv Kumar 85) and 229 for 9
Hyderabad 440 for 8 decl.
Drawn

A third-wicket stand of 229 between Gyanendrakumar Pandey (163) and Rizwan Shamshad (115) was the basis of Uttar Pradesh's ten-wicket mauling of Orissa in Kanpur. In reply to Orissa's first innings of 241 (Sanjay Raul 108*), UP totalled 487, with off spinner Sanjay Satpathy collecting 6-147. Orissa were then bowled out for 257 second time round, with Raul adding 82 and Raza taking 5-49, before UP eased home.

Orissa 241 and 257
Uttar Pradesh 487 and 14 for 0
Uttar Pradesh won by 10 wickets

PJ Bhatt made 110 as Saurashtra laid the foundations for an easy win over Haryana in Rohtak. In reply to Saurashtra's 405, Haryana were bundled out for 224, with off spinner Hitesh Parsana taking 6-68, and were asked to follow on. Rajesh Puri hit 114*, but received little support from his teammates, and Saurashtra were left to score just 94 to win.

Saurashtra 405 and 97 for 1
Haryana 224 and 274 (Firoz Bambhaniya 5-54)
Saurashtra won by 9 wickets

New Zealand

A ninth-wicket partnership of 189 between Neal Parlane (147) and Daryl Tuffey (89*) set up a convincing win for Northern Districts over Wellington at the Basin Reserve in the second round of the first-class Shell Trophy. The stand gave ND a first-innings lead of 151, after Tim Boyer (104) and Test batsman Matthew Bell (77) had made runs in Wellington's first innings of 285. Boyer then hit 64 second time round, but Wellington were skittled for 177, and ND cruised to victory.

Wellington 285 and 177 (Grant Bradburn 4-37)
Northern Districts 436 and 27 for 0
Northern Districts won by 10 wickets

Richard King struck 104 in Auckland's first innings as they overcame Otago at Dunedin. Replying to Auckland's 285, Otago reached 185, before Shayne O'Connor claimed 5-43 as Auckland totalled just 180 in their second innings. This set Otago 281 to win. They got to 128 for 3, but then subsided as Canning took 5-47. Matthew Horne hit 66.

Auckland 285 and 180
Otago 185 (Chris Gaffaney 82, Kerry Walmsley 4-43) and 210
Auckland won by 70 runs

A good spell of offspin bowling from Central Districts's Campbell Furlong put Canterbury on the back foot in Napier. Furlong tweaked his way to figures of 4-36 as Canterbury managed just 150 in response to CD's first innings of 358, in which captain Jacob Oram made 90. Following on, 208 behind, Canterbury fared better, with Michael Papps scoring 81, but, faced with a victory target of 119, CD got home for the loss of five wickets.

Central Districts 358 and 122 for 5
Canterbury 150 and 326
Central Districts won by 5 wickets

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Airtours in £240m bid for net travel agency

fields.headline: Airtours in £240m bid for net travel agency
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Airtours, the package tour group, is bolstering its attempts to break into the American holiday market with a £240m bid for Travel Services International, an internet travel agency which is one of the leading sellers of cruises and car hire.
fields.body:
Airtours, the package tour group, is bolstering its attempts to break into the American holiday market with a £240m bid for Travel Services International, an internet travel agency which is one of the leading sellers of cruises and car hire.

David Crossland, chairman of Airtours, whose north American profits have been hit by competitive conditions in Canada, said the deal would provide a leading position in the world's biggest leisure market as well as building the group's "e-tailing" capabilities.

The acquisition, which follows last year's failed bid for First Choice - along with the promise of greater exposure to internet sales - fired up the shares which closed 16%, or 38.25p higher, at 280p.

Airtours said TSI is one of the most technologically advanced travel retailers in the US, with sales of more than £687m and profits of £7.7m in 1999.

The company is estimated to have a 10% share of the rapidly growing cruise market and sold 450,000 shipboard holidays last year.

Its Auto Europe brand is also the largest seller of car rentals to American and Canadian holidaymakers visiting Europe. TSI's Lexington Services division handled more than 1.25m hotel reservations last year which Airtours claims makes it the largest provider of global hotel reservations in the US.

Mr Crossland added: "We believe the combination of TSI's technology and Airtours' products on a worldwide basis significantly enhances the growth prospects of both companies."

fields.headline: Struggling through university
fields.trailText: Women's cricket is one of the fastest-growing sports in Britain's universities, but despite the talent and efforts of many, the standard of play is not as high as it could be. Many teams have difficulty producing 11 players who are good enough: they rely heavily upon a small group of star players, and are then forced to include several others who are, frankly, making up the numbers. Why does this happen?
fields.body:
Women's cricket is one of the fastest-growing sports in Britain's universities, but despite the talent and efforts of many, the standard of play is not as high as it could be. Many teams have difficulty producing 11 players who are good enough: they rely heavily upon a small group of star players, and are then forced to include several others who are, frankly, making up the numbers. Why does this happen?

For a start, most of these players only took up the game when they started university at the age of 18, because they had no opportunity to play at school. There have been numerous articles recently bemoaning the lack of proper cricketing facilities in most schools, particularly in the state sector, but not one of them has pointed out that the situation is far worse for girls than it is for boys. Girls often have to overcome almost insurmountable obstacles just to get a game, let alone develop their skills.

In order to have any chance of playing cricket at school, a girl needs, above all, to have a PE teacher who is herself interested in cricket; these, sad to say, seem few and far between. And sometimes even this is not enough. A female cricketing friend who taught, briefly, at an independent school in the north of England wanted to start cricket practice for girls and was shocked to find not only that the male head of PE refused to let her use the square, the nets or any of the equipment, but also that the school offered her no support in the matter. This is the sort of attitude which can found up and down the country.

All this adds up to the fact that the vast majority of girls who may have wanted to play cricket are turning up at university, through no fault of their own, with no experience at all. This puts many of them off altogether, as they prefer to continue with sports which are more familiar to them. Those who are still determined to play are keen (which is great), but have few cricketing skills. This means that university teams have plenty of enthusiasm but often little technical know-how.

It's wonderful that more and more women and girls are taking up cricket, but their enthusiasm is not encouraged; deep-rooted bias is mostly to blame. There is still a widely-held belief that the place of women in cricket is to make the tea: until this changes there is likely to be little progress.

Catherine Hanley keeps wicket for the Sheffield University women's team

webTitle: The player, the baby, his wife and the manager

fields.headline: The player, the baby, his wife and the manager
fields.standfirst: So Becks missed a key training session because his baby was ill. But, hang on, wasn't Posh at a fashion party the same night? Jim White and Emma Brockes on the humbling of a football star
fields.trailText: So Becks missed a key training session because his baby was ill. But, hang on, wasn't Posh at a fashion party the same night? Jim White and Emma Brockes on the humbling of a football star
fields.body:
As footballing misdemeanours go, David Beckham's was nothing if not original. Endearing even. Not for him missing training because of a poisonous hangover, a spell in the cells at Her Majesty's pleasure or an overnight at the Priory. No, Beckham apparently missed a session at Manchester United's swanky new Carrington training complex because he was attending to his baby's nappy. Poor Brooklyn was suffering from gastroenteritis and Becks felt he needed to be discharging his parental duty at the boy's bedside in the Hertfordshire stockbroker belt rather than tearing around practising his crosses in Manchester.

Indeed, for a moment yesterday, David Beckham - footballer, Spice-spouse, celebrity clotheshorse - looked in danger of acquiring a rather more sober reputation for himself, as a champion of fathers' rights. Who, besides Sir Alex Ferguson, could resist the account of how he skipped training to tend to his baby? Who didn't sympathise when, reappearing on Saturday, he was castigated for his absence in front of other team members and ultimately kept out of the line-up for Sunday's crunch match against Leeds? This wasn't a petulant star throwing a tantrum. This was a father, being responsible, loving his sick son.

At least, that is the way that Beckham's public relations people have been selling it since Sunday night. The machinery that protects both Beckham and his wife, Victoria Adams, is so efficient that, within hours of the final whistle it had whirred into action, repulsing questions about Ferguson's snub with news of the baby's illness and Beckham's role as super-dad. Was it a piece of face-saving spin? Or a genuine clash between Beckham's new man sensibilities and Ferguson's old style dogma?

What isn't in dispute is the broader irritation that Ferguson has for Beckham's lifestyle. Unfortunately for the footballer, his admirable attempts at behaving like a new dad brought him foursquare into conflict with his manager, a man who can be described by many adjectives, new not among them. Committed would be a more appropriate description for the knight of the realm. Obsessed might be another. Sir Alex is a football manager who believes that nothing - not wine, not women, and certainly not a child - should come between a footballer and his profession.

But when Sir Alex chose to bawl his player out in full view of the press cameras in the middle of the training pitch on Saturday, rather than, say, behind the closed doors of his office, he was making a point which went far beyond this minor transgression. Ferguson is the most adept manipulator of the press in football management history. Nothing he does is by chance; he will have known how the row with Beckham will have played. He was sending out a very public signal which said there is only one way we do things round here: my way.

Over the past few months, Ferguson, a man who finds the increasing Hollywoodisation of football as perplexing as it is distasteful, has become more and more worried about Beckham's commitment. He believes that the boy's lifestyle is incompatible with the needs of a Manchester United footballer.

To be fair to Beckham, there is no sign whatsoever that he is going off the rails in the traditional footballing manner involving drink, women and industrial quantities of white powder. On the pitch he looks fit and alert, his abilities apparently at their peak. To the outside eye he appears dedicated. But Ferguson demands that his players, particularly at this crowded point of the season, concentrate all their focus on football. When not training and playing, they should be resting.

"Energy is so vital," is one of his favourite phrases. "It needs to be nurtured and preserved." It should certainly not, he believes, be wasted on a daily 350-mile round trip between the Beckham household in Hertfordshire and the Manchester training ground; or, indeed, attending such fripperies as film premieres, fashion shows and photo opportunities. Ferguson is worried that he is losing his protégé to an orbit he cannot and does not want to understand: the world of stellar celebrity.

To understand the nature of this distaste, one must look at the people who, with an acutely honed grasp of the dynamics of news agendas, handle the Beckhams' publicity. They could not be further from Old Trafford. Both Victoria and David are represented by Caroline McAteer, a company director at the Outside Organisation, a public relations firm specialising in rock acts that lists among its clients David Bowie, Elton John and Lenny Kravitz.

Last summer, McAteer oversaw the delicate revelation that her client Stephen Gates, singer with the band Boyzone, was gay. This potentially ruinous splash - Boyzone's fan base is made up of teenage girls in love with the band members - was turned by McAteer from a turkey into a soppy piece of feelgood. Gates' fans/mum/ boyfriend stood by him and he came out of the episode all the more distinguished for his courage.

And so, the cynical might speculate, it has been with Posh and Becks. Recall if you can that heady week last December when Beckham was in Minshull Street crown court, Manchester, defending himself on speeding charges. A week after receiving an eight-month driving ban for pushing his silver Ferrari 26mph above the limit, Judge Barry Woodward upheld Beckham's appeal and handed back his licence, citing "special circumstances". This meant Beckham's fame - and the footballer used his time in the witness box to reveal how he and Victoria had fended off a potential kidnapper who had tried to grab Brooklyn several days earlier. Headlines such as "Anger as Beckham escapes speeding by blaming snappers" melted into "How Posh stopped baby-snatcher." Beckham and Victoria were transformed from spoilt celebrities into heroic parents.

The Beckham's version of last Friday night's events carries off a similar about turn. News broke of the baby's illness on Sunday night, when McAteer made a statement to the Press Association news agency, explaining that, after ringing Old Trafford to excuse himself, Beckham had not shown up on Friday to look after Brooklyn. At this early stage, there was some doubt over the nature of his ailment. "David missed training on Friday because Brooklyn had a cold and he had to stay home to look after him," is how McAteer is quoted in that first report. By Monday morning, this "cold" had escalated into full-blown gastroenteritis, characterised in the Sun as "a raging temperature and breathing difficulties", and in the Daily Mail as "a bad cough".

"I just said Brooklyn was ill," says McAteer. "I didn't want to give out any details. I am having words with the writers who wrote otherwise." Not very stern words, one imagines, since McAteer can now spookily reveal to the Guardian that, in the middle of Thursday night, Brooklyn started coughing and throwing up, but that by mid-afternoon on Friday, he was fine again. Those sceptical of the gravity of his illness, however, noted that Victoria Adams was able to attend the finale of London Fashion Week on Friday evening. "I saw Victoria on Friday night and she said Brooklyn was a lot better," says McAteer. "She wouldn't have gone out otherwise."

Whether Brooklyn was ill or not is of less concern, one suspects, than the question of whether Beckham stayed at home at the behest of his wife. The subtext to this row, which left Beckham sulking in the stands for the biggest game of his club's season so far, was not so much the baby Beckham, it was the wife, the artist formally known as Posh.

In football, a strong wife has traditionally been regarded as the first indication of serial deviance. Football wives should quietly provide a stable home life and nothing more. Well, apart from Cup Final day when they should look decorative in the pre-match television feature filmed at the the hairdressers. As players such as Nick Barmby, David Unsworth and Trevor Francis have discovered, a wife who wishes to have some sort of say in where their husband might chose to work for a living - the kind of input partners in virtually any other profession would expect - will invite ridicule within the game.

And it is not just in Britain that such prejudice exists within the game. Last season, Zinedine Zidane, the France and Juventus player, was ridiculed by the Italian media after it became clear his wife was keen that he secured a move to somewhere warm. Juventus's owner, Gianni Agnelli, the Fiat magnate, called a press conference to laugh at the player. "Zizou must decide who wears the trousers in his household," he said.

Tittering reporters told Italian television viewers that they were keen to secure a response from Zidane but they couldn't because, although willing to talk, he had to dash home to do the ironing.

Victoria Beckham, however, is a new variant on the footballer's wife: a woman whose level of celebrity is even more elevated than that of her husband. Players have been married to pop stars before, but you could never imagine Billy Wright, married to one of the Beverley sisters, being quite so keen to be seen by her side at a fashion shoot. Moreover, Victoria appears to have an almost pathalogical need for publicity, she breathes the oxygen of headlines to reinforce her self-esteem, to reassure herself that she still matters. And there is no better way for her to accrue those headlines than with her husband by her side. Besides, they want to be together, they clearly dote on one another.

Thus Beckham finds himself pulled between two forces which represent the old and the new faces of football. On the one hand is the autocratic, old style football manager who gave him the opportunity he most wanted in his life - to play for Manchester United, the club he loved from boyhood - but who continues to demand that all peripheries should be sacrificed to the cause. On the other is the wife he adores, who doesn't quite understand why everyone gets so worked up about a silly game and believes since he is good enough to play for whoever he wishes, now might be the time to pursue his profession somewhere drier, somewhere closer to the centre of the world, frankly somewhere more convenient than Manchester - like Milan, say.

Oddly, in the end, the two forces might not be mutually exclusive: both might get their way. If, as is widely rumoured, Beckham moves on this summer, Posh will have her husband where she wants him and Ferguson will have re-established his authority. Plus he will have several tens of millions in his transfer account to pick up a player less distracted by incidentals. And Beckham? Well, at least he will get more time to spend with the family.

fields.headline: Separate sphere
fields.standfirst:
St Hilda's is Oxford's last women's college - but an impending vote could change all that.
You can vote on this issue by scrolling to the bottom of Education Unlimited's front page.
fields.trailText: St Hilda's is Oxford's last women's college - but an impending vote could change all that
fields.body:
Sitting next to a former principal of St Hilda's College during a recent formal dinner, I asked what the college was like during her time in the 1960s. She replied: "St. Hilda's was never the 'professional' women's college."

It was always expected that Somerville, the most high-profile and "political" of the original five, would survive Oxford's staggered shift to co-education. Yet it is St Hilda's which remains the university's last all-female college, and which alone will debate that status in a forthcoming referendum.

It is only four years since the last vote was taken on whether to "go mixed". The media attention was extensive, but the focus was always the same: a discussion of the "serious issues" alongside quirky college folklore (such as the tale of the girl who jumped naked into the Cherwell and posed for The Sun) and slogans such as "St Thrillda's", and the famous "Hildabeasts".

After reading those articles in my final year at school, having just gained a place at St Hilda's, it seemed there was almost nothing to be gleaned about what it is actually like to be a student in the only single-sex college in Oxford.

Three years later, and in my penultimate term, it seems that the public, and indeed the rest of the university, still have little idea. The image of the women's college appears bound to wholly inaccurate stereotypes, and St Hilda's - it seems for no other reason - has a woefully bad press. What was once a powerful symbol of women's education now struggles to transcend absurd caricatures.

In that light, my experience and that of many of my friends has been bittersweet. St Hilda's is supportive, laid-back and diverse; at the risk of sounding sentimental, a truly inspiring place to live and study.

The college accepts only women as fellows, and I believe I have benefited from the concentrated presence of female academics. Yet the perception of being the underdog does prove wearisome. Though it is an exceptional place, it is difficult when you are required continually to engage in debunking the myth.

When Somerville went mixed in 1994, the Junior Common Room received hundreds of letters from ex-Somervillians from around the world; octogenarians pledging to return in Somerville sweatshirts to fight the change. That image captures something of the spirit of women's colleges. But an ephemeral sense of the college in its "heyday" and a discussion of the issues at a high level of abstraction is not enough; that is plain from the way we have lurched from referendum to referendum.

The imminent vote, in contrast to its predecessor, will extend only to St Hilda's undergraduate body, and we will be asked whether we wish to accept men as students and as fellows. Its result will not be binding on the college.

Without wishing to pre-empt the debate, past arguments in favour of, and against, going mixed are remarkably evenly balanced. Factors include the evidence that women achieve better results in a single-sex environment, the decreased funding available from the government as a result of maintaining a single-sex fellowship (we are not an equal opportunity employer), and the challenge of competing with other colleges to attract quality candidates.

Other concerns seem more immediately relevant. It is too easy to rebut the accusation that St Hilda's is an anachronism with arguments about the under-representation of women at Oxford University. This is the most compelling justification for the status quo, but it is a view from outside, and says nothing about what it is really like to be at St Hilda's.

The students who study here have not come to "fight a cause", however important that cause may be, and the college cannot survive in its present form simply to provide a confined remedy to a university-wide problem. The challenge for St Hilda's must be to justify itself on its own terms, and I believe it can.

 Nicole Taylor is reading law at St Hilda's College, Oxford.

fields.headline: Lords revolt over mayor campaign
fields.trailText: The government was defeated in the Lords this evening over plans to ban free mailshots for candidates in the elections for London's Mayor and Assembly.
fields.body:
The government was defeated in the Lords this evening over plans to ban free mailshots for candidates in the elections for London's Mayor and Assembly.

Peers had protested that Labour's attempts to block free publicity for all candidates would allow them to "buy" the vote for their prospective mayor Frank Dobson.

The Lords voted 215 to 150, a majority of 65, backing a Tory call for a freepost delivery for candidates. Ministers were then defeated in a second ballot rejecting rules for running the elections by a majority of 63 votes.

For the Government, Lord Whitty said that clearly the "concerns" expressed would be returned to when the Lords debated the report stage of the representation of the people bill on Tuesday.

"As far as the orders are concerned we will be reintroducing them at the earliest opportunity," he said.

Lord Goodhart, for the Liberal Democrats, declared that the election needs a free post for the sake of democracy.

"Candidates must be able to get their message over to electors."

The government had protested that the unelected Lords had no right to debate electoral law. Deputy prime minister John Prescott said that as the London election was for a local government there was not the precedent for a mailshot that there would be in a general election or election to a devolved assembly.

Tory former cabinet minister Viscount Cranborne, who was sacked as party leader in the Lords last year, said the government had no reason to be "outraged".

"If that is so it really is rather curious in that the government is betraying a rather cavalier view of the constitutional place of a second chamber in our system."

Lord Cranborne said if the government wished to act "in a high handed manner" it could do so with its massive Commons majority - "until and unless your Lordships' House at least puts up its hands and says 'I think that we ought to think about this again'.

"Who, apart from your Lordships' House, is in a position to exercise at least a measure of warning?" he added.
fields.bodyText: The government was defeated in the Lords this evening over plans to ban free mailshots for candidates in the elections for London's Mayor and Assembly. Peers had protested that Labour's attempts to block free publicity for all candidates would allow them to "buy" the vote for their prospective mayor Frank Dobson. The Lords voted 215 to 150, a majority of 65, backing a Tory call for a freepost delivery for candidates. Ministers were then defeated in a second ballot rejecting rules for running the elections by a majority of 63 votes. For the Government, Lord Whitty said that clearly the "concerns" expressed would be returned to when the Lords debated the report stage of the representation of the people bill on Tuesday. "As far as the orders are concerned we will be reintroducing them at the earliest opportunity," he said. Lord Goodhart, for the Liberal Democrats, declared that the election needs a free post for the sake of democracy. "Candidates must be able to get their message over to electors." The government had protested that the unelected Lords had no right to debate electoral law. Deputy prime minister John Prescott said that as the London election was for a local government there was not the precedent for a mailshot that there would be in a general election or election to a devolved assembly. Tory former cabinet minister Viscount Cranborne, who was sacked as party leader in the Lords last year, said the government had no reason to be "outraged". "If that is so it really is rather curious in that the government is betraying a rather cavalier view of the constitutional place of a second chamber in our system." webTitle: Chancellor unveils plan to speed euro switch

fields.headline: Chancellor unveils plan to speed euro switch
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today face down Conservative charges of government dithering when he announces plans to accelerate Britain's preparations for joining the European single currency.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today face down Conservative charges of government dithering when he announces plans to accelerate Britain's preparations for joining the European single currency.

The move comes after a lacklustre launch of the "Out of Europe, Out of Work" campaign by the all-party Britain in Europe lobby at which the trade and industry secretary, Steve Byers, admitted that the UK is already losing influence in EU policy making.

As Mr Byers endorsed an independent academic report which confirms that at least 3m jobs depend on exports to the EU, a senior Tory called on Tony Blair to show that he is taking steps to ensure that Britain meets Mr Brown's five criteria for joining the 11-nation eurozone.

Mr Blair and his chancellor insist that their five tests of the national interest have not wavered. But in a speech in New York, Mr Brown will declare that the government is to publish the second phase of its "national changeover plan" within the next few weeks to help businesses trading in euroland.

The Tory leadership, which has called for the changeover plan to be scrapped, will seize on Mr Brown's speech as a sign that the chancellor is warming to the eurozone. But Mr Brown will make clear that the second phase of what Michael Portillo has dubbed the "national handover plan" is a natural step ahead of the introduction of euro notes and coins next Jaunary in the eurozone.

At yesterday's launch the pro-European side of the argument warned that Euro-sceptic propaganda has reached a dangerous point where up to 34% of voters now favour leaving the EU - and that this "political dogma damages the interests of British business and British jobs".

After he had endorsed the new Britain in Europe slogan - "out of the argument, out of influence, out on our own" - Mr Byers admitted that "there are certain (EU) committees we are not members of because we are not in the single currency. Therefore we are losing influence as far as these committees are concerned".

Also on the platform with Mr Byers were Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrats' treasury spokesman, and Ian Taylor, dropped from the Conservative frontbench for his Europhile views. The backbench Tory warned that delay on the euro is unsettling business, and urged ministers to make their preparations clearer.

Britain in Europe was embarrassed last week when an academic survey was twisted to suggest that job losses from leaving the EU could reach 8m - dismissed as "absurd".

Yesterday a new study by South Bank university confirmed that 2.5m jobs are directly dependent on exports to the EU, 900,000 more indirectly so.

The chancellor's message will be that the government is not afraid to continue with practical preparations for the euro, despite the Tories' new Keep the Pound campaign.

In his speech, Mr Brown will attack those who "seek to renegotiate the basis of our membership of the European Union" for putting at risk "the stability that is central to modern business and investment decisions.

"The real risk of endless talk of 'in' or 'out' of Europe is the risk that investors start to believe that Britain is semi-detached."

webTitle: Mapping mission comes to a successful end

fields.headline: Mapping mission comes to a successful end
fields.trailText: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour ended their ambitious Earth-mapping work on Monday after some anxious moments closing a hatch and prepared to come home, possibly at a seldom used landing strip in New Mexico because of bad weather.
fields.body:
Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour ended their ambitious Earth-mapping work on Monday after some anxious moments closing a hatch and prepared to come home, possibly at a seldom used landing strip in New Mexico because of bad weather.

Following a final mapping pass over Australia, the astronauts began to stow their equipment for Tuesday's scheduled landing, but there was trouble with the 20-story radar mast deployed just hours after their February 11 lift-off.

Although the 197-foot collapsible truss-structure folded easily into its canister in Endeavour's cargo bay, three latches designed to secure the canister's hatch refused to lock into place.

The Endeavour astronauts, working remote controls from the orbiter's crew compartment, tried three times to shut the lid before finally succeeding, using a maximum force setting.

Cheers erupted in Houston's Mission Control Centre when ground controllers saw the hatch close successfully in a television feed from the orbiter.

"Excellent job. A little extra work and well worth the effort," Mission Control told the astronauts.

If the astronauts had not been able to close the hatch, Mission Control probably would have ordered them to detonate small explosives that would have tossed the mast and its canister overboard.

"We can speculate as to the cause, but there's a lot of cables and harnesses that have to get folded up," Jeff Bantle, Nasa's chief flight director, told reporters. "One possibility is that just compressing those was a little difficult."

Although two of the astronauts were trained to leave the orbiter and repair the mast, Nasa discarded that option on Saturday when the space agency ordered an extra nine hours of mapping, using time that had been reserved for the contingency space walk.

The 2-1/2 hours spent on Monday trying to close the latches provided tense moments on the ground and in space.

"My knees weren't working," said project scientist Michael Kobrick.

Even if the mast had been sacrificed, the glitch would not have affected the focus of Endeavour's mission, collecting radar readings that will be used to create the most detailed 3-D surface maps ever assembled.

A new concern was raised later Monday when NASA said weather looked bad for landing at the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida, and was forecast to get worse at an alternate landing site in California.

That might force Endeavour to aim for a seldom used landing strip in New Mexico, Nasa said.

The space agency plans for bad weather by making sure there is enough fuel and other consumables, such as oxygen, food and water, for the designated landing day and two back-up days.

"Right now, the weather is somewhat questionable at the Kennedy Space Centre all three days," flight director John Shannon told reporters.

A high pressure system in the Atlantic Ocean was pushing stiff winds and a low-cloud ceiling over the Florida landing site.

Tuesday's weather at the alternate landing site, Edwards Air Force Base in California, looked better, but was expected to worsen Wednesday and Thursday.

That could leave NASA with no option but a landing strip at White Sands, New Mexico. Astronauts use the strip for practice landings in their training jets, but only one shuttle mission has landed there - in the early 1980s - and budget cutbacks have left the facility ill-equipped to process Endeavour after landing.

Still, Shannon said the space agency had no qualms about using White Sands, and would fly in the technicians and equipment if needed.

Since taking flight on February 11, the shuttle has mapped more than 46 million square miles of Earth's land formations, most of it twice. The data was stored on 326 digital cassettes inside Endeavour's crew compartment.

Only about two to three percent of Earth's topography has been mapped in the kind of resolution that Nasa hopes to accomplish with this mission.

The US military will be the chief beneficiary. The National Imagery and Mapping Agency, which supplies classified maps for US defence and intelligence agencies, is Nasa's primary partner on this flight.

Most of the highest resolution images are likely to remain classified. A lower resolution map, still superior to existing planetary topography images, will be made public. Scientists will be given access to the higher resolution images on a case-by-case basis, Nasa said.

fields.headline: Now here's the bad news...
fields.standfirst: Should children's books always have a happy ending?  Donald MacLeod heard some authors who think not
fields.trailText: Should children's books always have a happy ending? Donald MacLeod heard some authors who think not
fields.body:
Why do they always live happily ever after? Because in children's books we grown-ups expect them to, that's why. No matter how implausible, no matter how bleak the story - and there are some pretty bleak children's stories about - we expect a bit of hope at the end, or at least a moral to point our young ones in the right direction.

The idea of an immoral or nihilistic children's book is unthinkable, isn't it? So it came as a shock when at a seminar of English, Dutch and Belgian writers the idea of a "bad" children's book was floated.

Anne Provoost, a prize-winning Flemish author, told the gathering in Antwerp that if writers of children's books really wanted to be considered as artists rather than pedagogues, they would have to be totally honest and abandon any self-censorship. Was it not being condescending to children to shield them from negative emotions and the sense of futility? she demanded. (This was taking place in an old monastery, by the way.)

"This may well result in the politically incorrect... a children's book that reacts against monogamous love, a children's book that repudiates self-sacrifice and mocks the keeping of promises, and - probably 'worst' of all - a children's book that propagates intolerance," she said.

Could a book be written about a child who stole repeatedly and got away with it? Or even about a girl who seduced a grown man? "Don't misunderstand me, I am a supporter of the constructive and the optimistic, but does this necessarily mean that I am willing to submit to the dictate of the positive? It is not wrong to comfort and console children, but it is wrong to systematically shield them from futility and the feeling that some things are without any sense. Should some then say: we do what is good for the child, then we remain pedagogues instead of artists."

Her own book, Falling (Allen & Unwin, £6.99), deals with racist intolerance in a vivid and plausible manner - but the moral is clear. Wim Hofman, a Dutch author at the seminar, has gone a step further with his fatalistic version of the Snow White tale (Black as Ink - not translated into English) in which the heroine seems doomed to become as evil as her stepmother. On the other hand, Joke van Leeuwen's delightful Eep shows a much more hopeful delight in strange and wonderful things and carries a message about selfless love, albeit in an undidactic way. (Sadly, that is not published in English either.)

Philip Pullman, whose acclaimed Northern Lights (Scholastic, £5.99) and The Subtle Knife (Scholastic, £5.99) have (bizarrely) been accused by fundamentalist Christians of promoting satanism, commented that a nihilistic children's book might be possible as an experiment but would not work. Acts had consequences and a writer ought to show that.

Provoost's bombshell set the seminar buzzing and will doubtless provoke plenty of opposition when she comes to London for the "return match" in May, but she did expose a certain amount of doublethink at the heart of the children's book world in Britain as much as on the continent. Are these books to be judged as literature or not? And if so, shouldn't the same freedom to tackle anything apply?

The furore over Harry Potter and the Whitbread prize - should it go to the little wizard's creator, JK Rowling, or the poet Seamus Heaney for his translation of the epic Beowulf? - showed that some of the judges at least were prepared to reward a hugely popular children's book in ways that they wouldn't dream of doing for a good, racy adult read. The row left a lot of people feeling ambivalent - glad that a children's book was at last getting critical attention, but conscious that as literature, Harry Potter was open to unflattering critical comparisons.

fields.headline: Dream sequence
fields.standfirst: Friendship and stories are the twin themes of Bad Dreams. And Anne Fine feels very strongly about both.
fields.trailText: Friendship and stories are the twin themes of Bad Dreams. And Anne Fine feels very strongly about both.
fields.body:
Bad Dreams

By Anne Fine

Published by Doubleday

Price £10.99

Age 8+

Friendship and stories are the twin themes of Bad Dreams. And Anne Fine feels very strongly about both.

Mel is a bookworm: she eschews friendship in favour of reading. But then Imogen arrives, and Mel is forced to look after her.

Imogen is weird: she has a strange gift, or curse, which enables her to enter a book and be taken over by it. As a result, she is terrified of reading or even touching a book. Mystified, Mel sets out to discover how Imogen gets her strange insight. When she realises what it is, she takes the law into her own hands, even though it means sacrificing her own ambitions.

Imogen is free to be herself, but ungrateful to Mel. Was Mel right to try and save her? Anne Fine's crisp dialogue carries her views strongly while leaving her readers room to make up their own minds.

fields.headline: Babette's feast
fields.standfirst: Babette Cole reaches the parts other authors do not dare to reach...  Joanna Carey talks to her about feminist fairytales and books tackling 'difficult' areas
fields.trailText: Babette Cole reaches the parts other authors do not dare to reach... Joanna Carey talks to her about feminist fairytales and books tackling 'difficult' areas
fields.body:
"People always expect me to be a dear old thing in a cottage with roses round the door and a pussy cat on my knee," says Babette Cole. It's not how I'd pictured her - with books like Mummy Laid an Egg! and the recent Hair in Funny Places (about puberty) she's revolutionised the way small children can learn about the facts of life, and I imagined she'd be like the heroine of her very funny, feminist fairytale, Princess Smartypants, who didn't want to get married, and planned "to live in her castle with her pets and do exactly as she pleased". And I wasn't disappointed.

Babette lives not in a castle, but at her stud-farm in rural Lincolnshire. Small, blonde, rather glamorous in slinky caramel suede and a long fake fur coat, she meets me at the station in a colossal four-wheel drive vehicle, having just dropped off her "other half" on his way to London. Funny, friendly, she talks in exclamatory speech bubbles, with dizzy shrieks of laughter. She's only just back from a holiday which, among other things, involved crewing for the British Virgin Islands ladies yacht racing team, and a starry spell in New York discussing the forthcoming film of Princess Smartypants.

Back at work now, with her horses and her latest picture book, she talks about life down on the farm "among the acres of mangel Worzels". Like Smartypants, she's unmarried - but talks a lot about her "other half" - a Barbados-born Londoner, "quite unmarriable!" she says merrily - "and we've been together for 18 years"... she talks about money - she earned a "huge amount" in the 80s, when there was an upsurge in children's books; and now, translated into 72 languages, her sales are astronomical - "but then so are my vet's bills - around £1,000 a month!"

She moved from Kent some years ago to have more room for the horses and as we drive through the beautiful flat, frosty Lincolnshire landscape, she talks with passion about the threat posed to the rural economy by the government's plan to outlaw foxhunting - "it's a way of life round here," she says, as we stop at a tack shop to buy a huge pile of horse blankets.

Like a scene from one of her extravagantly funny books, Babette's house is full of dogs. A huge deerhound the size of an ironing board is chewing the back of a church pew in the kitchen, another sleeps on a duvet by the Aga, and a third reclines on a leopard-print sofa, wearing a tiara.

And horses are much in evidence - bridles, bits and halters dangle from the ceiling, the walls shimmer with satin rosettes, and equestrian trophies jostle for space with book awards. There's a stuffed fox and a glossy magazine offering "A Window on the World of Side-saddle", another of Babette's passions. Voted "Side-saddle Personality of the Year", there are countless photos of her - horsey, saucy and impossibly elegant soaring over Grand National-style fences.

"Riding side-saddle, I feel like a real lady," she says, describing with relish the costume - bowler hat, silk stock, tailored habit and a vital undergarment which, in true Smartypants style, is supplied by the Queen Mother's corsetiere in Knightsbridge. She's also a champion Team Chaser - and at the flick of a switch, sponsored by her publishers, the fearless Red Fox Letsgo Ladies team goes thundering by on video.

It's clear that to combine such horsemanship with a career as a best-selling author-illustrator of over 90 books needs an iron discipline - and a good head for business. Babette's studio is at the top of the house, a light-filled space, where, uninterrupted by dogs, she talks about her work. Born in Jersey, she attended a convent school and was good at drawing - "I made lots of feast day cards. Basically, the school offered a choice of three careers - you could be a nun, a wife and mother, or you could go off the rails..."

Babette chose to go to art school in England - with her pony. Accommodation with grazing facilities was unavailable in London, so they went to Canterbury art school, where she rented a field. By her third year she was taking ideas for books to publishers. After a spell at the BBC, she first made her name with her explosively funny feminist fairytales.

But what started her off on these "issue books"?

"One day my publisher asked me to do a book for young children about sex. He wanted it to be an animal book but I said no! I'll do it with real people. He said you can't! But I DID!" And in Mummy Laid an Egg! two children explain to their own parents the mechanics of human reproduction using their own schematic drawings. The book is hugely funny and graphically explicit though - at so many removes from reality - not alarmingly so.

Babette has no children and she says: "I probably couldn't have done this if I'd been approaching it from a 'motherly' point of view. Yes, I know these are difficult areas, but they should be addressed before they become difficult." Her uninhibited approach has raised a few eyebrows, but, spurred on by the scarcity of books of this sort (and a bold publisher), she has galloped headlong through sex, puberty, wet dreams, periods, health and hygiene, head-lice, worms, smoking, old age and even death.

"Complaints? Oh yes! Like the bishop who hated my divorce book [Two of Everything] in which a vicar conducts an "un-wedding" ceremony - disrespectful to the clergy, he said - but they were so unhappy, I told him, and it was you lot who married them!" She's currently writing about true love with a dog in the leading role and she shows me the preliminary storyboard stage of the book...

She draws with tremendous vitality and a watercolour technique, but adapts her style to the tone of the stories - which range from the mad cartoony stuff to the (relatively) reflective atmosphere you can find in Drop Dead. "Well I thought it needed a bit of sensitivity, since it's about death!" she says with a shriek of merriment.

The joie de vivre that surrounds Babette belies her punishing work regime, juggling studio and stud-farm. How does she cope? "The horses keep me sane, they're a great leveller." It's dark now and the stableyard is an oasis of calm. Nine magnificent show hunters incline their heads gracefully from immaculate looseboxes as Babette attends lovingly to their needs and turns up the ghetto-blaster. Each horse has a personal collection of CDs, for schooling purposes - "Flanagan likes boogie-woogie and swing; Buster likes military marches, Nemo loves the Captain Pugwash theme tune and Dan likes reggae music". But they all enjoy Classic FM and, as I leave, they are all chomping away by moonlight to Beethoven's piano sonata in C sharp minor.
fields.bodyText: "People always expect me to be a dear old thing in a cottage with roses round the door and a pussy cat on my knee," says Babette Cole. It's not how I'd pictured her - with books like Mummy Laid an Egg! and the recent Hair in Funny Places (about puberty) she's revolutionised the way small children can learn about the facts of life, and I imagined she'd be like the heroine of her very funny, feminist fairytale, Princess Smartypants, who didn't want to get married, and planned "to live in her castle with her pets and do exactly as she pleased". And I wasn't disappointed. Babette lives not in a castle, but at her stud-farm in rural Lincolnshire. Small, blonde, rather glamorous in slinky caramel suede and a long fake fur coat, she meets me at the station in a colossal four-wheel drive vehicle, having just dropped off her "other half" on his way to London. Funny, friendly, she talks in exclamatory speech bubbles, with dizzy shrieks of laughter. She's only just back from a holiday which, among other things, involved crewing for the British Virgin Islands ladies yacht racing team, and a starry spell in New York discussing the forthcoming film of Princess Smartypants. Back at work now, with her horses and her latest picture book, she talks about life down on the farm "among the acres of mangel Worzels". Like Smartypants, she's unmarried - but talks a lot about her "other half" - a Barbados-born Londoner, "quite unmarriable!" she says merrily - "and we've been together for 18 years"... she talks about money - she earned a "huge amount" in the 80s, when there was an upsurge in children's books; and now, translated into 72 languages, her sales are astronomical - "but then so are my vet's bills - around £1,000 a month!" She moved from Kent some years ago to have more room for the horses and as we drive through the beautiful flat, frosty Lincolnshire landscape, she talks with passion about the threat posed to the rural economy by the government's plan to outlaw foxhunting - "it's a way of life round here," she says, as we stop at a tack shop to buy a huge pile of horse blankets. Like a scene from one of her extravagantly funny books, Babette's house is full of dogs. A huge deerhound the size of an ironing board is chewing the back of a church pew in the kitchen, another sleeps on a duvet by the Aga, and a third reclines on a leopard-print sofa, wearing a tiara. And horses are much in evidence - bridles, bits and halters dangle from the ceiling, the walls shimmer with satin rosettes, and equestrian trophies jostle for space with book awards. There's a stuffed fox and a glossy magazine offering "A Window on the World of Side-saddle", another of Babette's passions. Voted "Side-saddle Personality of the Year", there are countless photos of her - horsey, saucy and impossibly elegant soaring over Grand National-style fences. "Riding side-saddle, I feel like a real lady," she says, describing with relish the costume - bowler hat, silk stock, tailored habit and a vital undergarment which, in true Smartypants style, is supplied by the Queen Mother's corsetiere in Knightsbridge. She's also a champion Team Chaser - and at the flick of a switch, sponsored by her publishers, the fearless Red Fox Letsgo Ladies team goes thundering by on video. It's clear that to combine such horsemanship with a career as a best-selling author-illustrator of over 90 books needs an iron discipline - and a good head for business. Babette's studio is at the top of the house, a light-filled space, where, uninterrupted by dogs, she talks about her work. Born in Jersey, she attended a convent school and was good at drawing - "I made lots of feast day cards. Basically, the school offered a choice of three careers - you could be a nun, a wife and mother, or you could go off the rails..." Babette chose to go to art school in England - with her pony. Accommodation with grazing facilities was unavailable in London, so they went to Canterbury art school, where she rented a field. By her third year she was taking ideas for books to publishers. After a spell at the BBC, she first made her name with her explosively funny feminist fairytales. But what started her off on these "issue books"? "One day my publisher asked me to do a book for young children about sex. He wanted it to be an animal book but I said no! I'll do it with real people. He said you can't! But I DID!" And in Mummy Laid an Egg! two children explain to their own parents the mechanics of human reproduction using their own schematic drawings. The book is hugely funny and graphically explicit though - at so many removes from reality - not alarmingly so. Babette has no children and she says: "I probably couldn't have done this if I'd been approaching it from a 'motherly' point of view. Yes, I know these are difficult areas, but they should be addressed before they become difficult." Her uninhibited approach has raised a few eyebrows, but, spurred on by the scarcity of books of this sort (and a bold publisher), she has galloped headlong through sex, puberty, wet dreams, periods, health and hygiene, head-lice, worms, smoking, old age and even death. "Complaints? Oh yes! Like the bishop who hated my divorce book [Two of Everything] in which a vicar conducts an "un-wedding" ceremony - disrespectful to the clergy, he said - but they were so unhappy, I told him, and it was you lot who married them!" She's currently writing about true love with a dog in the leading role and she shows me the preliminary storyboard stage of the book... She draws with tremendous vitality and a watercolour technique, but adapts her style to the tone of the stories - which range from the mad cartoony stuff to the (relatively) reflective atmosphere you can find in Drop Dead. "Well I thought it needed a bit of sensitivity, since it's about death!" she says with a shriek of merriment. The joie de vivre that surrounds Babette belies her punishing work regime, juggling studio and stud-farm. How does she cope? "The horses keep me sane, they're a great leveller." It's dark now and the stableyard is an oasis of calm. Nine magnificent show hunters incline their heads gracefully from immaculate looseboxes as Babette attends lovingly to their needs and turns up the ghetto-blaster. Each horse has a personal collection of CDs, for schooling purposes - "Flanagan likes boogie-woogie and swing; Buster likes military marches, Nemo loves the Captain Pugwash theme tune and Dan likes reggae music". But they all enjoy Classic FM and, as I leave, they are all chomping away by moonlight to Beethoven's piano sonata in C sharp minor.

fields.headline: Trading faces
fields.standfirst: So, the whiter-than-white Michael J Fox has quit Spin City. And who's his replacement? Professional bad boy Charlie Sheen, of course.  Mark Morris  looks at what happens when the star of the show needs a substitute
fields.trailText: So, the whiter-than-white Michael J Fox has quit Spin City. And who's his replacement? Professional bad boy Charlie Sheen, of course. Mark Morris looks at what happens when the star of the show needs a substitute
fields.body:
The team behind Spin City had some hard thinking to do after Michael J Fox's decision to give up the show having been diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease. Can a TV show survive without its star? Look at ER, an ensemble programme that sailed calmly through the departures of several original cast members, including the incomparable William H Macy. But the ER bosses were so panicked by George Clooney's departure that they went and got themselves a Doug Ross clone, only considerably younger, cheaper and topically Croatian (Goran Visnjic).

At least he can hide in the big cast, which gives new characters a chance to establish themselves and make you forget absent icons. The Queen Vic's most notorious past tenant is now Grant Mitchell, not Dirty Den; most Cheers fans will accept that Woody was a more sublime idiot than Coach; some prefer Rebecca's self-loathing to Diane's prissiness. NYPD Blue lost both David Caruso and Jimmy Smits, gained winsome former child star Rick Schroder, and still survived.

But Spin City wasn't like that: it was one fast talker and a half dozen (high quality) stooges. Spin City without Mike is In Sickness And In Health without Alf, Seinfeld with no Jerry, Frasier sans Frasier. The kind of thing that doesn't add up. True, there were long running rumours of The Larry Sanders Show going on without Larry, but that might have been one final metatextual joke. In fact, a Foxless Spin City brings to mind the entirely pointless series of Reggie Perrin done long after Leonard Rossiter's death. See, Michael J Fox doesn't just play the main character in Spin City, he's the reason the show exists.

As the term "spin doctor" started coming in to common currency, the most talked about practitioner of the media-manipulating arts was George Stephanopoulos, Bill Clinton's director of communications. Stephanopoulos is short, charming and improbably boyish. Naturally, when casting the Stephanopoulos-like spin doctor in 1995's The American President, Rob Reiner chose Michael J Fox. Gary David Goldberg, the creator of Spin City, followed the same logic.

He also knew that while Fox's film career has been up and down, in the States TV audiences never forgot his 80s sitcom Family Ties - which was also created by Goldberg (to enforce the continuity, Meredith Baxter plays Fox's mother in both series). Star and show were a perfect fit. But other cast members - notably Barry Bostwick, who plays the mayor - have been pleading for the show to be kept alive after Fox goes. And one name has come up again and again.

At first it might seem a little surprising. After all, Michael J Fox is a much loved man, and a decent family guy. Charlie Sheen, on the other hand, is officially the third most self-destructive guy in Hollywood after Robert Downey Jr and Christian Slater. He had sex with his first prostitute at the tender age of 15, and - according to the courts - spent a total of $53,000 at notorious Hollywood madam Heidi Fleiss's brothel. His once promising career - remember Platoon? - has vanished in a haze of drugs, booze, porn stars and films co-starring Kristy Swanson and Henry Rollins.

But look at it another way, and the man born Carlos Estevez looks like the predestined choice for Spin City. Fellow Brat Pack casualty Rob Lowe is thriving as an astute political mover and shaker in the TV drama The West Wing, which also stars Charlie's dad, Martin. And Martin Sheen was in the American President with Michael J Fox, which is either a great omen, or proof that most casting directors have very small contact books. Sheen was in Platoon, Fox in Casualties Of War. A surprisingly funny cameo by Brooke Shields on Friends convinced a network to give her her own sitcom (Suddenly Susan) - and Sheen was in a famous episode of Friends (as Phoebe's naval officer boyfriend).

What's more, he has become a strange kind of icon - there's an approving audience buzz when he turns up (as himself) - as John Malkovich's best friend in Being John Malkovich. When Malkovich was asked if Sheen was his friend offscreen, the great ham replied "No, but I wish he was."

Conversely, maybe Sheen is too much of an obvious choice. Recent events suggest an entirely different approach. While chat show god Dave Letterman has been recovering from heart surgery, the plan was to avoid the standard guest-host option. Instead, the slot has been filled by Late Show Backstage, in which former Letterman guests are interviewed about what being interviewed by Dave is like. And - in a development that would warm the hearts of Baudrillard and Umberto Eco - the show about the show has been getting better ratings than the show itself.

And, while Spin City with Charlie Sheen might be reasonably funny - another decent, occasionally inspired sitcom - the horrible truth is that the real ratings winner would be a docusoap account of Michael J Fox's last few weeks working on Spin City.

Fortunately, for all our sakes, ABC executives tend not to read the Guardian.

webTitle: School 'out of control' and facing closure

fields.headline: School 'out of control' and facing closure
fields.standfirst: Police break up fight at London secondary where head was killed
fields.trailText: The London secondary school where head teacher Philip Lawrence was killed more than four years ago is facing closure after education chiefs decided it was "out of control".
fields.body:
The London secondary school where head teacher Philip Lawrence was killed more than four years ago is facing closure after education chiefs decided it was "out of control".

Westminster city council announced yesterday that it was sending a private sector task force into St George's Roman Catholic school, in Maida Vale in north-west London, because of continuing violence caused by a breakdown in discipline.

The drastic intervention comes after the headteacher, Margaret Ryan, agreed at the end of last week to take early retirement.

On Tuesday last week police had been called in to break up a fight between two boys, one of whom needed hospital treatment. Pupils are reported to fight regularly in classrooms, corridors and the playground.

The authority said yesterday that this week's school half term would be extended by a further week while a task force led by a contractor, Nord Anglia, was installed to work with teachers on emergency measures.

The education chairman, Simon Milton, said a decision on the school's future would be taken within a month, but added: "Closure is one option being considered." Any decision would be taken in consultation with the Westminster diocese, which owned the school. In the meantime, it would reopen on March 6 .

In December 1995, Mr Lawrence was stabbed to death outside the school gates while trying to protect a pupil. His killing triggered a national debate about school safety and ownership of weapons.

Learco Chindamo, then aged 15, was convicted of Mr Lawrence's murder, a court having heard during his trial he was a member of a triad-style gang that had gone to "sort out" a pupil at the school.

Yesterday Mr Milton said: "We have been monitoring the school for the last few weeks, and it became clear that it was not fully under control.

"We are intervening to secure immediate improvements in teaching and behaviour, and to stabilise and manage any future options for the school. The extra week will allow time for teachers, senior staff and the authority to work together to make changes in how the school is run."

Ms Ryan had worked "incredibly hard" at the school after taking over from Mr Lawrence's deputy, said Mr Milton, but emergency action had become necessary.

Vincent Nichols, the bishop who chairs the Westminster diocesan education board, said: "The diocesan authorities are in full support of the decision to enlist a task force to assist with making necessary improvements at the school, so that the students can return from half-term break to an improved learning environment."

St George's was declared "failing" by the office for standards in education more than two years ago, and has higher than average rates of truancy as well as an academic record below the area's average.

Its governors acknowledged yesterday that insufficient progress had been made.

Peter Clare, chairman of the governors, said: "The school's performance has not progressed as quickly as is necessary to achieve better education standards for the students, therefore the council has taken necessary action to make immediate improvements.

"The board of governors is in full support."

 The transfer of school support services in Leeds to the private sector moved a step closer yesterday, after the government announced the appointment of consultants to advise Leeds city council on how best to respond to the damning findings of an Ofsted report published earlier this month.

Chris Woodhead, head of Ofsted, has described his inspectors' findings on education services in one of the biggest local education authorities in England as "shocking".

The consultants, PricewaterhouseCoopers, must report back to the education secretary, David Blunkett, and the council within three months.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, said that the move was "a key first step in providing the children of Leeds with the education which they deserve".

fields.headline: Watch this pace
fields.standfirst: East Durham College in Peterlee plans to put British sport back on top
fields.trailText: East Durham College in Peterlee plans to put British sport back on top
fields.body:
Name one successful English national team. Cricket? Hardly. A one-day win in Bulawayo against the lowest ranked Test side may be cause for fireworks and cartwheels at Lord's, but it doesn't exactly get the pulse racing anywhere else. Football? With an undeserved back-door qualification into Euro 2000, you've got to be joking. Rugby? Compared to the Kiwis, Aussies and Springboks, we're distinctly second division.

Still stuck? Then, try the women's football team of East Durham & Houghall Community College. Seriously. When the all-conquering Aussie team arrived in this country last year they thrashed a few of the other home counties, and the English team decided discretion was the better part of valour. So the women of East Durham offered the visitors a game. And beat them 5-1.

The result is less surprising than it seems, for East Durham's team contains 15 English and Scottish internationals, most of whom were destined to study and train in the US before the elite academy was established two years ago. It's not just footy that's packing them into the north-east either.

There's the boxing academy, which draws its students from as far afield as Bethnal Green, and is chocka with talent. Five of the students are expected to represent England at this summer's Olympic games in Sydney and Amateur Boxing Association officials predict that two of them have what it takes to become future world champions.

There's the basketball academy which already has 200 applicants for next September, of whom two play for the Manchester United of basketball, Newcastle Eagles.

And this is just the start. The college has ambitious plans in place for womens' academies for swimming, cricket, boxing, rugby, netball and basketball with one for lawn tennis more than a distant possibility. The driving force behind these radical initiatives is former Bolton Wanderers professional footballer turned college principal, Ian Prescott. So it's no real surprise to find him making a keynote speech at this Thursday's conference in Birmingham organised by Sport England on developing sport in the further education sector.

"The government gives money to promote sport in higher education, but further education is ignored completely at the moment," he says. "So youngsters with sporting talent, who haven't got the qualifications for university, either have to go to work, or turn professional immediately. Either way, they have to miss out on their education. And as most go to work, the country misses out on much emerging talent. For instance, our boxing course has boys who dropped out of education at 14. There are 3.5 million students in further education who are not getting the chance to develop their sporting and educational skills. Who knows how good our national teams could become if we allowed ourselves to tap into this resource?"

Prescott's proposals don't come cheap. He is looking to the government to establish three further education centres of sporting excellence in the north, the midlands and the south, with his college becoming the northern outpost. In an ideal world, East Durham alone would collect £5 million as an initial downpayment.

"The college has already spent £2.5 million out of its reserves and bank loans to upgrade the existing facilities to the necessary standards and we still have some way to go," he continues. "Furthermore, we are spending £400,000 per year alone on professional sports coaches."

For a man who has committed his college to such levels of capital expenditure and overheads, Prescott is remarkably sanguine about where the money is going to come from. Being situated only a few miles from Tony Blair's constituency front door obviously has high embarrassment potential for a government committed to lifelong learning, but even if no money is forthcoming he is adamant that the mission will go on. "I'm already having talks with three property developers to look at ways of raising money," he says.

His hybrid philosophy of inclusion and sporting excellence has a pleasing ring, not least, to those of us who dream of switching on the TV and watching England win something.
