webTitle: Your starter for a hundred and fifty quid

fields.headline: Your starter for a hundred and fifty quid
fields.standfirst: Plans are afoot to entice those elusive students into education with a bit of financial help
fields.trailText: Plans are afoot to entice those elusive students into education with a bit of financial help
fields.body:
The government is going to offer every employed adult 150 quid from the public purse. The deal - catch, some might say - is that it has to be spent on learning and, to get it, you'll have to put 25 notes of your own down.

In a few weeks the government will unveil radical plans encouraging anyone over 19 years old, and in work, to dip into their pockets and take far greater responsibility for organising and funding their own learning.

Individual Learning Accounts (ILAs) are seen as the way they will develop a vested interest in pursuing education and training throughout their lives.

The learning and skills bill going through parliament will give ILAs legal tender in a mission described recently by David Blunkett, the Education and Employment Secretary, as keeping people "on track for achievement".

The idea is everyone should be encouraged to save for learning, like they save for, say, holidays. One day, perhaps, in the ideal world envisaged by Downing Street policy beaks and the CBI, all further education will be funded in this way. But at the moment, under the ILA scheme, the state will give £150 to each person to spend on an adult education or training course - providing they first cough up £25 each to add to the "account".

But it would pay the fees of short courses or evening classes in aspects of, for instance, IT, food hygiene and other occupational-related subjects. Discounts of up to 80% on course fees, and other incentives for certain types of learning will be available to boost recruitment targets and address skill needs.

It will also be a source of information about "learning opportunities linked to other government initiatives" and a "mechanism to make it easier for employers to support employees' individual development aspirations".

No public money is going to change hands, because the treasury feared some account holders would be tempted to take the money and run. Although the printed statement - or "learning record" - will show there's £150 in the account, the reality is that this is just a promise to pay if the individual follows an approved programme of study. But the indications are that if you give people lots of support to learn, then they are more likely to remain in learning for a long time."

He added: "With individuals putting their own money in the account, they are demanding more support and higher standards. They have a vested interest and more motivation to carry on learning."

Bill Lucas, chief executive of the Campaign for Learning, a government-funded initiative, claimed ILAs and "personnel learning days" were overtaking cars as the main employment perk for high-flying employees in big companies like National Grid.

But Mick Fletcher, development officer at the Further Education Development Agency, remains sceptical about what ILAs are really trying to achieve.

"They could be a device to increase participation and combat social exclusion," he said. "They might improve the responsiveness of colleges and private sector providers to people's training needs.

"Or they could be a lever to get additional financial contributions from individuals. No one is saying this, but ILAs could be a way to make people pay higher tuition fees."

There are doubts, too, whether the accounts will actually widen participation, Mr Fletcher said. "So far the evidence shows the pilot scheme has been taken up disproportionately by people who would have paid anyway for education and training."

Such uncertainties haven't discouraged ministers from demanding a national uniform system of ILAs. What has to be added up is how far the new framework will command universal status and pay dividends to people who are not fully paid up members of the lifelong learning culture.

Denis Rossiter, 34, a heavy goods lorry driver for Liverpool City Council became an Individual Learning Account holder as a first step to becoming a lawyer. His first taste of education after a long gap was studying basic computer courses in office skills and varying uses of software.

"The way I see it," Mr Rossiter said, "it is an investment in education - not a financial gain. I think it is a godsend because you need IT for the legal course."

Single parent Wendy Stott, 34, a part-time accounts assistant at a Manchester import/export company, needed to boost her accounting skills. With an ILA, she enrolled at Bury College to study two nights a week for an Association of Accounting Technicians qualification. This costs £450 a year so, she says, the ILA comes in handy.

"Bringing up a child on your own and studying part-time isn't easy. There are child-minding costs, not to mention course fees and textbooks. The ILA has made a big difference to my purse."

Asda cashier Marie Jorgensen, 45, had rejected promotion to management to raise her three children. Years later, when she returned to work, computers had taken over, and she realised her chances of keeping a job were limited unless she upgraded her skills.

"I wasn't brought up in the computer era. But if I had lost my job, then I just wouldn't have had the skills to be able to walk into another job, saying 'I can do this, I can do that'."

Mrs Jorgensen, of Rochdale, spied a local newspaper advert for a computer literacy course, linked to an ILA. She said: "This ILA was wonderful because it meant I could afford to retrain. It has also given me the confidence to be able to look for other or better employment in different areas, should I need to."

fields.headline: Artists earn their spurs
fields.standfirst: Research into the performing and creative arts has at last been put on the academic map by a fellowship scheme that could revolutionise how the subjects are taught.  Elaine Williams  asks what this means for artists, often held back by poor pay and scant recognition
fields.trailText: Research into the performing and creative arts has at last been put on the academic map by a fellowship scheme that could revolutionise how the subjects are taught. Elaine Williams asks what this means for artists, often held back by poor pay and scant recognition
fields.body:
Julie Roberts calls herself a historian, a researcher who seeks to interpret the past. But she doesn't write books or spend time among dusty archives. She is an artist who paints unsettling, highly charged, surreal pictures. They are painstaking canvases of historic objects and scenes, such as Sigmund Freud's desk and chair; Charles Darwin's study; macabre old surgical instruments all rendered with intense and vivid realism floating in isolation against a background of strong, unbroken colour.

Until now Roberts, 37, has been earning her living tutoring part-time at the Glasgow School of Art and selling her work internationally through exhibitions. But a new fellowship scheme means she will receive government funding for practice-based research that will give her time to pursue her interests further.

Those working in the creative and performing arts have long argued that at least some of what they do is about pushing back the boundaries of knowledge and perception and should be funded as research. Until now artists and performers have had to choose between teaching or selling their work or skill.

Although many universities have tried to plug the gap with artists-in-residencies, these have varied greatly from institution to institution, and have often been poorly paid with no clear role for the person in post. A major complaint is that they have suffered from lack of parity with the humanities, which have traditionally enjoyed post-doctoral fellowships funded by the British Academy.

In response, the Arts and Humanities Research Board has announced its first appointments of Fellows in the Performing and Creative Arts, their field ranging from art and design and media studies to music, drama and dance.

Thirty-two fellows have been selected, each one undertaking a substantial research project supported by their institution for which they will receive £45,000 over three years. The scheme is to be advertised annually.

According to the research board, the scheme has been designed for researchers with an established record "who show outstanding potential" but who do not hold a full-time post in a UK university.

Glasgow School of Art is delighted that the innovation it fosters at the heart of its creative culture is at long last being recognised. It is one of only two institutions to have received funding for two fellowships, Southampton University being the other.

Clare Barclay, 31, is a very different kind of artist to Roberts. She is a sculptor who investigates society's relationship to nature and "wilderness" - the way it uses and views materials. Her works of art often look like found, abandoned objects.

Although respected in her field and a graduate of Glasgow, she has made a precarious living from her art. The fellowship, she says, frees her to pursue her investigations and develop her work further without always having to produce a saleable product.

Clare is being given studio space in the art school where students will be able go and learn from her work. "It will be very much hands-on," she said. "I will be developing my knowledge and skills in using materials, such as metal machining and what students will see is the practical graft involved in making an art object from beginning to end."

Roberts will undertake the Ruskin Project - a series of paintings and works on paper in a book about the Victorian artist and writer. "I'm interested in the way artists in the past have tried to control the way we regard social and political events, for example, in the role of David (the French neo-classical painter) in the French revolution.

"Similarly I want to look at the way Ruskin wanted to control the way we see things, and the way he controlled those around him such as the women he corresponded with. But I shall do this through making sketches, paintings and even film."

Roberts also wants to tie this in with "new ways" of teaching. She will take students with her on her visits to the places Ruskin stayed at and, through her work, teach about all aspects of painting, technique, application and criticism.

Bob Wyatt, deputy chairman of Glasgow's fine art research committee said the fellowships were an important, formal acknowledgement that art practice could be viewed as research. He also felt artists would benefit from being accountable to an outside agency as well as their institution and having to work to definite outcomes. He said: "We think this is the best thing that has ever happened to art schools."

Paul Langford, chief executive of the research board, said that as the British Academy post-doctoral fellowship scheme had produced distinguished scholars for the humanities over the years, there should be the same opportunity for the arts.

"We have a very strong sense of mission to make a major contribution to the development of university-based arts research," he said, adding that it would give new universities a chance to excel. "Some of the new universities have a strong commitment to the arts and they will benefit from this in being able to reinforce a research culture."

The scheme, he said, would also avoid the pitfalls of an artist-in-residency by requiring institutions to specify what support they will give to fellows and fully including them in the university's research endeavour. "We would regard the fellowship as having failed if artists feel isolated."

This first wave of fellowships includes an enormously wide range of projects and some distinguished practitioners such as Howard Brenton, the political playwright, who will be based at Birmingham University. He has entitled his research programme The Playwright and the State, and will look at the cultural and performance contexts of political drama through the production of a monograph, three experimental "labtexts" for performance produced through student workshops, as well as papers and postgraduate seminars.

David Norris is one of the fellows appointed to Southampton University. A successful international concert pianist as well as a broadcaster, he was a former professor at the Royal Academy of Music and is currently Southampton's head of keyboard, a part-time post.

As part of his Fellowship he will become a tutor to the university's new Performance MA, but he will also pursue research into the relationship between the composer JC Bach and the square piano. Square pianos, made by Saxon immigrants, dominated the piano market between 1770 and 1800. Shaped like a coffin, they sat on a trestle and instead of damper pedals they had levers.

JC Bach, the son of Johann Sebastian, promoted the work of his compatriots and wrote many pieces for this instrument, taking into account its peculiarity that the performer would need a free hand at times for the levers.

"If you play JC Bach's work on a modern piano it sounds simple, but on a square piano it's very rich," said Norris. "In his time he was regarded as a great composer - Mozart included one of his tunes in a piano concerto as a tribute. My aim is to revive a repertoire as well as an instrument, and it's wonderful to be given the time and the funds to concentrate on it fully.

"The fellowships will encourage universities to see performing arts as a proper subject to get involved in at every level."

Norris also felt that because the work of fellows will be closely monitored it will also encourage rigour. "I'm not being paid just to have fun with a square piano. I will be covering some very wide-ranging ideas."

fields.headline: It's payday
fields.standfirst: Low pay is now the big gripe among lecturers and at last they can legally back their claim with strike action
fields.trailText: Low pay is now the big gripe among lecturers and at last they can legally back their claim with strike action
fields.body:
The lecturers' union, Natfhe, is putting in a flat-rate pay demand of £2,500 this week for all its members in the further education sector.

A strike ballot will almost inevitably follow if employers, in April, refuse the sum, which would raise the average lecturer's salary by about 11%, officials warn. Industrial action could be triggered before the end of the academic year, if called for.

A major obstacle which has hampered Natfhe from taking wholescale industrial action in the recent past - the requirement to provide names of everyone balloted - was removed in last year's Employment Relations Act. Natfhe's lawyers are checking exactly when this part of the act takes force.

Delegates from the union's 13 English and Welsh regions, with an eye on the £365m of new money which the sector is getting from government, have overwhelmingly backed the lump sum claim which would benefit particularly the lower paid among the union's 55,000 further education members.

They also declared "outright opposition" to any form of performance-related pay, said Barry Lovejoy, one of the union's national further education officials. They suspect performance-related pay is wrapped inside education ministers' demands of "something for something" in return for the biggest increase ever in further education funding.

Any move to industrial action would inevitably fracture the recent joint initiative between Natfhe and the employers, the Association of Colleges, to try to persuade the government to fund a decent pay claim.

Both sides agree that all lecturers have seen their salaries drop badly behind schoolteachers over the past seven years. Indeed, so do ministers, but the government's non-interventionist line that it is down to colleges as independent bodies to sort out pay - reiterated to Natfhe delegations by Baroness Blackstone and Malcolm Wicks - does not look like cracking.

Owing to serious erosion of pay - and, say the union, of conditions - since colleges were incorporated in 1993, the average annual rate for a main-grade senior lecturer stands at £18,000, nearly £6,000 behind the £23,904 which the National Union of Teachers reckons is the average teacher's salary.

Both the union and the Assocation of Colleges stress that they expect other joint initiatives - on casualisation, part-timers, equality issues and staff development - will carry on.

"It's fair to say that pay has now become the priority issue for the membership," Lovejoy said.

He said that members are particularly inflamed by recent disclosures that the average principal's salary is £85,000.

General secretary Paul Mackney said: "Lecturers are furious that principals are getting this kind of money while they, who have worked so hard to insure the success of the colleges, have seen their own pay plummet."

David Gibson, the association's chief executive, said: "Staff in further education, and not just lecturers, have seen their pay fall behind, and there's no doubt that in some cases there are recruitment difficulties as a result."

Employers and union had stressed to ministers and civil servants that pay has got to be a major priority, he said.

"We wouldn't fall out over that, but obviously our colleges can only pay so far if they have the money to deal with it."

fields.headline: Great expectations
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot talks to the head who has turned around Lordswood
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot talks to the head who has turned around Lordswood
fields.body:
Anybody scanning Ofsted's recent list of 80 outstanding secondary schools might have been mildly surprised to note that four of them are in Birmingham. Only one other local education authority, Essex, could boast as many. Less surprising, considering the number of top-80 qualifiers employing some form of selection, is that three of the Birmingham contingent are grammar schools. Lordswood Girls' is the city's only listed "comprehensive", although headteacher Jane Hattatt prefers to put the term in inverted commas.

Yes, her school takes all-comers (female ones, anyway) with widely differing abilities. But, no, there are not too many pupils from the middle-class homes on the edge of leafy Harborne where Lordswood is set. With a few notable exceptions, the brightest among them usually find their way into one of Birmingham's seven grammars. "Seven!" Hattatt exclaims, as though still not quite able to believe it after all these years. "That's quite extraordinary. When you add on the independent fee-paying schools, you can see how heavily creamed we've been academically. It seems to me disgraceful that successive Labour councils have not removed the grammars many years ago."

fields.headline: Call it a spade
fields.standfirst: Don't make them vocational A levels, says  Alan Smithers; what practical qualifications need is a name that reflects their distinct status
fields.trailText: Don't make them vocational A levels, says Alan Smithers; what practical qualifications need is a name that reflects their distinct status
fields.body:
What to call GNVQs was unfinished business left by the Qualifying-for-Success consultation. The options were to keep the acronym, or call them applied A levels or vocational A levels. In plumping for the third, the government has opted for the worst of all possible worlds.

An important purpose of advanced qualifications is to allow universities and employers to differentiate on the basis of clear and accurate information. The term vocational A level is deeply confusing. On the one hand, it suggests the qualifications are about work, which is the province of NVQs, and, on the other, about academic study, which has been the traditional strength of A levels.

As I understood it, the intention of GNVQs was to secure for practical learning its rightful place in an education system where it has long been undervalued. They have, however, been fundamentally compromised by being presented as for students for whom A levels were not appropriate.

We therefore had the ludicrous situation of subjects like business studies, media studies and technology being developed both as A levels and GNVQs, with the students doing well at GCSE going on to A levels and those doing less well taking GNVQs.

Far from promoting practical learning GNVQs only succeeded in underlining it as second class.

Any government serious about raising its status needs to go back to square one.

As Sir Ron Dearing pointed out in his review of qualifications for 16- to 19-year-olds, there are essentially three organising principles for learning at that stage: academic, practical and occupational. Of these, practical is the least familiar and most in need of an attractive brand name.

Vocational A level, with I guess in time the prefix disappearing, relegates practical learning to an offshoot of academic study. Retaining GNVQ or calling them applied, would at least have been distinctive. If business studies and other practical A levels had been moved across, there would have been a clear set of awards.

The argument for muddling everything up seems to be parity of esteem. But even within common titles, like degree or baccalaureate, pecking orders emerge. The current status accorded academic and vocational qualifications is not arbitrary; it reflects what you can do with them.

The label vocational A-level seems designed to sweep the differences between academic and practical under the carpet as if they were somehow embarrassing. Come on, Mr Blunkett, stand up for practical learning and give its qualifications a decent name!

 Alan Smithers is the Sydney Jones Professor of Education and Director of the Centre for Education and Employment Research at the University of Liverpool.

fields.headline: Bus-stop brain power
fields.standfirst: You don't have to sit chained to your desk just because exams are looming. Not the whole time, anyway.  Jerome Monahan suggests ways to revise while you're out and about
fields.trailText: You don't have to sit chained to your desk just because exams are looming. Not the whole time, anyway. Jerome Monahan suggests ways to revise while you're out and about
fields.body:
It's Tuesday and the half term is three days old. Is school already a distant memory? Do this year's exams still feel like an age away? Or are you experiencing the odd pang of guilt amid the pleasures? If so, here are some tips to help you keep the heebie-jeebies at bay.

Don't panic. Organise your notes to get an immediate overview of each subject.

Make a list of the key topics you need to revise for each SAT or GCSE and create a realistic revision schedule. At least then you will have something to measure your progress by.

Make a note of questions that crop up while you revise; you can ask your teachers when school resumes.

Decide when in the day you study best and fence that time off.

Read, read, read!

So far, so good, but no one expects you to stay strapped to your desk all week. You need to lead a balanced life. But every outing contains moments of lost time that can be filled. These brain-boosters can be done as you wait for a bus to arrive.

See how much of a speech you can memorise from one of the set scenes in the Shakespeare play you have studied for your SATs. Imagine the effect of handing round the ingredients for the witches' potion in Macbeth to your fellow travellers.

Be like Charles Dickens - observe people. Collect details of appearance, habits, or snatches of conversations which you could use in a story.

Do some mental arithmetic. How long do you spend at bus stops in the average year?

Look out for evidence of M.R.S. N.E.R.G or the seven characteristics of living things. Movement, respiration (breathing), sensitivity and nutrition (eating) should be easy to detect, growth less so - unless the bus is seriously delayed. If excretion or reproduction are in view then perhaps you are in the wrong part of town. How would you prove to an alien that a bus isn't alive?

Give yourself a science quiz: name three metals or three acids; what evidence of oxidation or acid rain can you see from where you are standing; what "forces" will need to operate for you to get on the bus or press the bell?

Play "I spy" in any language.

Make vocabulary cards and test yourself as you wait. Learn the beginning phrases that you will need for your oral tests, such as "I should like..." or "where is...?" or "it's not good enough..." - phrases that will be occurring to you anyway as you hang around.

Look up. What evidence can you spot that suggests the historic development of the buildings nearby? Faded painted signs on walls revealing the previous use of shops and dates stamped into old guttering are examples of good primary evidence on display.

Look up higher and work out what weather is coming, according to the clouds in the sky.

Think about the human geography that surrounds you. What kinds of shops are in sight? Are they mainly convenience stores or can you see some "comparison stores" too, such as jewellers, and do these places make where you are a high- or low-order settlement?

Study the advertisements in the bus shelter. What kinds of products are being promoted and what do they say about the people who use public transport?

Is GCSE PE on the horizon? Then play the "physical characteristics" game. Is the person waiting there with you a mesomorph, an endomorph or an ectomorph, and what sports should they take on? On a more practical level, what about rotating your ankles to increase flexibility and prevent injuries ahead of any trampolining or running you may doing?

How many of these things can you do at the same time?

Have you missed your bus?

When it comes to revision, little and often is better than mind-numbing splurges. You may have places to go and people to see, but every day contains lost pockets of time that you can fill.

 My thanks to staff at Cator Park School in Beckenham, London for these bus-stop tips. BBC Bitesize has just launched a website for key stage 3 revision.

fields.headline: Cheats are scaring us stiff
fields.standfirst: Is this a student's work I see before me - or just a ready-made, paid-for download from the internet? It's a question starting to bother lecturers and one that won't go away
fields.trailText: Is this a student's work I see before me - or just a ready-made, paid-for download from the internet? It's a question starting to bother lecturers and one that won't go away
fields.body:
"I know the meaning of plagiarism," remarked Chloe, a colleague's eight-year-old. "You do?" her astonished mother replied. "Yes, our teacher told us about it today. It's when you take sentences from a book and pretend they're your own. We also learned about footnotes and bibliographies."

When I heard this, all I could do was remark how strange it is that a concept understandable to an eight-year-old seems incomprehensible to my students.

Plagiarism is causing lecturers enormous anxiety. Do the few cases we detect each year indicate the actual size of the problem, or the tip of the iceberg? I thought colleagues were paranoid when they suggested one quarter of all essays were probably plagiarised. Now I'm not so sure.

A lot of plagiarism is innocent. Students, lacking Chloe's training, copy too indiscriminately from books and fail to give due recognition to sources. When alerted to this problem, most apologise profusely and don't repeat the mistake.

But the best plagiarists are the most difficult to detect. Well-written essays, carefully focused on the assigned topic, do not usually raise suspicion. A consistent writing style suggests the work is the student's. Alarm bells might start ringing when a student who scored highly on written work suddenly gets weak scores on exams, but by then it's usually too late to investigate the provenance of the essays.

Sadly, it's now incredibly easy to cheat. Computers allow students to cut and paste at will. Recently, two students turned in exactly the same essay. One stole the essay from a computer used by both. The two copies differed only in the font used and the name at the top. The culprit apparently assumed that, given a class of 200 students in which the work is marked by five different tutors, the forgery would go undetected. That was, in fact, a pretty safe assumption since the discovery was entirely accidental.

Essays can also be easily downloaded from websites. Ten minutes on Yahoo yielded around 20 sites offering essays for sale. The titles - "Evil House of Cheat", "Other People's Papers", "The Essay Powerhouse", and "FreeEssays.com" - leave no confusion as to their content. Key in "Origins of the First World War" in the topic box, press return and within seconds a choice of 50 essays is offered. Enter a credit card number and the chosen essay is e-mailed back immediately.

It is even possible to select from a range of qualities, rather like grades of linoleum. This is useful if a mediocre student doesn't want to raise suspicions by suddenly submitting first-class work.

Each site usually has a disclaimer denying any intent to encourage plagiarism. For example, BuyPapers.com warns customers that "any paper sold represents an original work created by our company and provided only as a model paper for research use to be properly cited in any original report on the same topic that you will ultimately go on to write yourself". Pigs might fly.

In contrast, the more candid "Smart Essays" offers a "huge selection of student homework to cheat from" and doesn't bother with a disclaimer.

The entrepreneurial spirit flourishes on both sides of the plagiarism divide. Glatt Plagiarism Services sells software that tests suspect work for authenticity. Every fifth word in the essay is automatically removed, with the accused required to supply the word within a prescribed length of time under test conditions. The software then analyses the results.

Glatt claims that "no student has ever been falsely accused", but in these days of increasingly litigious students, that seems cold comfort. I would not go into battle with a weapon that seems no more dependable than a lie detector test.

Every teacher complains about declining standards, but in this case the complaint seems to have merit. I don't remember plagiarism being a problem 10 years ago. When I first started teaching, if cheating was suspected, I looked the student straight in the eye and said I wanted to give the essay to a colleague who loves a challenge.

I then explained that if plagiarism were proved, the student would fail the course. If, however, he confessed immediately, he would only fail the essay. The student always owned up. But that no longer works. The student now just sneers, leaves the room and turns the matter over to his solicitor.

It is easy to blame the plagiarism epidemic on a decline in student morals, compounded by technological wizardry. But we've partly brought this problem on ourselves. We seldom talk any more about the beauty of intellectual enrichment. University has been reduced to a mere process designed to turn the high school student into a young professional.

Lecturers are required to pepper course materials with references to "learning outcomes", the suggestion being that "this is what you will become if you take this module".

The student's responsibilities are intentionally downplayed; the need to spend long hours in the library writing essays is not mentioned. Yesterday's student knew that a degree was something earned through hard work; today's customer is encouraged to believe success can be bought.

 Dr Gerard J DeGroot chairs the modern history department at St Andrews University.

fields.headline: Changing places
fields.standfirst: Last week's annual report from the chief schools inspector logged a growing worry that children are sliding backwards in the year or two after they start secondary school.  Karen Gold assesses the evidence
fields.trailText: Last week's annual report from the chief schools inspector logged a growing worry that children are sliding backwards in the year or two after they start secondary school. Karen Gold assesses the evidence
fields.body:
Noxious smells and puffs of coloured smoke emerged from the labs the day the nervous primary school children visited their new secondary school.

"It was a brilliant science lesson," says Professor Maurice Galton, who was at the unnamed school doing a research project into primary-secondary transfer. "It was as if Ofsted had turned up. But when those children actually moved to the secondary school in September, their science lesson consisted of five minutes filtering some water and 25 minutes copying the experiment up from the board."

The move to "big school" is an educational milestone. Children, parents, primary and secondary schools invest huge amounts of time and emotion in it. There are prospectuses, league tables and visits; staff meetings, passing on of records, taster days and induction weeks. Yet researchers and policy-makers increasingly suspect that all this preparation and anxiety may end in disappointment. There is talk of sowing the seeds of boredom and disaffection, of a "lost year" at the start of secondary school. So what is going wrong?

If you take Professor Galton's research seriously - and the government certainly does - something certainly is. In 1998 he and his colleague Dr Linda Hargreaves tested a group of children in English and maths at the end of year 6, their final year of primary school. A year later they looked at the same children - now year 7s in secondary school - again. One-third of the children had made no progress during that year and some had gone backwards to a lower level than before. The decline in English was worse than in maths; boys were more affected than girls.

Galton and Hargreaves also measured the children's attitudes to schoolwork. The two of them sat in on year 6 and year 7 lessons, observing each child every 25 seconds to see whether they were concentrating or messing about. In the primary classroom, about 60% of the pupils concentrated for three-quarters of the lesson, whatever the subject. But after a year of secondary education, only 50% of them concentrated for that amount of time in maths, and only 35% of them paid attention in science. "Nearly two-thirds of all (year 7) pupils taking science were distracted for significant periods of the lesson," Professor Galton says.

Education secretary David Blunkett, seeing his hard-won literacy and numeracy improvements in primary schools at risk of trickling away - 13-year-olds' test scores, unlike their junior counterparts, have remained resolutely static - will not ignore research like that.

In a recent speech he said lack of progress by children in the early years of secondary school is "unacceptable". He quoted two dissatisfied 12-year-olds interviewed by another researcher, Professor Jean Rudduck of Homerton College. According to one, "year 7 work is not too difficult because it's more or less the same as year 6." The other observed: "My friend Harriet doesn't feel intellectually stimulated this year."

Harriet's ennui will soon be put to the test. The government has promised optional national tests to measure progress in year 7 by this summer, more summer schools for 11-year-olds this year, primary-style literacy and numeracy hours in year 7 starting in September, extra classroom training for all secondary teachers and pressure on secondary schools to set performance targets for years 7-9 by the end of next year.

So will it be enough? If secondary schools are forced to measure their pupils' progress from the very first term, with the threat of inspection and league tables over them, will that give them both the motivation and the means for change?

It would certainly help to focus attention on academic performance, says Professor Rudduck. According to another piece of research she carried out with Galton and Professor John Gray, also of Homerton, this one commissioned by the Department for Education and Employment, school transfer has been perceived as a problem for at least 20 years - but the problem has mainly been seen as one of relieving stress.

Ever since then, she argues, schools have been working at making children feel secure, often very successfully. But in doing so they may have taken their eye off the academic ball. "It's very important to reduce young people's anxiety," says Rudduck. "But by putting so much effort into the social dimension of transfer, schools may be neglecting to tell young people what learning is like and how important it is in the secondary school."

In some ways, if that is the case, it is not surprising. For the stress of transfer is almost certainly what concerns children and parents most. George Gercke, 12, is in year 7 at Parkside Community College, an 11-16 comprehensive in the middle of Cambridge. Before he left his village primary school, he did not worry about whether secondary school work would be interesting enough. What he worried about was whether he would cope: "I thought it would be hard, and I thought there would be bullying."

In fact, neither worry was necessary: "There's almost no bullying: they've got absolutely hundreds of anti-bullying things. And the work is harder, but I can do it." His brother Laurence, due to make the same move to the same school this September, nevertheless expresses a carbon copy of George's fears: "I'm terrified. Terrified of bullies."

In that frame of mind, many schools would say, the last thing he needs as soon as he arrives is academic pressure. He will have had plenty from his SATs this summer - and that in itself, some would argue, is a big factor in the apparent under-performance that many children show in year 7. For there is anecdotal evidence that SATs are the cause as well as the measure of peaks and troughs in 11-year-olds' performance. Year 6 builds up relentlessly to the tests in English, maths and science in May, after which children may take on a project or focus on art or drama.

Instead of a six-week summer break, they may have 10 weeks with little formal English or maths. Those who just squeezed up a level may slip back.

Of course, they could be driven upwards again by more national tests at the end of year 7, which they might take more seriously than mere researchers' tests - another possibly explanation for their apparent under-performance. But the government also needs to take into account that it is asking children to spread themselves across a much wider curriculum in year 7, says Ann Mullins, headteacher of Highbury Fields Girls school.

If children are tested in English, maths and science, what will be the effect on their initiation into drama, French, more formal history, geography, design technology and IT?

"They are pretty focused in primary schools with the literacy hour and the numeracy hour. When they come into secondary school the curriculum is much wider."

Galton, Gray and Rudduck argue that these kinds of statements simply underestimate the intellectual level of work in the primary school. Galton describes asking a group of primary and secondary teachers to design an experiment for their pupils to show that they can use a thermometer. "In the primary school they set the children lots of problems to which they had to find the answers. In the secondary school the experiment consisted of dropping the thermometer into hot water and cold water, noting the temperature, and filling in a worksheet."

The difference can partly be attributed to the way secondary schools are organised, he says: with 40 minute lessons, teachers cannot let children work in the investigative way primaries do over a whole afternoon. But that is not the whole story: "Children are operating at a high cognitive level at the end of primary school; secondary schools have to learn to build on this."

If they do not at present, it may be for several reasons. They may simply not possess the information they need: a study in Worcester local education authority showed that only half the middle schools passed on children's SATs results to high schools (though 80% passed on pastoral information) and only one school in five also passed on records or portfolios of work.

Secondary liaison teachers struggle to visit all their primary intake in the era of parental choice: they may now accept children from 40 different primary schools. It is true that all of them follow the National Curriculum, but the ways of working may still be very different.

And in any case, says Maurice Galton, passing on information makes little difference to the many secondary teachers wedded to the idea of a "fresh start". They are sceptical of SATs, they know the summer break will make more difference to some than others, they want to give children a chance to shake off old self-images and show what they can do.

In practice, he argues, this rarely does anybody any good: "I have come across a teacher who assumes everybody is at level five and then gives extra help to children who can't do it. But generally if people talk about a fresh start they mean going over the basics. If you do that in, say, maths, then children who are bright and can already do the work get bored, while the children who found it difficult the first time round find the pace too fast and can't keep up. Everyone loses out."

Yet a fresh start is exactly what George and Laurence perceive as the attraction of secondary school. George, proudly displaying a merit certificate, believes: "I can cope even though the work is harder, because I've gone up a level." Laurence can't wait: "I want to meet new people. I want to do harder work. I want to be away from all these little children running around in the playground who bump into you and then say you pushed them over."

The difficulty secondary schools must grapple with, says Jean Rudduck, is balancing the desire for a fresh start - among pupils and staff - with the understanding that successful academic work builds on what has gone before. Children need to feel that they have cast off their primary selves and get work to make them think. They also need to be told that secondary learning will require them to process more facts, to practise more skills, and that if they sit back their learning will suffer.

Teachers need to have more knowledge of, and more faith in, their primary colleagues' achievements. "It's almost as if they don't trust them when it comes to building on the knowledge and skills their new year 7s bring with them," says Maurice Galto. But, says Rudduck, they also need to be explicit to their new intake about the work that will be involved.

"Pupils come to secondary schools with these very high expectations, partly generated by exciting taster days. Then they find there is repetition in year 7, they feel let down and boredom sets in.

"They need to get the message that learning is important, that it is cumulative, that they are moving on to a more advanced stage."

fields.headline: A funny business
fields.standfirst: Links with industry and commerce aren't all they're cracked up to be, says Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Links with industry and commerce aren't all they're cracked up to be, says Francis Beckett
fields.body:
I shall feel better when I've told someone. The fact is, and I can't keep it hidden all my life, that I don't think business education links are a good thing at all.

I found it hard to summon up the proper level of shock at the recent revelation that further education colleges are rather laggard at sending their staff on placements in businesses, and getting business placements in college. Schools do a lot more of it, according to a recent report from the Further Education Development Agency.

Nor am I moved by the discovery that business governors are hard to come by these days. If further education colleges end up being run by the people who work and learn in them, that's fine. Let the lunatics take over the asylum with my blessing.

This, these days, is politically incorrect on a grand scale. The most overworked buzzword we have is "partnership". For everything they want, colleges are supposed to enter partnerships with business. I suspect that if your college needs its drains cleared, it enters into a partnership with a local plumber.

But what about these business placements? Surely they, at least, are a good thing. Surely teachers ought to know what is going on in the world which their students are soon to enter.

Not at all. If schools want their teachers to waste time trailing around after some local business bigwig, doing his photocopying, watching him talk into his dictaphone, make telephone calls and fidget with his mobile in public places, let them do so. There is no need for colleges to copy them.

But surely you need business governors, I hear you cry. You need their professional expertise in such matters as business practise, the law and accountancy, to keep a proper check on the principal; and you need their guidance about the sort of teaching you do, so that you are producing the people they want to employ.

No, you don't need any of those things. You're better off without them. In those colleges where in recent years the top management has, shall we say, cut a few corners, the governing bodies were stuffed full of local business people, who were about as much use at policing the activities of the management as Toytown's community copper, Mr Plod. In nearly all cases, the scandals were brought to light by the staff.

And as for telling the colleges how to produce employable people, that's exactly what we have to avoid. Colleges, contrary to popular opinion, ought not to be turning out tame pullers and pushers of corporate levers. They exist for the benefit of their students, not for the benefit of their students' future employers. And yes, there is a difference.

webTitle: E-uni quest for best of British

fields.headline: E-uni quest for best of British
fields.standfirst: Ambitious plans for an international web-based UK university are credible but can only succeed if resources are pooled as quickly as possible
fields.trailText: Ambitious plans for an international web-based UK university are credible but can only succeed if resources are pooled as quickly as possible
fields.body:
The race is on to become one of the founder members of Britain's "e-university" following last week's announcement by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary. Observers expect half a dozen of the most advanced research universities working with the Open University to form the initial consortium - Oxford and Cambridge may not be quick enough off the mark to participate, said one.

The project - the most ambitious since the foundation of the Open University in the 1960s - is intended to draw together the cream of expertise in British universities to mount web-based courses around the globe, competing with the major corporate and virtual universities emerging in the US. As Blunkett said, no one institution has the range of expertise or the financial clout to undertake the job.

Universities and private companies throughout the UK are being invited by the Higher Education Funding Council for England to bid to become part of a consortium to run the e-university.

The funding council, which will put up the pump-priming money, decided against asking existing regional consortia in an effort to secure the "best of British" in higher education. They may well use existing links with overseas universities, especially in countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and China.

With proper funding the e-university could become the biggest in the world, teaching millions of students, according to Tim O'Shea, master of Birkbeck College, London, and a member of the funding council's steering group.

Professor O'Shea, who is also provost of Gresham College, predicted start-up costs could be as high as £120m over two years, much of it coming from private sources. Fees income is potentially huge - UK universities expect to take £560m in overseas student fees this year.

Birkbeck's online masters degree in cystallography has two virtual seminars a week - one timed for Europe and the east coast of the US and the other for the west coast and the Pacific Rim. Prof O'Shea said for academics there would be a huge change - designing an hour-long learning experience on the web would take 200 hours so the concept depended on attracting large numbers. Tutors would also need to learn how to support students online through the use of email and computer conferencing.

"It is exciting and innovative but also credible," he said. "No other country has said it will try and take the best of its higher education and make it available for electronic delivery over the web."

Alice Frost, who is heading the project, gives full details on the council's website. There will be no physical campus and there will be no new incorporation as in the case of the Open University. Much of the funding will come from student fees, including professional reskilling by people in work.

There was no shortage of universities with high quality teaching and learning materials and expertise in their delivery via the internet or other new technologies, she said. "Many are seeking to develop web-based applications on their own or in groups. But no single institution has the resources to exploit existing materials and expertise with the necessary scale and profile.

"Such investment can only be justified if one can be confident of reaching a large market at home and overseas. Hence the need for a pump-priming initiative to bring together existing resources and talents in a way that achieves the necessary critical mass."

Frost said that many - even most - universities and colleges were carrying out activities relevant to the project. "Our aim is to ensure this project adds substantial value in the form of new opportunities and a major boost to collaborative initiatives in virtual distance learning, rather than duplicating existing efforts.

 A conference on "borderless education" is being held by the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals on March 28 to discuss a wide-ranging report by Robin Middlehurst at Surrey University.

fields.headline: Against all odds
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan finds out how Kingsdale has triumphed
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan finds out how Kingsdale has triumphed
fields.body:
Steve Morrison feels he is at the centre of one of the most extraordinary stories in modern education. As the new head of Kingsdale School in south-east London, he already had his work cut out turning round one of Southwark's 10 schools under special measures. Then he was told that his school was to be the destination by default of students from Dulwich High School - named, shamed and then finally shut in July 1999.

Kingsdale had plenty of its own problems before it had to take on the amalgamation. Two in three of its pupils were in receipt of free school meals, nearly a quarter of those enrolled were on the special needs register and 14% had identified emotional and behavioural difficulties. It had failed its Ofsted inspection in February 1998, the inspectors' report cataloguing among its shortcomings its inability to attract more able students or increase its number of girls.

Meanwhile, its local education authority was about to blow its own Ofsted inspection for serious shortcomings in its strategic management of the area's schools and for producing an "incoherent borough education plan". Hardly surprising, then, that it took arm-twisting from HMI to ensure that Southwark did not send Kingsdale any more students with records of challenging behaviour or exclusion while it was under special measures. It was to be a short-lived concession.

According to local councillor William Rowe, "Dulwich High School had to close - its examination results were appalling and its year 7 intake had collapsed." With local schools fighting successful campaigns to resist invasion and preserve their single-sex status, it became clear that Kingsdale would have to be the destination of the 150 Dulwich students who could not make alternative arrangements.

"On paper this looked like a recipe for disaster," explains Steve Morrison. "Coming from the Peckham side of the borough, the Dulwich boys appeared to be the natural rivals of our students, many of whom travel in from Lambeth. And, despite being under special measures, we had to take in numerous students with behavioural records that should have disqualified them from coming here."

That the situation did not explode was due in part to several simple measures. "We staggered the amalgamation," says Morrison. "The year 10s quietly joined us in May. It gave me great pleasure back in July to tell representatives from the local community, worried sick about the merger, that many of the boys had already been with us for six weeks without mishap.

"It was equally important that many of the staff from Dulwich came across to help with the main transfer in September - including the school's popular head, Lloyd Marshall. The value of familiar faces at such a traumatic time for the students was enormous."

Southwark is keen to stress that it responded appropriately to the challenge it set itself by closing the Dulwich school, pointing to the sizeable extra revenue and capital funds it made available to Kingsdale.

Morrison tells another tale. He is convinced there was an expectation in the borough that Kingsdale's roll would collapse and that is why it took a struggle to secure approval for the deficit budget needed to secure extra teachers. "We couldn't wait until September to see how our numbers shaped up and then start looking for staff. That we were made to feel like a charity was unacceptable, given that we were being affected by decisions that were being imposed on us."

Problems aside, the expected blow-up among the students never materialised. There was the inevitable honeymoon period, and the joke among education department staff overseeing the transfer of pupils was that Kingsdale's success would promote a spate of school closures across the country.

"It was some way into the winter term that pupils really started to test the boundaries," says Morrison. "The vast proportion of more serious incidents concerned boys from Dulwich testing the stricter regime here or taking advantage of our more open site to hop out of school.

"In 12 months' time," he says, "this place will be unrecognisable. A £5m redesign of the school will be under way, the construction of special facilities for the girls, including a garden, will be complete and the new students will have settled in."

Morrison is also encouraged by the change in attitude he senses towards league tables. He points to the success Kingsdale is already achieving in terms of adding value to the students over their school career. "I am not interested in changing the intake of the school, my concern is to do the very best for the students I have to work with. Our last inspectors' report in November indicated the school was improving in terms of all its key objectives - and after what we have been through, that represents a unique achievement."

A student survey reported to governors this week shows that the vast majority think they attend a good school. "I've seen far worse," says 14-year-old Luis Gracia. "To me this place is a palace".

fields.headline: Don't hog that, it's ours
fields.standfirst: Lee Elliot Major explains why, without the protective ring fence, industry could get vital science money
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major explains why, without the protective ring fence, industry could get vital science money
fields.body:
The protective ring-fence for the science budget may come under threat in this year's government spending review, it has emerged. The funding proposals for the research councils and the Office of Science and Technology (OST) will for the first time form part of a combined bid from the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) in forthcoming budgetary battles in Whitehall.

The Treasury wants research budget plans for all government departments to be tied much more closely to their overall aims agreed during the spending review. But officials are warning that this may mean that the science budget is seen as money used for the sole purpose of underpinning the DTI's policies to strengthen industry, rather than priorities throughout government, for example in health and environment.

"There are two concerns if the DTI and OST is run as a whole bid together," said one senior government official outside the DTI. "If the DTI does not secure enough money for its own purposes, it might feel it has the right to tap into the science base for money if there is no ring-fence. The science base should also underpin all departmental research interests. But it now looks like being tied to DTI objectives, which will be about industry, not agriculture, health or the environment."

Former director general of research councils, John Cadogan, first reassured research councils that their £1.4 billion science budget for universities and research institutes would be ring-fenced when the OST moved from the Cabinet Office to the DTI five years ago. During the government's 1998 comprehensive spending review, Cadogan led the group in charge of a single science bid for extra funds. This time round, much closer links are being drawn between the DTI's central innovation budget and the budget for science.

Senior officials at the OST though have strongly rebutted suggestions that the special ring-fence status for science has eroded away in the current spending review. They say that there will be both a single bid for the science budget as well as an integrated DTI bid in the spending review. The government's chief scientific adviser, Sir Bob May, said: "The ultimate Whitehall operational definition of the ring-fenced budget is that it is announced as a separate budgetary item, with two separate announcements for DTI - one for OST and one for the rest - in a manner that doesn't prevail in most other departments, and that is not in question."

But some research council heads are known to be increasingly nervous that science is being fully assimilated into the DTI. Last month, the government set out its plans for strengthening ties between science and industry in a new science and innovation strategy. Innovation is also the major theme of the Treasury-driven cross-cutting review into science and research as part of the current spending review, which will determine budgets for departments for the next three years.

Further calls for infrastructure support for university equipment and facilities, meanwhile, are set to be a key element of the DTI science bid. Despite allocating £700m into scientific facilities, the joint-infrastructure fund announced by the government and the Wellcome Trust after the last spending review has left the vast majority of university proposals unfunded.

One suggestion is that the "son of JIF" will be a recurrent infrastructure fund, although Wellcome are currently not committing any more funds to the scheme. The science bid focuses on three overarching priorities for the research councils: IT, post genome research and sustainable land use.

Treasury officials remain unconvinced by evidence presented on academic salaries in the recent independent review of academic pay structures. But interim findings of a study being carried out for university heads by the Science and Technology Policy Research (SPRU) group at the University of Sussex suggest that research has an even larger impact on the economy than first estimated.

fields.headline: Landscape architecture
fields.trailText: Landscape architecture
fields.body:
Sounds like a fancy term for gardening. Well, you're wrong. It's the creation of landscapes.

Haven't they been, as it were, created already? Well, yes, all right, it's recreating landscapes.

<B<I see. You improve on things? We like to think so. A landscape architect might design, for instance, a public park to be in harmony with the environment.

Is that it, then? You make parks? Hardly. Landscape architects, also known as landscape designers, are concerned with planning, designing and constructing the whole outdoor environment.

Go on, give me some examples. Landscape architects work on settings for all types of buildings, roads, play areas and any sort of construction projects. They are also involved in preservation, for instance, of a coastline. And they are called in to rescue derelict sites - disused pits, quarries and so forth.

Are there any rules? The aim is to fit any design into its environment and to do the least possible damage to the local scenery and ecology.

How do they manage that? Ideally, by becoming involved with a project in the early stages. Working alongside architects, planners and surveyors, landscape architects/designers can suggest alterations to plans that will help a new development blend into the existing landscape. They visit sites, draw up surveys and then draw up plans and designs. These have to include projected costs, including cover for maintenance after the project is finished.

Lumme! And once the work begins, the landscape architect naturally visits a site from time to time to make sure all's going smoothly.

So, they need to be dab hands with the old HB. A landscape architect is fundamentally a designer, so creative ability is important. But to produce a design, he or she must understand civil engineering, surveying, geology, horticulture, earth-moving... I get the picture. It's an outdoor job. Actually, landscape architects usually spend less than a quarter of their time outdoors. Mostly they are toiling at their desks, or in meetings. Good communication skills are an obvious advantage.

So, how do I dig into this world? It takes a degree, if not a further degree.

Ooh er! Yep. You can start by taking an undergraduate degree in landscape architecture. Two A levels or their equivalent are minimum requirements for entry. Art, biology, botany and geography are considered relevant subjects at A level. Or you can do a postgraduate course after taking a degree in a related subject, eg architecture or horticulture. Mature applicants may get exemption from some requirements if they have relevant experience, eg at technician level in horticulture, botany etc.

And then wham! Tote that island, shift that hill. The recognised qualification for landscape architects is Member of the Landscape Institute (MLI). To get this you must get Associate membership of the institute, having gained two years' practical experience, at least, and then you have got to pass the Institute's professional exam.

webTitle: Designs on politics Austrian far right leader targeted at fashion show

fields.headline: Designs on politics Austrian far right leader targeted at fashion show
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Politics took centre stage at the Milan fashion collections yesterday when designer Guglielmo Mariotto showed a skirt with a picture of Austria's far-right Freedom party leader, Jörg Haider, and the word "No" written in red.
fields.body:
Politics took centre stage at the Milan fashion collections yesterday when designer Guglielmo Mariotto showed a skirt with a picture of Austria's far-right Freedom party leader, Jörg Haider, and the word "No" written in red.

Warm applause welcomed the Sudanese-born model Clara Benjamin as she walked down the catwalk wearing the "anti-Haider" full-length skirt, which featured a swastika next to the politician's face.

"It's very simple," Mr Mariotto, a designer for the Gattinoni label, said before the show. "Designers get ideas from actuality, from what's going on, from the atmosphere of a country. I live in Europe. This is what is happening in Europe."

About 150,000 people protested in Vienna at the weekend against the inclusion of Mr Haider's party in Austria's ruling coalition.

Benjamin, who was raised in London, said she had no qualms about wearing the skirt. "When he [Mariotto] asked me I said yes right away due to the fact that I'm African but I grew up in Europe.

"I have family in Austria so it is something very personal for me."

The Gattinoni collection highlighted the house's long-running relationship with the cinema.

Founded after the war, Gattinoni dressed some of Hollywood's top stars, such as Ava Gardner and Ingrid Bergman, when they travelled to Italy to shoot films during the 1960s.
Reuters, Milan

fields.headline: Mix-up over human gene patent
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: A patent on a process which could be used to create genetically altered humans has been granted to Edinburgh university "by mistake", the European patent office admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
A patent on a process which could be used to create genetically altered humans has been granted to Edinburgh university "by mistake", the European patent office admitted yesterday.

The patent was granted in December, but the fact that it referred to humans as well as animals - in violation of European law - was only detected by the German branch of Greenpeace, which yesterday forced European patent officials into an embarrassing retreat.

"This brings us significantly closer to producing human beings in the laboratory and then patenting them," said Greenpeace's Christoph Then.

"It's a mistake," said Rainer Osterwadter of the German patent office. "What's missing is the disclaimer that it does not refer to humans." The patent, originally applied for in 1994, was granted to the university itself.

The inventors are named as Austin Smith, of the centre for genome research in Edinburgh, and Peter Mountford, chief scientific officer of the Melbourne-based biotech company Stem Cell Sciences Ltd. Dr Mountford studied with Dr Smith in Edinburgh on a Royal Society fellowship.

A spokeswoman for Edinburgh university said last night: "The context in which this patent was taken out was a research interest Dr Smith and his colleagues have in ex amining how human cell tissue might be encouraged to develop in the laboratory in such a way as to eventually make possible the replacement of diseased tissue in human patients."

The patent title refers to "Isolition, selection and propagation of animal transgenic stem cells."

But paragraph 11 of the patent description says: "In the context of this invention, the term 'animal cell' is intended to embrace all animal cells, espcially of mammalian species, including human cells."

The main thrust of Dr Smith and Dr Mountford's work is to patent a new method of producing embryonic stem cells - the building blocks of humans or animals, cells which can grow into any kind of organ.

But they have also patented a method of creating a "transgenic animal" - an animal with artificially altered genes - which could then pass its altered genes onto its offspring. Transgenic animals have been patented in Europe before but a new European patent directive explicitly excludes patenting humans.

At present, it is illegal to tinker with the "germ line" of human beings - to artificially introduce genes into humans in such a way that the alteration would be passed on from generation to generation.

In Greenpeace's interpretation, that is what would be allowed by Edinburgh university's European patent number 695351.

fields.headline: 'Blair more extreme than me' - Haider
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, claims to share "amazing similarities" with Tony Blair, whose policies on asylum seekers he says are arguably more extreme than his own.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, claims to share "amazing similarities" with Tony Blair, whose policies on asylum seekers he says are arguably more extreme than his own.

Mr Haider compares his own nationalist party with New Labour, claiming that both he and the British prime minister defy the traditional labels of right and left.

Writing in today's Daily Telegraph, he argues that he takes a more moderate line than Mr Blair on the question of immigration and asylum seekers.

While Mr Haider's Freedom party has called for a halt to immigration to allow the "integration" of foreigners already in Austria, he claims his policy is "less tough" than the Blair government's.

He writes: "Are Blair and Labour extreme right because they do not accept the Schengen [EU open borders] agreement and advocate stricter rules on immigration? If Blair is not extreme then nor is Haider.

"The latter is arguably less tough on asylum seekers and immigrants than Labour and Blair."

Mr Haider rose to international prominence earlier this month when his party joined a new coalition government with Austria's conservative People's party, after winning 27% of the vote in last year's general election.

The coalition was greeted with widespread protests within Austria and condemnation from the EU and around the world over his extreme nationalistic views.

But Mr Haider claims in the article - in which he extensively quotes the Labour leader - that his party, like Mr Blair's, is committed to social justice and finding "a new sense of community".

A Downing Street spokesman last night dismissed Mr Haider's comments: "The idea that there are genuine similarities between the two is so risible that I do not think it is worth wasting our breath."

Mr Haider claims the similarities are extensive, with both parties looking for solutions in a "globalised world" and free of "ideological ballast".

"The once dogmatic left Labour party and the right-nationalist FPO of old have undergone an ideological metamorphosis," he writes.

Both parties have abandoned their anti-European stances, and adopted a "positive attitude to Europe", he claims. The Freedom party no longer holds its "German nationalist stance" but has become an "Austrian patriotic movement".

He adds: "Both parties stand up for the weak and underprivileged."

Mr Haider, who has also been criticised for praising the Nazi employment programme, draws parallels between his own party's employment policies and Mr Blair's.

Both the Freedom and Labour parties, he writes, believe the jobless should not be "encouraged to be inactive through state assistance but should be given jobs".

Echoing New Labour's pledge to create a stakeholder economy, Mr Haider discusses giving workers a stake in their companies and in the economy.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Mobile Branson | Recoed profits for  CMG
fields.body:
Outwardly mobile Sir Richard Branson is planning to try to crack the sluggish US mobile phone market after signing a deal with Cable & Wireless Optus to break into Australasia. Virgin Mobile , the joint venture formed for around A$100m (£40m) with Optus, hopes to grow on the expected surge in demand for internet services via wireless telephony around the world. Insiders say Sir Richard is now planning an assault on the US and Europe as well as Australia and south east Asia.

 Bug-related Anglo-Dutch IT services group CMG posted record profits but warned turnover growth and margins could be squeezed in the short term. Pre-tax profit for the full year to December 31 1999 was £85.8m, an increase of 45% on the previous year. Turnover climbed 37% to £608m, while earnings per share rose 48% to 45.4p. Shares fell 154p to £67.60.

fields.headline: Deutsche announces 1bn-a-year online spend
fields.standfirst:
Germany adapts for survival on the new frontier
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Deutsche Bank soared yesterday after it took the wraps off plans to invest €1bn (£618m) a year to build up its online business.
fields.body:
Shares in Deutsche Bank soared yesterday after it took the wraps off plans to invest €1bn (£618m) a year to build up its online business.

The bank is linking up with Europe's biggest software group SAP and AOL Europe in two separate initiatives as it attempts to establish a leading position in the internet-based financial services market.

"Our aim is to make optimum use of any new opportunities that arise. The first mover in this business has a real advantage and we want to exploit it," said Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Rolf Breuer.

The net effect saw Deutsche Bank's shares climb almost 6% to €85.22 yesterday, making it one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lacklustre Frankfurt market.

"It is important that Deutsche Bank is taking a comprehensive approach to business in the internet age," said a German analyst.

Deutsche, which has spent heavily on investment banking, including the $10bn (£6.2bn) acquisition of Bankers Trust, has increasingly sought to bolster the retail side of its business.

Last year, for instance, it held talks with Dresdner Bank about a merger of their retail operations, although the talks came to nothing.

Deutsche has reached agree ment with SAP, best known for its business to business products, which will allow the bank to offer financial and trading services to investors through web-based virtual exchanges.

The deal with AOL Europe, a joint venture between AOL and German media group Bertelsmann which has been the subject of speculation about a split, will provide online banking and brokerage services.

Later this year Deutsche plans to launch net start-up investment funds in the US and Asia. An internet portal named Moneyshelf.com offering services from investment to insurance is also planned.

Mr Breuer said yesterday that the bank would fund its investment programme from the capital gains realised by selling parts of its large portfolio of industrial investments.

The German government has recently announced plans for the withdrawal of capital gains tax on the profits realised by companies from the sale of shares in other domestic firms, making it more attractive to businesses to liquidate their holdings - which are often of long standing.

Competition in German retail banking is increasing rapidly. Recently both HypoVereinsbank and Commerzbank announced online initiatives - the former through a €100m investment programme and the latter through a portal deal with T-Online, the internet subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom.
