fields.headline: Online boom generates billions of yen
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: "I'm only looking for 30m initially," whispered the anxious but determined-looking man who had just introduced himself as an internet entrepreneur in search of funds.
fields.body:
"I'm only looking for 30m initially," whispered the anxious but determined-looking man who had just introduced himself as an internet entrepreneur in search of funds.

"I can't say much now," he said, lowering his voice and moving closer to ensure that no one else in the packed nightclub was listening. "But I have a unique idea for selling women's fashion on the web."

There are not many places in Tokyo where a scruffy journalist can be mistaken for a millionaire investor, nor many dancefloors where people would rather exchange business cards than body fluids. But these are no ordinary times for Japan and this is no ordinary event.

After years of hesitation, everybody in Japan suddenly wants a piece of the web. And Bit Style, a monthly gathering of internet entrepreneurs and venture capitalists, is where they go to get it.

In 12 months, this event - held most recently at Velfarre, Tokyo's biggest nightclub - has become the most talked-about party in town. Against a background of techno music, flashing lights and lasers, it is here where Japan Inc is becoming intimate with the internet in a coupling that could decide the nation's future.

It is a passionate but awkward embrace. Far from the cool and casual geek style of Silicon Valley, most of Japan's internet wannabes look stiff and uncomfortable out of the office. Dark suits and side partings - the traditional salaryman uniform - far outnumber jeans, trainers and ponytails.

"I sort of felt I had to wear a suit and tie," says Yoshikatsu Ezaki, a self-confessed computer otaku (geek) who names Bill Gates as his hero. "I know we have to change that way of thinking, but first impressions count. Maybe next time I'll dress more casually."

Self-conscious young entrepreneurs hang together in twos and threes apparently uncertain whether they should try to seduce or be seduced by the slick money men.

It is clumsy and uncertain, but the intensity of the spectacle - in many ways, the sight of Japan trying to re-invent itself - draws a huge crowd.

When it started 12 months ago, Bit Style attracted just 200 people - many of whom were computer geeks, returnees from America and others on the periphery of Japanese society. But 2,000 squeezed into the latest gathering, and among those who queued up for half an hour to enter were international investors and representatives from some of Japan's biggest corporations.

Despite its reputation as a technological powerhouse, Japan is a late convert to the internet. Thanks partly to sky-high connection charges, the number of Japanese internet users is low at 18.3m, or 14% of the population - less than half the proportion of users in the United States.

The culture of the internet could not be more at odds with the country's traditional social and business models. While the world wide web creates a chaos of horizontal links between consumers, Japan Inc is built on rigid group hierarchies and the pre-eminence of production.

For years, this meant that the web was associated with otaku and outsiders such as Masayoshi Son, the Korean-Japanese founder of Softbank and now the world's most powerful e-investor.

"In Japan, the internet appeals to those who have been alienated or isolated from traditional practices. They are people who have nothing to fear or lose from change," says Noriko Hama of the Mitsubishi Research Institute. "In that respect, the element of revolution is much larger in the Japanese economy than in the west."

This has made Bit Style an important stage for those seeking to lead Japan's nascent new economy. Last month Mr Son cut short a trip to Davos and spent £150,000 to charter a plane so that he could share his evangelical message with the young Bit Style crowd.

"Our age is coming," the 41-year-old told the adoring throng. "This is a period of revolutionary change. In years to come, people will say that we were the ones who transformed Japan and brought it into the information age."

But these days it is not just the geeks who are listening. Mainstream Japan is also paying attention. It has little choice, having waited in vain for most of the past 10 years for the US e-bubble to burst, while Japan's economy has been stagnating.

In a sudden conversion, corporations, public agencies and trust funds have created an ocean of capital - by some estimates as much as 750bn yen (£4.2bn) - for new internet start-ups.

The Tokyo stock exchange has hurriedly established an over-the-counter market - the oddly named Mothers - for venture companies. Two other new bourses are in the pipeline that will make it easy for technology companies to list their stocks with few questions asked.

Even the ministry of trade, which has guided Japanese industry for the past 50 years, has declared that the best way it can encourage the new economy is by non-interference. Deregulation is already starting to reap dividends in the field of internet-capable mo bile phones, where Japanese companies have taken a commanding lead.

But with a huge amount of money now chasing a small number of internet stocks, few analysts dispute that a bubble is forming.

"Not many investors know what they are doing," said Hirohiko Sasaki of Netyear Group, one of the leading lights in the Japanese e-community, and a founder of Bit Style. "They are just throwing capital at the internet, not because they love the companies, but because they want to make money."

With Bit Style now as big and frenzied as a Klondike goldrush, Mr Sasaki said the organisers have decided not to hold any more events on such a scale. "Our aim this year is to cool things down," he said.

But that is likely to prove difficult. The dot.com revolution has generated a confidence and excitement that has been all too rare in Japan during the past decade.

"Japan has been well known for improving existing technology," said Veryan Allen, an investor at the Bit Style event. "Who's to say it won't do the same with the internet?"

The number of Japanese internet users - now 18.3m - has been growing by about 20 per cent each year, but it is expected to surge to more than 45m by 2002 because of the popularity of web-capable cellphones.

The amount of capital available for Internet start-up firms in Japan has surged in the past year from almost nothing to between 400 billion yen to 750 billion yen (£4.2 billion) as investors, led by Softbank and Hikkari Tsushin, rush to stake a claim at the new Internet Klondike.

Revenue from e-commerce in Japan is projected to grow from $3.2 billion last year to $66 billion in 2004, according to Andersen consulting.

Despite the recession, the value of Internet advertising has almost doubled each year to hit an estimated 20bn yen (£111m) in 1999.

Hiroshi Mikitani - Founded Rakuten, a cybermall, in 1997. The company has since grown from 13 shops to 2,000 with 600,000 registered consumers. Preparing IPO in April that is expected to raise $100 million.

Yoko Aoki and Kikuko Yano - Posted idea for a new Women's web site on an Internet notice board. Within a week, they had $100,000 in seed money for CafeGlobe.com.

fields.headline: Net boom drives £2.75bn freight deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's largest freight companies, NFC and Ocean, yesterday announced plans to merge to form a £2.75bn group capable of cashing in on the boom in deliveries generated by internet trading.
fields.body:
Two of Britain's largest freight companies, NFC and Ocean, yesterday announced plans to merge to form a £2.75bn group capable of cashing in on the boom in deliveries generated by internet trading.

The enlarged business, to be known as Exel, will be owned evenly by the shareholders of both Ocean and NFC.

Industry sources said the all-share deal would accelerate consolidation in the logistics sector. The companies emerg ing from recent mergers expect to handle not only physical deliveries but also order taking, warehousing and billing for internet-based businesses.

Ocean has a strong air and sea freight forwarding business which is seen as a good fit for NFC's mainly local ground-based facilities. Both companies concentrate on business to business operations. The combined group is also expected to increase its logistics management consultancy side.

John Allan, Ocean's chief ex ecutive, said the enlarged group would serve almost 70% of the world's top 250 companies. It would aim to boost its share of their freight business, which in some cases was "relatively modest".

The companies aim to capitalise on the €300bn (£186bn) a year outsourced logistics market which is expected to grow by up to 20% a year with the rise of e-commerce and the growing outsourcing trend among multinationals.

The new group, which will be relatively debt free, is planning to spend up to £1bn on acquisi tions. Mr Allan said: "It's not our intention that it should remain debt free with an inefficient balance sheet indefi nitely. The company ought to be capable of handling debt in the short term of £500m to £1bn."

Gerry Murphy, NFC's chief executive, said he would resign once the merger was complete. He is expected to receive a pay-off of up to £1.5m.

The two companies said they expected to reduce operating costs by at least £15m a year within two years through reduced overheads, operating efficiencies and combined buying power. Impact on jobs was forecast to be modest.

NFC, then known as the National Freight Corporation, was privatised in the Thatcher government's first big employee buyout. It was floated in 1982 and employees now own less than 5% of the shares.

It sold the Pickfords removal business to a US company for £280m last year and said that it would concentrate on its logistics operations.

Consolidation in the industry included the Post Office's £300m takeover of German Parcel last year. That deal increased the PO's stake in US-based General Parcel to 23%, a stake which has been increased by further acquisitions.

The PO claims that it has been held back in the takeover stakes because, until recently, it had to obtain prior approval from government. The organisation, which also owns Parcelforce, may now make small acquisitions using its own resources, but still has to seek government backing for big deals.

It claims that its big foreign competitors are not so restrained.

Deutsche Post, the world's largest integrated logistics group, recently completed the purchase of Express International Corporation, another US business.

fields.headline: Heseltine attacks 'ruthless' dome critics
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: "Ruthless" and "irresponsible" criticism of the Millennium Dome cost tens of millions of pounds in lost sponsorship, the former Tory deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, claimed last night.
fields.body:
"Ruthless" and "irresponsible" criticism of the Millennium Dome cost tens of millions of pounds in lost sponsorship, the former Tory deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, claimed last night.

Mr Heseltine, a New Millennium Experience commissioner, said negative press attention made the task of raising £150m sponsorship "well-nigh impossible". He attacked the press for continuing to repeat the criticism despite polls showing the "vast majority" of visitors enjoyed their experience.

Mr Heseltine delivered his ringing defence of the dome during a Commons debate on a Tory motion blaming "government interference" for making the dome "a source of national embarrassment". But he also accused some sponsors of trying to turn their zones into "closer to a trade show than what the editorial concept was designed to be".

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, admitted that there had been "a few glitches", but said that the overwhelming majority of the 700,000 people who had visited the dome had enjoyed their day. The dome had experienced its "four best ever days of attendance", he told MPs. On Friday, 27,000 people visited, on Saturday, 24,700 and Sunday 26,200. Yesterday tickets were sold out by 11.30am.

Both Mr Smith and Mr Heseltine praised Jennie Page, who was ousted from her job as New Millennium Experience Company chief executive earlier this month.

Opening the debate, the shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, claimed the dome had become a symbol of a "trite, self-regarding and bossy government", and ministers had failed to meet the nation's aspirations. The Tory motion was defeated by 275 votes to 141.

fields.headline: Hunt for new NHS chief
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A search was under way last night for a new chief executive of the NHS, after it was announced that Sir Alan Langlands is to leave the job early to take up an academic post.
fields.body:
A search was under way last night for a new chief executive of the NHS, after it was announced that Sir Alan Langlands is to leave the job early to take up an academic post.

Ministers will see the choice of a successor as of critical importance if they are to restore confidence in their handling of the service, after the flu crisis and opinion polls showing a sharp fall in support for Labour on the health issue.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, yesterday thanked Sir Alan for making "a major personal and professional contribution to modernising health care in this country".

Observers feel the two have had a rather uneasy relation ship, however. While the minister, and his advisers, have been impatient for results - particularly since Tony Blair expressed his frustration at the pace of NHS change - Sir Alan has stood firmly by health managers and given only realistic assessments of what is achievable.

Famously, he startled the audience at the main NHS conference last summer by telling them that they were not expected to absorb every word of Whitehall guidance and that it was "healthy if you do not read some of it".

Sir Alan, 47, a career health manager, has been chief executive since 1994. Last summer he agreed to a three-year extension of his contract, worth more than £100,000 a year, but will now leave at the end of August to become principal and vice-chancellor of Dundee university.

He said yesterday: "It has been a tremendous privilege to do my present job. My career in the NHS spans 26 years, and my passion for its founding principles is undiminished."

Mr Milburn also remarked upon Sir Alan's "absolute commitment to the principles of the NHS". In 1998 this commitment went as far as a public threat to resign if any government was to introduce charges that conflicted with the ideal of free health care.

Friends say Sir Alan is exhausted by the pressure of the job, which is based in Leeds but involves much time spent in London, and is looking forward to a role that will take him back to his native Scotland.

There is also a feeling, however, that Labour has not treated him well. One associate talked of a "quite demeaning" attitude towards him that was all too typical of ministers' behaviour towards senior public servants.

Other observers say that Sir Alan has often appeared unenthusiastic about some key reforms, particularly primary care groups and trusts and the commission for health improvement - the new NHS inspectorate.

One leading health analyst claimed that Labour had never wholly trusted Sir Alan, who took up the post under the Conservatives. Although he had worked satisfactorily with Frank Dobson when he was health secretary, the return of Mr Milburn to the health department had probably tipped the balance in favour of an early move.

The post will be advertised on a salary scale of £98,000-£168,000. Likely candidates include Geoff Scaife, NHS chief executive in Scotland, Nigel Crisp, head of the NHS London region, and Neil McKay, recently appointed Sir Alan's deputy.

Famously, he startled the audience at the main NHS conference last summer by telling them that they were not expected to absorb every word of Whitehall guidance and that it was "healthy if you do not read some of it". Sir Alan, 47, a career health manager, has been chief executive since 1994. Last summer he agreed to a three-year extension of his contract, worth more than £100,000 a year, but will now leave at the end of August to become principal and vice-chancellor of Dundee university. He said yesterday: "It has been a tremendous privilege to do my present job. My career in the NHS spans 26 years, and my passion for its founding principles is undiminished." Mr Milburn also remarked upon Sir Alan's "absolute commitment to the principles of the NHS". In 1998 this commitment went as far as a public threat to resign if any government was to introduce charges that conflicted with the ideal of free health care. Friends say Sir Alan is exhausted by the pressure of the job, which is based in Leeds but involves much time spent in London, and is looking forward to a role that will take him back to his native Scotland. There is also a feeling, however, that Labour has not treated him well. One associate talked of a "quite demeaning" attitude towards him that was all too typical of ministers' behaviour towards senior public servants. Other observers say that Sir Alan has often appeared unenthusiastic about some key reforms, particularly primary care groups and trusts and the commission for health improvement - the new NHS inspectorate. One leading health analyst claimed that Labour had never wholly trusted Sir Alan, who took up the post under the Conservatives. Although he had worked satisfactorily with Frank Dobson when he was health secretary, the return of Mr Milburn to the health department had probably tipped the balance in favour of an early move. The post will be advertised on a salary scale of £98,000-£168,000. Likely candidates include Geoff Scaife, NHS chief executive in Scotland, Nigel Crisp, head of the NHS London region, and Neil McKay, recently appointed Sir Alan's deputy.

webTitle: Ken will want to stand, but he'll be running nowhere

fields.headline: Ken will want to stand, but he'll be running nowhere
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: If Ken Livingstone doesn't run for mayor of London, he will be a busted flush. The platform he craves will have been surrendered without a fight. He could call himself the leader of the left, and might be treated that way by the media. He would certainly be its most famous member. But he would have no base. By the rules of politics he would be a loser, buried never to be re-born. For a man driven by personal ambition, in which the active ingredient has always been celebrity more than achievement, this would be hard to bear. The obscurity of his first dozen years as a backbench MP would beckon once more: an intolerable prospect.

If Ken Livingstone doesn't run for mayor of London, he will be a busted flush. The platform he craves will have been surrendered without a fight. He could call himself the leader of the left, and might be treated that way by the media. He would certainly be its most famous member. But he would have no base. By the rules of politics he would be a loser, buried never to be re-born. For a man driven by personal ambition, in which the active ingredient has always been celebrity more than achievement, this would be hard to bear. The obscurity of his first dozen years as a backbench MP would beckon once more: an intolerable prospect.

So running as an independent has attractions. There's an even chance that he will do it, boat-burning though this would be. He has said often enough he never would. But it has plainly been in his mind throughout. Leaving the party he says he loves was always a possibility. What else explains his extraordinary advice to his supporters, within minutes of defeat, that they should stay with Labour? Why ever would they do anything else, if jumping the ticket wasn't an imminent possibility? Whether Livingstone now does that has become a decision for his head not his heart. It is no longer about visceral love for the old party, enduring beneath more recent visceral hate for Tony Blair and all his works. It's about what is best for Ken. Instead of should I try? - can I win?

This, as argued here before, is as it always should have been. There is no future for Ken Livingstone in New Labour. He fights it, despises it, rejects it. He doesn't merely deride much of what it does, he detests its entire animating spirit - its very existence, one might say. His proper place was as an independent candidate, putting his charisma to the test in the city where he was once a folk hero and now offers himself as the prime minister's chief political rival. He should have done this long ago, instead of entering Labour's electoral college process and rejecting the result. His failure to do that will make it more difficult for Labour people to support, even in secrecy, an independent Ken. His delay will cost him support in the election proper.

Nonetheless, if he does jump now, the event will have major consequences, most of them bad for all concerned. He will be tempted to think he can do no other. But the exercise will have its costs for the party, even if he loses, and great hazards for himself.

If Livingstone quits the party, a sort of declaration will be made that the party no longer has space for one of Labour's traditions. For it will be very big thing to do, the scale of which can perhaps only be understood by others who have made the freakish choice to give themselves, body and soul, for a lifetime to the sacred political construct that will celebrate its centenary next weekend. Livingstone may be a crooked opportunist, and his supporters may not quit the party with him. Few leftist MPs, even among those who voted for him, actually like him. But an act of self-exclusion will have been performed by the standard-bearer of a brand of socialism which many activists, in and out of London, would still like the party to half-believe in.

Mr Blair would no doubt call this a cleansing. Given the devious manoeuvrings of the Livingstone left, that word, coming from the leadership, is understandable. Purging, though, would be more accurate. The demon of old Labourism would depart, and the Blair ascendancy would be the more complete. This would announce that no other form of Labour politics mattered, a message with which Labour activists and voters are capable of feeling seriously disillusioned. Livingstone's exit from the party would be unlikely to gain a single vote for Labour at next year's general election.

But the cost to the man himself would also be great. He would be banking everything on the resumption of folk-hero status, transcending party, organisation, money and prominent political support - for he would have difficulty accumulating any of these. Sheer celebrity, dependent entirely on the media, would be his weapon, making a maverick appeal for popular support based on two propositions.

The first concerns the stealing of the Labour electoral college. Here Livingstone has a grievance and a point that could strike some fire. The college was a stitch-up, the block votes were a scandal, the result produced a terribly unimpressive nominee. But the second makes the assumption that Livingstone is a plausible anti-politician: the man to capitalise on public cynicism about the political class: the figure in shining raiment who can ride to victory as the great rescuer of London, indeed the country, from the evils wrought by incompetent professional politicians. This is an adventurous myth that could not survive the 10 weeks of campaigning that now begin.

The mood exists, but Livingstone can't take ownership of it. Nobody in active Labour politics has a longer record of obsessional engagement with politics to the exclusion of any other civilising interest. The notion that this is the man to rise above the swamp asks us to overlook the fact that he's the most hardened crocodile patrolling its murky waters. What such an independent appeal relies on, instead, is a wave of anti-Blairism. This is linked to the putative candidate's media domination. Here is the politician, they will say, to take Blair down a few pegs, make trouble for him, tweak his nose, challenge his crazy obsession with controlling everything in sight.

I don't believe this would survive the campaign either. Such a line, taken by an independent candidate who could represent himself as cheated by the party, might have some purchase against a government that was falling apart. But the Blair government is far from collapse, and its leader is the most popular halfway-stage prime minister in the history of opinion polls. The Tories have a good candidate. For Livingstone to mobilise support across Labour, Tory, Lib Dem and uncommitted voters presumes a titanic popularity, of which yesterday's instant opinion poll is likely to be a false reflection.

Yet it may push the ego-tripper on the way he would dearly love to take. This would lead him, ultimately, nowhere. Even if he won, what could he do for London save rant and whinge against his enemies in Whitehall? What, later, would become of the new Livingstone anti-Labour party, in the absence of nationalist parties or other receptacles for dissidents? The prospect is of floating free, a one-off onanist, but it may seem better than returning to the dark.

webTitle: Rail victim's mother rages at safety failings

fields.headline: Rail victim's mother rages at safety failings
fields.standfirst:
Paddington train crash: special report
Interactive guide to how the trains collided

Inadequate safety measures led to daughter's death, witness tells inquest into Paddington crash in which 31 people died
fields.trailText: The mother of a woman killed in the Paddington rail crash yesterday blamed inadequate safety measures for the death of her daughter, and demanded that the accident be the last of its kind on Britain's railways.
fields.body:
The mother of a woman killed in the Paddington rail crash yesterday blamed inadequate safety measures for the death of her daughter, and demanded that the accident be the last of its kind on Britain's railways.

Birgit Andersen told the jury on the opening day of the inquest into the deaths of the 31 accident victims that the crash could have been prevented.

Her daughter Charlotte, 32, was among those killed when a three-coach Thames Turbo service from Paddington to Slough collided with a First Great Western train from Cheltenham travelling in the opposite direction. The Thames train is believed to have passed through a red signal shortly before the collision at Ladbroke Grove, two miles outside Paddington station.

Mrs Andersen said: "On the morning of October 5 1999 she [Charlotte] was killed in a crash which I believe could have been prevented. She lost her life due to lack of safety measures.

"Her sister, her father and I were robbed that morning at 8.11am. We feel angry as well as worried and feel it is a matter of time before more lives are lost in a similar accident if safety is not improved.

"I plead that the dead of Ladbroke Grove be honoured by ensuring that this does not happen again. We will never hear her voice again and we will never see her smile again," she said, before handing a picture of her daughter to the jury.

Mrs Andersen, who flew from her home in Virginia in the US with her husband Per and youngest daughter Tina to give evidence to the inquest, added that she had thought her daughter would be safe in Britain.

"My daughter ... lived, studied, travelled and worked in many places around the world, including Europe and America, and many which I considered under-developed," she said.

"I used to worry about her safety but when she began to work in the United Kingdom three years ago I felt no need to worry. Then she commuted to work by Thames train from Paddington to Slough."

Charlotte was living in Notting Hill, west London, and working as a product manager in Slough.

She is thought to have been sitting in the front carriage of the Thames train. Her body was thrown from the carriage on impact.

Speaking outside the court, Charlotte's father vowed to do everything in his power to ensure that "the responsible authorities are brought to court".

Earlier the inquest heard from the first police and fire officers to arrive at the scene. Detective Superintendent Patrick Bracken, the senior investigating officer, said that the two trains collided when the Thames train attempted to join the down main line heading away from London, crossing the path of the Great Western train.

The combined impact speed was around 100mph, he said.

Fireman Richard Hodson, chief of North Kensington fire station, said that the first two fire engines at the scene were prevented from getting to the crash site by an electronic security fence protecting a Eurostar depot alongside the track.

He scaled the fence and ran down to the wreckage, where he found a scene of devastation.

In a statement read to the inquest by the coroner, Paul Knapman, Mr Hodson said: "I was confronted with a situation the enormity of which took my breath away."

In total, 228 people were sent to hospital and 296 received first aid at the scene. Some 319 police officers from the Metropolitan and British Transport police attended the scene, along with 152 firefighters and 31 ambulances and 20 other vehicles and crews from the ambulance service.

Dr Knapman indicated the inquest was likely to be adjourned after evidence regarding the death of all 31 victims. Lord Cullen's inquiry into the crash is due to begin hearing evidence next month, and an investigation by British Transport police is continuing.

The inquest continues today.

Hearing told how eight were killed

Yesterday the inquest heard details of the deaths of eight of the people killed in the crash:

Khawar Tauheed, 44

A microbiologist, Dr Tauheed was born in Pakistan and moved to Britain in 1986. He was married with two children and was travelling in the front carriage of the Thames train.

Cause of death: Head injuries and smoke inhalation. Death was instantaneous.

Anthony Beeton, 47

Married with two children, Mr Beeton was an adviser to Mo Mowlam at the Northern Ireland office. He boarded the Great Western train at Didcot, and took his normal seat in a rear carriage. On the approach to Paddington, as he did every morning, he walked to the front of the train. His body was thrown from the front coach into the power car.

Cause of death: Head and pelvic injuries. Death instantaneous.

John Northcott, 24

Mr Northcott, an IT consultant from Leyton, was in the front carriage of the Thames train heading to Slough.

Cause of death: Multiple head injuries. "He suffered a form of brain damage," said pathologist Iain West.

Charlotte Andersen, 32

Ms Andersen was in the front carriage of the Thames train, and was thrown onto the tracks.

Cause of death: Multiple injuries. Death instantaneous.

Sean Donoghue, 45

A statistician from New Cross, Mr Donoghue was also on the Thames train.

Cause of death: Multiple injuries.

Derek Antonowitz, 25

A computer consultant born in Harare, Mr Antonowitz had been in Britain three months when he died on the Thames train.

Cause of death: Injuries to head, chest and abdomen.

Ola Bratlie, 26

A Norwegian telecommunications engineer living in north-west London, she was also on board the Thames train.

Cause of death: Multiple injuries. Death instantaneous.

Delroy Manning, 39

A plasterer from Lewisham, Mr Manning was married with two children. He had been travelling to a new job he was due to start that morning in Ealing, west London. He was knocked out and thrown from the train on impact.

Cause of death: Head and chest injuries.

webTitle: The crucial handful who swung the vote

fields.headline: The crucial handful who swung the vote
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: One of the few successful battles I've fought for the freedom of the press was to overturn a ban on reporting the proceedings of the national committee of the engineering union.
fields.body:
One of the few successful battles I've fought for the freedom of the press was to overturn a ban on reporting the proceedings of the national committee of the engineering union.

When I heard that my press credentials as a reporter for Socialist Worker had been refused (probably because both warring factions in the union hated suspect Trotskyists more than anything else on earth), I was outraged - but also miserable. I had reported the committee's proceedings at Scarborough, and had been enormously impressed.

The 50 members of the committee were all elected by the union rank and file. There was no limit to the issues they could discuss, and their decisions determined union policy. Each session started with a roll call, with terrible consequences for any delegate who was late without excuse. I had reported debates at the House of Commons, the House of Lords, the US Senate and House of Representatives, but nothing I heard in any of these places could compete, intellectually or politically, with those proceedings at Scarborough. Even the delegates with whom I disagreed (most of them) worked out what they thought and how they should express it. For the only time in my life in this country I caught a glimpse of what a workers' democracy could be like.

So I fought the ban and, with the help of the National Union of Journalists, beat it. When I was finally readmitted - at Hastings - I reflected that the engineering union was probably the most democratic workers' organisation in the world. A key to that democracy was that all its fulltime officials, from lowly district secretaries, to regional organisers to executive council members, right up to general secretary and president were subject to regular elections by postal ballot.

How to explain, then, the grotesque charade in which the AEEU, after a single poorly attended meeting, decides that Frank Dobson should be Labour's candidate for mayor of London, when every single union which balloted its members discovered vast majorities preferring Ken Livingstone? Are the views of engineering union members really so different to those of all other workers? Can it be that the union's president, Sir Ken Jackson, has supernatural powers which give him an insight into the unique preferences of his members?

A spokesman in Sir Ken's office explains that the decision to support Dobson was taken by a meeting of 73 people (out of 180 entitled to attend). The 73, he explains, were delegates from their branches to their local London Labour party general committees. He assumes, but cannot ensure, that the question of the union choice of candidate for mayor would have been discussed in the union branches first. No ballot was held to test the views of rank and file AEEU members. In the stitch-up laughably known as Labour's electoral college, the decision of the 73 was enough to give Dobson the majority he needed to crown him the Alun Michael of London.

The spokesman from Sir Ken's office explained that the democratic structure of the old engineering union was drastically altered in the recent merger between the engineering union and the electricians' union. After a ballot in 1998, the merged union replaced the old fuddy-duddy AEU system of electing officials with the new dynamic ETU system of appointing them. A democratic organisation was replaced by a bureaucratic monolith.

An intriguing argument for this conversion comes from the old ETU. They point out that the problems inherent in democratic elections were exposed by the Communist party which for some years kept control of the ETU by rigging ballots. The answer to the scandal of ballot- rigging suddenly becomes obvious: get rid of the ballots.

 Every day comes news from the government that there is no money for this, no money for that. They seem to have the same problem at the Pru, where finance director Les Cullen has left because he thinks his future lies elsewhere. "Les leaves us with our best wishes," says the Pru's chief executive, who of course is called Bloomer. Those best wishes are topped up with a pay-off of £350,000 for the five months hard work put in by Mr Cullen, which can be added to the £750,000 pay-off he got from Inchcape last year. The desperate straits of government departments are exposed by the news that buying and refurbishing two buildings for MI5 and MI6 cost us £547m, compared with the original estimate of £252m.

The grimmest parsimony comes from football's Premier League. Football is always being criticised for overpaid players, but at least they play. The Premier League have paid £12m to two former Sky executives, Sam Chisholm and David Chance, for doing nothing at all. When the clubs found out the details of the two men's contracts as advisers, they refused to ratify the deals. Two years haggling later, the two men have been "compensated" with £12m. Watch out for some harsh criticism on Sky News or for that matter in the Times, the Sunday Times, the Sun or the News of the World.

A spokesman in Sir Ken's office explains that the decision to support Dobson was taken by a meeting of 73 people (out of 180 entitled to attend). The 73, he explains, were delegates from their branches to their local London Labour party general committees. He assumes, but cannot ensure, that the question of the union choice of candidate for mayor would have been discussed in the union branches first. No ballot was held to test the views of rank and file AEEU members. In the stitch-up laughably known as Labour's electoral college, the decision of the 73 was enough to give Dobson the majority he needed to crown him the Alun Michael of London. The spokesman from Sir Ken's office explained that the democratic structure of the old engineering union was drastically altered in the recent merger between the engineering union and the electricians' union. After a ballot in 1998, the merged union replaced the old fuddy-duddy AEU system of electing officials with the new dynamic ETU system of appointing them. A democratic organisation was replaced by a bureaucratic monolith. An intriguing argument for this conversion comes from the old ETU. They point out that the problems inherent in democratic elections were exposed by the Communist party which for some years kept control of the ETU by rigging ballots. The answer to the scandal of ballot- rigging suddenly becomes obvious: get rid of the ballots.  Every day comes news from the government that there is no money for this, no money for that. They seem to have the same problem at the Pru, where finance director Les Cullen has left because he thinks his future lies elsewhere. "Les leaves us with our best wishes," says the Pru's chief executive, who of course is called Bloomer. Those best wishes are topped up with a pay-off of £350,000 for the five months hard work put in by Mr Cullen, which can be added to the £750,000 pay-off he got from Inchcape last year. The desperate straits of government departments are exposed by the news that buying and refurbishing two buildings for MI5 and MI6 cost us £547m, compared with the original estimate of £252m. The grimmest parsimony comes from football's Premier League. Football is always being criticised for overpaid players, but at least they play. The Premier League have paid £12m to two former Sky executives, Sam Chisholm and David Chance, for doing nothing at all. When the clubs found out the details of the two men's contracts as advisers, they refused to ratify the deals. Two years haggling later, the two men have been "compensated" with £12m. Watch out for some harsh criticism on Sky News or for that matter in the Times, the Sunday Times, the Sun or the News of the World.

Red letter day
Lib Dem MP Bob Russell, who paid the price for an inspirational Freepost scheme for his Colchester constituents to express concerns. Topless model Teresa May. She was snubbed by her Conservative MP near-namesake as she delivered a bunch of flowers to parliament. fields.headline: The biggest stitch-up since Bayeux
fields.trailText: For the last two and a half years I have been secretary of my constituency Labour party. Out of respect for democracy, I have carried out my duties regardless of whether I agreed with the party's policies.
fields.body:
For the last two and a half years I have been secretary of my constituency Labour party. Out of respect for democracy, I have carried out my duties regardless of whether I agreed with the party's policies.

I now find that the party's democratic structures can be tossed aside when it suits the leadership. In the ballot to determine the London mayoral candidate, an electoral system in which an MP's vote is worth a thousand times more than mine is introduced at the last moment; unions and other affiliates vote without balloting members; members' money is spent on rallies at which the leader attacks one candidate; MPs are leaned on to support Millbank's choice; and a candidate wins two of the three electoral college sections convincingly but still loses.

This election is the biggest stitch-up since the Bayeux Tapestry. Why should I continue giving up my spare time if party democracy is a sham? Why should I campaign for Millbank's poodle?
David Pope
London

 As a member of the Welsh Labour party, I am only too familiar with how Ken Livingstone and the London Labour membership have been cheated by the leadership. However, it would be a grave error for Livingstone to stand as an independent candidate. Apart from the fact that the party is bigger than any individual, it would be a gift for the Tories and an opportunity for the leadership to expel any active leftwingers involved in the campaign at a time when support for the left in the party and trade unions is growing significantly, as indicated by the vote for Ken among individual members of both the party and those trade unions that bothered to ballot their members in London.
Colin Penfold
Llanbrynmair, Powys

 Does Tony Blair really imagine that the many thousands of non-militant Labour party members who voted for Livingstone will weakly accept their disenfranchisement? I'm not sure whether urging party members tactically to abstain in the general election is an expellable offence, but a quick telephone poll of my fellow moderates suggests that most see that as being Blair's Nemesis.
G Colin Jimack
London

 Mr Livingstone cannot, with integrity, stand as an independent candidate after his public undertakings not to do so. But a massive "write-in" of his name in the final ballot would invalidate this absurd and tawdry election quite beautifully, wouldn't it?
Peter Regent
Newport-on-Tay, Fife

 On my Labour party membership card it reads "...all of us a community in which power... in the hands of the many not the few". Why then, when the many delegated that power to Ken Livingstone, did the few go against Labour's 100-year-old philosophy and tell them that they were wrong?
Matthew Bishop
Sheffield
HIA99MLB@Sheffield.ac.uk

 This undemocratic stitch-up is not just an attack on Ken Livingstone, but on the overwhelming majority of the Labour party in London who have seen their candidate blocked. All Blair and Dobbo have achieved through this is the demoralisation of the party, which will probably see our lame-duck candidate beaten by the Tories, as no one will be willing to do any work in the election for him. I just hope Dobbo "amazes us" by doing the decent thing and resigning, to undo the damage done by the Millbank tendency.
Graham Copp
London
coppgd@sbu.ac.uk

 I was phoned by the chair of our constituency Labour party last week and asked to canvass for the May elections. What should my answer be now, after the grotesque spectacle of a Labour government rigging an election? This is not just an issue for London, but for all party members, who have to work out if they can stand in doorways over the coming months wearing a Labour badge on their jackets. And will those Labour posters in our windows tell the whole world what frauds we all are?
Jeremy Harmer
Cambridge
Jeremy.Harmer@btinternet.com

 Now that the process of selecting Labour's mayoral candidate has been completed, some of us are wondering about the government's preferred system of electing MPs. I have an idea that Tony Blair will favour last past the post.
Pater Banks
Sale
pebanks89@talk21.com

 In Iran the reformist party can win 60% of the popular vote and gain a parliamentary majority. In Britain Ken Livingstone can win 60% of the popular vote and lose'. Perhaps Ken should stand as the next democratically elected mayor of Tehran?
Alex Windscheffel
Egham, Surrey
a.windscheffel@virgin.net

 Not long before he died, John Smith was seen on television saying, "the opportunity to serve, that is all we ask". Compared with that, New Labour is a travesty, a disgrace, as Livingstone and all who voted for his candidacy are no doubt contemplating. We, like Scotland and Wales before us, are on the receiving end of a big, ripe raspberry from Blair and his machine.
John Robinson
London

webTitle: Moonie massive in mauve as a star is born

fields.headline: Moonie massive in mauve as a star is born
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Yesterday I went up on the London Eye, the Millennium Wheel, or whatever it's called. It was stunning. You rise above the ghastly wastelands around Waterloo station, past the dredgers on the river, beyond the disconsolate lines waiting to get into the Aquarium, all queuing in the muddy puddle that covers most of the South Bank.
fields.body:
Yesterday I went up on the London Eye, the Millennium Wheel, or whatever it's called. It was stunning. You rise above the ghastly wastelands around Waterloo station, past the dredgers on the river, beyond the disconsolate lines waiting to get into the Aquarium, all queuing in the muddy puddle that covers most of the South Bank.

After five minutes you're almost as high as Big Ben. Soon Nelson appears on his column, a dinky little figure like the end of an apostle spoon. Minutes later you can see St Paul's and Westminster Abbey at the same time. Buckingham Palace is a doll's house; hard to imagine that it's a nest of poisoners, like the Borgias' staff canteen.

A Eurostar train starts for Paris. Canary Wharf winks from the east, Primrose Hill rises to the north, and looking from the very top you can make out the yellow struts of the Dome.

At this point you can see up to 25 miles all round. The whole of London, the Great Wen, is merely the foreground. And as we hung there, almost motionless, I reflected that probably none of this will ever belong to Frank Dobson.

I like Frank a lot; he's a decent, competent, unpretentious and humorous man who would probably make a good mayor. But the system which brought him the nomination would have brought a blush to those leftwing fixers and back-room dealers Tony Blair once promised to get rid of.

It's intriguing that after a week in which the despots of Zimbabwe and Iran have been stunned by the democratic will of the people, freely expressed, the electors of London have been victims of a stitch-up which would have been applauded by the late Kim Il Sung of North Korea.

An hour later I was in the Commons, half expecting to watch the Millbank octopus strangling a few more otherwise thoughtful members. Instead we had defence questions, which most MPs at least pretend to take seriously. There are few of these questions: "Is my right honourable friend aware that the people of Barchester are delighted that since we came to power, not one nuclear device has exploded in the Barchester area, and does this not prove that New Labour works for the many, not the few?" It wouldn't be apt.

A star was, however, born. Dr Lewis Moonie, a bridge-playing former Communist psychiatrist who sits for Kirkcaldy, is the new junior defence minister. He was wearing a lavender shirt with matching lavender tie; rather than pretty in pink, he was massive in mauve, being built along the lines of Fat Bastard in the Austin Powers film, though the resemblance ends there, since he has a soft east of Scotland accent like one of those golf commentators who sighs with almost sexual pleasure at the sight of a well-holed putt.

Dr Moonie is an exponent of the soft answer which doesn't just turn away wrath but sends it whimpering into a corner. Michael Fabricant roared about military attaches who have to camp in other country's legations. Had he talked to the foreign secretary, who even now was trying to bring home yet more of our ambassadors from their embassies?

Dr Moonie mused for a moment, then reflected gently that well, it sounded to him like a very cost effective way of providing accommodation for the homeless attaches. Meaningless, of course, but so politely expressed that Mickey Fab himself sat preening with pleasure.

Later Nigel Evans asked why more food purchased for our armed forces was not "sourced" in Britain.

Perhaps it was the unconscious pun, perhaps it was the fact that Mr Evans is an easy target - low-hanging fruit, as we say these days, but Dr Moonie said one word: "Joy!" and the whole house sighed with pleasure along with him.

webTitle: What to do next about racism

fields.headline: What to do next about racism
fields.trailText: Your excellent race supplement and lead report (Poll shows big shift against racism, February 21), shows a hugely welcome shift in attitudes. The problem however still lies in the extent of real discrimination rather than attitudes. A recent TUC report shows that while we now think more liberally about race, Black unemployment has risen (from 11 to 13%) since the 1990s and while non-whites have broken into the professions very few hold senior management positions. Clearly, it is the attitudes of employers at the sharp end that count.
fields.body:
Your excellent race supplement and lead report (Poll shows big shift against racism, February 21), shows a hugely welcome shift in attitudes. The problem however still lies in the extent of real discrimination rather than attitudes. A recent TUC report shows that while we now think more liberally about race, Black unemployment has risen (from 11 to 13%) since the 1990s and while non-whites have broken into the professions very few hold senior management positions. Clearly, it is the attitudes of employers at the sharp end that count.

As the weekend demonstrations in Austria should teach us, racism is a complex issue. Better attitudes, particularly among the young, still mask an increase in race discrimination where it matters. That is why the new race bill in the UK and Article 13, which will provide race discrimination legislation across the EU, are so critical.
Claude Moraes MEP

 It is most heartening to see the Lawrence inquiry being revisited, but sad that a crucial point has been missed. We do not ask how it has come about that racism is so widespread in Britain. As we cannot be born with it, we must learn it. Where? I would suggest that we learn it from the culture in which we grow up, and in our schools.

Macpherson recognised the importance of education and made three specific recommendations. These have been completely ignored by the government. Does no one want to recognise that the racist cops, employers, columnists, comedians, etc, as well as rightwing groups such as Combat 18, are the products of both our society and our schools?
Marika Sherwood
Institute of Commonwealth Studies
marikas@a1.sas.ac.uk

 I note that "English" and "British" are used as synonyms in the G2 feature on race. I've always found this habit rather offensive. Is it 'cos me Welsh?
Steve Phillips
Bristol

 Many years ago, when Enoch Powell was in his heyday, there was a letter in the Guardian which simply said: "If repatriation were taken to its logical conclusion, we would soon all end up in the Olduvai Gorge". I think this bears reprinting now.
Liz Moore
Burnley, Lancs

fields.headline: All change
fields.body:
In the bad old days of apartheid the regime banned foreign journalists who wrote things it didn't like in foreign publications, usually without bothering to tell them. Now they are ordered to fly to South Africa (Racism inquiry calls FT editor, February 21) and attend a quasi-judicial inquiry where the rules of evidence don't apply and the penalties for "guilt" are unclear - or face six-months in jail if they fail to do so and subsequently turn up in South Africa. How things have improved.
Chris Jones
Luton

fields.headline: New wave
fields.body:
Stephen Moss asserts that our design for the South Bank Centre was "deemed to be too expensive" (Master builder, February 18) and therefore could not be afforded. In fact, the "glass wave" roof cost only 14% of the total development cost and enclosed many new cultural events as well as reducing the maintenance and energy conservation costs of the South Bank Centre. Contrary to Mr Moss's implication, our scheme, which conserved and significantly upgraded all existing facilities, addressed not only the outward appearance of the site but also provided a wide range of public activities. That said, I think Rick Mather's new masterplan is excellent and look forward to the finished results.
Richard Rogers
London

fields.headline: In defence of shelf life
fields.trailText:
Why are people so rude about librarians, when we spend our professional lives helping people? In your report of a fashion show (London thrills me, February 18) the "inspiration [was] sexually frustrated librarians". I am a librarian and I might plead guilty to plainness or perhaps dowdiness, but definitely not to sexual frustration. On my salary I probably couldn't afford even one of Mr Constable's "long pleated belts made from fake hair" - should I want one.
Clare Abbott
Oxford

 I hope that if readers follow Simon Regan's example and make cannabis cake (By golly, it's good, February 9; Letters, February 17) they also take note that he told his friend to whom he gave it "exactly what it was". My daughter unknowingly consumed cannabis cake at a party and was made extremely ill. She had to drive home with her toddler daughter, where she was reduced to crawling round the floor to reach the telephone to summon help.
Mary E Webster
Exeter

 Catherine Bennett (February 17) rejects a political solution to the conflict in Ireland and praises Lord Tennyson's suggestion that the island be towed into the middle of the Atlantic. Surely, if prior to the 11th century Britain had been towed beyond the Arctic Circle Ireland would not have suffered centuries of mayhem and misrule. However, given the fact that England was determined to subjugate its nearest neighbour we might well now be looking at the breakdown of the peace process in Greenland.
John Morgan
Luton

 Roy Hattersley (A boost for the bard, February 21) does not think much of Burns or Sir Walter Scott. What, I wonder, would they think of the author of such classics as Buster's Diaries?
Stephen Higgins
Staines, Middx

fields.trailText: I have followed with keen interest reports on the nuclear installations inspectorate's investigations (Sellafield told: clean up or close down, February 19), particularly because of the incident last autumn at the nuclear installation at Tokaimura, which resulted in one employee dead, two seriously ill and about 350 local residents waiting to discover the long-term effects of their exposure to radiation.

The report on what went wrong at Tokaimura is chillingly similar to the NII's conclusions on Sellafield, pointing to sluggish manage ment, the lack of safety culture and poor staff training. To those who think privatisation is a solution to Sellafield's problems, I point out that the Japanese plant was run by a private company.
Taeko Midorikawa
Alloa, Clackmannanshire

fields.headline: Run, Ken, run
fields.standfirst:
But don't tear Labour apart

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: It should be a match made in political heaven. Ken Livingstone wants the job of London mayor, and Londoners want him to get it (or so say the polls). Yet somehow politics has failed to make that happen. Thanks to a fix by the Labour hierarchy, the capital is to face a ballot paper excluding the name which 50%, according to yesterday's London Evening Standard, want to mark with a cross. Instead the choice is between a Labour candidate that Labour party members did not want, Frank Dobson, and a Conservative most Tories did not want, Steve Norris (soundly beaten first time round by Jeffrey Archer). Or they could choose a Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer, who is pinning her hopes on the second preferences allowed under the new voting system. In other words, London faces a field of second choices - unless their first choice dares enter the ring alone.
fields.body:
It should be a match made in political heaven. Ken Livingstone wants the job of London mayor, and Londoners want him to get it (or so say the polls). Yet somehow politics has failed to make that happen. Thanks to a fix by the Labour hierarchy, the capital is to face a ballot paper excluding the name which 50%, according to yesterday's London Evening Standard, want to mark with a cross. Instead the choice is between a Labour candidate that Labour party members did not want, Frank Dobson, and a Conservative most Tories did not want, Steve Norris (soundly beaten first time round by Jeffrey Archer). Or they could choose a Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer, who is pinning her hopes on the second preferences allowed under the new voting system. In other words, London faces a field of second choices - unless their first choice dares enter the ring alone.

Yesterday we argued that Mr Livingstone would have to pause before taking such a profound decision. It would mean a break from the party that has consumed his life for 30 years. It would also risk splitting Labour in both the short and long term. Short term, by dividing the Labour vote, handing victory in May to Mr Norris. Long term, by triggering a breakaway of hundreds of pro-Ken activists, followed by mass expulsions and years of recriminations. All those who remember the SDP rupture of the 1980s know how badly that cost Labour, arguably keeping the Tories in power.

Happily there is, to coin a phrase, a third way. It is not the latest wheeze - dump Dobbo and marshall Mo - for that would make a greater mockery of Labour's internal democracy even than the farce we have had already: to have spent all that effort backing Mr Dobson only to drop him and impose a new candidate, even one of Ms Mowlam's calibre, would smack of desperation and crude machine politics. It would assume Londoners can be taken for granted, choosing whoever parachutes into the city wearing a Labour rosette. No, that is not the third way. Instead the best solution is an independent Livingstone candidacy - without rupturing the London Labour party.

First, the case for Ken to run alone. One does not have to want to see Mr Livingstone as mayor to support it. Rather it is a simple matter of democracy: for two years Londoners have made clear their support for Ken, placing him at the top of the polls, yet thanks to a stitch-up they are being denied the chance to express that will. Only an independent candidacy can right that wrong. Otherwise a dozen members of the South London Co-operative Society, who between them determined 4% of Labour's electoral college, will have succeeded in vetoing London's choice. Moreover, for those who long to see a fresh politics, outside the claustrophobic box of the party system, a strong, independent bid could serve as an exciting precedent. The race for the London mayoralty will be enlivened with Mr Livingstone in it, a grey affair without him. Some estimate his participation will boost turnout by a huge 20%.

All this can happen without tearing Labour apart. Mr Livingstone will simply have to renew his appeal to party activists to stay inside Labour, while he runs with a slate of fellow independents - and not a Trot in sight. He will have to run a campaign with no organisation, using the airwaves and the papers instead. Mr Livingstone is too much of a one-off individualist to trigger a breakaway; this will not be the birth of a new leftwing party. Instead it would be a chance to make the mayoral race what it was always meant to be: an unprecedented event - and an exciting one.

fields.headline: Iran's power shift
fields.standfirst: Now Khatami must respond to freedom
fields.trailText: The victory of the reformists in Iran is especially heartening because it is an example of a society reviving its indigenous democratic traditions. The pluralism of Iran throughout history, the attempts at a parlimentary system in Iran early in the 20th century, and the development of party politics after the second world war all suggested that Iran was a country with strong democratic instincts. Western models were influential precisely because they met an Iranian need for a system that could accommodate diversity. This was the lesson the Shah learned, if at all, too late, and it is one the religious class who have dominated politics since the 1978 revolution have had to grasp anew. They shattered the united front which had brought down the Shah, discarding and persecuting former allies. But even in its harshest days the revolutionary regime was no monolith, and within strict limits there was some political competition and popular choice.
fields.body:
The victory of the reformists in Iran is especially heartening because it is an example of a society reviving its indigenous democratic traditions. The pluralism of Iran throughout history, the attempts at a parlimentary system in Iran early in the 20th century, and the development of party politics after the second world war all suggested that Iran was a country with strong democratic instincts. Western models were influential precisely because they met an Iranian need for a system that could accommodate diversity. This was the lesson the Shah learned, if at all, too late, and it is one the religious class who have dominated politics since the 1978 revolution have had to grasp anew. They shattered the united front which had brought down the Shah, discarding and persecuting former allies. But even in its harshest days the revolutionary regime was no monolith, and within strict limits there was some political competition and popular choice.

These limits have gradually expanded over the years, and the weekend's successes for reformist candidates in parlimentary elections represent the most striking such expansion so far. They will not transform Iran into a secular society, nor magically remove the differences be tween Iran and western states. Nor will they end the complicated struggle between moderates and conservatives, two labels that conceal diverse and shifting coalitions. The conservatives still have a powerful base in the Council of Guardians and in the institutions they control, like the armed forces and the judiciary. In parliament, the political inclinations of the many independents and even of a number of those running under the reformist flag are not that clear, and President Mohammed Khatami may not have as easy a time of it as some imagine.

Equally important is that there remains a common interest between most conservatives and reformists - to maintain the Islamic nature of the regime. In part, their differences have arisen out of a debate about how best to preserve the revolution. But there has been a shift in the balance of power, the most important being that the wishes of ordinary Iranians, especially women, count for more than they did. The Khatami government must respond to those wishes - for more personal freedoms, for education, jobs and housing - in a situation where the opposition of the weakened conservatives no longer provides an excuse for failure.

webTitle: The BBC's third of a loaf

fields.headline: The BBC's third of a loaf
fields.standfirst:
But Gavyn Davies gets only crumbs

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: With his announcement yesterday of a BBC licence increase of £3 this year then inflation plus 1.5%, Chris Smith confirmed the government's reputation for trimming its sails before the huffs and puffs of press barons and the supposed prejudices of the public. This might have been an occasion for a grand gesture - if not the big-bang digital supplement recommended by Gavyn Davies then a new century's premium for a broadcaster which needs the money if it is keep its end up. Instead Mr Smith sought to palliate Murdoch (no digital supplement). He did, however, shuffle some way towards the BBC's revenue position. It got a third of a loaf and that is more than can be said for Mr Davies.
fields.body:
With his announcement yesterday of a BBC licence increase of £3 this year then inflation plus 1.5%, Chris Smith confirmed the government's reputation for trimming its sails before the huffs and puffs of press barons and the supposed prejudices of the public. This might have been an occasion for a grand gesture - if not the big-bang digital supplement recommended by Gavyn Davies then a new century's premium for a broadcaster which needs the money if it is keep its end up. Instead Mr Smith sought to palliate Murdoch (no digital supplement). He did, however, shuffle some way towards the BBC's revenue position. It got a third of a loaf and that is more than can be said for Mr Davies.

We should be grateful for small mercies. The government did not listen to the wheedling of Murdoch mouthpieces and warn the BBC off the maintenance of its 24-hour news channel. It did not submit the corporation to investigation by the national audit office - which would have damagingly defined its revenue as public spending.

It is hard to put an exact figure on how much the BBC does need in order to (continue to) provide a first rate non-commercial broadcasting service across the various platforms. The BBC asked for £700m a year over seven years. The government is allowing £200m rising to £300m. But its calculations rest on £490m in extra cost savings and income enhancement - as if the BBC had not been investigated to death. Still, a new director-general has the wherewithal to plan ahead for nearly a decade: the BBC can now get on and make programmes. There is enough in the kitty to introduce a children's channel and much else, but insufficient to make the BBC a player once again in the market for national sporting events. Chris Smith extols his enthusiasm for sustaining the BBC at the centre of the UK's cultural life. His accountants' arithmetic may mean that ambition remains touch and go.

fields.headline: Tensions erupt in Kosovo march
fields.standfirst:
Kosovo: special report

Nato-led troops clash with Albanian protesters amid Serb taunts
fields.trailText: Nato-led troops fired volleys of tear gas and used batons to disperse angry Albanian protesters yesterday after thousands of marchers broke an agreement not to advance on the main bridge in Kosovo's divided city of Mitrovice.
fields.body:
Nato-led troops fired volleys of tear gas and used batons to disperse angry Albanian protesters yesterday after thousands of marchers broke an agreement not to advance on the main bridge in Kosovo's divided city of Mitrovice.

The huge build-up of demonstrators, who pushed through a flimsy cordon to reach the bridge, brought tension to its highest point since 10 people were murdered two and a half weeks ago. Loudspeakers across the river on the Serb side played nationalist songs to taunt the crowd.

Mitrovice has become the worst flashpoint in the unfinished war in Kosovo. When troops from the Nato-led international peace force, K-For, arrived last June they promised to defuse the tension. The clashes between protesters and peacekeepers yes terday lasted for more than an hour but subsided towards evening, by which time most of the crowd had dispersed.

The commander of the Kosovo contingent of Britain's Royal Greenjackets, Lieutenant-Colonel Nick Carter, appealed to the crowd for calm. "Please, let the British stay where we are," he said from the top of an armoured car. "Don't push us. Please stay where you are."

He estimated the size of the crowd stretching back from the bridge at 60,000-70,000.

In another ominous sign, George Robertson, Nato's secretary general, yesterday warned against violence in a Serbian region where several hundred ethnic Albanians live. The alliance would not tolerate fresh conflict, he said.

"There is clearly rising tension in the southern part of Serbia and large numbers of additional Yugoslav troops have moved into the area," he said of the Bujanovac-Presevo-Medveda region bordering south-east Kosovo, where local people have reported a spate of tit-for-tat killings.

Albanians say they are being driven out of the area, while Serb authorities say they face Albanian terrorism. The UN refugee agency has reported that 43 families from the village of Dobrosin have fled in recent weeks. Kosovo Albanian leaders argue that Presevo could be a staging ground for Yugoslav action to test K-For's cohesion, but Nato sources have ruled out K-For troops moving across the border.

Albanian newspaper reports earlier this month claimed Serb police had almost tripled their strength in the area.

The Yugoslav 3rd Army commander, General Vladimir Lazarevic, has accused Nato of failing to prevent guerrilla infiltration of a 5km-wide (3-mile) security zone around the province agreed between Belgrade and Nato. He said Albanian "terrorists" had infiltrated the zone and carried out attacks on Yugoslav police in the Kursumilja and Leskovac areas, north and west of the Presevo valley.

Under the "military-technical agreement" signed by Belgrade and Nato last June, when Serb troops withdrew from Kosovo after 11 weeks of Nato bombing, no Yugoslav army units are permitted in the "ground safety zone". The pact allows Nato to compel withdrawal of any forces, or stop activities posing a potential threat to the mission.

Asked about reports of a new "liberation army", Nato's peacekeeping commander in Kosovo, General Klaus Reinhardt, said last week that "this could become a problem in the spring if they launch attacks into Serbia".

The march to Mitrovice was in protest against violence by Serb gangs which has caused 1,500 Albanians to flee the north of the city in two weeks. The marchers accuse K-For of doing too little and allowing the city's partition. Before last year's Serb offensives, Albanians formed the majority on both sides of the river.

Tens of thousands of Albanians yesterday set out from the provincial capital Pristina, ac companied by UN police. There were a few British military police Land-Rovers at the head of the column, but no sign of any K-For barricades to halt the march on the city.

One of the protest organisers, Felatin Novosella, said help was needed to control the crowd. "We can't stop them," he said. "The aim of this march was not to march across the bridge in Mitrovice. It was just to show solidarity with the people."

The protesters had passed the town of Vucitrn, where a K-For spokesman in Pristina earlier said the organisers had agreed to stop. Only 12 representatives would be allowed to deliver a letter to UN officials in Mitrovice. Many protesters, including women and children, were walking. Others drove in cars, vans and buses. They waved the Albanian flag "Mitrovice - the heart of Kosovo", read one banner.

At least 10 people - eight Albanians and two Serbs - have died and about 20 been wounded in violence this month in Mitrovice.

A house-to-house weapons search, launched on Sunday, was suspended. "K-For had to take some of its soldiers away to provide security for these demonstrations," said Lieutenant Commander Philip Anido, a Nato spokesman.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: The other Teresa | And then some adults
fields.body:
A story on Radio 4's Today programme about how Teresa May, "a soft-porn star and page three model", and Theresa May, Conservative spokesman on education and employment, are receiving each other's mail prompted several annoyed readers to phone Sidelines last week.

John Humphrys asked Theresa the politician if she had "a view about the sort of activities in which she [Teresa May] gets involved?" The MP replied it was up to her. But Humphrys wouldn't leave the issue of passing judgment there: "You're not censorious, then?" "It's up to her," she repeated. He then asked "the other Teresa": "Do you enjoy your job?" - an irrelevant question and one not put to the politician. Later, the latter said: "My job is revealing the failure of the government to deliver" to which Humphrys said: "Whereas Teresa's is revealing different sorts of things." Public schoolboy service broadcasting indeed.

 And there's more Today annoyance from a reader up early enough to hear a Stanstead hijack reporter say: "They came in an orderly fashion. Women and children first, and then some adults."

 Thirty years ago, a meeting was held at Ruskin College, Oxford that kicked-started current writing and discussion about women's history. To mark the anniversary, a follow-up conference is being held at the college on March 18. Keynote speakers include Sally Alexander, Sheila Rowbotham (pictured below) and Lynne Segal. For a registration form, contact Kirsty Reid on 0117 928 8117.

webTitle: Equal pay laws must be enforced, say campaigners

fields.headline: Equal pay laws must be enforced, say campaigners
fields.trailText: Equality campaigners yesterday called on the government to respond to new evidence showing women suffer heavy pay discrimination, by compelling employers to prove they pay men and women equally and refusing to do business with those who do not.
fields.body:
Equality campaigners yesterday called on the government to respond to new evidence showing women suffer heavy pay discrimination, by compelling employers to prove they pay men and women equally and refusing to do business with those who do not.

Following the publication of a government-backed study revealing an average woman will earn almost £250,000 less in her lifetime than a similarly qualified man - even if she has no children - the TUC demanded a strengthening of equal pay laws to force employers to carry out pay audits by gender.

The equal opportunities commission, which also supports pay audits, called for legal reform to streamline the cumbersome employment tribunal process and make it easier for women to bring equal pay cases.

Research revealed yesterday confirmed that the pay gap between women and men stands at around 20%, with women paying a heavy price simply for being female.

A professional woman graduate, for example, will earn £143,000 less than an equivalent man over a lifetime, even before she has children. Motherhood will cost her a further £19,000, while having children will lose a woman worker with no qualifications £285,000 in earnings over a lifetime.

The ministers for women Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell yesterday acknowledged that women were still hit by a "female forfeit" and said the report - Women's Incomes over the Lifetime - exploded longstanding "myths" that women's incomes were lower than men's because they took time off to have children.

But campaigners argue that government pledges to encourage schoolgirls to opt for better paid professions, and to help women keep in touch with the employment market if they take time off to raise children, are inadequate to deal with the problem.

Lucy Anderson, TUC equal rights officer, said the government should legislate to force employers to conduct and publish pay audits comparing men's and women's salaries, rather than merely urging them to do so. The TUC also wants a body such as the central arbitration committee to be given powers to look at pay structures in general.

Unions want action to tackle pay inequality for the lowest paid women workers, who suffer discrimination because they are the backbone of traditionally low-paid sectors such as caring professions and nursing.

The equal opportunities commission said that, without action, the pay gap would remain stuck at 20%. Its chairwoman, Julie Mellor, said the government should show leadership by tackling the pay gap in the public sector.

"The government should insist that taxpayers' money is not spent paying suppliers who do not pay women equal wages," Ms Mellor said.

She added: "Twenty-five years after the sex discrimination act was introduced, women are still sacked because they are pregnant, paid less for equal work and earn less over a lifetime than men, even if they never have children."

The equal opportunities commissioner, Jenny Watson, said the government should set a date for promised moves to reform employment tribunals, making their findings applicable to whole employment sectors rather than simply individual workers.
