fields.headline: Daylight robbery
fields.standfirst: Figures released yesterday turned the spotlight yet again on the yawning gap between women's wages and men's.  Yvonne Roberts  asks what's being done to stop the short-changing
fields.trailText: Figures released yesterday turned the spotlight yet again on the yawning gap between women's wages and men's.  Yvonne Roberts  asks what's being done to stop the short-changing
fields.body:
The patient - a society that wastes female talent and prices caring at next to nothing - has, of course, been sickly for a long time. But now the government's women's unit has published a study that ought to speed the provision of a radical cure. So what should Doctor Blair do?

According to research conducted for the unit by the London School of Economics, a woman who chooses not to have children and competes "equally" with men will still earn £100,000 less over a lifetime. If you're a mother, the forfeit is up to £250,000. A woman with GCSEs will "lose" £50,000 more than one with no qualifications. A low-skilled woman with two children will earn half a million less than her husband.

A sack full of recent statistics, apart from the LSE's research, paints a picture of inequality that is nothing short of scandalous. What's even more troubling is the frustration of the hope that better-educated females would expedite change. In the 1960s, women made up 25% of undergraduates; now that figure is 52%. In 1975, the 10% of top female earners received 59.7% of male colleagues' salaries; by last year, that had crawled up to 62.7%. High-flyers have done little to dent the attitude that they are worth infinitely less than men - not because they have children but because they might.

According to research conducted by the Greater Manchester Low Pay Unit in 1999, women's earnings increased at a marginally faster rate than men's as a result of the national minimum wage. Still, 25 years after the abysmal Equal Pay Act was passed, women earn less than three- quarters of men's full-time weekly earnings. Part-time women earn 60%.

"Women often work flexible, unsocial hours for a basic rate," points out Mary-Anne Stephenson of campaigning women's group the Fawcett Society. "Men work flexibly, too, but it's called shift work and overtime, and they are paid extra."

A man in manual work earns, on average, £335 per week, a woman £221. In non-manual employment, a man earns £525, a woman £346. Whichever way you shake the wages kaleidoscope, women are the losers. More than a quarter of full-time female workers earn less than £220 per week - that applies to only one in 10 men. Even in the higher-earning, male-dominated sectors, male administrators are paid £16.78 per hour, women £12.19. Identical job, different gender.

What's the result? Six out of 10 of those without access to a bank account are women; female incomes, in retirement, are half those of men. Only one in three part-timers has an occupational pension; five times as many women as men depend on income support in retirement.

Elaine Kempson of Bristol University's Personal Finance Research Centre has asked women why they don't make better provision for their old age. "They say: too young, too poor or too late."

Once upon a time, women's attitude to making provision for the future was that Prince Charming would provide. Now they can get caught on a different hook. Jan Pahl, professor of social policy at Kent University and author of Marriage And Money, says: "Younger women are reared on the idea that they need to look after themselves. Even if they live with someone, they have their own income. But what happens when the baby or divorce comes along? Is his income hers too?"

The government has launched a range of proposals including the working family tax credit and, in next month's budget, an integrated child credit. All are important to boosting incomes, especially those of the poorest, but at heart they continue to shore up a system in which employers pay too little and caring is cut-price. And they ignore a culture in which part-time work offers no appropriate use of qualifications and no training; 90% of mothers working part-time say they don't want a full-time job - but does that also mean they have to put their brains on ice?

Anthony Giddens, interpreter of the mysterious Third Way, recently said: "We should develop a more dynamic conception of equality, placing more stress on opportunity." "Opportunity" is not gender neutral. It means little until women are compensated rather than penalised for combining the roles of parent, carer and employee.

So what might make a difference? A requirement on all employers to implement a part-time charter offering advancement not staganation, including the right to return to the same job after childbirth, but as a part-timer. A remodelling of National Insurance. A high-profile, Tony Blair-led equal pay offensive - a recognition that women's contribution to society may be different from men's but is no less valuable.

So far, the government has rejected both an overhaul of the Equal Pay Act and the EOC's suggestion that government suppliers and the public sector should set equal pay standards, while all companies should be obliged in law to implement pay audits. On National Insurance paid on wages of £66 or more, research indicates that many don't understand that if they fail to pay it, they will be ineligible for benefits.

Ignorance is only part of the problem. If you are one of half a million women who have two part-time jobs, if, say, each pays £30, for a total of 15 hours per week, you will be unable to make a contribution towards a state pension. In contrast, a high-paid woman working only five hours and earning £70 will be able to contribute. Gabrielle Cox of the Low Pay Unit suggests contributions are paid on a minimum number of hours worked, not wages, thus opening up benefits to many more.

Jay Ginn, a pensions expert at Surrey University, also points out that a single woman who has saved modestly and has a small second pension could find herself disqualified from a number of benefits and worse off than the person who hasn't saved a penny. Ginn suggests a much higher earnings-related basic pension (now £66.75) and a gentler taper. In Denmark, the basic pension of £110 is paid regardless of a partner's income or home-time for child-rearing. Its criteria is 40 years' residence. Such individualised benefits (rare here) help women.

The new stakeholder pension, for those earning between £9,000 and £20,000, contains problems but it will permit a woman to continue to pay into her pension, tax free, even when she has time out from work, for instance when she has a child. Why can't the government extend the principle and offer help with that pension contribution, as it does with some maternity payments?

Of course, in addition, women have to acquire the balls to ask for more. American labour organisation the AFL-CIO has a website through which an employee supplies her qualifications, experience and job - and is told how much less she earns than her male colleagues. Bolshiness helps - but, as our women's ministers have pointed out, it's the system that sucks.

webTitle: Who's afraid of the thin blue line?

fields.headline: Who's afraid of the thin blue line?
fields.standfirst: In the first of a new fortnightly column following her pregnancy, Forward Prize-winning poet Kate Clanchy faces the moment of truth
fields.trailText: In the first of a new fortnightly column following her pregnancy, Forward Prize-winning poet Kate Clanchy faces the moment of truth
fields.body:
Do you remember when home test kits for pregnancy first became foolproof, commercial and advertised on TV? There was an ad that sticks in my mind, one with a woman who stared at a little white stick in her wedding-ringed hand, then rushed off to a park to where a man on a bench was waiting. It wasn't clear why he was in the park but he, too, was flashing a wedding band, so he must have been her husband, or someone's husband anyway, and they embraced and wept joyfully. It was shot in black and white, perhaps to make the whole clinical business seem more romantic, perhaps to get round the problem of the yellow, urinous end of that little white stick.

That advertisement was one of the first times I really grasped that advertisers don't just exaggerate but actually, knowingly, create a false audience for their customers to identify with. With the same epiphanous certainty as realising the Bomb was Wrong and Just Seventeen was bought only by 13-year-olds, I decided that pregnancy test kits were not designed for happy couples but for frightened teenagers to use in their best friend's bathroom while the best friend looked up the number of the Marie Stopes Centre. Three brands, a TV campaign and a £10 price tag seemed to require that sort of desperate market.

In fact, I didn't believe that Wives ever used test kits at all. Surely those alien creatures, Grown-Ups, would keep the 10 quid and go sensibly to the doctor's and be tested with some soothing, official substance - something from the large green stoppered vase in the pharmacist's window, perhaps. So it was strange - as strange as catching yourself using your parents' phrases - to watch a wedding-ringed hand reach for a pregnancy test in Boots and see a teenage girl suddenly transfer her attention to the nail varnish. They still cost £10 and it still seemed sheer exploitation. I nearly offered to go halves on a pack of two.

And it was stranger still to see the blue line slowly form, just as shown in the diagram, and to embrace my husband and weep with joy. It wasn't just the extraordinary fact of conception, the fact that my body could really perform the elaborate, delicate trick I'd read about so often. It was more the sense of suddenly taking on a whole new script, of changing sides mid-match. My generation of girls had been brought up to believe we could have it all, that we could get an education, jobs and property, just like a man - provided we acted like a man.

Starting at that little blue line, I was going to have to stop pretending. I was going to grow an indisputably woman's body and go through woman's-only pain. I was going to perform a thousand menial childcare tasks, like my mother, my aunts, my grandmother, and I wasn't sure I had time to learn how. Childcare, flexible working hours, respect - wages - for housework and the disposable nappy debate were all going to become real issues, not lip-service. I would never be able to grumble about a co-worker's maternity leave again.

And I had to admit that Wives use test kits. I think it may even be quite common and that many Grown-Ups are just as furtive, curious, even ambiguous, as teenagers. In any case, home tests really must be the discovery moment for lots of women, because there isn't a large green vase of Official Pregnancy Test at the doctor's. Mine, disconcertingly, just took my word for it and started fiddling with a prayer-wheel thing to find my due-date.

But I still maintain that ad is hopelessly idealised. That black and white woman would never have got to the park without pausing to projectile-vomit outside the chip shop, to breathe in glorious whiffs of some unexpected smell - rain-water butts and puddles do it for me - and would probably have told her husband to stand three paces off because of the unbearable cloying scent of his aftershave. Early pregnancy turns you into a species of collie dog, unable to turn off the full spectrum of smells. Or in my case a bloodhound, since my nose leads me infallibly to the butcher's to purchase yet more unwonted quantities of red meat. I really don't seem to be able to stop myself. Sad - when I first saw that test-kit ad, I was a vegetarian, too.

webTitle: Day of truth for McCain and Bush

fields.headline: Day of truth for McCain and Bush
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: John McCain was fighting a last-ditch battle yesterday to defend a shrinking opinion-poll lead over George W Bush in Michigan, which votes today in a Republican primary election that could make or break Mr McCain's chances of being the party's nominee to run for the US presidency.
fields.body:
John McCain was fighting a last-ditch battle yesterday to defend a shrinking opinion-poll lead over George W Bush in Michigan, which votes today in a Republican primary election that could make or break Mr McCain's chances of being the party's nominee to run for the US presidency.

Michigan polls taken after Mr Bush's big win in South Carolina on Saturday show Mr McCain, an Arizona senator, hanging on to a two-point lead over the Texas governor. This contrasts with a Detroit News poll last week that gave him a 43%-to-34% lead.

Victory in today's Michigan contest - and in today's other primary in his home state of Arizona - is critical for Mr McCain who, since his South Carolina defeat, has adopted a more aggressive tone in a whirlwind drive for votes in the big midwestern state. All 6.7m Michigan voters are eligible to vote today, a far larger electorate than in any of the presidential primaries so far.

Denouncing Mr Bush for his combative South Carolina campaign style, Mr McCain told a rally of more than 1,000 voters yesterday in Traverse City, Michigan, that they should "reject this negative campaigning, reject this character assassination, reject the low road to the presidency and support the high road".

Mr McCain is trying to rebuild support among mainstream Republicans, who gave Mr Bush an almost 3-1 advantage in South Carolina. "I am a proud conservative Republican with a 17-year voting record," he repeated at several campaign stops yesterday.

Mr McCain was due to fly to Arizona last night to await the results from today's primaries. He is almost 20 points ahead in Arizona, surveys indicate.

Ralph Nader, a long-time consumer rights campaigner, announced yesterday that he would again seek the Green party's presidential nomination. Mr Nader, 65, took just under 1% of the vote when he stood for the Greens in the 1996 presidential contest.

fields.headline: Women versus babies
fields.trailText: Throughout the 1970s, the arguments for a woman's right to choose seemed relatively straightforward. "Free abortion on demand" was a central tenet of the women's liberation movement. It was understood that women needed to control their fertility if they were to participate in society on equal terms with men and, since contraception sometimes failed, legal abortion was essential if women were to enjoy their sexuality.
fields.body:
Throughout the 1970s, the arguments for a woman's right to choose seemed relatively straightforward. "Free abortion on demand" was a central tenet of the women's liberation movement. It was understood that women needed to control their fertility if they were to participate in society on equal terms with men and, since contraception sometimes failed, legal abortion was essential if women were to enjoy their sexuality.

To argue against "the right to choose" was to argue that women should fulfil their traditional domestic destiny as wives and mothers at a time when sexual freedom and women's economic independence were celebrated.

But today, abortion is no longer a left versus right, radical versus reactionary, feminist versus anti-feminist issue. Today, there are fewer "fundamentalists" on either side. Just a tiny - if vocal - minority believe that abortion is always wrong. Even most of those who campaign for tighter legal restrictions concede that there are circumstances when abortion may be legitimate.

On the other side of the debate, there are fewer voices prepared to argue a robust defence of a woman's absolute right to choose abortion. Some believe abortion on grounds of abnormality is uncomfortably close to eugenics; sometimes a line is drawn at a particular gestational limit.

The issues surrounding late abortions are particularly contentious. Techniques in foetal medicine have made it easier to sustain the lives of severely premature babies. Infants can now be saved at gestations when foetuses can be legally aborted.

Increasingly, obstetricians talk of having two patients - the woman and the foetus. Discussions about the rights of the child (and, indeed, the rights of animals) have encouraged debates about what rights, if any, should be conferred on the foetus, while the abortion debates in the 1970s were about the social status of women.

In the past, law and religion defined our understanding because science had little to say, as science writer Greg Easterbrook argues in a recent US New Republic article. He claims the case for liberal provision of early abortion is strengthened by evidence that the natural termination of potential life is far more common than previously assumed - but scientific discoveries about the brain activity of the more developed foetus stand as an argument against late abortion.

Easterbrook believes this is a message the pro-choice movement does not want to hear lest they be compelled to trade off liberal earlier abortion for restrictions on those in later pregnancy.

Those of us who provide abortion services cannot afford to insulate ourselves from contemporary debates. For example, it is not uncommon for women seeking to end a pregnancy to be concerned about whether a procedure causes pain to the foetus. Our clinicians would be failing their profession if they were not aware of developments in neo-natal medicine.

Because of the need for open debate, British Pregnancy Advisory Service hosted a meeting in London yesterday of almost 100 clinicians, academics, policy makers and campaigners, including those hostile to abortion, to consider the "new ethics" of abortion.

Each year we provide nearly 55,000 abortions - most are in early pregnancy, but some are late. We see no need for apology or moral defensiveness. Rather we believe there is a strong case for trying to wrest the moral imperative away from those who assume they have the monopoly on ethical concerns.

Within the confines of the law we strive to allow women to exercise "procreative autonomy", that is to assert their own control over if and when they have children. We believe that a civilised society accepts that women are creatures with a moral conscience, capable of making responsible decisions for themselves. This is as true for women who seek late abortions as it is for women in early pregnancy. Women do not request abortion because they are ignorant about foetal development but because, for some reason, they find their pregnancy intolerable.

Science may be making new discoveries about foetal development, but it has little to tell us about the real lives of women. The issue is not so much whether or when the embryo/foetus is deserving of respect per se, but how much respect and value we accord to a life (that does not even know it is alive) relative to the respect and value we have for the life of the woman who carries it.

Some argue that civilised society can be judged by its attitude to the "unborn child". We believe it can also be judged by its attitude to women.

fields.headline: Man who tackled burglar murdered
fields.trailText: A father of three who confronted a burglar at his home was killed in a violent struggle early yesterday as he tried to protect his family.
fields.body:
A father of three who confronted a burglar at his home was killed in a violent struggle early yesterday as he tried to protect his family.

Philip Street had challenged the intruder, who was in the back garden of his semi-detached home in the residential area of North Reddish, Stockport. Mr Street, 48, a builder, was stabbed in his left shoulder and suffered head and chest injuries. His wife Elaine dialled 999, but he was dead on arrival at Manchester royal infirmary.

The killer, who had also broken into two garages in a neighbouring road, fled leaving a pile of stolen goods.

Neighbours last night expressed shock at the killing. It is thought that Mr Street found one of his children's bicycles had been stolen from a shed when he investigated a noise outside his home at 1.30am. His killer fled through neighbours' back gardens.

Johnny Maher, a pensioner who lives around the corner from Mr Street, also had his garage broken into but did not realise anything was amiss until police knocked on his door several hours later.

"All men would have done exactly the same as Mr Street if somebody had touched their property," he said.

The burglar had piled up stolen items outside Mr Maher's home, which backs on to Mr Street's house, and did the same thing next door. Mr Maher said: "He seems to have done these two houses before going on to murder."

Mr Street's daughter, Emma, is in her late 20s. He also has two sons, Andrew, 21, and Daniel, 15, and a four-year-old granddaughter, Morgan-Leigh.

Andrew told Mr Street's employer, Ken Slow, of his father's death. Mr Slow said: "He called me up and said to me: 'My dad's been attacked and he's been stabbed. I couldn't get to him in time.'"

Emily Booth, a neighbour, said: "They were a very, very nice family and were well respected in the neighbourhood. I feel devastated and very sad about what has happened." Another neighbour, Jacqueline Doyle, described Mr Street as a friendly man who always spoke to her in the mornings when she left for work.

"I just can't believe it," she said. "He was such a friendly bloke."

Greater Manchester police set up a mobile incident room outside his home and the im mediate area was sealed off. His family have been moved out of their home while police inquiries continue.

Scenes of crime officers in blue overalls combed the area for clues which might lead them to the killer.

Patrick Davies, the assistant curate at nearby St Elizabeth's Church of England church, said: "People here live quite ordinary, normal lives and they look out for one another, doing each other's shopping and looking after each other's houses. This is a very tragic incident."

A spokesman for Greater Manchester police confirmed that the death was being treated as murder.

A post-mortem examination was carried out yesterday afternoon.The ambulance service said they were called to the house shortly after 1.30am.

"He had a puncture wound to his left shoulder and head injuries. We took him to the Manchester royal infirmary, but he was dead on arrival," said a spokesman.

fields.headline: The incompleat angler
fields.standfirst: Roman statue 'seen for first time in 2,000 years'
fields.trailText: The old fisherman is standing upright for the first time in 2,000 years. The scattered pieces of the Roman statue have been reassembled as plaster casts at the Ashmolean museum in Oxford.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The old fisherman is standing upright for the first time in 2,000 years. The scattered pieces of the Roman statue have been reassembled as plaster casts at the Ashmolean museum in Oxford.

Bert Smith, professor of classical art and archaeology, said: "We are seeing him as he was intended to be seen, which nobody has done since the Romans."

The torso and head were found 85 years apart, in different parts of the site of Aphrodisias, now farmland in a Turkish river valley but once a rich and powerful city of the Greek and Roman empires.

Excavations have been running every summer since 1961, led by a team from New York university. When Professor Smith took over five years ago, he started a trawl through the thousands of fragments of marble in the site museum store, and six more pieces of the statue were found. Eventually he realised that he had enough pieces to attempt a reconstruction.

Casts were taken, using silicone rubber moulds, of all the fragments in Germany and Turkey. The Ashmolean conservator, Daniel Bone, reconstructed the statue with the aid of a human skeleton hanging by his side. Having both feet and the right thigh gave him the length and position of the legs. Not enough survived to be certain about the arms, which probably held a fishing rod and basket.

The torso was found in an excavation of the Aphrodisias public baths in 1904, by a French engineer and amateur archaeologist, Paul Godin. He took many objects, including the torso, which was sold in a curio shop in Smyrna to a collector from the Berlin museum, where it remains.

The head was found in 1989 about 100 yards from the site of the torso.

The figures of old fishermen generally represented old men bent and battered by a life of labour.

But in Aphrodisias the type was transformed. The fisherman, though thin and bent, became smooth, elegant, even noble, rather than a grotesque and comic figure.

The reconstruction will go on display in the Ashmolean from tomorrow.

webTitle: Mystery of murder rate drop solved

fields.headline: Mystery of murder rate drop solved
fields.trailText: A US criminologist has solved the great American murder mystery: why the national homicide rate has been falling for the past six years.
fields.body:
A US criminologist has solved the great American murder mystery: why the national homicide rate has been falling for the past six years.

Part of the answer was quite simple, Richard Rosenfeld, a member of the US national consortium on violence research, told the meeting.

First of all fewer people were getting married so there were fewer spouses to murder. The increased status of women and the influence of domestic violence services had also encouraged the drop in spousal homicide.

Secondly, the dramatic rise of numbers in prison had removed more potential killers from the homicide arena.

From 1980 to the mid-1990s the rate of imprisonment in the US had tripled. At least one fourth of the decline in homicides could be explained by the fact that inmates were likely to be drawn from the most dangerous neighbourhoods.

"That must be counted as good news, but it comes with a huge price tag," he said. He calculated that to avert one homicide, there had to be a net increase of 670 prisoners a year.

However, these two factors could not explain all of the drop in killings. "More prisons and fewer families are at best temporary, limited and negative remedies for violence."

There was a third factor. "What we may be seeing is a real and sustained intolerance for unregulated violence. Historians call it a civilising process," he said.

fields.headline: Good side of nicotine discovered
fields.trailText: Nicotine could be about to make a gentle comeback. Studies have found that patients with Parkinsonism and children with Tourette's syndrome showed both immediate and longer-term benefits.
fields.body:
Nicotine could be about to make a gentle comeback. Studies have found that patients with Parkinsonism and children with Tourette's syndrome showed both immediate and longer-term benefits.

Nicotine, long known to South American tribes as a medicinal herb, has been tested on a small group of people with mild to moderate Parkinsonism.

After two weeks, Paul Newhouse of the university of Vermont told the association, the patients could stand, walk and sit more easily, use their fingers more dexterously and react more swiftly to stimulus. The effects lasted up to two weeks.

Nicotine has been known for years to improve memory and cognition, and to lower anxiety in Alzheimer's patients. Smokers have a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease. It has helped some patients with attention deficit disorder. Scientists see nicotine as one of those drugs that may be beneficial only in very precise doses and none recommend smoking.

Paul Sanberg of the university of Florida has been testing nicotine gum and patches on children with Tourette's syndrome, a terrible disorder of nervous tics, rage reactions and involuntary obscenities.

They showed significant improvements and there has been no sign of addiction. But there have been reports of nausea and gastrointestinal problems, and researchers are looking for drugs that cause less discomfort.

webTitle: Vacancy signs as hotels lose staff

fields.headline: Vacancy signs as hotels lose staff
fields.trailText: The sign outside says Investors in People - which certifies that this place excels in the training and development of its staff - but it seems that the five-star Langham hotel, in central London, is lacking in the people to invest in. Like hotels and catering businesses across the country it is suffering a recruitment shortage.
fields.body:
The sign outside says Investors in People - which certifies that this place excels in the training and development of its staff - but it seems that the five-star Langham hotel, in central London, is lacking in the people to invest in. Like hotels and catering businesses across the country it is suffering a recruitment shortage.

There are in excess of 100,000 vacancies within the industry and many of them look like they will remain empty for a very long time.

This week the Langham Hilton hotel has 308 staff, down from 320 last week and well below the desirable figure of 356. And that is in a hotel with a much lower turnover than a number of its rivals.

The hotel needs a sales person, two engineers, a telephonist, four concierge staff, two waiters for its Palm Court restaurant, one bartender, three people to work in conference banqueting, five kitchen staff, eight stewarding staff and six valet parkers.

Prospective employees can afford to be fussy. Unemployment in Britain is at its lowest for 20 years and many forecasters say it will drop below 1m for the first time since 1975, while the number of people in work is at an all-time high of 27.5m.

Instead of working in a business which is perceived as low-paid and stressful, job hunters are opting for reasonably well-paid jobs in call centres and on supermarket tills.

This inevitably means there are fewer people around to provide the levels of service required by an ever more discerning customer. Hotels admit that it will not be long before guests start complaining.

A report by the Hospitality Training Foundation says that the industry advertised 104,200 positions in job centres across the country in the three months to July 1999, with 44% remaining unfilled.

"This is likely to represent only one third of the vacancies, given that hospitality employers also use recruitment agencies, trade and local press and word of mouth to attract new employees," says the report.

The office of national statistics estimates there are now 1,377,000 jobs in the sector, compared with 989,000 in 1987.

Andy Westwood, director of development at the employment policy institute, believes that the estimates of 100,000 vacant jobs could be "slightly conservative", which he says proves that scaremongering over the introduction of the national minimum wage was groundless. The industry is finding it has to pay more.

Westwood points to what he calls the industry's star performers, such as the coffee bars that have opened over the past year and taken staff away from the larger hotels.

"The cappuccino economy has really taken off. Rather than go and be a silver service waiter in a big hotel, you can go and be a barista in Starbucks and become someone who knows which kind of coffee bean to grind for which coffee," he said. "That's a recruitment tactic; they are paying a decent wage and they are trying to make it a skill to be in the service sector."

Kevin Brett, executive assistant manager of the Langham, said: "The hours are perceived as unsocial, the salaries and packages we are paying don't compare to the more glamorous and high paying vacancies elsewhere in London."

Traditionally hotels have recruited around 70% of their staff from foreign nationals. But those with a good grip of the English language are turning to other jobs.

fields.headline: Hydrogen grown from pond scum
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford at the American Association for the Advancement of Science conference in Washington
fields.trailText: Californian scientists claimed yesterday that they had found a way to "grow" hydrogen gas from pond scum. A small commercial pool of algae could one day produce enough fuel to power a dozen cars for a week.
fields.body:
Californian scientists claimed yesterday that they had found a way to "grow" hydrogen gas from pond scum. A small commercial pool of algae could one day produce enough fuel to power a dozen cars for a week.

Hydrogen is the commonest element in the universe but expensive to make. It has to be extracted from methane, natural gas. But hydrogen burns with oxygen to produce water, which makes it the cleanest fuel of all.

Tasios Melis, a biologist at the university of California, Berkeley, told the American Association for the Advancement of Science meeting that he had found a metabolic switch that could make the microscopic alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii react with sunlight to make quantities of hydrogen.

Berkeley and Prof Melis's partners at the national renewable energy laboratory in Colorado have taken out a patent on the process. So far only small scale cultures of the algae have been tested. "I guess it is the equivalent of striking oil," said Prof Melis. "It was unbelievable."

Algae were among the first of the planet's inhabitants, and would have evolved in the very different atmosphere of early earth. Certain types of algae have been known for decades to produce traces of hydrogen as they grew in sunlight. But no one had been able to make the yield rise to anything worth collecting.

The breakthrough was the discovery of a molecular switching process which could turn off the cell's usual photosynthetic apparatus, and direct the cell to use its own stores of energy, with hydrogen as a byproduct. The switch is, reportedly, simple to activate. It depends on the absence of sulphur from the nutrients on which the algae will grow. Without sulphur there is no photosynthesis. To keep going the cells have to turn on another fallback energy source which releases hydrogen.

"They are utilising stored compounds and bleeding hydrogen just to survive," Prof Melis said. "It's probably an ancient strategy that the organism developed to live in sulphur-poor anaerobic conditions."

The researchers grew the algae using the sun's energy, allowing the organisms to build up their carbohydrate stores. Then they transferred the microbes into sulphur-free bottles and waited while the algae consumed the remaining oxygen.

Within 24 hours the algae switched to their ancient emergency process and began to leak hydrogen to the top of the bottles. The plants could keep the process going for four days before they went back to normal photosynthesis to build up new reserves of hydrogen. Two or three days later, they could be tapped again.

Every litre of the culture yielded an hourly average of three millilitres of hydrogen. The scientists believe they could increase the yield 10-fold. They expect to see hydrogen-generator plants developed for small-scale use and for industry.

"We thought we would get trace amounts, but we got bulk amounts," Prof Melis said. "Hydrogen is so clean burning that what comes out of the exhaust pipe is pure water. You can drink it."

The man, 53, from Lincolnshire, retired on medical grounds in 1995 after he was diagnosed with reactive depression. He was told yesterday that he will receive one of the biggest compensation payouts for stress. He does not want to be identified because he would find the publicity too stressful.

He joined the post office in 1963 and became ill after a business review in 1992 led to an increased workload.

His solicitor, Andrew Darke of Irwin Mitchell, said: "Our client has suffered greatly, and his award will enable him to have some form of financial security.

"This case should be seen as a signal that when a worker shows signs of stress, the employer is obliged to attempt to reduce the burden," he added.

Murder suspect held in Paris
A Frenchman wanted in connection with the murder of his British mother-in-law and the wounding of his estranged wife was yesterday being held by French police after being arrested at a Paris railway station.

West Midlands police said that 37-year-old car dealer Cherif Doua had been arrested by French authorities on Sunday.

A force spokeswoman said: "We can confirm that Mr Doua was arrested by French authorities at the Gare du Nord at 3.50pm on Sunday afternoon. He is being held in custody."

Forces around Britain and international authorities had been seeking Doua for almost a month.

His mother-in-law, 62-year-old Valerie Brocklesby, was stabbed to death in her home in Hateley Heath, West Bromwich, on January 24.

His estranged wife, Jayne, 27, was also found in the house with multiple stab wounds.

She subsequently underwent surgery for injuries to her upper body and has now been released.

Spainsh regret leak on Pinochet
Spanish authorities have "expressed regret" over the leaking of Augusto Pinochet's medical report to Spanish newspapers, but denied knowledge of how it happened, the home office said today.

The Spanish government said in response to a formal request for an explanation that it could not even be certain that the details had been handed over in Spain. Details from the confidential medical report were published hours after they were handed over to Spanish officials on the orders of the high court.

A home office spokesman said it had no plans to launch its own investigation into how the leak happened.

The matter is also being investigated by the attorney general's office as a possible contempt of the court order which stated that the report should be treated "in strictest confidence".

Copies of the report were sent to Spain, France, Switzerland and Belgium, which are requesting the extradition of the 84-year-old general to stand trial for alleged abuses of human rights.

The four countries have until 5pm today to comment on the medical report before the home secretary, Jack Straw, makes a final decision on whether to drop the extradition case launched by Spain against Pinochet on humanitarian grounds - which could see the former dictator heading home before the end of the week.

Supporters of the general said yesterday he was recovering after suffering bruises to his face and right hand in a fall on Friday at his rented Surrey home.

Extracts from the report published in newspapers and later on the internet disclosed that the four doctors who examined Pinochet concluded that he was suffering from "extensive brain damage" which had left him unfit to stand trial. His short- and long-term memory had been affected.

The deterioration in his condition was linked to a series of strokes he suffered last year, and was likely to worsen, the report said.

Teachers top lonely hearts
More teachers subscribe to dating agencies than people from any other profession, according to a survey by the computer agency Dateline.

Of its 25,000 subscribers, 744 were teachers, and of these 467 were women, the company said yesterday. In the three years since the last survey teachers had overtaken nurses as the most frequent subscribers.

A spokesman for the National Union of Teachers said teachers were "all working so hard they never get the chance to meet people".

The National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers' spokesman said: "Teachers wouldn't be looking so hard for love if they felt their employers loved them a bit more."

Woman sent MP dead mouse
A disgruntled constituent was yesterday jailed for two weeks for sending a maggot-infested mouse through the post to her MP.

Mother-of-two Mee San Lee-Reed, 50, sent the decomposing rodent to David Jamieson, Labour MP for Plymouth Devonport, with a note that read: "Nazi scum, you are dead."

The package was opened by Mr Jamieson's wife at their home last July, Plymouth crown court heard.

Lee-Reed also sent a dead rodent to Plymouth city council offices, the court heard.

Lee-Reed, of Plymouth, pleaded guilty to two charges of sending indecent or obscene material and asked for four other offences to be taken into consideration.

Hugh Cornford, prosecuting, said Lee-Reed had also sent dog faeces and sanitary towels covered in tomato and soya sauce to people against whom she had a grudge.

In mitigation, Nick Lewin said Lee-Reed felt let down by her MP in her efforts to find out more about the murder of her relatives in her native Indonesia.

She held a grudge against Plymouth city council following a rent dispute, which caused her losses of £40,000, he added.

Navy ship saves 11 from yacht
A Royal Navy destroyer rescued 11 people, including eight Britons, yesterday as their yacht sank in the Caribbean, writes Stuart Millar.

HMS Manchester, on a four-month patrol from its Portsmouth base, picked up a mayday at 2.40am local time from a 148ft motor cruiser, Shiralee, which had begun taking in water 35 miles north east of Puerto Rico.

The warship, the only vessel in the vicinity, dispatched its Lynx helicopter to the scene where it found the crew had abandoned ship and taken to two life rafts.

Manchester was guided in from 20 miles away to pick up the four women and seven men, the last of whom was taken on board by 4.10am, fewer than 90 minutes after the distress call.

After a medical check, they were given fresh clothes and hot soup before being transferred to a US coastguard cutter, which took them back to the Puerto Rican capital, San Juan.

The cause of the Shiralee's sinking remains unknown.

Commander Bob Brown, Manchester's captain, said: "There were no injuries and they all seemed very grateful to have been rescued so quickly." A navy spokesman added: "It was dark and there were no other ships around, so they were very lucky that the only one in the area had a helicopter."

fields.headline: See-saw bounced by bureaucracy
fields.trailText: Roland Bolter, the village blacksmith, built Bledington's see-saw stoutly, with an reinforced plank and an iron channel.
fields.body:
Roland Bolter, the village blacksmith, built Bledington's see-saw stoutly, with an reinforced plank and an iron channel.

"I made it safe and I made to last", he said yesterday - 40 years on. It has stood on the green in all those years without an accident. Generations of children, and a few adults, have bounced one seat on the ground while the other flies up, in a game as old as childhood.

But now the contraption has to come down - and the Cotswold village feels it has lost part of its sovereignty. Like hundreds of others still in use in Britain, the village's traditional British see-saw is doomed by official standards which measure safety in millimetres.

See-saws are not allowed to touch the ground any more. The news was broken after an inspection by the Gloucestershire playing fields association.

Villagers were told that "a new directive imposed by Brussels" is to blame. But that turns out to be another Euro-myth. The real culprit is Britain's own increasingly "low public tolerance towards playground accidents", according to the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents' playground safety adviser, Peter Heseltine, yesterday.

As long ago as 1979, a voluntary British safety standard set out to discourage bouncing see-saws. It recommended that seats should be stopped 203 mm (less than an inch) above the ground.

Three years ago, with strong British backing, the EU standardisation committee urged a stricter limit of 230mm.

Since then, inspectors have visited playgrounds suggesting that "risk assessments" be carried out if see-saws fail either or both standards.

Compliance remains voluntary. But failure to observe the standards can be cited in a prosecution or civil action for damages brought by a parent after an accident.

For Bledington parish council, that was enough. Yesterday its chairman, Graham Richardson, said: "The see-saw is impossible to bring up to new standards.

"I just don't know where all these rules and regulations are going to end. It seems ridiculous to me."

Mr Bolter, aged 75, said: "I'm disgusted".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Backpacker's body 'found'
A team of Metropolitan police detectives is in Kashmir investigating claims that the body has been found of a British backpacker, Paul Wells, from Blackburn, Lancashire, who was kidnapped by Islamic militants in 1995.
fields.body:
Backpacker's body 'found'
A team of Metropolitan police detectives is in Kashmir investigating claims that the body has been found of a British backpacker, Paul Wells, from Blackburn, Lancashire, who was kidnapped by Islamic militants in 1995.

Mr Wells, then aged 24 and a photography student, was abducted with Keith Mangan, of Middlesbrough, and four other tourists, who are all missing presumed dead, by Al-Faran demanding the release of 21 jailed militants.

Eurasia award for Rushdie
Salman Rushdie's latest novel, The Ground Beneath Her Feet, yesterday won the Eurasia Regional prize to go on the shortlist for the main £10,000 Commonwealth Writers Prize 2000 in April. The best first book prize went to the Indian author Raj Kamal Jha for The Blue Bedspread.
Maev Kennedy

Pub hours opposition
Most people are opposed to the extension of pub drinking hours and any liberalisation of the alcohol laws, despite government proposals, according to a survey for the Institute of Alcohol Studies.

It found that 59% of people think it would be a bad idea to extend late-night drinking hours and only 12% favoured an extra hour's drinking time in non-residential areas.

United history
A collection of Manchester United programmes dating back to 1890 when they were known as Newton Heath will be sold by Phillips at Old Trafford next month. Leslie Millman's collection includes a programme from that year, for a game against Walsall, with drawn, named figures in their positions.

webTitle: Tea dance brawl lands pensioner of 77 in court

fields.headline: Tea dance brawl lands pensioner of 77 in court
fields.trailText: An ageing romeo gave another pensioner a broken nose during a tea dance after being accused of getting fresh with his dance partners, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An ageing romeo gave another pensioner a broken nose during a tea dance after being accused of getting fresh with his dance partners, a court heard yesterday.

Aubrey Powell, 77, attacked Mark Lester, 71, with a file wrapped in a tea towel during the weekly dance held in Brent town hall, north London, last September.

The attack put Mr Lester in hospital with a fractured nose, head injuries, and a fractured wrist.

Yesterday Powell, of Stamford Hill, north London, was given an 18 months prison sentence, suspended for two years, at Harrow crown court in north-west London after pleading guilty to wounding with intent.

He was also ordered to pay £500 compensation to his victim, which Powell agreed to pay at £15 a week out of his pension.

The row began last March at the afternoon tea dance, where the elderly ladies lined up on the left of the dance floor and the men on the right.

The two men had known each other, by sight only, for about 30 years, attending the same dances on a regular basis, said Polly-Ann Comfort, prosecuting.

Mr Lester accused Powell of sexually harrassing ladies at the dance. Powell told the court that, on that occasion, Mr Lester had given him a "rabbit punch" on the back of the head.

Powell reported the attack to police; though no action was taken, officers attended one dance at Powell's insistence but there was no trouble.

From then on Powell took the file to the dance to protect himself, said Kathryn Hirst, defending. She said he had once been attacked in his home by burglars, and this led him to fear for his safety and to arm himself "to protect himself from this much bigger man [Mr Lester]."

The attack last September occurred when Powell saw Mr Lester enter the dance, Miss Comfort told the court. "He anticipated Mr Lester's approach, thought he was going to attack him, and raised what looked like a rolled up newspaper before raining blows upon him."

Judge Barrington Black told Powell: "I don't think I have ever had to deal with a case of two 70-year-olds brawling over some remark made to a lady with whom the other person was dancing."

Outside court afterward Powell said: "[Mr Lester] said I was interfering with the ladies. But I'm a gentleman, and anyway I'm impotent. I just enjoy dancing and chatting. Most of the ladies have Zimmer frames anyway, and it takes a lot to get me excited.

"I just want to go home and forget about it all."

fields.headline: Off the shoulder
fields.standfirst: Sex appeal in Milan
fields.trailText: The beginning of Milan fashion week is traditionally given over to diffusion lines. Alberta Ferreti's Philosophy line, Versace's Versus and Dolce and Gabbana's D&G have already taken a spin down the runway.
fields.body:
The beginning of Milan fashion week is traditionally given over to diffusion lines. Alberta Ferreti's Philosophy line, Versace's Versus and Dolce and Gabbana's D&G have already taken a spin down the runway.

Yesterday it was the turn of Anna Molinari's Blumarine label. The show concentrated on ideas first explored for spring/summer four months ago, experimenting with contrasting fabrics like chiffon, leather and cashmere but adding an eighties feel with accessories like skinny belts, bright leather gloves and huge stiff bows atop models' heads.

Colours were bright: fuchsia, purple and turquoise. Blumarine's signature skinny-fit cardigans came trimmed with thick mink collars and were worn with crocodile leather pencil skirts. Backless halter neck chiffon dresses in grape or peach looked sexy for evening, while belted trench coats in black patent leather or camel cashmere were a strong statement for day.

As usual, there was sparkle and sex appeal aplenty from the label, which caters for that brand of Italian miss for whom no dress is too small nor any diamond too big.

webTitle: Railtrack's key role will not be changed

fields.headline: Railtrack's key role will not be changed
fields.standfirst:
Paddington train crash: special report
Interactive guide to how the trains collided
fields.trailText: Railtrack's safety role is to remain unchanged after the Paddington train crash even though some of its safety management has been found wanting, reports will confirm today.
fields.body:
Railtrack's safety role is to remain unchanged after the Paddington train crash even though some of its safety management has been found wanting, reports will confirm today.

A "hit squad" of rail inspectors, set up by the health and safety executive, has found that some of the safety procedures will have to be tightened.

But another report will say that Railtrack can keep its overall responsibility for controlling safety. The only apparent change is that Railtrack is to be or dered to set up a subsidiary company to take responsibility for safety.

In the third of a series of reports today Sir David Davies, president of the Royal Academy of Engineering, is to deliver his verdict on safety mechanisms.

On the day of the Paddington crash John Prescott said money "would be no object".

But this inquiry has suggested a money-saving compromise. For now the most sophisticated equipment to stop signals being passed at danger will be sanctioned on new trains for routes such as the west coast main line.

A less expensive system that only stops trains when they are at speeds of up to 70mph is recommended for less important routes, offering a saving of around £700m.

webTitle: As ordinary voters declare support, MPs urge caution

fields.headline: As ordinary voters declare support, MPs urge caution
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's strengths and weaknesses were shown in stark relief yesterday. While ordinary Labour voters rang newspapers to protest their support for an independent candidacy for London mayor, Labour MPs who know him and their party better urged caution.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's strengths and weaknesses were shown in stark relief yesterday. While ordinary Labour voters rang newspapers to protest their support for an independent candidacy for London mayor, Labour MPs who know him and their party better urged caution.

The division amounted to the classic split between hard-headed New Labour roundheads and romantic cavaliers, except that some leftwing cavaliers - some of them admirers of Mr Livingstone's politics - were suddenly falling into line behind their party.

John Prescott spoke for many MPs on Channel 4 news last night when he insisted: "Ken signed up for [the electoral college]; he actually said, 'If I lose I will loyally support whoever wins."' Party HQ at Millbank issued 13 quotes from the Brent East MP in which he said precisely that.

"I have made it clear again and again that I have no intention of leaving the Labour party and it is becoming very tiresome that I have to repeat this," he told one paper in June last year. "I am passionate about both London and Labour," he told the Guardian five months later.

"My hunch is that he won't do it. Dobbo getting 40% of the popular vote makes him a viable candidate," one leftwing MP said last night. A leftwinger's researcher agreed: "He'd burn too many bridges with the party; he'll sit back and bide his time."

Mr Livingstone's supporters are telling him Millbank reneged first on the deal made when he was allowed to join the Labour shortlist. Some MPs believe he will run. "What has he got to lose?" asked several.

Many leftwing MPs interviewed by the Guardian predicted that Mr Livingstone would draw back from a final breach with his party. Their assessment of his motives ranges from the charitable - "It's too great a breach" - to the calculated - "He'd be the man who let Steve Norris win."

With no organisation and the public support of few well-known figures outside show business, Mr Livingstone will also have to counter the glee with which the Tories have greeted Labour's split. "A very good week for Steve," said one Tory Greater London assembly candidate.

In the chatter around the corridors some attacks were vitriolic and personal, resting on Mr Livingstone's record at the old GLC and what many MPs see as his fundamental untrustworthiness - believing him to be an egotistical loner who has never built up alliances or a following even within his natural home, the leftwing Campaign Group.

"I have no reason to like him after what he did to me in the NEC elections," said one leftwing MP, who thinks he will run. "Ken's support comes from white Stalinists over 50," said another.

There may be plenty more of that to come.

 The government today faces near certain defeat in the Lords over its refusal to concede a free mailshot to candidates in the election for London mayor, amid opposition accusations that it is seeking to "buy" the result of the poll.

Labour was denying candidates the chance to send a leaflet free to every London voter specifically to disadvantage Mr Livingstone, who would not have the resources for a mailshot, the Liberal Democrats claimed.

"I have made it clear again and again that I have no intention of leaving the Labour party and it is becoming very tiresome that I have to repeat this," he told one paper in June last year. "I am passionate about both London and Labour," he told the Guardian five months later. "My hunch is that he won't do it. Dobbo getting 40% of the popular vote makes him a viable candidate," one leftwing MP said last night. A leftwinger's researcher agreed: "He'd burn too many bridges with the party; he'll sit back and bide his time." Mr Livingstone's supporters are telling him Millbank reneged first on the deal made when he was allowed to join the Labour shortlist. Some MPs believe he will run. "What has he got to lose?" asked several. Many leftwing MPs interviewed by the Guardian predicted that Mr Livingstone would draw back from a final breach with his party. Their assessment of his motives ranges from the charitable - "It's too great a breach" - to the calculated - "He'd be the man who let Steve Norris win." With no organisation and the public support of few well-known figures outside show business, Mr Livingstone will also have to counter the glee with which the Tories have greeted Labour's split. "A very good week for Steve," said one Tory Greater London assembly candidate. In the chatter around the corridors some attacks were vitriolic and personal, resting on Mr Livingstone's record at the old GLC and what many MPs see as his fundamental untrustworthiness - believing him to be an egotistical loner who has never built up alliances or a following even within his natural home, the leftwing Campaign Group. "I have no reason to like him after what he did to me in the NEC elections," said one leftwing MP, who thinks he will run. "Ken's support comes from white Stalinists over 50," said another. There may be plenty more of that to come.  The government today faces near certain defeat in the Lords over its refusal to concede a free mailshot to candidates in the election for London mayor, amid opposition accusations that it is seeking to "buy" the result of the poll. Labour was denying candidates the chance to send a leaflet free to every London voter specifically to disadvantage Mr Livingstone, who would not have the resources for a mailshot, the Liberal Democrats claimed.

webTitle: Polite impasse when Ken met Tony

fields.headline: Polite impasse when Ken met Tony
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report

No alternative job offer by premier, and now the key consideration for Livingstone is whether his public popularity can be sustained
fields.trailText: The crunch meeting between Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair, when it came at 10am at Chequers on Saturday morning, was by all accounts a gentle affair. After months of political warfare by proxy, the two men chatted amiably in jeans and trainers in the prime minister's study at his official Buckinghamshire residence. With them were Mr Blair's political secretary, Sally Morgan, and the Brent East MP's political adviser, Simon Fletcher.
fields.body:
The crunch meeting between Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair, when it came at 10am at Chequers on Saturday morning, was by all accounts a gentle affair. After months of political warfare by proxy, the two men chatted amiably in jeans and trainers in the prime minister's study at his official Buckinghamshire residence. With them were Mr Blair's political secretary, Sally Morgan, and the Brent East MP's political adviser, Simon Fletcher.

The prime minister also saw Frank Dobson later that morning and Downing Street was at pains yesterday to emphasise that he met both candidates with a realistic chance of winning Labour's mayoral nomination to discuss how they could work together.

But the main purpose of the encounters from Mr Blair's point of view was undoubtedly to sound out Mr Livingstone's plans if, as expected, the former Greater London council leader lost.

After talking round his objections to partial tube privatisation, Mr Livingstone told the prime minister Mr Dobson would be a disaster for Labour and urged him to advise the former health secretary to stand down. "I can't tell him what to do," was Mr Blair's reported response.

The Chequers conversation on Saturday skated over the issue of Mr Livingstone going it alone. But, if opinion polls continue to confirm his expectation that he could win the mayoral election on May 4 as an independent, he now looks increasingly likely to declare his candidacy this week or next - and begin an extraordinary solo campaign.

His closest political intimates believe he is already 95% sure that he should stand, setting aside frequent statements over the last few months that he would never fight against the official candidate of the Labour party he has served for more than 30 years.

Ruled out

Just over a year ago Mr Livingstone crossed the psychological barrier that prevents most politicians from conceiving of such a break. At that stage he was readying himself to run as an independent if Mr Blair blocked him from the selection shortlist.

The former GLC leader is already understood to have ruled out the possibility that he might quietly withdraw from the race in return for a job offer from Mr Blair. The prime minister has nothing to give that Mr Livingstone might find more attractive than taking on the mayoral brief.

In any case, no job was even floated at the Chequers meeting. Mr Livingstone told the prime minister he had been won over wholesale to Mr Blair's enthusiasm for directly elected mayors. There were only two other jobs he would find more exciting: "But I don't think you'd give me the same leeway as Gordon, would you?"

Simple arithmetic

In Mr Livingstone's mind, the question whether to stand as an independent boils down to straightforward political arithmetic. He will run only if his lead in the opinion polls is commanding enough to survive a likely weakening of support during fierce campaigning against him by the official parties in the run-up to the poll.

His probable calculation is that 45-50% support would be sufficient at this stage if the other candidates were fairly evenly split. Yesterday's poll in the London Evening Standard satisfied that test by giving Mr Livingstone 50%, with 22% for Frank Dobson, 15% for the Conservatives' Steve Norris and 8% for the Liberal Democrats' Susan Kramer.

"Ken is minded to stand, and as long as Londoners show they want him, he will do it. He doesn't want to hang around on the backbenches in Westminster when he has the chance of getting stuck into solving the problems of London Transport," a close supporter said yesterday.

Mr Livingstone will have up to six weeks to get his organisation together before nominations close on April 3. He is understood to be preparing to assemble a slate of independent candidates to run on his coat-tails for seats in the Greater London assembly. If he can find what he wants, they will be business people, independents and even Tories, with few leftwingers and no Trotskyites in sight.

Mr Livingstone's showbiz allies are understood to be turning their minds to fund-raising for a campaign that could cost at least £500,000 and may need £1m. This would dwarf the £70,000 raised last year to fight his way on to the Labour shortlist and campaign for the electoral college vote.

Mr Livingstone could be expected to run a presidential-style campaign, using the media instead of large numbers of canvassers, who would be hard to organise from a standing start.

The biggest items of expenditure would be likely to be printing an election address and preparing a party political broadcast. Given the need to save cash, it is unlikely that Mr Livingstone would spend anything on a legal challenge over Labour's electoral college procedures.

John Carvel, Guardian education editor, is Ken Livingstone's biographer. Turn Again Livingstone, Profile Books: available for £6.99 plus 99p p&p; freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0500-600102

fields.headline: Secret plan to ditch Dobson
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report

Mowlam lined up to take on Livingstone
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has drawn up a contingency plan to ditch Frank Dobson and back Mo Mowlam as Labour's candidate for mayor of London if, as now looks increasingly likely, Ken Livingstone decides to run as an independent and takes a convincing lead in the opinion polls.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has drawn up a contingency plan to ditch Frank Dobson and back Mo Mowlam as Labour's candidate for mayor of London if, as now looks increasingly likely, Ken Livingstone decides to run as an independent and takes a convincing lead in the opinion polls.

As the former Greater London council leader yesterday promised to "listen to Londoners" and the first polls showed him to be runaway favourite for mayor, it emerged that Mr Blair's most popular cabinet minister has agreed in principle to step in if Mr Dobson stands aside.

The likelihood of Mr Livingstone going it alone after his defeat in Labour's widely criticised electoral college has increased after a secret meeting with the prime minister at Chequers on Saturday produced no government job offer or prospect of political accommodation.

Ms Mowlam is regarded in Downing Street as Labour's most appealing vote-winner and a potential saviour if Mr Dobson finds himself trailing in the polls and the party leadership decides he has been irreparably damaged by allegations that he won the nomination through a stitch-up.

The crisis strategy would not require a re-run of the Labour selection campaign. Downing Street advisers envisage that Mr Dobson would step down shortly before the start of the campaign in April, allowing the party's national executive to use emergency powers to install a replacement.

The cabinet office minister is understood to have been willing to put her name forward for the mayoralty late last year, as her job in the Northern Ireland office came under threat. But the plan came to nothing because Mr Dobson agreed to be the prime minister's candidate before anything could be settled.

"Frank has been put through the mill and understandably wants the gain after all the pain," one senior Labour figure said last night. "But politics is politics. If the polls tell a particular story, might he not have to look reality in the face?"

Mr Livingstone is understood to have told Mr Blair at their meeting on Saturday that Labour could not win the mayoral contest in the capital with Mr Dobson and that the long-term electoral damage to the party from a heavy Dobson defeat would be considerable.

He is said to have pressed Mr Blair to advise the former health secretary to stand down. "I can't tell him what to do," Mr Blair retorted.

A Downing Street spokesman insisted yesterday that Mr Livingstone was bound to abandon any idea about standing as an independent once it had become clear that no significant Labour figure or union would back him.

But the first opinion poll of Londoners for the Evening Standard suggested yesterday that Mr Livingstone would get 50% of the vote if he stood as an independent, with Mr Dobson a poor second on 22%.

Another telephone poll for Carlton TV's London Tonight showed that 93% of those who called thought the former GLC leader should stand as an independent after winning the majority of votes from party members and trade unionists but losing the nomination.

John Prescott called on Mr Livingstone to "stop whining" about the electoral college system that defeated him and accept the outcome of the process. The deputy prime minister said Mr Livingstone was "a Labour guy through and through - he has said he was born in Labour and would die Labour. I think that's exactly what will happen."

Mr Blair led the campaign to bolster Mr Dobson's support, saying the longer that Labour's internal contest had gone on, "the more support he attracted, and the reason for that is the more people got to know him, the more they like him and trust him".

Labour officials also downplayed the significance of the polls, insisting that Mr Livingstone's lead would melt away under the heat of a public contest with all three main parties' electoral machines.

But if Mr Livingstone gets corroborating evidence from other polls, he is expected to declare his candidacy later this week or next, earning automatic expulsion from the party he joined 32 years ago in the process.

Mr Dobson yesterday kicked off his first day as Labour's official mayoral candidate by making a symbolic break with the party's Millbank headquarters and declaring that he would "not be having anybody else poking their nose" in his campaign.

As speculation continues about whether or not Labour will face an independent chal lenge from Mr Livingstone, the government meanwhile faces defeat tonight in the House of Lords, when the opposition parties plan to vote down its regulations for the mayoral contest due to take place in less than three months.

Ministers have refused to compromise over their insistence that there will be no freepost delivery for mayoral candidates.

If the regulations are rejected, there is a serious possibility that the mayoral contest may have to be postponed.

fields.headline: Legal threat over Pinochet leak
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet on trial: special report

Pinochet leak: threat to papers
fields.trailText: The attorney general has warned a number of newspapers that they could be in contempt of court for publishing details of a leaked medical report into the health of General Augusto Pinochet last week.
fields.body:
The attorney general has warned a number of newspapers that they could be in contempt of court for publishing details of a leaked medical report into the health of General Augusto Pinochet last week.

The Guardian, the Daily Telegraph and the Times, which carried extracts, have all been contacted by the attorney general's office. Other newspapers that carried quotes from the report, including the Independent and the Daily Mail, have not yet been asked to explain their actions.

A letter sent to editors yesterday asked for representations about the circumstances in which the details came to be published. The attorney general will examine these before considering whether to bring contempt of court proceedings. After the leaking of the report, solicitors acting for Gen Pinochet asked the attorney general's office to investigate.

The report - commissioned by Jack Straw, the home secretary, to establish whether the general was fit enough to be extradited to Spain to face charges of human rights abuses - was leaked to newspapers in Spain and Chile last Tuesday night.

The previous day three high court judges had ruled that the four states with outstanding extradition warrants against the general - Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland - were entitled to see the report, which carries the conclusions of three doctors who examined the general last month at Northwick Park hospital, north London.

Two Spanish newspapers, El Mundo and ABC, carried the report's conclusions on their websites on Wednesday morning. Early morning news bulletins on TV and radio in the UK carried the report's findings, attributing them to the Spanish sources. English re-translations were then published on British websites, including those run by the BBC and the Guardian.

The Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, said last night: "These medical reports had already been published in Spain's leading newspapers and were available on the internet. It is an astonishing waste of taxpayers' money to be threatening to sue British newspapers for republishing reports which anyone in the world with a computer and modem could read."

The Spanish foreign ministry was believed responsible for the leaking of the report in Spain, while sources close to the case suggested that "friends of the general" might have leaked it to Chilean publications.

Yesterday Spanish authorities expressed "regret" over the leaking of the report to Spanish newspapers, but denied any knowledge of how it happened.

The home office wrote to the Madrid government after details from the confidential medical report were published within hours of their being handed over to Spanish officials on the orders of the high court.

A home office spokesman said last night: "After making inquiries, they [Spain] did not consider it possible to conclude that the leak to Spanish newspapers occurred in Spain.

"They have expressed regret for any difficulties caused as a result of the breach of confidence and the partial disclosure of the report."

Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland have until 5pm today to make representations to the home secretary and his decision that he is "minded" to allow Gen Pinochet to return to Chile.

webTitle: Hindley's punishment is degrading, law lords told

fields.headline: Hindley's punishment is degrading, law lords told
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley accused the home secretary, Jack Straw, of subjecting her to "inhuman and degrading punishment", as she took her plea for freedom to Britain's highest court yesterday.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley accused the home secretary, Jack Straw, of subjecting her to "inhuman and degrading punishment", as she took her plea for freedom to Britain's highest court yesterday.

The decision that "life must mean life" for someone imprisoned at the age of 23 singled her out for "uniquely harsh treatment", her QC, Edward Fitzgerald, told five law lords. It meant she could spend 60 or 70 years in jail, he said.

Hindley, now 57, who was convicted with Ian Brady in 1966 of the murders of Lesley Ann Downey, 10, and Edward Evans, 17, was the only offender subject to a "whole-life tariff" - meaning she could expect to die in prison - who was not the actual killer, said Mr Fitzgerald.

Yet she was a "reformed" person who presented no danger to society and had been recommended by the parole board for transfer to an open prison.

Mr Fitzgerald told Lords Browne-Wilkinson, Nicholls, Steyn, Hutton and Hobhouse that Hindley was now in her 35th year of imprisonment. "There is no dispute that her crimes were of the utmost gravity and deserving of punishment. But there is uncontradictable evidence that she has reformed and presents no danger to society."

Hindley is contesting an appeal court ruling in 1998 upholding the lawfulness of life detention for the worst murderers, without hope of parole.

The courts have held that the policy is lawful as long as it allows for release if the prisoner has made exceptional progress in custody. Hindley's lawyers have asked Mr Straw to release her on this ground but he has refused to take a decision until after the law lords give their judgment in a few weeks time. The hearing is expected to take four days.

Mr Fitzgerald said his challenge was to the legality of whole-life tariffs in general, as well as to the particular sentence imposed on Hindley.

Parliament had given no authority for life detention based solely on the gravity of the crime, though it had intended that prisoners who were dangerous could be detained for life, he said.

At the most it provided for a recommendation of minimum tariffs and did not contemplate a category of prisoner for whom release from prison on licence could not be contemplated, except in "exceptional circumstances".

When Hindley was sentenced in 1966, the trial judge made no recommendation as to how long she should serve, though Lord Lane, Lord Chief Justice, later recommended a minimum of 25 years. In 1988 whole-life tariffs were introduced, and that tariff was imposed on Hindley in 1990.

In 1987 Brady and Hindley had confessed to involvement in the further murders of Pauline Reade and Keith Bennett, which had contributed to her receiving the whole-life tariff. However, Mr Fitzgerald said police now accepted that Hindley was corrupted by Brady, which was a mitigating factor rather than grounds for increasing the penalty.

fields.headline: CCTV 'filmed assault by constable'
fields.trailText: A police constable yesterday denied assaulting a man despite a video showing him apparently slamming the man's head against a panda car while arresting him.
fields.body:
A police constable yesterday denied assaulting a man despite a video showing him apparently slamming the man's head against a panda car while arresting him.

Weymouth magistrates' court in Dorset was shown a closed circuit television recording of the events surrounding the arrest of Adman Lamonby by PC Michael Hughes, 36, while on duty in Bournemouth one Friday night last April.

The video showed, the prosecution alleged, the officer "bouncing his [Mr Lamonby's] head off the back windscreen of his patrol car".

Prosecuting solicitor Gareth Evans said that, after PC Hughes noticed the CCTV camera, his partner then appeared to try and conceal the treatment of Mr Lamonby by standing in front of the lens.

Mr Evans told the court: "The prosecution would say that this officer's whole demeanour was of someone not in fear of his own safety. He was a man on a mission.

"A police officer is entitled to use reasonable force during an arrest if they believe it to be necessary.

"On no basis can what the defendant did that night be justified as reasonable."

Denying one charge of common assault, PC Hughes had said he had been confronted with a baying mob of youths.

But Mr Evans said the group of four men on the video appeared to be standing calmly waiting for a taxi, one of them with his hands in his pockets.

Following Mr Lamonby's arrest, he and his friend Shaun Stubbs, who was also arrested, were immediately released by the custody sergeant at Bournemouth police station without charge. They had been detained for being drunk and disorderly.

webTitle: Photo of Blair son broke code

fields.headline: Photo of Blair son broke code
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission has upheld a complaint by Tony and Cherie Blair against a tabloid newspaper that published a picture of their son Euan kissing a girl at a party.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission has upheld a complaint by Tony and Cherie Blair against a tabloid newspaper that published a picture of their son Euan kissing a girl at a party.

It ruled that pictures in the Daily Sport of Euan, 15, at the Mistletoe Ball at the Ministry of Sound nightclub in south London in December breached the editors' code of practice.

The code says that newspapers must obtain parental permission before publishing pictures of children under 16, and must not publish details of a child's private life simply because the parents are famous.

Downing Street last night said in a statement that the ruling underlined once again "the right of Mr and Mrs Blair's children, and those of other public figures, to grow up as other children do, free from unwarranted media attention".

The Blairs have long made it clear that they do not want pictures of their three children - Euan, Nicky, 14, and Kathryn, 11 - published without their permission. Downing Street reiterated the message last year after announcing that Mrs Blair, 45, was expecting another child.

In its defence, the Daily Sport argued that the Mistletoe Ball had become a regular event for newspapers and photographic agencies who attended by invitation.

The editor in chief, Tony Livesey, who offered a penalty shoot-out with the prime minister's spokesman Alastair Campbell to settle the dispute, said after publication: "In my opinion these pictures don't break the code. They were taken in a public place, and quite a few other kids were there. We haven't intruded on the boy's privacy, nor on that of his parents. The pictures showed a healthy young man having fun and indulging in normal behaviour."

The picture of Euan was under the headline: "Go on my son, Blair junior snogs at Bra 'n Bare Bums Ball".

The Blairs last night thanked newspapers which had decided not to use the photographs.
