webTitle: Lennon did not give cash to IRA, says Yoko

fields.headline: Lennon did not give cash to IRA, says Yoko
fields.trailText: Yoko Ono, widow of the former Beatle John Lennon, has been quick to deny reports that her late husband helped fund the IRA. That was not true, she said, but he did send money to Ireland.
fields.body:
Yoko Ono, widow of the former Beatle John Lennon, has been quick to deny reports that her late husband helped fund the IRA. That was not true, she said, but he did send money to Ireland.

Ono said the musician sent money to many countries, including Ireland, but that it was intended for "children, orphans and women in need."

At an exhibition of her art works in the northern Spanish city of Zaragoza, she said: "My husband did not give money to the IRA. My husband gave money... when it was asked for by people who were in need."

Her denial comes after the Observer reported on Sunday that former MI5 intelligience officer David Shayler said he had seen files which claim that Lennon helped to fund the Workers Revolutionary Party in Britain, paying £46,000 to the Trotskyist group.

Ono shared her husband's views on pacifism, and the couple famously appeared naked in bed in a protest for peace.

"Even in the 1960s, I did not believe that violence was a way of getting things," she said.

The disclosures about Lennon's possible links with the IRA came after a US court order last weekend ordering the FBI to release two letters and notes from a phone conversation, which has raised the possibility that other secret files on Lennon may now be released.

It was prompted by a 17-year campaign by the author and historian John Wiener, who tabled a legal request three years after Lennon's murder in 1980 for all US government documents on him.

MI5 sent a file on Lennon to the FBI after the Nixon administration ordered an investigation into the former Beatle, who became a vocal opponent of the Vietnam war after moving to the US in the early 1970s.

Mr Shayler said British security service files also said Lennon gave money to the official IRA, before it split in the early 1970s, when the Provisional IRA was formed.

Lennon participated in Troops Out marches in Britain. After Bloody Sunday on January 30, 1972, Lennon said: "If it's a choice between the IRA and the British army, I am with the IRA."

Shortly afterwards, at a rally organised by the US Transport Workers Union attended by members of the IRA, Lennon issued a statement saying he was protesting "against the killing of Irish people in the civil rights movement".

Later that year he wrote the song, The Luck Of The Irish, dedicated to the victims of Bloody Sunday. The song appeared on the album Sometime in New York City, and proceeds were donated to the Irish civil rights movement.

webTitle: Sell your home 'in days' by computer

fields.headline: Sell your home 'in days' by computer
fields.trailText: The time it takes to buy and sell a home could be dramatically cut from about three months to a matter of days under government plans to introduce conveyancing by computer.
fields.body:
The time it takes to buy and sell a home could be dramatically cut from about three months to a matter of days under government plans to introduce conveyancing by computer.

The documents which transfer the title to the property will be replaced by a few strokes of the keyboard and a national database of land information will give instant access to information which is now collected laboriously by correspondence.

The electronic communications bill, which will receive its second reading in the Lords today, will pave the way for the abolition of ancient property laws and bring conveyancing from the 19th to the 21st century.

Laws which now require contracts for the sale of land and deeds conveying land to be in writing and signed, and deeds to be witnessed by a third party, will be repealed. These requirements date back to 1677 and 1845.

A nationwide electronic database, with input from local authorities, public utilities and others involved in the process will be set up to allow the searches and other inquiries now done by post to be processed by computer in a fraction of the time.

The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, said: "The government is committed to creating confidence in the use of IT so as to make electronic conveyancing a reality.

"By cutting the time of individual transactions, the time taken for chains could reduce dramatically. The technology could enable bottlenecks to be identified and show what has to happen to clear them."

Ministers hope electronic conveyancing will become the norm, but those who want to use the traditional method will be free to do so.

The lengthy process of conveyancing in England and Wales encourages tactics such as gazumping - sellers backing out when they get a higher offer - because the contract only becomes binding several weeks into the process after lengthy inquiries.

A single database for local searches and other inquiries could cut the process by weeks.

A pilot scheme is underway in Bristol to test the feasibility of sellers providing a pack with completed searches, rather than leaving it to the buyer.

If this goes ahead, the pack could be provided electronically.

The land registry already has a database of registered titles for 15m properties, which can be searched online. Under the plans, a property's new ownership would be registered without the need for paper.

The lord chancellor's de partment said draft rules to abolish the need for written contracts would be published later this year, with legislation planned for the end of the year.

But time would be needed for creation of a national electronic database of land information with comprehensive online search facilities. There was "a long way to go."

The adoption of the new technology by professionals and financial institutions would also take time. But the government was "determined to foster an environment in which electronic communication will flourish".

fields.headline: Labour arms shares listed
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour Party, the Church of England, health trusts and a range of charities - including the Royal Opera House - are continuing to invest tens of millions of pounds in weapons companies, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The Labour Party, the Church of England, health trusts and a range of charities - including the Royal Opera House - are continuing to invest tens of millions of pounds in weapons companies, according to figures released yesterday.

Companies in which they hold shares include Britain's main arms manufacturers such as BAe Systems, GKN, GEC, Vickers, and Hunting, makers of the cluster bomb, the Campaign Against the Arms Trade has claimed in a report published on the internet.

It said the Labour Party had more than 45,000 shares in both GEC and Vickers. Labour-controlled Edinburgh council had hundreds of thousands of shares in BAe, GKN, GEC, Rolls-Royce and Racal. Other councils with large investments in big defence companies included Rhondda, Bradford, Derbyshire, Devon, South Yorkshire, Wolverhampton, Lambeth and Islington.

The pension fund of Unison, the public service union, had large shareholdings in BAe and GEC.

The Church Commissoners and Central Board of Finance of the Church of England - which last year sold its shares in BAe because of ethical considerations - still had more than 2m shares in GKN and GEC, the report said.

The Leukaemia Research Fund had shares in BAe and GEC and the Children's Society in BAe. Other health-related organisations with shareholdings in BAe and GEC included Bolton hospice, Liverpool health authority and the Bradford hospital NHS trust.

The Universities Superannuation Scheme, the Cooperative Insurance Society and the Mineworkers' Pension Scheme had thousands of shares in Hunting, as did the Transport Hospital Fund trustees.

The Royal Opera House had 10,000 in GKN.

The campaign said yesterday such shareholdings continued despite government support for ethical investment.

fields.headline: Clinton pardons Labour MP's father
fields.trailText: The father of Oona King, Labour MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, was last night granted a "full and unconditional pardon" by President Clinton almost 40 years after refusing to serve in the United States armed forces.
fields.body:
The father of Oona King, Labour MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, was last night granted a "full and unconditional pardon" by President Clinton almost 40 years after refusing to serve in the United States armed forces.

Preston King, a professor at the University of Lancaster, fled the US after his local draft board refused to call him "mister" in a racial snub. He had refused to take an army physical examination until the members of the all-white draft board in Albany, Georgia, addressed him as "mister".

Mr King was sentenced to 18 months in prison on a conviction of draft evasion.

The White House said last night that he had been given a pardon on his draft evasion conviction, which would allow him to return to the US for the funeral of his brother later this week. Jim Kennedy, a White House spokesman, said: "President Clinton took into account the entire record _ and came to the conclusion that clemency was warranted."

Several prominent Americans had called for Mr King's pardon, as did the judge who presided over his case in 1961.

Former US representative, Elizabeth Holtzman, of New York, said: "Preston King was like Rosa Parks. He challenged government racism and he paid a huge price and finally he can come home."

Clennon L King, a nephew of Preston, said the pardon righted an old wrong.

Preston King had wanted to take a doctorate at the London School of Economics but the draft board ended the student deferrals that had allowed him to pursue a master's degree at the school. Mr King said that the board stopped addressing him as mister after learning that he was black.

He now carries an Australian passport, is a professor of political philosophy at Lancaster and has held academic posts in several other countries. His daughter Oona, 32, has made her mark as a fierce campaigner for human rights, the Third World and Europe.

fields.headline: Hague U-turn on pensions
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague followed Michael Portillo's example yesterday by embarking on a personal U-turn when he ditched one of his central policies introduced during his brief spell as a social security minister in the mid 1990s.
fields.body:
William Hague followed Michael Portillo's example yesterday by embarking on a personal U-turn when he ditched one of his central policies introduced during his brief spell as a social security minister in the mid 1990s.

In a speech in London, the Tory leader said the government should radically alter a ruling - which he hailed in 1995 as "fair and realistic" - to make it easier for pension funds to invest in venture capital businesses.

Labour was delighted by Mr Hague's speech to the British Venture Capital Association, which appeared to have been inspired by Peter Mandelson. In one of his last speeches as trade and industry secretary - delivered to the same audience in 1998 - Mr Mandelson also called for more pension funds to invest in venture capital businesses.

But Mr Hague went a few steps further when he called for changes to the minimum funding requirement, which he introduced in 1995 to protect pension funds from a future Robert Maxwell. Mr Hague said that the requirement was now outdated because it acted as a "direct disincentive" to pension funds investing in venture capital.

A Labour spokesman said yesterday: "William Hague clearly does not know whether he is coming or going. He has forgotten what he introduced in government and now appears to be backing Peter Mandelson's policy. We know that Michael Portillo is breathing over his shoulder but this is ridiculous."

Within days of being appointed as shadow chancellor, Mr Portillo ended the Tories' opposition to the minimum wage and to the independence of the Bank of England. Mr Portillo also offered less than enthusiastic support for Mr Hague's "tax guarantee" under which the Tories pledged to cut taxes as a proportion of national income.

fields.headline: Suffer the children
fields.trailText: Panorama
fields.body:
The biggest children's hospital in Europe, Alder Hey, has another boast. It's also the biggest collector of dead baby's organs: removed without permission while parents are still demented with grief; stored in plastic pots and marked - nice touch this - C257, C258. C259.

At the close of last night's Panorama (BBC1) the parents gathered in a huge, echoey chamber to ask what had happened to their C257 and C258. The camera never showed us who they were asking. Maybe it was a blank wall.

When Janet found out, by phone, that they'd "totally mutilated" her child, her natural instincts were to go to the churchyard. "I couldn't believe how I'd been going every week, putting flowers on the grave, and to find out half my child was still in hospital." Pauline couldn't afford to bury her baby, so the hospital said they'd "take care of it". Her son was dropped into a jar of preserving solution and sat on a shelf for 11 years. When Pauline found out, she asked if she could "say her final goodbyes". The pathologist told her "it'd be better if you remembered him as he was. You wouldn't recognise him now."

The pain of the parents made you want to punch the television. Alder Hey wouldn't take part in the film, so you didn't have the satisfaction of putting a face to the callous, butchering stupidity of the hospital. Instead, we had the complex character of Professor Dick Van Velzen, the Dutch pathologist who removed the organs of 845 children, the man who became an evil Mengele figure to the tabloids when the story broke, yet - ironically - helped bring this macabre, Victorian practice to public attention.

Velzen was expertly handled in the film. At first, he was drawn as a cool, scalpel-wielding monster: "Organs could be removed from dead babies at leisure", he said of the procedure. As a "researcher", he was expected "to hand organs over to the hospital: untouched, unopened, untampered with. This was a situation I didn't like."

If murderers become indifferent to the pain they inflict, what happens to doctors immunised from human suffering? Velzen betrayed no emotion, a stock phrase of the court journalist, and was riveting viewing: not for what he had done, but for how clinically honest he was about the whole sorry process.

Hospitals throughout Britain keep "cardiac collections" of babies' organs, he said. Stockpiles of spleens, kidneys and "whole systems" build up in basement corridors, never used for research (the excuse given for removing the organs in the first place). No one cares, except the parents, left waiting in a drafty hall for someone to answer their questions.

Like Panorama, Diet Diaries (C4) captured human pain and pinned it like a butterfly. The film showed the video diaries of seven studiedly unstereotypical people with food disorders. Strangely, the women were all called Sarah. Put next to one another, they acted like a time and motion study in human decline, chained to a cycle of binge and purge.

"That's a whole Asda coffee cake about to come up", Sarah Number 1 said. "God, I'm a useless waste of human life." She looked so tired, perched mechanically over the toilet with two fingers down her throat. "It wrecks your throat, rots your teeth and makes your gums bleed. Is there no end to the glamour?"

Sarah Number 2 had the parchment face of an 80-year-old woman. How old was she? It was impossible to say. "I'm ageing like crazy because of lack of nutrition", she said. Sitting in her Alice In Wonderland armchair, bony arms dwarfed by the armrests, eating her Alice In Wonderland-sized Rivita, you wondered what had happened.

Talking heads kept appearing to state the thesis of their book, but none of them could touch the strange reality of the anorexic. By the end, the truth seemed more elusive than at the beginning.

Anthony was a 60-year-old man who had become incontinent as a result of a failed operation "between the legs- they severed a muscle in my anus. It made me loathe food, this stuff coming out of me." Anthony could only cope by eating one food at a time - for months, sometimes years, on end.

First, it was cheese omelettes . "When cheese omelettes were coming to an end, I started on strawberries." But the strawberry season was also ending, and Anthony began to panic. He went to the supermarket to "find a new food" and began to cry in the aisle. It would have been funny, if it hadn't been so tragic. "I can't eat these strawberries," he told his wife. "They're from Scotland."

If murderers become indifferent to the pain they inflict, what happens to doctors immunised from human suffering? Velzen betrayed no emotion, a stock phrase of the court journalist, and was riveting viewing: not for what he had done, but for how clinically honest he was about the whole sorry process. Hospitals throughout Britain keep "cardiac collections" of babies' organs, he said. Stockpiles of spleens, kidneys and "whole systems" build up in basement corridors, never used for research (the excuse given for removing the organs in the first place). No one cares, except the parents, left waiting in a drafty hall for someone to answer their questions. Like Panorama, Diet Diaries (C4) captured human pain and pinned it like a butterfly. The film showed the video diaries of seven studiedly unstereotypical people with food disorders. Strangely, the women were all called Sarah. Put next to one another, they acted like a time and motion study in human decline, chained to a cycle of binge and purge. "That's a whole Asda coffee cake about to come up", Sarah Number 1 said. "God, I'm a useless waste of human life." She looked so tired, perched mechanically over the toilet with two fingers down her throat. "It wrecks your throat, rots your teeth and makes your gums bleed. Is there no end to the glamour?" Sarah Number 2 had the parchment face of an 80-year-old woman. How old was she? It was impossible to say. "I'm ageing like crazy because of lack of nutrition", she said. Sitting in her Alice In Wonderland armchair, bony arms dwarfed by the armrests, eating her Alice In Wonderland-sized Rivita, you wondered what had happened. Talking heads kept appearing to state the thesis of their book, but none of them could touch the strange reality of the anorexic. By the end, the truth seemed more elusive than at the beginning. Anthony was a 60-year-old man who had become incontinent as a result of a failed operation "between the legs- they severed a muscle in my anus. It made me loathe food, this stuff coming out of me." Anthony could only cope by eating one food at a time - for months, sometimes years, on end. First, it was cheese omelettes . "When cheese omelettes were coming to an end, I started on strawberries." But the strawberry season was also ending, and Anthony began to panic. He went to the supermarket to "find a new food" and began to cry in the aisle. It would have been funny, if it hadn't been so tragic. "I can't eat these strawberries," he told his wife. "They're from Scotland."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Armageddon (Michael Bay, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier

Doomsday scenario: an asteroid the size of Texas is headed for earth: send for top driller Bruce Willis and his bunch of lovable roughnecks to save the day. Among them is Steve Buscemi's standard weirdo and Ben Affleck, a son-in-waiting, in love with Brucie's daughter, Liv Tyler. They may be the wrong stuff, but Nasa man Billy Bob Thornton has them make like astronauts, land on the rock and bore nuclear-bomb holes into it. Awesome effects, incredibly loud (EVERYONE SHOUTS. ALL THE TIME), presided over by Willis, playing it so straight he must be kidding. Isn't he?

The Exterminating Angel (Luis Buñuel, 1962) 10.30pm, FilmFour

The bourgeoisie gather for a dinner party and are having an absolutely lovely time, until they realise that some strange force is preventing them going home. That force is, of course, the surrealist Buñuel, who having rudely interrupted the party, presides over the collapse of civilisation as all etiquette flies out the dining room window. Brilliantly black comedy.

The Gingerbread Man (Robert Altman, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier

Robert Altman directing an adaptation of a John Grisham tale would appear to be a recipe for slick suspense, but somehow The Gingerbread Man fails to get the pulse racing. Kenneth Branagh stars as a hotshot southern attorney who becomes embroiled in a judicial tangle - a hobo father, Robert Duvall, is menacing his own daughter. That there is more to the case than meets the eye is lazily apparent, but the Branagh character can't see it, showing a lack of basic common sense, let alone legal nous, charging into thriller-by-numbers set pieces in which his children are in danger, etc. Crassly conservative and misogynistic, it's almost fascinating - for all the wrong reasons.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
One of those extraordinarily indomitable Victorian women is the subject of the Afternoon Play. The Mantle Of The Earth (2.15pm, Radio 4) draws on the diaries of the artist Marianne North, who reacted to the death of her adored father by touring the world for the rest of her life, painting flowers and wildlife. More than 800 of her works, from places as separate as Sarawak, South Africa, and Brazil, are now housed at Kew Gardens.

Brighton's West Pier was another indomitable Victorian enterprise, built to let the nobs have the sensation of owning a yacht without the expense or discomfort. Down the years a succession of entertainments was added. Finally came com plete democratisation in the 1950s when the pier became a funfair, until changing tastes put it out of business in 1975. In Not The End Of The Pier Show (9.0pm, Radio 2) Pete McCarthy looks back on its history - and the brave plan to refurbish it.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Watch this The Antiques Show 8pm, BBC2
The magazine series returns, beginning with a pleasant amble down Irish country lanes as Tim Wonnacott gets to grips with the often whimsical way the Irish buy antiques. (Either they're playing up to the camera, or they really do clinch deals with the toss of a coin.) Fiona Bruce reports on the revival of British folk art, enjoyed more by Americans, and Madeleine Marsh visits a stunning Art Deco house, where the look has been much copied but not bettered.

Ape-Man 9pm, BBC2
According to experts, the enigmatic cave paintings made by our Ice Age ancestors are more than merely primitive drawings of animals and the like, as revealed in the opener of this six-part series exploring human evolution. Studying daubs in France and South Africa, scientists have strikingly concluded that the artists were in a trance-like state.

The Secret World Of Year 3 9.50pm, BBC2

The big step from infant to junior school is captured in this three-part series following a group of seven-year-olds in Peterborough. The children's tiny dramas, mainly about friendships, are magnified with restraint, sympathy and poignancy.

Queer As Folk 2 10pm, C4
The glitzy story of Manchester's fun-loving boys hurtles along at breakneck speed to its conclusion, but not before Stuart is given a few obvious hints that, really, all this hedonism is getting to be a trifle undignified for someone his age.

fields.headline: Shepherd without a flock
fields.standfirst:
People are leaving the Church of England in droves. Who is to blame? Step forward George Carey, the dithering cleric whose public pronouncements manage both to be bland and to offend. In the wake of the news that the Queen wants him to stay on, Andrew Brown examines how the Archbishop of Canterbury lost the plot
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: People are leaving the Church of England in droves. Who is to blame? Step forward George Carey, the dithering cleric whose public pronouncements manage both to be bland and to offend. In the wake of the news that the Queen wants him to stay on,  Andrew Brown  examines how the Archbishop of Canterbury lost the plot
fields.body:
George Carey is back in the news for two reasons. On Friday, he preached a lecture at Essex university which appeared to demand that politicians refrain from sex outside marriage, on pain of punishment by the media; and yesterday he let it be known, semi-officially, that he plans to remain in office for another three years, at the personal request of the Queen. She is, after all, one of the few figures in public life who both subscribes to and lives up to the traditional Christian morality he preaches. But the problem for the archbishop is not really that society as a whole has abandoned traditional Christian sexual morality; it is that most Christians have abandoned it too.

Fifty years ago it was clear that the church stood for lifelong marriage, patriarchy, and heterosexuality. It is still retreating from all these positions, but at different speeds in different places; and the strains of this disjointed retreat are breaking up all the structures on which Dr Carey's prestige depends.

He has been in office for 10 years now, and will probably stay for another five. There is some evidence that the hard core of support in the Church of England has stayed steady in his time in office: the number of people taking out covenants to their local churches has remained level at about 400,000. But every other number tells a story of brisk decline. The number of Anglican Sunday churchgoers has fallen - on official figures - from 1.14m to 950,000; of those that are left, perhaps 10% refuse to recognise women priests, and most of this minority consider themselves out of communion with Dr Carey, and would not accept the sacramental bread and wine from his hands. They are organised into Forward in Faith, a sort of church within the church, which has its own bishops, priests, and parishes. All it really shares with the official body is a pension fund, (though that is a powerful force for unity.)

The net effect of this is that the number of people obliged to take notice of the Archbishop of Canterbury's opinions has shrunk by about a fifth since he took office. The church will also lose a third of its bishops in the House of Lords; at the same time, Tony Blair, who actually appoints the bishops, has treated some of Dr Carey's nominations with unprecedented contempt. The hysteria when Princess Diana died was a great spontaneous uprush of religious feeling - but instead of showing that England was ready for a Christian revival, it showed that folk religion today has almost nothing to do with Christianity. The contempt with which the BBC treats religious broadcasting does not arouse protests from anyone except the General Synod.

Not much of this decline in power and influence is Dr Carey's fault. Much of it could be blamed on wider changes in European society which no church leader knows how to handle. But what he could make worse by his public performances, he has. He was probably the only man in English public life who thought it was a really cool thing to be associated with the dome, and struggled hard to be associated as prominently as possible with the opening ceremonies, where his performance was squirm-inducing. But so it had been, too, at the funeral of Diana; while his earlier clumsy attempts to mediate in the royal marriage had earned the distrust and dislike of both parties.

In small groups, and sticking to a script he has prepared, he can be forceful and convincing. But when ever he improvises in front of a microphone the results are disastrous. The Daily Mail, which ought to be a natural ally, gave up on him after one particularly pompous and uncertain performance on the Today programme. The only journalists who have written with informed admiration of him are those who have watched him behaving like a vicar, not an archbishop.

There is a rather bitter irony to all this. One of Dr Carey's constant themes, as anyone who has reached the last few pages of any his speeches will know, is that a great evil of our age is what he calls "the privatisation of religion". Yet throughout his career Christianity has drifted further and further from the mainstream of English public life until we now have an exceptionally religious prime minister who takes great care to keep his Christian beliefs private. And the organisational reforms into which Carey has put huge efforts have all tended to separate the Church of England from the other institutions with which it was entwined, such as parliament; and to make it into a distinct organisation run like a modern company, with bishops chosen for their managerial skills.

The old church had conspicuous palaces it could not afford to run. The new church has bishops who live in modern executive-style homes and whose average mobile phone bill is £3,000 a year; it advertises for dioce san spin doctors at a salary of £40,000 to work with a "communications department" which suppressed its membership figures when they looked bad.

It used to be said that the church was the only institution which existed primarily for the benefit of non-members. But this was an attitude which relied on a clergy who felt themselves part of the society around them and who were paid by the historic assets of the church, irrespective of their measurable performance. Now that the funds of the church go almost entirely to its pensions, the priests are paid fairly directly by their congregations.

To be a practising Christian means increas ingly to be one who pays for the church, and this tends to sharpen the sense of commitment and separation from the outside world that congregations feel. This means every move towards acceptance of secular morality on such issues as the equality of women (a real problem for conservative evangelicals) and the remarriage of divorcees in church has to be balanced by some move to show that Christians are different and better; and that usually means being clear about the awfulness of gays.

The battles over homosexuality that have continued throughout Dr Carey's period in office have been almost unique to the Anglican Communion. No other church has contin ued to fight the same battle for so long. One side or the other has elsewhere won fairly quickly. But in the Church of England and the wider Anglican Communion made up of the worldwide federation of churches, nothing ever seems to change. The two sides are locked in endless, unedifying combat.

One reason is the sheer number of gay clergy in the Church of England and their seniority. The evangelicals may wish to be rid of them; and can certainly enforce public standards of marriage, celibacy, or at least discretion. But they have an awful lot of people to police. When Dr Carey took over the church some of its most senior bureaucrats were gay; one of his first episcopal appointments was an early victim of Outrage! and the (married) bishop he chose to remodel the church's government has a conviction for cottaging. The Archbishop of York famously declared to the BBC that his own sexuality was "a grey area". No wonder Dr Carey felt obliged to oppose section 28 and the lowering of the age of consent. Within the diocese of London, about a quarter of the priests are reckoned to be gay. It is no doubt a coincidence that London is one of the few dioceses where churchgoing is actually on the increase.

It is also the diocese where the resistance to women priests is most concentrated. The Bishop of London, Richard Chartres, will not himself ordain women. And the battle over gays cannot be understood without understanding what a trauma the ordination of women was for the Church of England. Though there were issues of high principle involved, both sides in that battle privately liked to blame their opponents' intransigence on a homosexual agenda. "Women at the altar and boys in bed" is how one leading Anglo-Catholic bishop sums up the liberal programme; but many of the women priests regarded their opponents, with equal justice, as a bunch of hysterical old queens.

So to many evangelicals, resistance to gay clergy was an essential trade-off for their support of women priests. In this country women bishops are still prohibited by law, but in America, where there have been women bishops for 10 years, the battle over gay clergy has become the last ditch for conservatives to fight in. The American civil war, in which the Southern, conservative side has summoned help from African and Asian evangelicals, has now destroyed any pretence that there is such a thing as an "Anglican Communion", which allows Dr Carey to call himself a world spiritual leader.

There are supposed to be 80m Anglicans around the world who follow him, or as he told the United Nations once in a moment of unforgettably comic self-importance, "I want to put it to you that the worldwide Anglican Communion - which numbers over 70m people and is growing fast - has very great potential as a player on the international scene" It turns out that 25m of Dr Carey's followers are supposed to be found in England, a statistic reached by counting everyone in this country who was baptised Anglican and is not yet dead.

Still, even if there are only 50m Anglicans around the world, that would be a powerful number if they were united about anything much. But the deep and bitter divisions over homosexuality came to a head last month in a curiously furtive ceremony in Singapore Cathedral when the Archbishops of Rwanda and Singapore consecrated a couple of "missionary bishops" for American congregations who will preach the pure word of hostility to gays. This is simple and formal schism, a declaration that they belong to a different church from that of the bishops of the official Anglican body.

The joke is that Dr Carey's instincts are entirely on the side of the schismatics. His son Andrew is deputy editor of the Church of England Newspaper, a tiny weekly which is the house organ of the anti-gay forces. When the archbishop last week released a formal letter explaining that he cannot recognise the new bishops, it contained a passage suggesting that even though he must officially reprimand them, he would do so with his fingers crossed: "I do not question... their own perception that the situation in the United States is so serious that this action could be justified."

But here, as elsewhere, he can't be the decisive leader he pretends to be. To repudiate the official, liberal church in America would have the immediate effect of breaking up and probably bankrupting the Anglican Communion, just as a hard line on divorce and second marriages would drive numerous faithful Christians out of the church.

fields.headline: Josef Herman
fields.standfirst: Artist from Warsaw who captured the essence of labour on paper and canvas
fields.trailText: The artist Josef Herman, who has died aged 89, overcame barriers of nationality and religion to capture the essence of the British working man. He made the most mundane subject significant by depth of feeling.
fields.body:
The artist Josef Herman, who has died aged 89, overcame barriers of nationality and religion to capture the essence of the British working man. He made the most mundane subject significant by depth of feeling.

While best known for his portrayal of Welsh miners, his subject matter was much broader: the Mexican peasant, the Burgundy grape picker, or the Scottish and Suffolk fishermen were just as important. So were Notting Hill Carnival revellers, Wimbledon tennis players, world cup footballers, London children and, most recently and importantly, trees and birds.

His journey from the Warsaw slums through Brussels, Glasgow, Ystradgynlais, Suffolk and London is recorded in his marvellous autobiography, Related Twilights. Writing was another skill he mastered.

Herman's central theme was working men: the eternal ritual of labour. Although his brushwork was always broad, paying little attention to detail, he captured the essence of his sitters, the sacred ritual of work, and by concentrating on a single figure, he gave it what he called an "essence of all to capture the universal in the particular - the frieze of life".

His palette was rich, going from luminous reds and glowing oranges to blues of stained glass vividness, strong vibrant yellow and ochre, and the sweeping browns of anthracite coal. His output consisted primarily of works on paper - inkwashes, drawings and watercolours - for, starting at 4 or 5am daily he spent at least four hours sketching.

His paintings form a self-sufficient, separate body of work, a distillation of ideas from sketches, created very slowly, each layer sealed before the next coat of paint was applied. "Drawing is action," he said, "painting is meditation."

His deep human insight made him a distinguished portraitist, often overlooked. Commissions were rare, and nearly all his sitters were friends, including Arnold Wesker (the only one at the National Portrait Gallery so far) and Wolf Mankowitz.

An important influence, a collection of African wooden tribal sculpture, was started after the encouragement of his great friend, Jacob Epstein. Their simplicity, the elimination of facial features, and the depersonalisation of the figures had echoes in his work. In 1985, the Arts Council organised an exhibition with 50 of his drawings accompanied by 50 pieces from his tribal art collection.

Born in Warsaw, Herman's childhood was one of appalling poverty. Trained as a typesetter from the age of 13, he had to abandon this career because of lead poisoning, and earned his living as a book designer - a skill he practised and loved to the end.

The itch to paint prevailed and, after evening courses and 18 months at the Warsaw Academy, he had his first solo exhibition in 1932. He be came involved with politically committed artists, joined their "Phrygian Bonnet" group, and spent summers with them in the Carpathian mountains recording peasants' lives in an expressionist style.

In 1938, Herman left Warsaw and went to Brussels to be in the land of his beloved Flemish painters. Two years later, with the approaching German invasion, he escaped first to France and then, in 1940, arrived in Britain, and was sent to Glasgow.

Lonely and isolated, he poured himself into a visual diary of his childhood, capturing the fabric of that distant life and family. These works were discovered by him many years later and I was fortunate in being able to organise immediately the Memory of Memories exhibition in London and Glasgow. The only person with whom he could share the tragedy of having lost his entire immediate and extended family was the painter Yankel Adler, then also in Glasgow.

After a spell in London, where he had a 1943 exhibition with LS Lowry, Herman was discovered by the owners of a Cork Street Gallery, Roland Browse and Delbanco, with whom he was associated for 35 years.

A landmark in his life was a holiday trip to Ystradgynlais in south Wales, where he was immediately at home with its closely knit mining community. He lived at the Pen Y Bont inn and, six years later, bought a derelict factory that he converted into a studio and living space. He stayed in Wales for 11 years.

In 1951, Herman was commissioned to paint a mural, Miners (now at Cardiff's Museum of Wales in Cardiff), for the Festival of Britain.

His fame gradually grew and in 1952 he joined the London Group. During the next two decades he had a string of one-man exhibitions, displays and retrospectives, including Leicester and York (1953), Wakefield (1955), the Whitechapel Gallery in London and the Auckland Gallery in New Zealand (1956), Melbourne (1957), Frankfurt and Sheffield (1958), Bradford (1959) and Swansea (1963). Dresden, Toronto and Montreal also hosted solo exhibitions, while galleries in Britain and abroad started to acquire his work. The Tate Gallery owns many drawings by him and some of his best paintings.

Herman became somewhat marginalised during the late 1960s and 1970s. He had a third retrospective exhibition in 1975 at the Glasgow Museum and Art Gallery, and in 1976 his fourth and most important at the Camden Art Centre.

He is survived by his wife, Nini Ettlinger, one son and a daughter, his other daughter having predeceased him.

webTitle: FBI to fight Russian mob in Hungary

fields.headline: FBI to fight Russian mob in Hungary
fields.trailText: In a move that underlines the growing concern in the United States about Russian organised crime, the FBI is setting up its first office abroad in which its agents will serve as full-time investigators.
fields.body:
In a move that underlines the growing concern in the United States about Russian organised crime, the FBI is setting up its first office abroad in which its agents will serve as full-time investigators.

The office opens next month in Budapest, which is home to many Russian mafia leaders, who see the Hungarian capital as a well-situated portal to western Europe and the US.

"This will be truly a working squad," said Thomas Fuentes, chief of the FBI's organised-crime division. "They will develop and operate criminal informants. They will gather intelligence. There is no precedent for that."

The Hungarian government has requested help from the US in breaking up the Russian gangs that operate from Budapest. But by allowing the bureau to open a fully functioning office, Hungary has ceded more sovereignty than many other nations - the US included - would ever consider, US officials say.

FBI agents will have the right to carry weapons and, in conjunction with their Hungarian counterparts, to make arrests. The FBI will also have the final say in the hiring and firing of the 10 Hungarian agents who will work in the office alongside five US agents.

The bureau has long had agents posted in US embassies. It has also sent agents abroad temporarily to help foreign governments with major criminal investigations, as it did after the 1998 bombings of US embassies in Africa.

The push to set up a Budapest office has come from the FBI's organised-crime section and from the US embassy in Hungary.

Officials have had to overcome the concerns of some at the US state department that an armed clash between FBI agents and criminals could create an international incident.

The Hungarians, too, remain wary. It was only last week that the Hungarians and Americans reached agreement on sharing criminal intelligence. The Hungarians fear that highly sensitive evidence gathered by criminal investigators about the Russian mobs could be made public in US courts.

US officials say that if the FBI office in Budapest succeeds, it could be a model for similar offices in other regions struggling against Russian organised crime, including the Baltic states, Nigeria and South Africa.

One early target of the FBI's Budapest office is expected to be Semyon Mogilevich, a Russian who has operated out of Budapest for a decade. The FBI says Mr Mogilevich has engaged in trafficking of drugs, refugees and weapons, has run prostitution rings and has tortured and murdered his opponents. His lawyer denies that his client has committed any crime.

"Our objective is to strangle the Russian mafia that operates here," said the US ambassador in Hungary, Peter Tufo, who has been an enthusiastic advocate of the FBI's war on the Russian mafia.

He said that the Russian mob was a global operation reaching from Moscow to Budapest to New York, Los Angeles and Miami. "It's a multi-billion-dollar global enterprise."

Another major Russian crime group, the Solntsevskaya organisation, has stepped up its operations out of Budapest, Mr Tufo said.

An FBI report in 1995 described the Solntsevskaya organisation as the most powerful Eurasian organised-crime organisation "in the world in terms of wealth, influence and financial control".

Mr Fuentes said the bureau was prepared for criticism from some quarters that the FBI should concentrate on combating crime at home. But he said the activities of the Russian mob were "a direct threat to us".
New York Times

fields.headline: New York awaits judgment day
fields.standfirst:
Gun violence in America: special report

Policing methods in the dock along with four officers accused of murdering an unarmed man
fields.trailText: A jury's verdict this week in the case of four white policemen accused of murdering a young black street trader last February in the Bronx will be treated as a referendum on law enforcement in America's biggest city.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in Albany, New York
fields.body:
A jury's verdict this week in the case of four white policemen accused of murdering a young black street trader last February in the Bronx will be treated as a referendum on law enforcement in America's biggest city.

The name of Amadou Diallo, an immigrant from West Africa, would never have been known outside his immediate circle had he not been hit by 19 of the 41 police bullets fired at him in the entrance to his block of flats in New York.

But in the year since the shooting of Diallo, who was armed only with a wallet and a pager, the case has come to represent for New Yorkers the trade-off between crime-fighting and discrimination.

"It's tough being black in the United States," said Stephen Worth, a lawyer who is defending one of the four police officers. He is not referring to the fate of Diallo, 22. Rather, he is considering the chances of the county court jury in the state capital of Albany delivering a verdict of not guilty.

"The black jurors got to go back to their neighbourhoods and maybe answer for clearing white cops," said Mr Worth, after another day in court. "It's about what the jury believes," he added. "They killed the wrong guy. We don't deny that. But these are good lads."

Most mornings this month the four have trudged past ranks of cameras to enter the courthouse. Police guarding the building - some of them black - acknowledge their arrival with handshakes. Albany is 160 miles north of New York, but this is still the thin blue line in action, a camaraderie that is part of the mythology which, depending on the beholder, earns New York City policemen praise or derision as racists in and out of uniform.

The reason is plain enough. Crime in the city has plummeted in the past 10 years, with murders down from 2,245 in 1990 to 667 last year. But it took the death of Diallo, an immigrant from Guinea, to crystalise discontent at police methods.

Critics claim that, at its simplest, the policy of "zero tolerance"- cracking down on petty offences in the hope of discouraging more serious crimes - means searching blacks and Hispanics in the hope of finding firearms. Much of this work is done by the plainclothes special crimes unit, to which the four men on trial belonged.

The fall in crime figures allows New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, to boast: "New York is the safest city in America with a population of more than a million." But in a city where ethnic minorities account for more than 60% of residents, such targeting was bound to create resentment.

A judge ruled that the policemen could not get a fair hearing in the Bronx so the trial was moved north to Albany, seat of government and home to a population of about 100,000 which is more than 80% white.

The conduct of the trial has been muted, save for the day when Sean Carroll, at 36 the oldest of the policemen, broke down in tears as he explained how he was first to open fire.

The defence says that the policemen, who were looking for a rapist, made a tragic mistake by shooting Diallo, believing that he was reaching for a gun when in fact he was pulling out his wallet. The prosecution says that the men had no good reason to open fire, shouted no warning and carried on shooting after Diallo went down.

Now the jury must select from a range of charges: from second-degree murder, which carries a maximum of 25 years to life, to criminally negligent homicide with a minimum sentence of probation.

There have been daily prayer meetings and demonstrations in Albany against the shooting, but nothing like the star power that the black activist, the Rev Al Sharpton, was able to mobilise over this case a year ago. The Rev Jesse Jackson and the film star Susan Sarandon were among the more than 1,000 people who were arrested for trespass during those protests.

These days, though Mr Sharpton is ever-present, it is generally lesser known but equally passionate protesters who are turning out. They include students, clerics, those who say they have suffered at the hands of the police and members of lobby groups.

Inside the court, a couple of dozen policemen in the public gallery, activists up from New York City, sport badges saying: "Free the Bronx Four."

Other policemen prefer to keep their heads down, but that does not mean the Diallo case has not influenced them. "Now when I hear there's a situation, I don't rush there," said one in his 40s. "Why put yourself on the line? Now I'd rather get me a doughnut and coffee."

Sympathy could hardly be expected from Diallo's mother, Kadiatou. "The fact is they have seen a dark-skinned man and they just decided to take his life." She also acts as a reminder that her son was a person, not just a cause. "He is not an immigrant," she says. "He's somebody. He's human. He has a home and a family."

The accused

Sean Carroll

Age: 36

Years on force: six

Shots fired: all 16 in pistol

Edward McMellon

Age: 27

Years on force: six

Shots fired: all 16

Kenneth Boss

Age: 28

Years on force: eight

Shots fired: five

Richard Murphy

Age: 27

Years on force: six

Shots fired: four

fields.headline: Rosemary Varney
fields.standfirst: The adventurous potter and author of a classic book in support of the hospice movement
fields.trailText: Rosemary Varney, who has died at the age of 76, was a skilled potter and author whose book, written with her first husband, Victor Zorza, after their daughter died of cancer in the mid-1970s, gave a powerful impetus to the hospice movement in its early days.
fields.body:
Rosemary Varney, who has died at the age of 76, was a skilled potter and author whose book, written with her first husband, Victor Zorza, after their daughter died of cancer in the mid-1970s, gave a powerful impetus to the hospice movement in its early days.

Called A Way To Die: Living to the End, the book's frank but tender style owed most to Rosemary. For her, the book was not inspired by missionary ambition so much as the hope that others would benefit from sharing the experience of her family. It led to many other families choosing a hospice, rather than a hospital, for their dying relatives.

A similar desire to share her insights with her readers marked her other book (two novels never found a publisher) on pottery. She wrote it as a basic introduction to a craft in which she found great joy: "We take from pottery what we need and give what we can. The incoherent can express themselves vividly through clay; the voluble learn something of silence; and the tense relax. It's all very therapeutic and fulfilling."

Rosemary's father, an interior decorator from whom she inherited her artistic talent, had been severely wounded in the first world war and never fully recovered. On the day after the second world war started, Rosemary, then only 16, abandoned her education and, lying about her age, joined the Auxiliary Territorial Service (the women's army corps). Later, she led the first group of ATS to Bari in Italy in 1944 and became a sergeant-major.

After the war, as a secretary at the BBC monitoring service at Caversham in 1948, she met Victor Zorza, who was to become the Guardian's distinguished analyst of communist affairs. With the exception of a few years in Washington when her husband went freelance, they lived in a comfortable house in Burnham. Here Rosemary created her pottery studio and tended a beautiful garden. The annual summer exhibition of her latest stoneware in this lovely setting was always a delight.

While Victor's life was dominated by the effort to explain the cold war east-west rivalry and the Kremlin's inner workings, Rosemary was an altogether gentler and more forgiving person. An ideal future might perhaps lie ahead, she joked, when the world was not divided by opposing ideologies, but simply into those who made pots and those who bought them.

In the 1980s, Victor turned his energies to India. Under the title Village Voice, he wrote about life in a peasant community in the hill country north of Delhi where he took a house. Left behind in Britain, Rosemary contracted breast cancer, had a mastectomy, and then discovered she had Parkinson's disease.

During her wartime service in Italy, she had fallen in love with a young British naval officer. But he was married, and when their units returned to Britain they parted. Now virtually abandoned for much of the year, Rosemary rediscovered her naval officer beau. Victor encouraged the friendship with Peter Varney, although in 1991, when Peter's wife died and Rosemary decided to leave Victor, it came as a great shock to him.

Rosemary lived her last eight years happily in Abingdon, although by now her Parkinson's made it impossible to continue to produce pottery. She devoted her time to enriching the circle of her friends.

She is survived by Peter Varney and her son, Richard Zorza.

fields.headline: Storms and scares ravage oyster trade
fields.trailText: Their crops savaged by winter storms and smeared by a major oil spill, battered French oyster farmers yesterday declared that without more state aid one of France's most emblematic industries could go under.
fields.body:
Their crops savaged by winter storms and smeared by a major oil spill, battered French oyster farmers yesterday declared that without more state aid one of France's most emblematic industries could go under.

"The end of last year and the beginning of this have been simply catastrophic," said Goulven Brest, president of the National Oyster-grower's Association. "There's no other word for it. Unless the government intervenes, a huge number of growers will go out of business."

The French are the world's leading per capita consumers of oysters, cracking open some 150m dozen every year. Their gourmet enthusiasm keeps 8,300 farmers in business who, between them, turn over £155m annually.

But December's storms, which wiped out up to a fifth of the Atlantic coast's 17,000 acres of oyster beds, and the wrecked tanker Erika, which began spewing about 3m gallons of heavy fuel oil on to the same coastline shortly after Christmas, have dealt devastating blows to the industry.

"The fall in demand was felt dramatically from the very first days after the Erika catastrophe in mid-December," Mr Brest said. "People automatically assumed the oysters in restaurants and their local fishmonger would be polluted, which just isn't the case."

According to France's national food safety agency, any oyster currently on sale in France is safe because it would have been removed from the open sea and placed in well protected "purification beds" long before Christmas. The main damage is to crops that would normally be harvested in two or three years' time.

The agency has taken samples from several hundred batches of oysters and found none exceeded safety limits or were unsafe for human consumption. "No French shellfish currently on the French market deserves to be withdrawn," a spokesman said. "They can be consumed as abundantly as anyone likes."

But the agency's verdict is cold comfort to the oyster farmers, who say sales of the molluscs have plummeted by 40-50% in supermarkets and up to 60% at fishmongers and restaurants since December.

"It's plain that people aren't as keen as they usually are," said Jean-Pierre Faveau, a shellfish seller at a Paris street market. "They're asking a lot more questions. They're sceptical about the quality - I'm eating a dozen of the things a day just to show they're safe."

About 400 angry growers marched on the ministry of agriculture last week to demonstrate their displeasure and demand emergency state aid. Some £30m already pledged by the government in the immediate aftermath of the oil spill is not, they say, enough.

Christian Gireaudeau, president of the local oystermen's association in Fouras-Aix near the Ile d'Oleron, said practically all of his village's beds were destroyed by the storms, leaving farmers facing zero income in 2001 and 2002.

"The younger growers, without savings to fall back on, just won't survive," he said.

webTitle: Jury still out on emission trading

fields.headline: Jury still out on emission trading
fields.trailText: Planting forests in foreign countries is one way western governments or carbon-emitting industries hope to avoid forcing people to cut back on driving cars or burning the fossil fuels that increase global warming.
fields.body:
Planting forests in foreign countries is one way western governments or carbon-emitting industries hope to avoid forcing people to cut back on driving cars or burning the fossil fuels that increase global warming.

This comes under an international system of emission trading currently being finalised. In theory, countries could meet their obligations and everyone should benefit.

If country A feels for political or other reasons it cannot meet its carbon-reduction targets as set in the Kyoto protocol of 1997, it offers country B money to plant trees that soak up the man-made carbon that is believed to be contributing to global warming.

In doing so, country A no longer has to force its residents to cut back on burning fossil fuels and country B gets a pollution "credit", which will have a market value and can be traded. The latter also gets a lot more trees, which could stimulate jobs in forestry.

Net result: the rich pay to go on polluting, the less-industrialised nations have a new way of generating revenue and nature picks up the tab.

The Australian-Japanese trees-for-credit deal is the first to be struck between countries, but it is controversial for many reasons.

For a start, say environmental organisations such as Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace, the deal has been reached before the official introduction of carbon trading rules, which are expected to get the go-ahead in November at the next climate-change meeting in The Hague, known as Conference of the Parties No. 6.

It is also the wrong approach, say the two powerful environment groups. Polluting countries and industries, they argue, should be trying to reduce their emissions, rather than paying to avoid change. They say that trading pollution may reduce the net effect of carbon emissions, but it allows people to continue to abuse energy.

"It is a very uncertain way of tackling climate change", says Frances MacGwirre, of Friends of the Earth. "Although planting trees is generally good for biodiversity, reducing soil erosion and protecting water supplies, we need to know the sort of trees that will be planted."

Ms MacGwirre also says there is no guarantee that the trees will be still be standing in 100 years when global warming is expected to be intense, and points to scientific doubts about whether forests can continue to soak up carbon.

Recent studies suggest that since global warming is accelerating, the earth could be emitting more carbon, with the result that forests could switch from being "sinks" for carbon to being sources of the pollution.

webTitle: Japan in eco-credit deal with Australia

fields.headline: Japan in eco-credit deal with Australia
fields.trailText: Australian forest authorities have been contracted to plant 40,500 hectares of trees (about 100,000 acres) on behalf of one of Japan's largest power companies in a controversial scheme to fight global warming.
fields.body:
Australian forest authorities have been contracted to plant 40,500 hectares of trees (about 100,000 acres) on behalf of one of Japan's largest power companies in a controversial scheme to fight global warming.

The trees are meant to offset some of the greenhouse gas emissions generated in Tokyo.

The Tokyo Electric Power Company signed the deal, which could cost up to £50m, with the New South Wales's forestry division to grow hard and softwood plantations to capture carbon dioxide (CO2).

But environmentalists question whether the project, scheduled to run for 10 years, will work. They claim the area is too small and that the forests must be maintained forever or the CO2 will go back into the atmosphere when the trees are processed.

The New South Wales government courted Japanese industry investment in its forests to earn lucrative credits for offsetting gas emissions, under an international scheme proposed in the 1997 Kyoto Protocol on Climate Change.

In the protocol industrialised countries agreed to reduce their 1990 level of emissions by an average of 6% by 2010. Those unable or unwilling to meet their legal obligation to reach the target would - under the credit scheme currently being finalised, though yet to be ratified by protocol signatories - have the option of paying other countries to help reduce their emissions. Planting carbon-absorbing forests would be one way to do this.

The Labor premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, an avowed environmentalist, argued: "You've got the world's biggest privately owned power utility laying out plantations in NSW to compensate for the impact of its emissions. That is a big step."

The carbon-trading scheme, once ratified, would recognise forest expansion as one way to reduce overall emissions. But environmental experts claim such finely targeted efforts will be nowhere near enough.

"It's really good that people are starting to pay attention to the issue of global warming, but they should be conscious of the fact that there is no straightforward fix," said Chris Mitchell of CSIRO, which runs the Australian government's greenhouse research programme.

Concentration was needed on "using energy efficiently, developing new energy technologies and switching to less greenhouse-intrusive fuels".

A Greenpeace spokesman, Robbie Kelman, said massive areas of tree planting would be required to compensate for Australia's 400m tonnes of annual carbon emissions.

A company might be able to offset 5% of its emissions, he said. "But to offset just one year of Australia's emissions, we have calculated it would take an area about the size of the state of Victoria [about 23m hectares] every year."

Tokyo Power estimates that the plantations could earn it about 30,000 tonnes of carbon credits annually.

From July, the Sydney Futures Exchange will start trading the carbon credits, in a bid to become the centre of that niche's global trading. But although the New South Wales government became the first to encourage carbon trading by acknowledging the legal ownership of carbon rights in 1988, there is widespread disagreement about what the real cost of carbon dioxide will be.

Although the Koyoto protocol allows companies to buy credits or earn them by undertaking climate-friendly activities, there is no incentive to in turn spend the money generated by the acquisition of listed carbon credits on environment-friendly programmes.

webTitle: Six skiers swept to deaths by alpine avalanches

fields.headline: Six skiers swept to deaths by alpine avalanches
fields.trailText: Mountain rescuer workers in Italy and Switzerland searched last night for survivors of two heavy avalanches that swept down the Alps, killing six people.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and  Peter Capella in Geneva
fields.body:
Mountain rescuer workers in Italy and Switzerland searched last night for survivors of two heavy avalanches that swept down the Alps, killing six people.

In Italy, three people died and one was suffering from severe hypothermia after a group of seven German skiers accompanied by a local guide triggered an avalanche in the Val Venosta near the Austrian border, some 50 miles from the northern city of Bolzano.

Rescue official Luigi Weger said the group, which had been on an unauthorised route, became trapped by the avalanche. Rescuers recovered the bodies of two women and one man and accounted for the remaining five skiers, he added.

The avalanche was the second to strike the province of Alto Adige in as many days: two skiers died at nearby Punta Alta Croce on Saturday.

In eastern Switzerland, three people were killed and a fourth was injured when an avalanche swept into a ski run near Davos at the height of the winter holiday season.

Police blamed the avalanche on a German man and his son who skied into an area of deep snow despite avalanche warnings. The two set off a snowslide that covered the father, along with two Swiss men skiing farther down the mountain on a prepared course. Only the son survived.

Around 100 rescuers with sniffer dogs spent seven hours searching for survivors The three skiers' bodies were recovered and police said there were no more victims.

"There was an avalanche risk today, we triggered snowslides early in the morning and we did everything we could to avoid this", Markus Good, a local official said.

Avalanches rarely hit resort areas and prosecutors have opened an investigation.

Experts warned of a serious danger of more avalanches in days to come in what for most alpine resorts is the height of the winter sports season, with schools across Europe on half-term holiday.

More than 1.5m (5ft) of snow has fallen across Europe's Alpine regions in the past three days, and yesterday's bright sunshine dramatically increased the chances of large slabs of recent powder falling away from the compacted layer underneath.

webTitle: Muslims and Christians clash in Nigeria over implementation of strict Islamic law

fields.headline: Muslims and Christians clash in Nigeria over implementation of strict Islamic law
fields.trailText: Clashes between Christians and Muslims about plans to introduce sharia law left at least eight people dead and dozens of shops burning in the Nigerian city of Kaduna yesterday.
fields.body:
Clashes between Christians and Muslims about plans to introduce sharia law left at least eight people dead and dozens of shops burning in the Nigerian city of Kaduna yesterday.

The violence came after thousands of Christians took to the streets chanting "no to sharia" amid a wave of populist sentiment in favour of imposing Islamic law across northern Nigeria, following its introduction in the state of Zamfara.

The sharia code bans alcohol, adultery and women's football teams, and segregates schools and public transport.

In recent days, Zamfara carried out its first sentences imposed under sharia, with one man receiving 100 lashes for sex with an unmarried woman and another flogged for drinking alcohol in public.

Many of the other 18 northern states, including Kaduna, are drafting similar laws despite protests from Christians and southerners who see sharia as a form of ethnic persecution.

About half of Nigeria's 100m population is Muslim, with the vast majority living in the north, where sharia has long been applied to civil and family cases. But with the return to civilian rule last year, northern politicians have made political capital from pressing for more stringent Islamic laws.

Few Christians live in Zamfara, but the numbers are much larger in politically significant northern states such as Kano, which has a long and bloody history of religious strife. The state governor and the influential emir of Kano have resisted pressure to follow Zamfara's example because they fear it will cost more lives on top of the hundreds already lost in sectarian clashes in recent years.

But the two men have come under increasing pressure from radical religious groups, such as the council of Islamic scholars, which is threatening to mobilise its considerable support in the state legislature to impeach the governor.

The prospect of sharia alarms many of the 1m Igbo and Yoruba traders who live in Kano's Sabon-Gari district, with its thousands of bars and hundreds of brothels.

"What would happen to these people if sharia is introduced? There would be a massive exodus," said a local political leader and Christian, chief Tobias Idika. But Islamic radicals, such as Sheikh Ameendeen Abubakar, say the views of outsiders are irrelevant.

"Whether they are keen or not, whether they are interested or not, sharia is our right," he said. "And if they refuse to implement it, we are going to continue to ask for our right."

Christian leaders have called on President Olusegun Obasanjo to block the new laws but the president says the states are within their rights, provided they do not push it too far.

"Nobody in Nigeria can implement sharia with cutting off hands or stoning to death," he said. "The constitution allows for sharia, but only so far. This is not the first time someone has tried to make political mileage out of it, but I have no intention of interfering, so long as they don't break the constitution."

Some lawyers argue that Zamfara has already gone too far with its floggings, but that has not discouraged a host of other states.

Jigawa's parliament has set up three committees - planning, enlightenment and execution - to prepare for sharia. It also wants to shift the weekend to a Friday. Bars and shops that sell alcohol in Kebbi, Katsina and Sokoto states have been told to close in preparation for the new laws.

fields.headline: International round-up
fields.trailText: Barak says peace is achievable
fields.body:
Barak says peace is achievable

Israel's soldier-prime minister, Ehud Barak, rolled out the military metaphors yesterday to reassure Jewish American leaders that despite the deadlock in talks with both Syria and the Palestinians, he would pilot Israel to peace and greater security.

"We are in a phase of difficulty; we should not lose eye contact with the objective, and we should not lose our nerve," he said, speaking to US Jewish leaders in Jerusalem hours before the arrival of the US Middle East envoy, Dennis Ross.

"This difficulty on all tracks - with the Syrians and Palestinians as well as Lebanon - was quite predictable."

Mr Barak said his negotiators would unveil new measures to kick-start talks with the Palestinians that have been hanging for more than two weeks.

Following last week's expiry of the deadline by which Israel should have handed over 6.1% of the West Bank, Mr Barak said: "I don't think any date in this regard is sacred."

But there is rising anger among Palestinians at the delays in the peace process. The Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, told Israel Radio yesterday that Israel was deliberately stalling the talks so that Mr Ehud could strike a deal with Syria first.

Mr Barak yesterday blamed the Palestinians for the deadlock. "For some reason, they feel unripe at the moment to expose their positions," he said. He also blamed Damascus for the breakdown of talks with Syria last month.

But Mr Barak reaffirmed that Israel would go ahead with the withdrawal of its forces from south Lebanon by July even if no agreement was reached with its neighbours, although "it might cost some lives on both sides of the border".
Suzanne Goldenberg, Jerusalem

Cape Town dean sorry for devil ad

An Anglican dean in Cape Town, South Africa, who appeared in an advertisement for a gay and lesbian film festival with a devil's tail poking from under his vestments escaped dismissal yesterday, despite protests from parishioners and church wardens.

Rowan Smith, the openly gay dean of St George's cathedral, appeared in the advert preaching against hate. "They say homosexuals are the devil's spawn but I don't believe that," he says, before revealing the red tail and a caption reading: "Get thee behind me".

At Sunday services, the Rev Smith apologised for any "sense of disgust or confusion" caused by his role in the advert and for allowing it to be filmed in his church. But he claimed the demands for his dismissal were partly racially motivated - he is black, while most of his worshippers are white.

Many in the dean's congregation were not satisfied by his apology. Terry Crawford-Browne, whose wife resigned as church warden in protest at the advert, fashioned a monkey's tail from a dressing gown and wore it to Sunday's service. "The clergy think they can treat the laity like monkeys," he said.

The archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Ndungane, yesterday said the church wardens had been persuaded to withdraw their demand for Rev Smith's dismissal despite his "serious error of judgment". The archbishop said the dean would be taking a few days' leave while the "process of healing" got under way.

"He is very stressed and needs the guidance and support of the church," he added.
Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

Maverick artist dies at 71

The Austrian painter and architect Friedensreich Hundertwasser has died, aged 71, his manager said yesterday.

The artist suffered heart failure on Saturday, while travelling from his adopted home in New Zealand to Europe, aboard the Queen Elizabeth II, Joram Harel said.

Hundertwasser, never without his trademark odd socks, was renowned for his vibrant paintings which often featured a spiral spattered by droplets of contrasting colour.

In line with his philosophy that "the straight line is godless", Hundertwasser also designed rounded buildings with bulging, organic forms, in defiance of the classic rules of architecture.

Works such as a patchwork-tiled Vienna council house, a Vienna incinerator boasting a golden onion-shaped dome and a thermal spa complex in Blumau in Styria which has a roof topped with grass have become sightseeing favourites in Austria.

Born Friedrich Stowasser in Vienna in 1928, Hundertwasser spent the second world war in hiding with his Jewish mother. But he never renounced his homeland, the birthplace of Adolf Hitler, despite choosing to live and work in New Zealand.

"I want to make people feel that life is worth living," Hundertwasser once said in an interview. "I hate hopeless art."

As an architect, Hundertwasser's designs reflected his increasingly ecologically-focused beliefs. He aimed to bring nature back into the home by incorporating trees into his higgledy-piggledy houses. "I change sick houses into humane houses in harmony with nature," he said.
Reuters, Vienna

Turkish PM warns mayors

The Turkish prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, yesterday warned pro-Kurdish mayors in the south-east of the country to stick to local issues and stop playing politics. The warning came after three prominent mayors were arrested at the weekend, and accused of helping the Kurdish rebel group, the PKK.

The Kurdish issue is one of the most sensitive areas of disagreement between Turkey and the European Union, and some European diplomats in Ankara believe there are forces within the Turkish establishment that want to sabotage good relations between the two sides.

After Turkey was accepted as a candidate for EU membership in December, the EU had hoped it could begin preparing for formal membership negotiations by tackling some of the more non-controversial issues. But the arrest of the three mayors has put the Kurdish problem back at the top of the agenda.

"It takes two to tango," one senior European diplomat said. "One has to ask who is in charge of the public relations department here."

The arrests have also served to raise tensions in the mainly Kurdish south-east. Several thousand people demonstrated yesterday outside the office of the mayor of Diyarbakir, Feridun Celik, who was one of the three taken into custody. Officials from the pro-Kurdish People's Democracy party, or Hadep, said the protests would continue every day until the mayor is released.
hris Morris, Ankara

Dad chains up belly dancer son

Police in Istanbul have rescued a 19-year-old male belly dancer whose father chained him to a bed for three days to prevent him from performing at nightclubs, a newspaper reported yesterday.

Neighbours alerted Turkish police Sunday after they heard Mahmut Dagyolu's cries for help, the Hurriyet newspaper said. His left arm and leg were chained to the bed.

Mr Dagyolu said his father had chained him up because he objected to his belly dancing, the newspaper reported.

Although female belly dancing is common, several Istanbul nightclubs have recently begun to hire male belly dancers.
AP, Istanbul

Love's rich dream on the rocks?

Somewhere on a cruise ship in the Caribbean the honeymoon was said to be going well, but back on dry land it was all over for the instant television hit Who Wants to Marry a Multi-millionaire?

Some 23m people tuned in last week when Rick Rockwell, 43, the moneybags in question, married Darva Conger on television moments after they set eyes on each other.

But now Fox Television has cancelled tonight's repeat after court papers showed that Mr Rockwell was once accused of threatening a woman; his status as a multi-millionaire was questioned; and a former girlfriend doubted his sincerity about the marriage.

"Fox has become aware of information regarding Mr Rockwell's past," said a statement from the network. "In the light of that new information, the network feels that to re-broadcast the special would be inappropriate and consequently we have removed it from our schedule."

Barbara Summers, who has known Mr Rockwell since the early 1990s, said she was startled when she saw him on television last week. "I thought 'That's your millionaire?', you've got to be joking. He's a likeable guy and he's funny but we're all wondering when did he become a millionaire? How did we miss that?"

Mr Rockwell, a former stand-up comedian who is now a real estate dealer, was said to be worth $2m (£1.2m).

Mr Rockwell and Ms Conger were married on screen by a Las Vegas judge after he chose her from about 50 strangers.

fields.bodyText: Barak says peace is achievable Israel's soldier-prime minister, Ehud Barak, rolled out the military metaphors yesterday to reassure Jewish American leaders that despite the deadlock in talks with both Syria and the Palestinians, he would pilot Israel to peace and greater security. "We are in a phase of difficulty; we should not lose eye contact with the objective, and we should not lose our nerve," he said, speaking to US Jewish leaders in Jerusalem hours before the arrival of the US Middle East envoy, Dennis Ross. "This difficulty on all tracks - with the Syrians and Palestinians as well as Lebanon - was quite predictable." Mr Barak said his negotiators would unveil new measures to kick-start talks with the Palestinians that have been hanging for more than two weeks. Following last week's expiry of the deadline by which Israel should have handed over 6.1% of the West Bank, Mr Barak said: "I don't think any date in this regard is sacred." But there is rising anger among Palestinians at the delays in the peace process. The Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, told Israel Radio yesterday that Israel was deliberately stalling the talks so that Mr Ehud could strike a deal with Syria first. Mr Barak yesterday blamed the Palestinians for the deadlock. "For some reason, they feel unripe at the moment to expose their positions," he said. He also blamed Damascus for the breakdown of talks with Syria last month. But Mr Barak reaffirmed that Israel would go ahead with the withdrawal of its forces from south Lebanon by July even if no agreement was reached with its neighbours, although "it might cost some lives on both sides of the border".
