Rowan Smith, the openly gay dean of St George's cathedral, appeared in the advert preaching against hate. "They say homosexuals are the devil's spawn but I don't believe that," he says, before revealing the red tail and a caption reading: "Get thee behind me". At Sunday services, the Rev Smith apologised for any "sense of disgust or confusion" caused by his role in the advert and for allowing it to be filmed in his church. But he claimed the demands for his dismissal were partly racially motivated - he is black, while most of his worshippers are white. Many in the dean's congregation were not satisfied by his apology. Terry Crawford-Browne, whose wife resigned as church warden in protest at the advert, fashioned a monkey's tail from a dressing gown and wore it to Sunday's service. "The clergy think they can treat the laity like monkeys," he said. The archbishop said the dean would be taking a few days' leave while the "process of healing" got under way. "He is very stressed and needs the guidance and support of the church," he added. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg Maverick artist dies at 71 The Austrian painter and architect Friedensreich Hundertwasser has died, aged 71, his manager said yesterday. The artist suffered heart failure on Saturday, while travelling from his adopted home in New Zealand to Europe, aboard the Queen Elizabeth II, Joram Harel said. Hundertwasser, never without his trademark odd socks, was renowned for his vibrant paintings which often featured a spiral spattered by droplets of contrasting colour. In line with his philosophy that "the straight line is godless", Hundertwasser also designed rounded buildings with bulging, organic forms, in defiance of the classic rules of architecture. Works such as a patchwork-tiled Vienna council house, a Vienna incinerator boasting a golden onion-shaped dome and a thermal spa complex in Blumau in Styria which has a roof topped with grass have become sightseeing favourites in Austria. Born Friedrich Stowasser in Vienna in 1928, Hundertwasser spent the second world war in hiding with his Jewish mother. But he never renounced his homeland, the birthplace of Adolf Hitler, despite choosing to live and work in New Zealand. "I want to make people feel that life is worth living," Hundertwasser once said in an interview. "I hate hopeless art." As an architect, Hundertwasser's designs reflected his increasingly ecologically-focused beliefs. He aimed to bring nature back into the home by incorporating trees into his higgledy-piggledy houses. "I change sick houses into humane houses in harmony with nature," he said. fields.headline: Reformers take political prize:Tehran
fields.standfirst: The success of his followers in Iran's parliamentary election puts the president under enormous pressure to deliver social change
fields.trailText: Iran's reformers capped their nationwide parliamentary victory yesterday by capturing the biggest prize: nearly all the seats in Tehran, the main battleground for political and social change.
fields.body:
Iran's reformers capped their nationwide parliamentary victory yesterday by capturing the biggest prize: nearly all the seats in Tehran, the main battleground for political and social change.

Of 30 parliamentary seats in the capital, President Mohammed Khatami's allies were leading in 28 seats. His brother, Mohammed Reza Khatami, finished first.

"The people are the real winners in this election," said the interior minister, Abdolvahed Mousavi-Lari.

President Khatami and his allies have beaten their conservative rivals decisively at the ballot box - but their triumph may prove a mixed blessing. Millions of voters who handed reformers a victory in parliamentary polls on Friday did so expecting swift and significant change.

Since his election in May 1997, Mr Khatami was granted a grace period because he faced obstacles at every turn. The current parliament, dominated by his conservative rivals, was a hindrance to turning his policies into law.

"If the vote in 1997 for Khatami was a vote for change, the vote this time was to accelerate the pace of change and to show their [the voters'] dissatisfaction with the current pace, " said the political commentator Saeed Leylaz.

Now that empowered voters have improved President Khatami 's fortunes, they have high expectations which will be difficult to meet. The Islamic Iran Participation Front ticket, headed by Mohammed Reza Khatami, made grand promises to voters ahead of the poll. Its radical programme included pledges to improve citizens' rights, to cleanse the judiciary from special interests, and to establish political parties.

Despite their solid victory, there is no guarantee that the reformist candidates will follow the president 's agenda. More than 50 seats were won by independents, many of whom are closely aligned with Mr Khatami 's conservative foes. Even many so-called reformers may not back real change.

"I see names of winners who call themselves reformers but who are really conservatives, " said one reformist candidate, Fariba Davoudi. "To be a reformer you have to believe in the rule of law and believe in citizens' rights, but some of the winners do not believe this in their hearts."

President Khatami will also face increased pressure from conservative-dominated institutions still outside his domain, all of which are determined to cling to power.

Conservatives controlling the judiciary wasted no time in letting the country know they still control a major centre of power. Iran's supreme court has apparently ordered the execution of one student who participated in pro-democracy demonstrations, student leaders claimed yesterday. It also sentenced many other student demonstrators to years in prison.

Standing in the way of profound change is Islamic law. The interpretations of Islamic law by Iran's politicians will still ultimately have to meet the approval of the clerical establishment.

Among the demands of Iranian voters are improved rights for women. While more women receive a university education and are employed than at any other time in Iran's history, they are rarely able to divorce without their husbands' consent and face impossible odds in gaining custody of their children.

But many reformers believe the Islamic texts, which form the basis of the Iranian constitution, do not give women such freedoms.

Iranians are also eager to get law enforcement out of their private lives. Under President Khatami, the morality police, or basij, has become less zealous, but still routinely stops young single men and women who meet illegally in public.

Iran's youth, which accounts for a large proportion of the population, hopes the new parliament will bring social freedom.

Some 80% of the electorate voted for reformist candidates in almost all the main cities, rejecting conservatives even in places such as Mashhad, Iran's second city, home to the country's holiest shrine and traditionally a conservative stronghold.

The voters' message to traditionalists was also strong. Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, twice elected president and the conservatives' prime candidate in the race, was running in 27th place in Tehran. His supporters, a mixture of centrists and conservatives, had expected a spot in the top three places.

President Khatami and a close circle of reformist intellectuals have waited to merge an Islamic system with democracy for some 20 years. It is unclear if society is prepared to wait as long for fundamental change.

fields.headline: Ballot-box justice for jailed cleric
fields.standfirst: The man standing in the shadow of Iran's parliamentary election reappeared in public yesterday from his jail cell in Tehran's Evin prison.
fields.trailText: Abdullah Nouri, a dissident cleric now serving a five-year sentence, was freed for three days to taste the reformist victory that could have been his.
fields.body:
Abdullah Nouri, a dissident cleric now serving a five-year sentence, was freed for three days to taste the reformist victory that could have been his.

Mr Nouri was tipped to head the reform ticket and to become parliament speaker, but fearing the kind of overwhelming victory that Iranian voters handed President Khatami and his allies in Friday's elections, a conservative clerical court imprisoned Mr Nouri to exclude him from the race.

As he greeted guests in his living room yesterday, the bitterness in his voice told the story. The critique of the system Mr Nouri had started last autumn during his trial ended at the ballot box on Friday.

Voters continued his attack by crushing conservative candidates who supported the clerical establishment.

But the price Mr Nouri is paying for liberating the national consciousness is wearing on him. He has lost weight and spends his days in a cramped jail cell with two other political dissidents.

Still, he said the election will guarantee the future of Iran's Islamic system.

"The reformists' understanding of Islam is more open than the understanding of the conservatives - the election will mean the survival of the republic," he said.

Mr Nouri's brother, Alireza Nouri, ran as a candidate for a seat from Tehran in protest at his brother's imprisonment. He was one of the most successful candidates.

"The vote I got in reality is a bouquet of flowers from the people of Tehran to the prisoner in cell Number 11," he said.

Like Abdullah Nouri, there are other clerics in the background of Friday's election. When he returns to jail tomor row, Mr Nouri will join other dissidents who have been silenced.

His mentor, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, is under house arrest in the holy Shi'ite city of Qom. He has been a discreet inspiration to many reformers. Students campaigning for the reform ticket chanted that Ayatollah Montazeri should be freed.

Mr Nouri, appearing thin and weary, but maintaining a sense of humour, was asked if he thought Ayatollah Montazeri would soon be released.

"I am not worried about Montazeri now,"he joked. "I am only concerned about my own freedom."

webTitle: From great to ghastly - all the US presidents

fields.headline: From great to ghastly - all the US presidents
fields.standfirst: Survey of American historians puts Lincoln top and Clinton just average
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's hopes that his eight-year presidency of the United States will get a more glowing verdict from historians than it has received from contemporary commentators were dashed yesterday, when a survey of American historians declared him just plain average.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's hopes that his eight-year presidency of the United States will get a more glowing verdict from historians than it has received from contemporary commentators were dashed yesterday, when a survey of American historians declared him just plain average.

Given some of the things that his enemies say about him, Mr Clinton arguably did quite well to finish exactly in mid-table -ranked 21st out of the 41 - in a presidential survey of 58 American history professors conducted for the public affairs television channel C-Span. On one of the 10 qualities assessed by the historians - moral authority - Mr Clinton finished at the bottom of the pile, below even Richard Nixon. On relations with the US Congress, he came 36th.

While some will say that he was lucky his ranking was not worse, Mr Clinton did much better than the only other president to be impeached, Andrew Johnson, who finished next to bottom overall.

Mr Clinton is sure to feel personally slighted that the man he ousted so skilfully from the White House in 1992, George Bush, finished just ahead of him in the rankings, in 20th place, and that Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford, two of the least venerated American presidents of recent times, come in just on his heels.

The best scores Mr Clinton achieved were for the pursuit of equal justice, where he finished fifth, and in economic management, where he also ranked fifth. Mr Clinton was assessed 11th on his public persuasion skills.

America's greatest president, the historians agreed, was Abraham Lincoln, who led the US through its greatest crisis, the 1861-65 civil war with the secessionist southern confederacy. Lincoln came first in five of 10 qualities the historians considered which included crisis leadership, administrative skills, vision, pursuit of equal justice, and performance in the context of the times. Lincoln ranked second on moral authority, after the nation's founder George Washington.

Overall, Franklin Roosevelt came second, a choice which to some extent reflects the generation and influence of the historians surveyed. Roosevelt's achievements in saving the US from the great depression of the 1930s and then leading the nation through the second world war put him comfortably into second place, as well as giving him top marks in the public persuasion, economic management and international relations sections.

Revered at Rushmore

Perhaps surprisingly, George Washington only managed third place overall, but ranked first on moral authority, and second on administrative skills and performance for his times. Washington's imperishable status as the father of the independent US - he became president in 1789 - has been dimmed in parts of the country in recent years because he was a slave-owner on his Virginia estate.

Theodore Roosevelt's fourth place confirms his rising status not just among historians but also among today's generation of politicians of both parties. Both Mr Clinton, a Democrat, and the Republican presidential contender, John McCain, are fond of identifying themselves with TR's early 20th century version of Third Way government. In many ways the most remarkable rating is Harry Truman's fifth place. The reputation of the president who seemed eclipsed when he took over after FDR's death in 1945 and who led the US into the Korean war, has risen steadily since his death; he is now venerated for his decision-making, personal modesty and probity. One of the historians who directed the survey, Douglas Brinkley, a professor at the university of New Orleans, said yesterday that Truman had reached the pantheon of the truly great American leaders. "His face should be chiselled on Mount Rushmore right next to Theodore Roosevelt," he said.

And then there is the position of Ronald Reagan. His 1981-89 presidency is sanctified by many on the Republican right, yet he could only finish in 11th place in the survey. Mr Reagan, who is 89 and suffering from Alzheimer's disease, normally finishes much higher in modern-day surveys of the general public asking about American presidents. At the Mount Rushmore monument in South Dakota, where visitors can vote for their most revered president, Mr Reagan at the moment ranks fourth, behind Lincoln, Washington and FDR, in public esteem.

Hardly less striking than President Reagan's eclipse is the continuing rehabilitation of the man who finished one place above him in the survey, Lyndon Johnson. Forced to leave the presidency in 1968 because of the Vietnam war, President Johnson's posthumous reputation has continued to rise steadily and inexorably, largely on account of his civil rights legislation, which covered opportunity in education, and for his 1964 "war on poverty". Johnson, a Democrat, was the 36th president of the US and the only one in the survey other than Lincoln, Washington and FDR to finish first in a category - that of presidential relations with Congress.

The historians rated James Buchanan the worst president in American history. Buchanan, who presided over the descent into secession and civil war during his presidency from 1857 to 1861, finished last in four categories - those of crisis leadership, vision, pursuit of equal justice and performance. Buchanan was also the only bachelor president in US history, though there is no suggestion that this distinction was held against him.

White House winners and losers

1 Abraham Lincoln (1861-65)

From log cabin to White House, then won the civil war and set the slaves free. And was assassinated.

2 Franklin D Roosevelt (1933-45)

With New Deal, FDR brought recovery at the nadir of the Great Depression and saw US through most of the war.

3 George Washington (1789-97)

Well, the first president has got to rank highly.

4 Teddy Roosevelt (1901-09)

Remembered for the Panama Canal, starting America's national parks, and giving his name to the Teddy Bear.

5 Harry Truman (1945-53)

Dropped nuclear bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

6 Woodrow Wilson

(1913-21)

The most academic president, he brought US troops into the first world war in 1917.

7 Thomas Jefferson

(1801-09)

Drafted the Declaration of Independence, then went on to become the third president.

8 John F Kennedy (1961-63)

Womaniser remembered more for his youthfulness, civil rights and his assassination.

9 Dwight D Eisenhower (1953-61)

D-Day hero who presided over post-war prosperity and the early years of the cold war.

10 Lyndon Johnson (1963-69)

Took the reins on JFK's death, passed civil rights laws, and pumped troops into Vietnam.

11 Ronald Reagan (1981-89)

B-movie actor turned feelgood president, scourge of communists and friend of Maggie.

12 James Polk (1845-49)

Paid $15m for California and New Mexico.

13 Andrew Jackson (1829-37) "Old Hickory" saw the split of US politics into Democrats and National Republicans

14 James Monroe (1817-25)

Doctrine told Europe: keep your hands off the Americas

15 William McKinley (1897-1901) He annexed the Philippines, Guam and Puerto Rico.

16 John Adams (1797-1801)

He had a hard act to follow as the second president.

17 Grover Cleveland (1885-89) A big man, the only president to marry in the White House

18 James Madison (1809-17)

Declared war against Britain.

19 John Quincy Adams (1825-29)

The only president who was the son of a president

20 George Bush (1989-93)

Read my lips: but not on taxes

21 Bill Clinton (1993-) Forget the boom. Remember Monica

22 Jimmy Carter (1977-81) Peanut farmer humiliated over Tehran hostages.

23 Gerald Ford (1974-77)

Caricatured as the president who couldn't walk and chew gum at the same time.

24 William Taft (1909-13) More interested in law than politics.

25 Richard Nixon (1969-74)

"Tricky Dicky" authorised the Watergate break-in.

26 Rutherford Hayes (1877-81) Republican civil war veteran who promoted civil rights.

27 Calvin Coolidge (1923-29) Presided over 1920s boom.

28 Zachary Taylor (1849-50) Soldier who died in first year.

29 James Garfield (1881)

Term cut short by assassin.

30 Martin Van Buren (1837-41) Blocked annexation of Texas for fear of provoking Mexico.

31 Benjamin Harrison (1889-93)

Signed first anti-trust act.

32 Chester Arthur (1881-85) Immigration law excluded paupers, criminals and lunatics.

33 Ulysses Grant (1869-77) Victorious civil war general criticised for heavy drinking.

34 Herbert Hoover (1929-33)

Seen as doing little to mitigate misery of the Depression.

35 Millard Fillmore (1850-53) Gave slaveowners state aid for hunting down runaway slaves.

36 John Tyler (1841-45) Faced first impeachment.

37 William Harrison (1841)

Caught a cold and became first president to die in office.

38 Warren Harding (1921-23) Speeches were "an army of pompous phrases moving in search of an idea."

39 Franklin Pierce (1853-57)

Democrat who failed to resolve the slave controversy.

40 Andrew Johnson (1865-69)

Pro-Union southern Democrat who was impeached.

41 James Buchanan

(1857-61)

Like so many, retrospectively blamed for civil war.

Both Mr Clinton, a Democrat, and the Republican presidential contender, John McCain, are fond of identifying themselves with TR's early 20th century version of Third Way government. In many ways the most remarkable rating is Harry Truman's fifth place. The reputation of the president who seemed eclipsed when he took over after FDR's death in 1945 and who led the US into the Korean war, has risen steadily since his death; he is now venerated for his decision-making, personal modesty and probity. One of the historians who directed the survey, Douglas Brinkley, a professor at the university of New Orleans, said yesterday that Truman had reached the pantheon of the truly great American leaders. "His face should be chiselled on Mount Rushmore right next to Theodore Roosevelt," he said. And then there is the position of Ronald Reagan. His 1981-89 presidency is sanctified by many on the Republican right, yet he could only finish in 11th place in the survey. Mr Reagan, who is 89 and suffering from Alzheimer's disease, normally finishes much higher in modern-day surveys of the general public asking about American presidents. At the Mount Rushmore monument in South Dakota, where visitors can vote for their most revered president, Mr Reagan at the moment ranks fourth, behind Lincoln, Washington and FDR, in public esteem. Hardly less striking than President Reagan's eclipse is the continuing rehabilitation of the man who finished one place above him in the survey, Lyndon Johnson. Forced to leave the presidency in 1968 because of the Vietnam war, President Johnson's posthumous reputation has continued to rise steadily and inexorably, largely on account of his civil rights legislation, which covered opportunity in education, and for his 1964 "war on poverty". Johnson, a Democrat, was the 36th president of the US and the only one in the survey other than Lincoln, Washington and FDR to finish first in a category - that of presidential relations with Congress. The historians rated James Buchanan the worst president in American history. Buchanan, who presided over the descent into secession and civil war during his presidency from 1857 to 1861, finished last in four categories - those of crisis leadership, vision, pursuit of equal justice and performance. Buchanan was also the only bachelor president in US history, though there is no suggestion that this distinction was held against him. And was assassinated. 2 Franklin D Roosevelt (1933-45) With New Deal, FDR brought recovery at the nadir of the Great Depression and saw US through most of the war. 3 George Washington (1789-97) Well, the first president has got to rank highly. 4 Teddy Roosevelt (1901-09) Remembered for the Panama Canal, starting America's national parks, and giving his name to the Teddy Bear. 5 Harry Truman (1945-53) Dropped nuclear bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 6 Woodrow Wilson (1913-21) The most academic president, he brought US troops into the first world war in 1917. 7 Thomas Jefferson (1801-09) Drafted the Declaration of Independence, then went on to become the third president. 8 John F Kennedy (1961-63) Womaniser remembered more for his youthfulness, civil rights and his assassination. 9 Dwight D Eisenhower (1953-61) D-Day hero who presided over post-war prosperity and the early years of the cold war. 10 Lyndon Johnson (1963-69) Took the reins on JFK's death, passed civil rights laws, and pumped troops into Vietnam. 11 Ronald Reagan (1981-89) B-movie actor turned feelgood president, scourge of communists and friend of Maggie. 12 James Polk (1845-49) Paid $15m for California and New Mexico. 13 Andrew Jackson (1829-37) "Old Hickory" saw the split of US politics into Democrats and National Republicans 14 James Monroe (1817-25) Doctrine told Europe: keep your hands off the Americas 15 William McKinley (1897-1901) He annexed the Philippines, Guam and Puerto Rico. 16 John Adams (1797-1801) He had a hard act to follow as the second president. 17 Grover Cleveland (1885-89) A big man, the only president to marry in the White House 18 James Madison (1809-17) Declared war against Britain. 19 John Quincy Adams (1825-29) The only president who was the son of a president 20 George Bush (1989-93) Read my lips: but not on taxes 21 Bill Clinton (1993-) Forget the boom. Remember Monica 22 Jimmy Carter (1977-81) Peanut farmer humiliated over Tehran hostages. 23 Gerald Ford (1974-77) Caricatured as the president who couldn't walk and chew gum at the same time. 24 William Taft (1909-13) More interested in law than politics. 25 Richard Nixon (1969-74) "Tricky Dicky" authorised the Watergate break-in. 26 Rutherford Hayes (1877-81) Republican civil war veteran who promoted civil rights. 27 Calvin Coolidge (1923-29) Presided over 1920s boom. 28 Zachary Taylor (1849-50) Soldier who died in first year. 29 James Garfield (1881) Term cut short by assassin. 30 Martin Van Buren (1837-41) Blocked annexation of Texas for fear of provoking Mexico. 31 Benjamin Harrison (1889-93) Signed first anti-trust act. 32 Chester Arthur (1881-85) Immigration law excluded paupers, criminals and lunatics. 33 Ulysses Grant (1869-77) Victorious civil war general criticised for heavy drinking. 34 Herbert Hoover (1929-33) Seen as doing little to mitigate misery of the Depression. 35 Millard Fillmore (1850-53) Gave slaveowners state aid for hunting down runaway slaves. 36 John Tyler (1841-45) Faced first impeachment. 37 William Harrison (1841) Caught a cold and became first president to die in office. 38 Warren Harding (1921-23) Speeches were "an army of pompous phrases moving in search of an idea." 39 Franklin Pierce (1853-57) Democrat who failed to resolve the slave controversy. 40 Andrew Johnson (1865-69) Pro-Union southern Democrat who was impeached. 41 James Buchanan (1857-61) Like so many, retrospectively blamed for civil war.

webTitle: Robots to take fighter pilot role

fields.headline: Robots to take fighter pilot role
fields.trailText: The prospect of a revolution in warfare, in which fighter pilots are redundant and bombs are dropped by robotic drones directed by commanders sitting at desks miles away, was heralded yesterday at an international conference on air power in the new millennium.
fields.body:
The prospect of a revolution in warfare, in which fighter pilots are redundant and bombs are dropped by robotic drones directed by commanders sitting at desks miles away, was heralded yesterday at an international conference on air power in the new millennium.

According to defence experts, future bombing missions are likely to be carried out by drones, or uninhabited combat air vehicles (Ucavs).

It would be the ultimate step towards non-risk warfare - at least for the attackers - at a time when, as the Kosovo war demonstrated, governments and public opinion are loath to put their pilots in danger.

Drones, with such evocative names as Woodpecker, Kestrel, and Hunter, played a significant role in that conflict, but only for reconnaissance. Speakers at the Singapore conference said the drone could replace manned fighter aircraft.

Hi-tech drones are already being developed by the US. An aircraft without a cockpit would avoid radar, be lighter and easier to manoeuvre and save on pilot training.

Israel is developing combat drones directed by a manned aircraft, though Eitan Ben-Eliahu, the Israeli air force commander, warned that pilotless aircraft were not particularly cheap to run.

British military sources pointed out that one accurate pilotless weapon - the cruise missile - already exists.

Others expressed concern. "The technology is there but there would be legal and political objections," said Andrew Brookes of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.

fields.headline: Turned out beautiful again
fields.standfirst:
As a wind of change blows through the BBC weather department, Sam Wollaston bids a fond farewell to the specs 'n' sweaters brigade
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: As a wind of change blows through the BBC weather department, Sam Wollaston bids a fond farewell to the specs 'n' sweaters brigade
fields.body:
'John Kettley is a weatherman
A weatherman, a weatherman John Kettley is a weatherman And so is Michael Fish'

Remember the song? A minor hit for a band called A Tribe of Toffs in 1988. No? No matter - it's just that those poignant lyrics have just become a little less relevant in this early part of the 21st century.

Although John Kettley is still a weatherman, a weatherman, a weatherman - and so is Michael Fish - they are becoming less so by the minute.

Both have been banished from their prime-time, weekday BBC slots to the backwaters of the weekend. If they're lucky, they get to fill in when one of the regulars is - well, under the weather. The regular team is now Isobel Lang, Sarah Wilmshurst, Helen Willetts, David Braine and Helen Young, who has just replaced Bill Giles as head of BBC weather. None has had songs written about them yet - or, as Ian McCaskill did, earned a Spitting Image puppet and a spot in Rory Bremner's repertoire. But then, Ian McCaskill was part of the old school, the school Fish and Kettley belong to, before he stepped down, "thrilled and delighted", a couple of years ago.

Fish is 55 and has been presenting the weather for 26 years. Kettley is 47 and has been at it for 20 years. Young, Lang, Wilmshurst, Willetts and Braine are, respectively, 30, 29, 29, 28 and 37. You don't have to be able to predict a hurricane to see a pattern here... although I'd watch out if I were you, Mr Braine: at 37, you're no spring solstice any more. Worse still, you appear to be a bloke.

The BBC, naturally, are playing down the whole thing. The changes are apparently the result of a "regular talent review that all presenters have to undergo," according to a helpful BBC spokeswoman (probabably aged about 23). "I think people welcome fresh faces and welcome young people."

Well, maybe they do; no one's saying we don't need a bit of totty on the telly. But to read the weather? Is that not one of the little corners of modern life, like a dog track, or a park bench, where it's OK to be over 35, and (shhh) male? Perhaps even to wear glasses, a checked jacket and an ill-advised tie? We're not talking game-show hosts, or garden make-overs, after all - this is just a quick slot after the news, a couple of minutes of cold fronts and showers, and no one really listens anyway, do they? It's fine - comforting, even - to be read to by a middle-aged bloke.

In the US, the Weather Channel, all 24 hours a day of it, is fronted by impressive and powerfully dressed people. They stand in front of huge maps with important features to point out - Rockies, deserts, great plains, great lakes, grand canyons. And they have the weather to match: 100 degrees here, -100 degrees there, a tornado here, an ice storm there. This is weather that requires youth, pronounced jaws, strong white teeth and a powerful outfit. But a bit of drizzle over the Midlands, seven hours of sunshine in Lowestoft, the odd fog patch? This is weather that demands to be presented by Michael Fish and John Kettley. Of course, the one time in 1987 we did have a bit of excitement, weatherwise, Michael Fish got it wrong. For which we love him all the more.

T he BBC still recruits its weather people from the Met Office, so Isobel, Helen, Sarah, et al do at least know their isobars from their isotherms. And, as a Birmingham university survey revealed a couple of years back, all TV presenters are terrible at predicting the weather anyway. In fact, one wonders whether these changes are all for naught; another survey revealed that a couple of minutes after a weather forecast, most people couldn't remember a thing about it.

There was talk a couple of years ago of jacking in the Beeb-Met Office association, and there's no doubt the barometer is falling (sorry, last meteorological metaphor, promise) in the direction of Ulrika, Nicole in To Die For, or even worse, ITV weather. Sponsored by Powergen, no doubt. Meanwhile, watch out for A Tribe of Toffs' comeback single:

'John Kettley is on benefits

Benefits

Benefits

John Kettley is on benefits

And so is Michael Fish...'

fields.headline: No: 1581 Cats
fields.body:
Age: 18.

Appearance: Ubiquitous, on stages around the world.

Aha. You don't mean cats, you mean Cats: The very same: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Trevor Nunn's feline juggernaut, adapted from TS Eliot's Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats an aeon ago.

Who'd have thought that such shaggy, whiskery creatures would one day dominate British theatre? Yes, Nunn has done well for himself, hasn't he? His show took off, too. It's been seen by more than 50m people worldwide, and is Britain's most enduring musical.

And in the States? Lloyd Webber mortgaged his house to launch Cats on Broadway. The gamble paid off to the tune of $380m over two decades.

That buys a lot of tins of Whiskas: Cats surpassed A Chorus Line in 1997 to become the longest-running production in Broadway history. It's been performed 7,400 times.

Any more meaningless statistics? To construct wigs during the run 3,247 pounds worth of yak hair were used - more than the weight of a Volkswagen Beetle.

But you know what they say: hair today... Gone tomorrow. At the weekend, the Winter Garden Theatre in New York announced Cats' imminent closure. The theatre has been playing to half-empty houses.

Are the tabbies getting shabby? One actress, Marlene Danielle, has been performing in the Broadway production since its launch in 1982, which makes her long overdue a catnap.

No chance of Lloyd Webber joining the moggies in retirement? Afraid not. The perky peer has recently bought up 10 West End theatres, and is hard at work "with Ben Elton, of all people" on a musical about the Troubles in Northern Ireland.

Don't say: "Isn't TS Eliot an anagram of 'toilets' "?

Do sing, while staring tremulously into the middle distance: "Memory, all alone in the moonlight / I can smile at the old days / I was beautiful then."

Not to be confused with: The Lion King, Top Cat, The Waste Land.

fields.headline: Iron Eyes rides again
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles on: Indian casinos under attack | Dognappers and ransoms
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles on: Indian casinos under attack | Dognappers and ransoms
fields.body:
For many in the United States, and around the world whether they knew it or not, Iron Eyes Cody was, for more than half a century, the embodiment of the Native American: calm, dignified and the child of a Cree-Cherokee marriage. He appeared in almost every western from The Covered Wagon in 1923 through to Cimarron, Kit Carson, Comanche Territory, Alias Jesse James and A Man Called Horse.

He taught Roy Rogers Indian sign language in King of the Cowboys and appeared memorably in public service television commercials in the 70s exhorting people to protect the environment and Keep America Beautiful. When he died last year, at the age of 91, his obituaries largely celebrated his career as an Indian actor: he was said to have followed his circus performer father, Thomas Long Plume, into the entertainment business. The Washington Post described him as a "veteran Indian actor".

In fact, as the latest issue of Cineaste explains, he was a full-blooded Italian from Louisiana whose real name was Oscar DeCorti and his parents were not Crees or Cherokees but immigrants from the south of Italy who had arrived in New Orleans at the turn of the century. His father was a grocer. But Cody had always wanted to be an Indian and always wore Indian clothes. He used his success to help a variety of Indian causes, adopted two Indian boys as sons and gave much of his money to impoverished reservations. He and his wife, Bertha Parker, an anthropologist, became known as "Hollywood's Indian couple" and opened a small Indian museum in Los Angeles. He was honoured for his work in 1995 at the Native Americans' equivalent of the Oscars, First Americans in the Arts, although they specifically noted his "non-Native status".

All this has taken on a new relevance as network television stations and film studios are being put under pressure to reflect the diversity of the country in their drama series. Apart from westerns, there have been few parts for Native Americans (One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest provided one but that was back in 1975) and this fact has been much remarked upon of late. But over the coming weeks television viewers in California are going to become very familiar with one Native American - and he is the certainly the full shilling.

Mark Macarro, the chairman of the Pechanga branch of the Luiseno Mission Indians, has already started to appear in what will be regular television spots urging Californians to vote Yes to something called Proposition 1a when it and various other issues (gay marriages, the juvenile justice system) come before the electorate on March 7. For a decade now casinos have been operating on Indian reservations in California - and 27 other states - and their right to do so was endorsed by Californian voters in 1998. However, Nevada casinos, who stand to lose much if the reservation casinos expand, challenged the legality of the move, found it to be unconstitutional and so a revised proposition comes back before the voters.

The reservation casinos, which are backed by the majority of the Californian tribes, are extremely anxious to keep their operations running. They argue that unemployment on the reservations is down 50% - 50,000 people are employed by them - and welfare down 68% since the casinos arrived. They are duly spending $7.3m on advertising the benefits of casinos. The opposition is currently lying low, having noted the big money the tribes are spending and the fact that Californian voters backed them 2-1 last time. One of the Las Vegas companies has now complained that they cannot compete with the "superior firepower" of the Indians. Ah, that would have made old Iron Eyes smile.

A case for Doctor Bones
Nowhere can there be a greater variety of dogs than in LA and nowhere in this land of 53m of the creatures are they more prized. Our local canine salon is called Doggie Style, and many out-of-work actors or resting scriptwriters are able to make a living walking Dalmatians or Afghan hounds. But the growth in popularity of the pedigree dog has led to a new form of criminality as evidenced by the signs stuck on fences and lamp-posts: dog-napping.

It is not unusual to see rewards of $2,000 for the return of a dog. One poster, bearing blown-up mutt-shots, offers $1,000 and promises "no questions asked". Criminals fancying a change from car theft or crack dealing have realised that handsome ransoms will be paid.

But the gumshoes are already on the case. Private eye John Keane, who operates under the name of Sherlock Bones, is a "tracer of missing pets". His website contains "happy tails" of found pets and he awards people who help him with an Honorary Pet Posse medal. One local poster even gives his name for anyone willing to supply information. Can a TV series be far behind?

But just as human beings responded to rising street crime by taking self-defence and fitness classes, so too are the dogs. Fitness trainers are now hired for dogs by owners who don't have time to put them through their paces. Long walks are no longer enough: dogs go body-surfing, slide down chutes and even go to fitness camps. At one, Loved Dog Co, the dogs wait at the end of their workout to be picked up by their parents just like children after school. Now that a finely-honed chihuahua has become a TV star here, through Taco Bell ads, presumably fellow dogs are hoping to catch the agent's eye, too.

This has all been given a political dimension by a recent proposal to increase the licence fee in LA for an unneutered dog to $100. Altered dogs will still pay the existing fee of $10. This has been proposed because of the number of dogs running free in the city and has understandably caused a fuss. Breeders have hired lobbyists to try to block the measure, arguing that they are not allowed to put altered dogs in for shows and thus they are effectively forced to pay the extra. But the city officials point them at the grim statistics: 59,663 dogs and cats taken into LA animal shelters last year ended up taking the long walk.

This has been proposed because of the number of dogs running free in the city and has understandably caused a fuss. Breeders have hired lobbyists to try to block the measure, arguing that they are not allowed to put altered dogs in for shows and thus they are effectively forced to pay the extra. But the city officials point them at the grim statistics: 59,663 dogs and cats taken into LA animal shelters last year ended up taking the long walk.

Maths department, from page 9, Sport, yesterday, where our Five [sic] Nations timetable (correctly) listed the following six nations: England, France, Wales, Ireland, Italy and Scotland.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Dolly creates 150 jobs | Biomedica's pet project
fields.body:
Dolly creates 150 jobs
PPL Therapeutics, the company which created Dolly the sheep, has secured funding to build a £42m factory in Scotland. The facility will extract AAT, a protein used in treating cystic fibrosis, from the milk of transgenic sheep.

It will mean at least 150 new jobs in the Lothians. The company's shares rose 18.5p to 135p on the announcement.

PPL threatened last year to move the project to the US or New Zealand, complaining that few incentives were on offer in Scotland. However, it has secured £2.5m in regional assistance and a £13.5m loan from Royal Bank of Scotland underwritten by Scottish Enterprise.

Biomedica's pet project
Gene therapy company Oxford Biomedica is to develop cancer vaccines for cats and dogs in a tie-up with French veterinary drugs group Virbac. Chief executive Alan Kingsman said the market in cancer products for pets was worth $200m (£125m) in America and Europe.

The company has several vaccines already in development for humans and believes these could be replicated for animal use.

AstraZeneca spin-off inquiry
The US federal trade commission has asked AstraZeneca for more information about the £9.5bn spin-off of its agrochemicals division.

The business is due to be merged with Swiss group Novartis's agrochemicals operation, creating a new group, Syngenta. Analysts believe regulators will require the sale of products in seeds and crop protection to overcome competition concerns.

Despite the request, AstraZeneca said it believed it could complete the deal in the second half of this year as planned.

Tesco, Barclays row over £1 levy

Tesco will remove Barclays' cash machines from its stores if the bank introduces fees for using them.

Barclays, which has 200 machines in the company's stores, last year proposed introducing fees for customers of other banks who use its machines. Tesco reacted today by saying it had invited Nationwide building society, which backs free access to cash machines, to tender for Barclays' slots.

Barclays and Tesco are due to sit down with the 32 other members of the cash machine alliance, Link, next week to make a final decision on charges.

Red Star makes drastic cuts

Red Star Parcels, the company sold by British Rail for less than £1 when it was privatised, has shut down 60 collection points, a third of its entire UK network because of heavy losses. In some cases customers will now have to travel more than 100 miles if they want to send goods by rail. David Burtenshaw chief executive of Lynx, the company which bought out Red Star two years ago, said the decision was due to "commercial viability".

fields.headline: Esser joins takeover watchdog
fields.trailText: Klaus Esser, the Mannesmann chairman who failed to block his company's takeover by its British telecommunications rival Vodafone AirTouch, has been co-opted on to a new German government committee set up to create new rules governing hostile takeovers.
fields.body:
Klaus Esser, the Mannesmann chairman who failed to block his company's takeover by its British telecommunications rival Vodafone AirTouch, has been co-opted on to a new German government committee set up to create new rules governing hostile takeovers.

For more than two months Mannesmann fought off its British rival before eventually succumbing nearly three weeks ago. During the fight Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, was even given the disparaging sobriquet of "Mr Cricket" by Germans upset by the hostile takeover of one of its industrial powerhouses.

Mr Esser will join other senior corporate figures advising Chancellor Gerhard Schröder on drafting new rules regarding hostile takeovers in Germany, said government spokesman Bela Anda.

Hostile takeover bids have previously been a rarity in Germany and have even more rarely succeeded. Tyre company Pirelli laid siege to Germany's Continental in the early 1990s but eventually had to walk away empty-handed.

The German tradition of firms being controlled by a small number of shareholders made hostile takeovers generally less likely to succeed.

But the recent trend towards increasing use of the financial markets and therefore widened shareholder bases has made German companies more vulnerable.

Planned tax changes which will lift big capital gains tax li abilities from German companies selling shares they hold in other domestic firms are likely to stimulate merger and acquistions activity, too.

The success of the Vodafone AirTouch campaign to merge with Mannesmann has made corporate Germany reassess its position. The £104bn Mannesmann takeover is the biggest corporate merger in Europe and close to AOL's record-breaking purchase of Time Warner at the beginning of the millennium.

As Alison Cottrell, chief international economist at PaineWebber in London, noted recently, although the bid did not change Germany it showed Germany had already changed. "In doing so it altered the way Germany was perceived and how it perceived itself; a shift of enormous importance to potential predators and targets alike."

Mr Esser will be joined, among others, by Allianz's chief financial officer Paul Achleitner; Veba's chairman Ulrich Hartmann; Deutsche Boerse chief executive Werner Seifert; state premier for North Rhine-Westphalia, Wolfgang Clement; and the head of IG BCE - the labour union for the chemicals, mining and energy sectors - Hubertus Schmoldt, Mr Anda said. The committee will begin its deliberations on March 9.

The government will be represented by the finance minister, Hans Eichel, justice minister Herta Daeubler-Gmelin and economy minister Werner Mueller. Further participants may also be invited in due course, Mr Anda added.

webTitle: Kermit and Miss Piggy go to Munich

fields.headline: Kermit and Miss Piggy go to Munich
fields.standfirst: Promising to revive the Muppets, German family media group EM.TV & Merchandising bought the Jim Henson Company yesterday for $680m (£425m)
fields.trailText: "Kermy don't tell me! You're going to announce our engagement!" Miss Piggy told a Munich news conference, basking in the spotlight in a pink and gold lame sequinned dress.
fields.body:
"Kermy don't tell me! You're going to announce our engagement!" Miss Piggy told a Munich news conference, basking in the spotlight in a pink and gold lame sequinned dress.

But instead of announcing her yearned-for marriage to Kermit the Frog, EM.TV revealed it had paid £212.5m in cash and the same amount in 6m new shares for Los Angeles-based Henson.

EM.TV, whose share price has surged to 213 times forecast earnings on expectations of a big purchase, pleased analysts with the much-touted acquisition. Henson will control about 5% of EM.TV's stock, the group said.

"In one stroke we are a major player in the world's biggest and most important media market," said EM.TV's founder and chief executive, Thomas Haffa.

The buyout of Henson, which gives EM.TV control of US and Asian TV company stakes, multimedia interests and an innovative special effects studio, will also boost sales.

EM.TV said analysts' forecasts of group revenues of DM500m to DM600m (£158m-£189m) in 2000 without Henson were realistic. Henson said it expected sales in 2000 of £100m, but EM.TV finance director Florian Haffa stressed there would be major synergies.

His brother Thomas, who with the rest of the family holds about 60% of EM.TV, said the group plans to launch an internet portal for children's entertain ment in the next six months and refused to rule out acquiring an internet company to capitalise on EM.TV's branded content.

Henson's other well-known show is the educational children's puppet show Sesame Street.

The show is broadcast in more than 140 countries and is the winner of more than 50 Emmy awards.

fields.headline: Brussels investigates MCI WorldCom/Sprint merger
fields.trailText: Europe's top competition watchdog said yesterday that it will launch a full scale investigation into the proposed £80bn merger of MCI WorldCom and Sprint.
fields.body:
Europe's top competition watchdog said yesterday that it will launch a full scale investigation into the proposed £80bn merger of MCI WorldCom and Sprint.

The inquiry means that the two companies will have to wait four months before learning if, and on what terms, the European commission's competition directorate will allow the bid to go through.

"The commission has serious doubts as to the compatibility of the proposed merger between MCI WorldCom and Sprint, mainly because of the impact on competition in the market for top-level internet connectivity," the EC said in a statement yesterday.

The commission's competition arm, which is headed by former single market commissioner, Mario Monti, will also look at global telecoms services provided to major international companies and the impact on transatlantic traffic. A key concern for the commission is how much global telecoms business traffic would be in the hands of just two companies - the merged MCI WorldCom and Sprint, and Concert, British Telecommunications' joint venture with AT&T.

The EC's investigation is expected to run in parallel with a similar inquiry being undertaken by the US justice department and the Federal Communications Commission with which the European competition watchdog has pledged to co-operate.

The US and European authorities co-operated in looking at the 1998 merger of MCI and WorldCom, eventually demanding MCI shed its internet activities in order to avoid overlap. The subsequent sale to Cable & Wireless is believed to be the biggest disposal ever ordered by competition authorities.

Last month Sprint announced that it was selling its share of Global One, the joint venture with France Télécom and Deutsche Telekom, to the French telecoms company.

But yesterday's announcement makes it clear that the EC will be looking for further concessions - especially in the area of internet connectivity.

After the announcement the two US companies said they were confident of winning approval from Brussels and that the merger remained on course to be completed in the second half of this year.

fields.headline: Rattled BT moots break-up
fields.standfirst: Cellnet and Yellow Pages up for listing by 'undervalued' company
fields.trailText: A rattled British Telecom is considering plans to list its key operations - including Cellnet, its mobile phones business, and Yellow Pages - separately later this year to restore battered investor confidence and fend off an unwanted takeover.
fields.body:
A rattled British Telecom is considering plans to list its key operations - including Cellnet, its mobile phones business, and Yellow Pages - separately later this year to restore battered investor confidence and fend off an unwanted takeover.

Buffeted since the new year by a series of commercial setbacks and political rows in what insiders are already calling an annus horribilis, senior BT executives hope the plans will double the group's value by the start of 2001.

Sir Peter Bonfield, the group's chief executive, has disclosed moves for a restructuring of the group into separate business divisions. This could involve sweeping management changes.

But, angered by what they see as a systematic under-valuation of the former state monopoly in the face of the relentless advance of alternative operators and mobile phone companies, he and his co-directors plan to use this platform to float the units.

The hint that such plans are in the offing - though seen as highly defensive - was enough yesterday to send BT stock, which peaked at £15.13 on December 30, up almost 9% from 964p ("a steal" in the words of one industry source) to £10.51. It is understood that the plans are quite far advanced.

Analysts say that a "sum-of-the-parts" valuation of BT would put its share price closer to £15 or a market capitalisation approaching £100bn - rather than the £67bn it reached at the end of last week.

But the group estimates that, if and when the various floats go ahead, BT could be worth nearer £19 a share or closer to the values put on fellow "PTT" groups such as Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom.

"And they're still largely in state hands, with a heavy bureaucratic legacy," one exasperated insider said of the German and French giants which are flexing their muscles and earning plaudits by moving successfully into internet-related operations.

Yellow Pages, which also owns Yellow Book in the US and could be listed separately in New York and London, is said by industry sources to be worth £6bn.

But analysts at JP Morgan said the fixed-line operation could be worth £38.3bn, the internet operations £8.5bn, the Concert global venture with AT&T, £13bn, the disparate European interests £13.6bn and Asian investments £5.6bn. They have put a value of £21.2bn on Cellnet, the now wholly-owned mobile phones business, but other experts have suggested that rival group Orange - to be demerged or floated off later this year as part of Vodafone's merger with Mannesmann -could fetch more than £30bn.

Cellnet is the UK's second largest operator after Vodafone, although it lost ground to Orange in the surge of sales in the run-up to last Christmas. BT would hope to top Orange's value in any float.

The group, which refused to comment publicly yesterday, insists that its independence is not in question despite rumours that several rival groups, in the US and Europe, are considering approaches.

These include Deutsche Telekom, owner of the fourth UK mobile phone operator, One2One, SBC of America and Bell Atlantic. But analysts at Commerzbank believe a full-scale merger with AT&T, BT's Concert partner, is "the most obvious pairing".

Sir Peter, who fell out last week with the chancellor Gordon Brown over the timing of BT's plans to open up the "local loop" is said to be determined to beat off his critics with his plans.

webTitle: Courtaulds to axe more jobs as it fights US predator

fields.headline: Courtaulds to axe more jobs as it fights US predator
fields.standfirst: Foreign production to rise
fields.trailText: More British jobs are to be axed at Courtaulds Textiles as part of a plan to fend off a hostile takeover bid by American competitor Sara Lee.
fields.body:
More British jobs are to be axed at Courtaulds Textiles as part of a plan to fend off a hostile takeover bid by American competitor Sara Lee.

Colin Dyer, the Courtaulds chief executive, refused to say how many of the remaining 11,000 UK posts at 40 plants would be affected but insisted a further move to lower-cost countries was vital to increase the firm's competitiveness.

About half of the stitched apparel sold in Britain by Courtaulds is produced abroad, but that will be increased to 75% by the end of the year, using factories in Sri Lanka and Mexico. Courtaulds has already cut the number of British factories by a third.

Sara Lee eight days ago unveiled a £104m bid - at 100p per share - which was rejected by Courtaulds. Shares had fallen from a high of 355p two years ago to 60p just before the offer, but last night they closed up 1p at 127p.

Mr Dyer reiterated his view that the bid from the makers of the Wonderbra range badly undervalued his company but he would not confirm reports that he had demanded a price of 200p per share in earlier talks with the American predator. A formal defence document will be published by March 1.

Courtaulds, owner of the Gossard and Berlei lingerie brands and a top supplier to Marks & Spencer, is struggling to counter the impact of price deflation in the UK and the US which pushed down annual pre-tax profits before exceptionals from £36.1m to £27.8m.

A final dividend of 4.8p brings a total for the year to 10p, down from 15.3p last time.

Sales pressed ahead from £893m to £900.1m in the year to December 31 but Courtaulds will take a £42m charge during the next 18 months to cover the move to a lower cost production base.

Mr Dyer said: "We have accelerated the pace of our restructuring programme with a target of becoming globally competitive by 2001." The aim is to increase margins from 4% to over 6%.

Management also outlined a range of new initiatives including e-tailing ventures such as selling its Gossard Ultrabras and the new Shock Absorber sports bras over the internet plus development of a so-called slimming bra.

It also hopes to benefit from an increase in its business from M&S - which recently decided to reduce the number of clothing suppliers to three, including Courtaulds and Coats Viyella.

Courtaulds' 1999 financial results were not helped by falling sales at M&S, but the manufacturer admitted it had added to the difficulties with its own production problems, which lasted three months.

Like Courtaulds, Coats Viyella has been cutting back, closing 20 of its 35 plants in Britain and slashing the number of employees. It is at present trying to recruit British textile workers for relocation in Sri Lanka in order to help with the establishment of new plants over there.

webTitle: Staff given apology for job loss leak

fields.headline: Staff given apology for job loss leak
fields.trailText: Unions last night called for a Stock Exchange inquiry into extensive leaks of the insurance merger which meant thousands of employees learnt they may lose their jobs through the press.
fields.body:
Unions last night called for a Stock Exchange inquiry into extensive leaks of the insurance merger which meant thousands of employees learnt they may lose their jobs through the press.

George Paul, chairman of Norwich Union, yesterday apologised "most sincerely" for what he described as "an appalling leak" which meant most of the Sunday newspapers carried details of the £20bn transaction.

"We are upset that the staff who work for our companies had to learn about it this way," he said.

The insurers had sought Stock Exchange approval to delay the announcement of their deal - which will cost some 4,000 jobs in Britain - until 8.45 yesterday morning to allow time for staff to be briefed. The leak meant the deal had to be confirmed at 7am before any shares could be traded.

Roger Lyons of the MSF, which has members at both CGU and Norwich Union, demanded a "thorough inquiry".

webTitle: Bourse flotation plans take French leave

fields.headline: Bourse flotation plans take French leave
fields.trailText: The Paris bourse is in danger of being late for its own flotation. The French stock market had indicated it would launch a public offering of its shares this year - but yesterday a spokesman admitted that the timetable for the sale was likely to slip. "I can't say it [the sale] will take place in 2000. It seems more probable it will take place in the first half of next year."
fields.body:
The Paris bourse is in danger of being late for its own flotation. The French stock market had indicated it would launch a public offering of its shares this year - but yesterday a spokesman admitted that the timetable for the sale was likely to slip. "I can't say it [the sale] will take place in 2000. It seems more probable it will take place in the first half of next year."

But though he acknowledged the bourse had planned to launch a public offering on the basis of last year's figures - implying an offer for sale in 2000- he insisted that the sale had not been postponed. "It would only have been postponed if we had set a date and we had not done that."

Could it be that with cross-border share dealing in Europe turning into something that resembles a corporate battle zone, with established exchanges and upstart rivals slugging it out for position, the bourse is worried someone might launch a takeover bid?

"Absolutely not," insisted the spokesman. "If we were afraid we would not list at all." The official reason for the sale now being pencilled in for 2001 is to give time for two of the bourse's subsidiaries, Euronext and Clearnet, to build up recently announced alliances. But why should the bourse seek a stock market listing at all? It is already demutualised and a third of its existing shareholders are non-French.

For a start, it would mean the bourse would then be subjected to the same rules that it applies to companies listed on the Paris exchange - but it also wants to have shares it can use for acquisitions and joint ventures.

The snag is that key decisions about the most important development - the planned alliance between eight of western Europe's leading exchanges - is expected to be taken by November this year - well ahead of the likely flotation date.

fields.headline: Ford staff plan further strikes
fields.trailText: More than 3,000 Ford white collar workers took part in a one-hour strike yesterday despite last week's news of 1,500 job cuts at the group's main Dagenham plant in Essex.
fields.body:
More than 3,000 Ford white collar workers took part in a one-hour strike yesterday despite last week's news of 1,500 job cuts at the group's main Dagenham plant in Essex.

The professional staff at all Ford's British plants are planning to follow up yesterday's action with full-day walkouts on February 24 and 29, and a three-day strike early next month. The dispute is over a pay claim and the company's plans to merge the white collar and hourly paid workers' pension funds.

A Ford spokeswoman said it was too early to calculate the impact on business of the one-hour walkout but she expected it to be "minimal". She said that more than half the company's engineers, computer staff and clerical workers did not belong to the unions involved in the action.

The industrial action came amid further evidence of the deteriorating state of the British motor industry. Car production during the six months to January was 3.4% lower than the previous six months, according to figures published by the office for national statistics. Production for the domestic market alone was 9.8% lower than the previous six months.

At the same time, rumours of a takeover bid for BMW, the German car group weighed down by its loss-making Rover subsidiary, re-emerged on the Frankfurt stock exchange. Only last week the Quandt family, which controls 46% of BMW, was forced to reiterate that its shares are not up for sale.

About 1,000 Ford professional staff from four different plants or research centres attended a packed meeting at Basildon during their lunchtime action and were addressed by union leaders.

Robert Graham, a trade union official at Ford of Europe, said: "The strike sends out a message to the company that the professional staff aren't going to tolerate being treated as second-class."

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said: "I hope Ford recognise the strength of feeling and agree to meet us for meaningful negotiations."

However, the Ford spokeswoman said no meetings were planned, although the offer of an 11% rise over three years was still on the table.

She said the white collar staff were being offered the same as the hourly paid workers. However, union officials claimed that the manual workers were effectively getting 3% more because their hours are being reduced - with no loss of pay - to the 37.5 hours a week already worked by professional staff.

An MSF spokesman said he expected that the one-day strikes would either stop or slow production at Ford plants. "We do not think that agency staff and senior management will be enough to run operations across the country smoothly," he said. He said the action by a traditionally moderate section of the work force sent the group a message to come back to the negotiating table and strike a deal.

 The European Commission yesterday cleared Volkswagen's plans to buy from the Accor hotels and travel group the 50% of the Europcar International car hire business that it does not already own. It concluded that despite the virtual integration, Volkwagen would not have a dominant position in Europe.

fields.headline: Convergence Holdings
fields.trailText: Charles Cornwall yesterday achieved in a morning what he has spent the past five years trying to do with Eidos.
fields.body:
Charles Cornwall yesterday achieved in a morning what he has spent the past five years trying to do with Eidos.

The South African-born deal maker became chief executive of Eidos in 1995 and has since transformed it from a sluggish video compression company into the UK's leading computer games company valued at £718m.

But with just 3.3% of the equity he has "only" benefited to the tune of £24m. Friends say his lack of ownership is a sore point and Eidos's recent profits warning, which wiped more than a third from the value of its shares, only added to his frustration.

Mr Cornwall, who now spends most of his time in Los Angeles, was probably in far greater spirits last night. His £3m personal investment in Convergence Holdings, the latest internet investment vehicle, was worth £33m by the end of its first day's trading. The shares, placed at 10p climbed 11-fold to 110p, valuing the group at £112m. Mr Cornwall owns 30% of the company. Property tycoon John Beckwith and Carlton founder Mike Luckwell also bought 30% stakes for £3m.

Together they hope to invest in companies offering content and commerce to converging media. They have three invest ments: a 75% interest in consumer finance channel Invest TV; a 10% holding in PipingHot Networks, which provides broadband fixed wireless systems for data services; and NewMediaHotBed, a Los Angeles based incubator fund. Two more deals are on the way.

But can Convergence shares maintain their early form? The experience of the most recent soaraway incubator floats suggests not. Shares in Oxygen, the Elisabeth Murdoch-advised incubator, have fallen from 65p to 29.5p since their first day of trading last month. NewMedia Spark, the three month old Luke Johnson backed vehicle, trades at about a third below its high.

Short term demand distorts the price. Investors should wait a few weeks before deciding whether to join the rush.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After the sharp fall on Wall Street on Friday night, which saw 300 points wiped off the Dow Jones, and with New York's financial markets on holiday yesterday, there was little to support prices in London.
fields.body:
After the sharp fall on Wall Street on Friday night, which saw 300 points wiped off the Dow Jones, and with New York's financial markets on holiday yesterday, there was little to support prices in London.

Traders even turned their noses up at the appearance of another £20bn merger - the sort of deal which would have sent the Square Mile into a frenzy of dealings before we became completely blasé about big numbers.

So the FTSE 100 was allowed to drop as low as 6,030 at one stage, before closing a net 83.4 points weaker at 6,081.6. The leading indicator might have dropped back below the 6,000 level but for British Telecom , up from 964p to £10.51 after followers did their potential break-up valuations, and the electricity sector, which suddenly became a target for tech investors after PowerGen's deal with Affinity .

Elsewhere, it was all pretty glum. BP Amoco shed 18p to 468p - a near 4% move -while Shell was also under pressure, moving back from 457p to 463p after the recent crude price-inspired gains.

The banking sector was something of a disaster, with the likes of Barclays down from £16.48 to £15.73, Royal Bank of Scotland off 44p at 735p, bringing the price of stock in its new acquisition, NatWest , back from £11.26 to £10.72.

Before the e-threat rattled investors in the sector, and at the height of competition to buy NatWest, shareholders could have sold out at £15.

Having threatened to break through the 5,000 level (and having doubled since its launch in early November) the TechMark 100 was overrun by profit-takers, closing 91 points lower at 4,874.15.

Notable tech stocks under pressure included chip designer ARM Holdings , off 128p at £41.60, BATM Advanced Communications , sliding 312p to £57.25, Cedar Group (off 102p at £10.35) and Sema Group (losing 144p to £13.60).

Against this, there was some healthy demand for drinks group Diageo , which rallied 31p to 533p. The stock recently slumped to a three-year low, however, and interim figures are due on Thursday.

At the other end of the corporate ladder, the former financial journalist Steven Hargrave appeared on the market with a new penny internet stock, PrintPotato .

The venture, which is being backed by serial shell investor Nigel Wray, promises to provide company stationary over the internet.

Despite the unglamorous nature of the business, the shares surged from an institutional sale price of 3p a share to 13p at one stage, before settling at 12p on the AIM market.

webTitle: Reflections on a better Mirror image

fields.headline: Reflections on a better Mirror image
fields.standfirst:
Skinsavers for Piers Morgan
<A HREF="http://www.newsunlimited.co.uk/more_about/0,5167,133806,00.html">More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: The senior management of Trinity Mirror boast a phalanx of City advisers: investment bankers Greenhill & Co, corporate brokers Warburg Dillon Read and Charterhouse Securities, public relations consultant Finsbury, legal firm Lovells - and apologies to anyone left out. Yet they seem to be having trouble getting the best editor the Mirror newspaper has had in years off the rack.
fields.body:
The senior management of Trinity Mirror boast a phalanx of City advisers: investment bankers Greenhill & Co, corporate brokers Warburg Dillon Read and Charterhouse Securities, public relations consultant Finsbury, legal firm Lovells - and apologies to anyone left out. Yet they seem to be having trouble getting the best editor the Mirror newspaper has had in years off the rack.

Almost three weeks have elapsed since details of Piers Morgan's suspicious dealings in Viglen Technology emerged. Since then, two Mirror journalists have been sacked, Mr Morgan's stockbroker has left his employer, Kyte Securities, by mutual consent and at least three regulatory investigations are under way. While Trinity Mirror, a publicly quoted company, continues to reassure us that an internal inquiry at the Mirror - circulation 2.3m - has concluded that the matter should now be left to rest, the continuing dribble of fresh information on Mr Morgan's profitable sideline ensures it will not be allowed to do so.

So here are a few ideas on how Mr Morgan's skin might be saved:

 Point out that everyone is "up to it". It is well established that most, if not all, of those who invest directly in the stock market do so in the belief that they know something more than the next person. All speculators think of themselves, to some extent, as "insiders." Over the past six months the number of wannabe insiders has mushroomed. So many people are tipping, puffing and pumping that the whole matter has, in effect, been decriminalised.

 Draw attention to the fact that the regulators themselves are not in a position to throw stones. The stock exchange is charged with deciding, in the first instance, whether Mr Morgan or any of his associates might have done something wrong. Yet the exchange has had its own internal insider dealing problems. It is not widely known, but the department of trade began an inquiry into possible insiders within the exchange itself two years ago. It was claimed this was an isolated problem related to the company announcements office, but there was clear evidence that details of corporate activity had been leaking out of the so-called listings department - the most sensitive area of the exchange. Two years on, the DTI inquiry still appears to be under way and the work of the listings department is being transferred to the parent City watchdog, the financial services authority.

 Publish all Mr Morgan's trades, hand round the tin hats and hope the bombardment is over in a day or two. This is a basic rule of crisis management public relations. Failing to follow it leads outsiders to believe that there is something to hide and risks the drip, drip of new information we are now seeing at the Mirror. Alternatively, ignoring the rule may point to a misunderstanding about who the victims are: which is more sacred, Mr Morgan's privacy or the right of investors to be sure they are not being shaken down?

 Re-hire the City Slickers and back their "tips" with hard cash - publicly and after publication. This is the "tabloid" option. There is no doubt the Mirror's investing readership will miss the show-biz approach to financial journalism developed by Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell. But the danger with it was the creation of "bubbles" of demand for obscure, thinly traded stocks, with the end result that the main beneficiaries proved to be the City's market makers and other professional traders.

If Mr Morgan was to wager, say £1,000, each morning we might even construct a new Slicker index, charting the erosion of the editor's wealth. Given present market conditions, this would be a true public service.

Choice merger
The City has been massively underwhelmed by the planned merger between Norwich Union and CGU.

The perception is that the deal is defensive, and the most exciting aspect is that it could put both parties in play and spark off another round of consoli dation in the industry. Norwich Union and CGU see things differently, of course. They believe that by building up their domestic position they will provide themselves with a much stronger springboard into Europe. Together they would be the UK's biggest general insurer.

It is at this point consumers should sit up and take note. The European insurance industry already has some chunky players. Further consolidation - especially if those companies making the running are doing so on the basis of strong positions in their respective domestic markets - would hardly make for more competition at a time when, ironically, technology can make consumer choice a greater reality.

As an old eastern European joke goes: "Before the Berlin wall came down the authorities would not let us go on holiday in the west. Now the wall has gone none of us can afford to."

fields.headline: Screenplay Rank completes sale of Odeon group
fields.trailText: Leisure and entertainment group Rank yesterday completed the deal to sell its Odeon cinema chain to European private equity firm Cinven for £280m.
fields.body:
Leisure and entertainment group Rank yesterday completed the deal to sell its Odeon cinema chain to European private equity firm Cinven for £280m.

The sale marks the latest stage in Rank's restructuring under chief executive Mike Smith, who sold the company's nightclubs business for £150m last October. Proceeds will reduce the group's debts of £1.3bn.

The sale price was slightly below market expectations - industry sources had indicated that the deal could be worth £325m.

Cinven plans to merge Odeon, the largest British cinema chain with 20.6% of the market from 470 screens in 75 locations, with its ABC cinemas, the sixth largest chain in Britain with 57 sites. The deal makes Odeon 60% larger than its next competitor. Behind Odeon, UCI has 16.5% of the market.

Richard Segal, chief executive of Odeon - pictured above at Leicester Square in London - said Cinven would continue the investment programme.

"Odeon cinemas have been transformed in recent years and we now have the opportunity to roll that out to an enlarged group," he said.

webTitle: MPs give drugs chiefs rough ride

fields.headline: MPs give drugs chiefs rough ride
fields.standfirst: Glaxo and SmithKline's plan to move head office to US worries select committee
fields.trailText: The executives of merging drugs groups Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham had a grilling from MPs last night about their plans to move the combined company's operational headquarters to the United States.
fields.body:
The executives of merging drugs groups Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham had a grilling from MPs last night about their plans to move the combined company's operational headquarters to the United States.

At a meeting of the House of Commons' science and technology select committee, MPs sounded the alert about job cuts and demanded assurances that research and development functions would remain in Britain over the long term.

SmithKline's chief operating officer, Jean-Pierre Garnier, insisted the firms would keep open their research sites in Stevenage, Hertfordshire and Harlow, Essex "as long as the environment is favourable".

But he warned: "We are businessmen. Clearly, if there is a dramatic change to the environment in Britain, you would not expect us to stay." Mr Garnier was appearing alongside Glaxo's chairman, Sir Richard Sykes. They appealed for the government to invest more in further education in order to provide a supply of skilled scientists.

Sir Richard said: "The government has to ensure the universities remain competitive - that they breed excellence within the top institutions." Mr Garnier added: "There is no reason to be parochial. If the best science was in Beijing, we would go to Beijing."

They faced hostile questioning from some MPs: Labour committee member Nigel Beard said: "You are giving us a conditional assurance, rather than a real assurance.

"With the company's operational headquarters in America, won't there be inevitable pressure to push research and development over there?"

Labour MP Ian Gibson asked: "Do you understand the nervousness over here about your decision to move the headquarters abroad?" Sir Richard pointed out that the company would remain incorporated in Britain, with a corporate head office answerable to UK shareholders.

However, he insisted it was necessary to site operational control in America, close to the company's revenue base. Mr Garnier said: "The operational headquarters contains less than 0.5% of the company's population. It will not have a meaningful effect on the economy of Great Britain."

On job losses, the two men agreed that there would be redundancies "across the board" in Britain. Sir Richard said: "There will certainly be some duplication - there will be redundancies in the UK. But it would be foolhardy for us to make top scientists redundant."

They insisted that the number of cuts remained uncertain, and described unions' estimates of up to 5,000 job losses as "pie in the sky". MPs asked why the deal was more likely to go through this time than the failed attempt two years ago.

Sir Richard said the companies' manufacturing structure had converged during the interim period and Mr Garnier added: "We have overcome all the difficulties."
