webTitle: IPE halts wrangling with vote to end mutual ownership

fields.headline: IPE halts wrangling with vote to end mutual ownership
fields.trailText: Europe's largest energy market voted yesterday to end mutual ownership and become a for-profit public company. The vote ended a year of bitter wrangling about the future of the International Petroleum Exchange based in London.
fields.body:
Europe's largest energy market voted yesterday to end mutual ownership and become a for-profit public company. The vote ended a year of bitter wrangling about the future of the International Petroleum Exchange based in London.

Chief executive Richard Ward confirmed that share certificates were likely to be issued on April 3. From that date members will be free to trade their stakes in an exchange estimated to be worth £36m.

But any bid for the IPE would face a big hurdle, in that the clearing members of the exchange - as opposed to members interested only in trading - will each be required to hold stock equivalent to 1% of the equity.

Given there are 37 clearing members, that puts a near 40% roadblock in the path of a bid, and anyone making an offer would need first to call for and win a 75% majority at an extraordinary general meeting for a change in the articles of association.

Dr Ward said the 37% block was "a natural in-built defence mechanism", but a source close to the New York Mercantile Exchange, or Nymex - which last year bid for control of the IPE - said the American exchange had not ruled out another attempt.

The source said there remained a "neat logic" in the creation of a global trading platform based upon Nymex and the IPE.

Meanwhile the five "outside investors" lined up by the IPE to buy a total of 70% of the market as part of last year's failed demutualisation plan are now free to buy shares from any willing sellers.

The package approved yesterday involved only the principle of demutualisation.

A new company, IPE Holdings, will be created to own IPE Limited, the excha nge. Shares in IPE Holdings will be issued to members and will become tradeable, as will trading rights on the exchange.

The board retains the power to block share transfers, but will do so only if a potential shareholder is thought unfit by the financial services authority.

fields.headline: A kinder, gentler, better America
fields.standfirst: Over 25 years millions of listeners have fallen in love with Garrison Keillor's folksy, feel-good radio show.  Martin Kettle  meets the man behind the legend
fields.trailText: Over 25 years millions of listeners have fallen in love with Garrison Keillor's folksy, feel-good radio show. Martin Kettle meets the man behind the legend.
fields.body:
Garrison Keillor is sitting in his dressing room reading sonnets. Three thousand at the latest count, he says, and rising every time the postman calls. All because he suggested on the radio that listeners might try their hand at a Valentine's day poem.

"There are depths of love out there that we barely knew about," Keillor says. "It's not the simplest thing to sit down and write 14 lines. All these people, overcome by the need to write a sonnet. Just imagine that."

Imagining it is easy. A Prairie Home Companion - the programme that Keillor hosts each week - inspires levels of devotion that few radio shows can rival.

There are people who plan their holidays around A Prairie Home Companion so as never to miss a show, and people who plan their holidays so they can attend live recordings at the Fitzgerald Theatre in St Paul, the show's Minnesota home. So if Keillor asks these people for sonnets, he should expect sonnets.

A Prairie Home Companion goes out every Saturday across the US's National Public Radio network, just as it has done since it first started in 1974. This is therefore the silver jubilee season, and, to celebrate, Keillor and his team are bringing the show to Scotland and Ireland over the next couple of weeks, beaming it back live to the US and recording two episodes to be broadcast on Radio 4 and Ireland's RTE.

The show is a mix of all kinds of music and comedy sketches, culminating in a set piece "News From Lake Wobegon" monologue delivered by Keillor to about 3m rapt listeners. The show begins with and returns to Keillor. At 5pm Central Time he starts it, singing "Oh, hear that old piano/ From down the avenue..." Two hours later, as he announces, "And that's the news from Lake Wobegon, where all the women are strong, all the men are good-looking and all the children are above average," the audience know it's home time.

A Prairie Home Companion is an expression of Keillor's personality, his imagination and his values. Though the show is very funny, and the music is great, in some ineradicable way it is Keillor's loving and funny evocation of a kinder, simpler, better US that is at the heart of its appeal. "It's based on a kind of show that existed in my youth," says Keillor, who grew up in 50s rural Minnesota. "It's a live variety-show broadcast, but with some important differences." Like the range of its music, which can run from a cappella chorus through jazz, bluegrass, Cajun and Celtic, and occupies at least half of each show. And like the fact that Keillor devised and writes much of the show himself, sometimes finishing his script only just before the show airs.

Watching Keillor in rehearsal and then as he hosts his show, it's hard not to wonder why he subjects himself to it. What would make this bespectacled middle-class Minnesotan gentleman of 57 stand on a stage and perform Great Balls of Fire for the millions? What would make a man with a new marriage and young daughter rise every morning at 5am to write? Whatever else Keillor keeps hidden about himself, and there's a sense of a dark side to him, you know that this is a driven man.

He says that doing the show is "good work". He says it's "a little harder than you'd like to be doing ideally in your late 50s", but that it would be "a terrible waste to just drop it". He says he finds it easier to do these days. "One of the great secrets that they don't tell you is that your declining years are really a lot more fun than when you were riding high and you were nervous about losing your touch."

"In my view," says producer Christine Tschida, who has worked with Keillor for the past 10 years, "Garrison just has a need to stand up in front of an audience every Saturday."

People in Britain know Keillor mostly as a writer - which is also how he likes to see himself. Lake Wobegon Days, published in 1985, was the first - and in many people's eyes the best - of a succession of novels and comic writings that have appeared at regular intervals ever since. His latest - Me by Jimmy (Big Boy) Valente as Told to Garrison Keillor - is a satire on the other iconic Minnesotan of the present era, the state's improbable governor Jesse Ventura, the man they call the Body Politic.

Lake Wobegon is Keillor's Minnesotan never-never land. It permeates his books, and it has the honoured place in A Prairie Home Companion. "It's both real and imaginary," he explains. "But it does exist, it very much exists. Even here in Minneapolis and St Paul."

"All these rural people have come to live in the city, but they like to live on the outskirts, and they like to have an acre of land, two acres, three acres. These are Lake Wobegon people and they are a part of midwestern culture that's describable, and I think that I describe it.

"I write about it with love," he continues, "but I also write about it satirically, because the people themselves have a satiric mind. They're very ironic people. But I think their reticence is funny - their dishonesty, their inability to tell the truth to each other, the great length they go to. And they are stoics. Stoics I think are comical. They never give up. They keep at hopeless tasks. And these people don't believe that they are entitled to happiness."

Like the man himself, the writings may leave Minnesota from time to time, but it is to Minnesota that they always return. And the same is true of A Prairie Home Companion. Every year it goes on the road, occasionally, as now, overseas. But most of the shows are broadcast live from the Fitzgerald, the century-old theatre in downtown St Paul that Keillor helped to save a few years back, renaming it after the greatest of St Paul's literary sons. Keillor is an enthusiast of the author of The Great Gatsby - his cat is named F Cat Fitzgerald.

The on-stage understanding between Keillor and his house band (led by keyboard player Rich Dworsky), actors Sue Scott and Tim Russell, and sound-effects man Tom Keith, speaks of years of respect. But there's no disputing that the only real place to see the show is at the Fitz, in winter, on Keillor's home ground, with snow in the streets and a theatre full of cheering devotees, which is where I saw it earlier this month.

The weather looms large in Minnesota, and thus in the Lake Wobegon fantasy, and thus in A Prairie Home Companion too. "It's a neutral place for a conversation to start," Keillor says. "The show is about ordinary things. You don't need to have seen movies, or watched TV, or read books to understand the show."

Winter is a big deal in Minnesota - bigger than anyone in the Britain can really know. "Growing up in a place that has winter," Keillor has written, "you learn to avoid self-pity. Winter is not a personal experience - everybody else is as cold as you - so you shouldn't complain about it too much."

That passage is reprinted on a coffee mug that I bought in what must surely be the only store in the world devoted wholly to a radio show. Lake Wobegon USA is in the largest shopping mall on the planet - the Mall of America, outside Minneapolis airport. Dave Edin, who runs the shop, will talk Garrison Keillor with customers for as long as they are willing to listen. Which, in most cases, is a long time.

"I think about America every day," Keillor once wrote, "and imagine a town, an avenue of old frame houses, a boulevard of tall trees, a June night, lawn sprinklers swishing across the grass and popping the flower bushes by the porch. A dog on the porch. Lights behind the curtains. Rock'n'roll in an upstairs bedroom. Charcoal smoke in the air, a whiff of burgers. A gang of kids skidding around on gravel, giggling. A screen door slaps and a dad marches out to the garage. Yard after yard, block after block, every sight and sound and smell utterly familiar. This is the American neighbourhood of childhood comfort and fantasy, of teenage ambition, and of the tenderness and misery and splendour and comedy of marriage. Movies and novels of brutality and greed may sell a zillion copies, but they're irrelevant to the life of this avenue, which is based on faith, hope, love and humour."

In a sense, that's the key to the appeal of A Prairie Home Companion. "I hope you enjoy the show," Keillor tells the Minnesota audience just as they go on air. "And I hope I do too." It is great entertainment with a high purpose - and if you can come up with a better working definition of art, then you're welcome to it.

 A Prairie Home Companion will be performed in the Queen's Hall, Edinburgh (0131-668 2019), on Friday and Saturday and broadcast on Radio 4 on April 1 and 8.

fields.headline: Frantic assembly
fields.standfirst:
Even Goya, Freud and Renoir can't redeem an
uneven show at Walsall's New Art Gallery, says
Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Even Goya, Freud and Renoir can't redeem an uneven show at Walsall's New Art Gallery, says Adrian Searle
fields.body:
I bumped into Jacob Epstein's 1915 sculpture Rock Drill twice last Thursday. An amalgam of a real industrial stone drill and a futuristic - not to say Futurist - figure, the piece is an unwitting ancester to generations of pulp comic covers and TV and movie aliens. It also presaged a lot of sculpture which came much later in the century.

I came face to face with the 70s reconstruction of the original - which is now lost - standing guard over a new display of the modern collection in Birmingham City Art Gallery in the morning, and caught up with it again that evening, at the grand opening of the New Art Gallery in Walsall, a few miles up the road. Here, Epstein's masterpiece was perched uncomfortably on a chair, looking shagged-out and sweaty, taking a break from being a seminal work of 20th century art. The sculpture was, in fact, a stilt-walker in fancy dress.

Designed by architects Caruso St John, the New Art Gallery is a beautiful collection of spaces. The detailing of the building is exquisite, and the articulation of smaller and larger rooms, the internal staircases and interior balconies, make for an entirely pleasurable architectural experience.

The gallery is the new permanent home for the Garman Ryan collection. Occupying two floors of the building, this includes parts of Epstein's own collection (those pieces which weren't sold off, on his own insistence, after his death in 1959), and works which his widowed second wife, Kathleen Garman, continued to collect and to deal in with her subsequent partner, Sally Ryan, an American artist who had been Epstein's pupil.

Garman came from the Black Country and donated the collection to Walsall; since 1974, it has been housed in Walsall Library. Now it has been installed in a series of interconnecting spaces, unexpectedly clad in Douglas fir. It's like a flashback to the 60s pine kitchen; the effect is actually rather beautiful, intimate and beguiling.

The works form an uneven agglomeration. There's nothing wrong with that, of course, and the overall effect reminds one that this was, originally, a domestic and happenstance collection, based around Epstein's own works and his ethnographic collection (much of which was sold), and brought together by luck, life and accident.

The works are arranged thematically, which is probably the only way to deal with such an eclectic hotch-potch. Going from room to room, you make your own discoveries. There are some terrific things here: great etchings by Durer, Goya, Manet and Millet, a William Blake watercolour of Christ in the carpenter's shop, and a very iffy remnant of a Titian putti. There's a sombre, lowering Constable landscape in such a horrific gilded frame it looks like a tea-tray. These vie with glutinous and unambitious paintings by Ryan herself, as well as by Garman and Epstein's son, Theo. Just keep going, you tell yourself, it'll get better again in a moment.

The collection has many surprises: a tense little Géricault male nude, Van Gogh's Sorrow, an angular, self-consciously wracked drawing from 1882, a Matisse, a Renoir. Three Lucien Freud portraits - Freud married Epstein and Garman's daughter Kitty - have a concentration and intensity that stop me in my tracks.

It's a bumpy ride, however: here is a little Maori figure, there a Roman head of a mourning woman who has lost her nose (although that's not why she's mourning), in between some Inuit ivories. Epstein's sculpture of Frisky the dog and his portrait bust of TS Eliot are included, but the Epsteins here are mostly footnotes to a career. The collection was donated in a generous spirit, and that's the way we should look at it. Even so, there's enough that's worthwhile here to make one want to return.

Classic white walls take over in the temporary exhibition spaces upstairs. Currently hanging is an exhibition dedicated to the colour blue. This isn't terribly useful as an exhibition rubric, but it is a fairly gentle and uncontroversial way to introduce the Walsall public to the pleasures and terrors of modern art. Blue period Picasso meets Damien Hirst dots, an Yves Klein watery veil meets Derek Jarman's intimations of Aids-induced blindness, Bridget Riley does her optical fizz and a great little Miro sings from the wall. Blue isn't a great show by any means, but I'm lulled by all the blueness.

Looking out over Walsall's hideous shopping precinct, with the part tithe-barn, part Legoland castle of Woolworths hard by the New Gallery, I'm glad I'm up here rather than down there. Downtown Walsall is as dispiriting as a townscape gets, although artist Richard Wentworth has done something magical with the pedestrianised paving. He has resurfaced the streets and canal towpath in regular stripes of dark tarmac grey and gravel-yellow. Wentworth's intervention - which owes something to Daniel Buren, and something to the spirit of de Chirico - gives the townscape an air of mystery, makes us aware of perspective and distance, dramatises the people unconcernedly walking about on the stripes, which recede along the canal's edge, into a distance you can pace with the eye. The effect is haunting, and makes even Woolworths look peculiarly interesting.

A sense of mental place, of the geography of the mind as much as of buildings and landscape, is the key to the exhibition currently at the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham. Curated by the artist Tania Kovats, the show is called Lost. Unlike Blue - which is a self-evident catch-all - I'm not sure I entirely get the thesis for this exhibition. Here there is at least a conscious attempt to put together works by different artists which speak to one another in meaningful ways, rather than colour-coding them or arranging them into vaguely universal, totalising themes. And the Ikon has rarely looked better.

There's a real point to hanging an Agnes Martin hand-drawn grid (owned by the Tate) near Roni Horn's large metre-and-a-half rectangle of 99% pure gold foil, spread expensively across the floor. Both intimate a kind of energised plane, and make you wonder what it would be like if it went on forever. They make my mind ricochet back to Wentworth's stripes.

Before them, in a kind of anti-chamber, squats Thierry de Cordier's Trou-Madame. De Cordier has, as far as I know, never been shown in Britain, despite many hopeful curatorial treks through Belgian mud to the artist's remote fastness. His sculpture looks as though it has risen from the earth: it's a tarry, bituminous lump, like a misshapen bowler hat with a fat rubber brim made - so it appears - from the bumper of a dodgem car. This odd, curiously sexual sculpture - part lair, part coat, part female body - is so rich in association and metaphor it deserves an article all to itself. Other works in the exhibition - including Kovak's own - can barely compete.

But there are some very good things here, including a burlesque male and female couple with huge green apple heads, alarming sexual organs and peculiar extruded bodies, by West Coast artist Paul McCarthy. His Apple Heads on Swiss Cheese is a sort of gone-wrong Adam and Eve, born not into the Garden of Eden but into Disneyworld. I can see them now, wandering Woolies in Walsall, in search of a snake.

 Blue is at the New Art Gallery, Walsall (01922 654400), till May 1. Lost is at the Ikon Gallery, Birmingham (0121-248 0708), till April 2.
fields.bodyText: I bumped into Jacob Epstein's 1915 sculpture Rock Drill twice last Thursday. An amalgam of a real industrial stone drill and a futuristic - not to say Futurist - figure, the piece is an unwitting ancester to generations of pulp comic covers and TV and movie aliens. It also presaged a lot of sculpture which came much later in the century. I came face to face with the 70s reconstruction of the original - which is now lost - standing guard over a new display of the modern collection in Birmingham City Art Gallery in the morning, and caught up with it again that evening, at the grand opening of the New Art Gallery in Walsall, a few miles up the road. Here, Epstein's masterpiece was perched uncomfortably on a chair, looking shagged-out and sweaty, taking a break from being a seminal work of 20th century art. The sculpture was, in fact, a stilt-walker in fancy dress. Designed by architects Caruso St John, the New Art Gallery is a beautiful collection of spaces. The detailing of the building is exquisite, and the articulation of smaller and larger rooms, the internal staircases and interior balconies, make for an entirely pleasurable architectural experience. The gallery is the new permanent home for the Garman Ryan collection. Garman came from the Black Country and donated the collection to Walsall; since 1974, it has been housed in Walsall Library. Now it has been installed in a series of interconnecting spaces, unexpectedly clad in Douglas fir. fields.headline: Fuel fallout
fields.standfirst: The nuclear industry says its energy provides the answer to climate change. But it's still too expensive and too risky for the free market
fields.trailText: Thanks to Sellafield's troubles, the future of nuclear power is up for grabs again. Recently the nuclear industry has been upbeat. Gerald Doucet of the World Energy Council claimed here that nuclear will play "an essential role in electricity production and strategies against global warming".
fields.body:
Thanks to Sellafield's troubles, the future of nuclear power is up for grabs again. Recently the nuclear industry has been upbeat. Gerald Doucet of the World Energy Council claimed here that nuclear will play "an essential role in electricity production and strategies against global warming".

The pro case says nuclear power is carbon dioxide free and its waste can be reprocessed. It already provides a significant share of world energy (a quarter of the UK's electricity for example) and unlike other alternatives it is proven - nuclear works. Nuclear electricity is more expensive than gas but only because we avoid paying the true costs of burning fossil fuels. Create a level playing field by taxing carbon emissions and the market might decide to buy nuclear.

Or not. Energy policy in the developed world is driven by market liberalisation and the need to tackle climate change. But liberalised markets do not favour nuclear. Despite decades of public support for nuclear research and development, it is still too expensive. Its energy is more than twice the cost of the cheapest alternative. Gas costs 2p per kilowatt hour while, on an equivalent basis, nuclear costs 4.1p. Private investment in new nuclear capacity will make sense only if carbon taxes are very high indeed. Carbon taxes would need to double and possibly quadruple the current price of fossil fuels to level the playing field. Alternatively, each new nuclear power station would require £2bn of public subsidy. Neither is on.

The market favours gas for generating electricity. Nuclear stations cost too much, take too long to build and do not fit with a growing trend towards decentralised electricity generation. A new generation of smaller, more efficient nuclear stations could change the bare economics, but who will pay for the necessary research and development? The public? The UK nuclear industry received £7.8bn in subsidy from the fossil-fuel levy in the 90s alone. This compares with £0.4bn subsidy for renewable sources of fuel over the same period.

The private sector is unlikely to step into the breach. The technological breakthrough that would need to attract investment is unlikely after 40 years of intensive research and development. The long-term nature and political uncertainties of storing nuclear waste create huge financial risk for private investors. Reprocessing of waste is worse, as it combines high cost and the problem of plutonium proliferation - a threat so severe that most governments, including the US, want to end reprocessing of civilian nuclear waste.

Far from providing the answer to climate change, nuclear thus faces considerable challenges. So what should energy policy look like? Although carbon emissions have fallen since liberalisation of the UK's electricity market, this has been entirely fortuitous: a lower carbon fuel (gas) was cheaper than a high carbon fuel (coal). But reliance on gas will not bring deep and long-term cuts in emissions, particularly when existing nuclear stations have all reached the end of their lives, in around 20 years.

So how can we match energy policy to the business and environmental drivers, that require cheap, flexible, low-risk and low-carbon power? Carbon taxes alone are inadequate, at least in the short term, as energy sources cannot be changed quickly and prices have to rise a long way before consumption is reduced.

We need low-carbon options that are attractive to privatised markets. At present, many such options, mainly renewables, are either in the same uneconomic position as nuclear (or worse) or face political/practical limitations of their own. But this can be changed. It is up to the government to promote innovation and bring forward options that will allow climate change to be tackled.

This might not be so difficult. Many of the more innovative renewable and low-carbon technologies are already attracting the interest of private industry. Costs are falling rapidly. For example, the price of photovoltaic or solar cells are dropping by 15% each year. In 1980, wind power cost 22.5p per kilowatt hour - it is now 3p per kilowatt hour, competitive with nuclear and producing none of the waste. The oil and motor car industries now talk of climate change as a "business opportunity". The result is significant investment in developing renewable energy and other "clean" technologies - fuel cells, solar photovoltaics and microturbines for example. Market drivers, such the appetite for "green" electricity also have a role to play.

The state should encourage new energy technologies by means of tax incentives and support for demonstration projects and dissemination. Definite targets and close collaboration with industry could kick-start an important new industry - something Denmark and the Netherlands clearly recognise for offshore wind power, for example. Providing the revenues for these should be a key short term role for a fairly modest carbon tax.

As for nuclear, it needs to focus on the enormous technical and financial problems of decommissioning and radioactive clean-up. A paradox is that alongside failures at Sellafield, British Nuclear Fuels has proven highly successful at expanding its environment-friendly business cleaning up American military sites and dealing with the nuclear legacy of the communist era. This, not climate change, is the real task for the nuclear industry.

 Will Cavendish and Robert Gross specialise in energy and environment research at Imperial College, London

fields.headline: England v Argentina: the classics
fields.trailText: England versus Argentina clashes over the years have always been memorable, either through controversy or because of a moment of magic. Tomorrow's game at Wembley, though only a friendly, should be no exception.
fields.body:
England versus Argentina clashes over the years have always been memorable, either through controversy or because of a moment of magic. Tomorrow's game at Wembley, though only a friendly, should be no exception.

June 30, 1998, World Cup second round (St Etienne): England 2 - 2 Argentina (Argentina win on penalties)

The match was set alight when Michael Owen first bemused, then bedazzled the Argentinian defence before beating keeper Carlos Roa with a sublime finish.

But the clash was overshadowed by David Beckham's act of petulance as he kicked out at Diego Simeone while prone on the ground after being fouled.

The incident led to his sending off and widespread condemnation as England, despite a heroic rearguard performance through extra-time, crashed out to penalties.

June 22, 1986, World Cup quarter-finals (Mexico City): England 1 - 2 Argentina

Famous for Diego Maradona's controversial "hand of God" goal and his ravishing run at the England defence and finish.

The 114,000 crowd inside the Azteca and the millions more around the world witnessed him punch the ball into the net ahead of Peter Shilton's lunge. The Tunisian referee Ali Ben Nasser missed the blatant cheating.

Four minutes later there was no need for subterfuge as Maradona's talent exploded. After picking the ball up near the halfway line, with power, grace and almost condescending ease, he evaded three tackles before dummying Shilton and sliding the ball home.

England responded through Gary Lineker nine minutes from time. But it was too little too late.

July 23, 1966, World Cup quarter-final (Wembley): England 1 - 0 Argentina

The game which led to then England manager Sir Alf Ramsey describing the Argentinians as "animals" as they spat, tugged hair, poked fingers in eyes and kicked throughout a brutal encounter.

All hell broke loose inside half an hour when Antonio Rattin, who had spat in front of referee Rudolf Kreitlein, questioned every decision of the German referee and fouled all those who crossed his path, was eventually sent off.

It took eight minutes to quell the mayhem which followed as Rattin first refused to go, while the Argentinians threatened to walk off in protest. Order was finally restored to a match in which Geoff Hurst finally made England's numerical advantage count 13 minutes from time.

May 9, 1951, friendly (Wembley): England 2 - 1 Argentina

England met South American opposition at Wembley for the first time - they were only the second country (after Scotland) to play at the world-famous venue. Despite England dominating the early stages, they were constantly denied by eccentric goalkeeper Rugilo.

Argentina scored with their only serious attack of the first half and they held the lead until the 79th minute, but Stan Mortensen and Jackie Milburn netted late on to preserve England's unbeaten home record against foreign teams.

webTitle: Premiums may ease for long-suffering drivers

fields.headline: Premiums may ease for long-suffering drivers
fields.trailText: The CGU-Norwich Union merger could provide some relief for motorists who have endured sharp increases in car insurance premiums over the past year or two.
fields.body:
The CGU-Norwich Union merger could provide some relief for motorists who have endured sharp increases in car insurance premiums over the past year or two.

Industry observers predict that some of the cost savings resulting from the link-up would be passed on to motorists in the form of cheaper cover. But whether this will be enough to send the general trend for rocketing motor premiums into reverse still seems unlikely.

AA Insurance, which compiles a quarterly "premium index," said insurers are putting motor insurance prices up at a rate of 2% a month in an attempt to stem huge losses resulting from the spiralling costs of claims.

Its research shows that last month the average comprehensive policy cost £507 - 15% up on the figure of £438 for January 1999. In January 1996 the same policy would have cost just £334.

Younger drivers have been hit especially hard - a typical motorist under 25 saw average premiums shoot up 31% between December 1998 and December 1999, according to another survey, by insurance services group Hill House Hammond.

One insurance industry analyst predicted that a merged CGU and Norwich Union would be of a sufficient size to reap significant savings, part of which would be likely to be passed on to customers. The enlarged group would be the largest provider of general insurance in Britain.

fields.headline: For future reference
fields.trailText: I have recently had a job offer withdrawn becuase of "some aspects of my references which were unsatisfactory". I am really worried about my future job prospects and can't seem to find out why the job offer was withdrawn. Where do I go from here?
fields.body:
The problem

I have recently had a job offer withdrawn becuase of "some aspects of my references which were unsatisfactory". So far they've been unwilling to advise me exactly what aspects were unsatisfactory and my two referees are saying it is not their policy to provide copies of references. I am really worried about my future job prospects and can't seem to find out why the job offer was withdrawn. Where do I go from here?

The solution

What a nightmare! Unfortunately, your referees are under no obligation to reveal references to you, so, as you fear, you might never know what has been said about you. The simplest solution would be not to use these referees for future job applications. This would obviously be conspicuous since it is normal to put your last two employers down as references on job applications. Their absence could possibly be explained by excuses of managers leaving the firm etc., but would still leave doubts.

The other option then, is to take action against your referees. Referees can be sued for providing damaging references - if they cannot be justified. In other words, if your referee has said something negative, they must be able to substantiate it with evidence (such as written warnings to you etc.). Referees can also be sued for providing damaging references if you have reason to believe that they have done so because of your gender, race, sexual orientation or disability.

You will have to take legal advice now since there is little you can do on your own. If you are a member of a union, contact them and they should be able to take it from there. Otherwise, contact your local Citizen's Advice or a solicitor.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

The simplest solution would be not to use these referees for future job applications. This would obviously be conspicuous since it is normal to put your last two employers down as references on job applications. Their absence could possibly be explained by excuses of managers leaving the firm etc., but would still leave doubts. The other option then, is to take action against your referees. Referees can be sued for providing damaging references - if they cannot be justified. In other words, if your referee has said something negative, they must be able to substantiate it with evidence (such as written warnings to you etc.). Referees can also be sued for providing damaging references if you have reason to believe that they have done so because of your gender, race, sexual orientation or disability. You will have to take legal advice now since there is little you can do on your own. If you are a member of a union, contact them and they should be able to take it from there. Otherwise, contact your local Citizen's Advice or a solicitor. Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work (Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: Opera
fields.standfirst: Pelléas et Mélisande *** Ladywood Centre, Birmingham
fields.trailText: A reduced Pelléas et Mélisande, in English - can it work? The answer, after the first night of City of Birmingham Touring Opera's new production, seems to be yes and no. The reduction of Debussy's luscious orchestral score for two pianos is surprisingly effective - full credit to the sensitive playing of Jonathan Hinden and Steven Maughan. The very least one can say for Hugh Macdonald's translation is that it isn't embarrassing.
fields.body:
A reduced Pelléas et Mélisande, in English - can it work? The answer, after the first night of City of Birmingham Touring Opera's new production, seems to be yes and no. The reduction of Debussy's luscious orchestral score for two pianos is surprisingly effective - full credit to the sensitive playing of Jonathan Hinden and Steven Maughan. The very least one can say for Hugh Macdonald's translation is that it isn't embarrassing.

As for the cuts, some of them do prevent the action from reaching a standstill. But the removal of Mélisande's death, and of any references to her child, are as devastating as the amputation of a limb. They also leave the music trailing off inexplicably at the end. This surgically altered Pelléas fits with director Franco Ripa di Meana's idea that the old king Arkel and his daughter Geneviève are reincarnations of the tortured prince Golaud and Mélisande. But I only realised that because I read the programme; I wouldn't have guessed it from what happens on stage.

The set is a triumph. Economical to the point of minimalism, it adapts itself cleverly to each dramatic situation. It also works well acoustically, supporting the voices when they most need it. It's a shame it has to be loaded with inexplicable clutter: a rusty winch stretched just above the singers' heads, and lumps of what look like coal scattered and rearranged (noisily) about the central dais.

Soaring above all this is Christopher Purves's pained, tragic Golaud: beautifully sung and acted, this Golaud's failing is simply that he is all too human. He should be given a chance at the role again soon - only next time let's have the whole score, and the whole story.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Insurers hit the takeover trail
fields.standfirst: Legal and General the next target as CGU and Norwich Union confirm tie-up
fields.trailText: Takeover speculation swept through most of the leading players in the insurance sector yesterday after confirmation that CGU and Norwich Union are planning a £20bn tie-up designed to dominate the British market.
fields.body:
Takeover speculation swept through most of the leading players in the insurance sector yesterday after confirmation that CGU and Norwich Union are planning a £20bn tie-up designed to dominate the British market.

Legal & General, whose merger with NatWest Bank was scuppered last year, was tipped as a likely target while Allied Zurich was being named as a potential suitor for Royal Sun Alliance. Among the second tier companies, United Assurance admitted it has received a takeover bid from Royal London.

Shares in both CGU and Norwich Union wilted as they outlined details of their planned alliance which will cost 5,000 jobs around the world, sparking speculation that they might become prey for one of the big insurance groups such as the Netherlands' Aegon, Allianz of Germany or Italy's Generali.

However, negotiations have been under way for some time and a merger strategy is already in place, making it harder for a hostile bid to succeed. Underlining the problems faced by any corporation which might try to break up the agreed transaction, Richard Harvey, chief executive of Norwich Union, said: "We believe this is an immensely positive deal which will create excellent shareholder value. We believe this is the best transaction going."

Indeed, Mr Harvey and Bob Scott, the head of CGU who will become chief executive of the combined group, made it clear that they intend to hit the takeover trail mopping up other insurance companies and fund management businesses to increase the £200bn they will have under management. An offer for Gartmore, which is being sold by NatWest, is likely.

The enlarged company - which will be called CGNU but will trade as Norwich Union in Britain - sees much of its growth coming from savings business on the continent. But executives also promise cost cuts of £250m a year within 18 months.

The often divisive issue of executive positions in the boardroom and corporate succession has already been agreed. Mr Scott will head the company until he retires next year when Mr Harvey will take over. A new bonus scheme will be installed to offer incentives to managers to work towards the successful integration of the two companies.

Although neither CGU, which unveiled profits of £771m for last year and whose investors will own 58.8% of the enlarged corporation, nor Norwich Union has yet talked to any major shareholders about the deal, some institutional investors are known to be unhappy that the deal does not provide any premium to the Norwich Union share price which is barely above the levels at which it was floated three years ago.

Big shareholders are also keen for cash bids which will allow them to take money out of the unpopular financial sector and plough it into the fashionable telecoms, media and technology sectors.

But Roman Cizdyn at Merrill Lynch said: "The companies have recognised that they must be bigger. They are both quite lean machines so should achieve good cost savings."

fields.headline: Beyond the trends
fields.standfirst: BBC Symphony/ Oliver Knussen Royal Festival Hall, London/ Radio 3 ****
fields.trailText: It cannot have been an easy task to convey anything like the full range of Hans Werner Henze's music in a single portrait concert. There's no living composer of similar stature who has written so much, in so many genres, with such blithe disregard for musical trends and dogma. He has celebrated lyricism in an age when it was proscribed by the avant garde, composed operas when they were regarded as museums of the past, nailed his colours to the political mast when the musical establishment was doing its best to avoid such commitment. Henze's achievement is impossible to pigeonhole
fields.body:
It cannot have been an easy task to convey anything like the full range of Hans Werner Henze's music in a single portrait concert. There's no living composer of similar stature who has written so much, in so many genres, with such blithe disregard for musical trends and dogma. He has celebrated lyricism in an age when it was proscribed by the avant garde, composed operas when they were regarded as museums of the past, nailed his colours to the political mast when the musical establishment was doing its best to avoid such commitment. Henze's achievement is impossible to pigeonhole.

In their Festival Hall programme Oliver Knussen and the BBC Symphony Orchestra concentrated on three facets of that teeming output. There was nothing operatic, but the neoclassical world of the early 60s was represented by the Fifth symphony and Ariosi, rarely heard orchestral settings of Tasso; the Eighth symphony defined the Bergian chromatics of his recent music; while in the choral Orpheus Behind the Wire, to sub-Brechtian texts by Edward Bond, there was an echo of the fierce political radicalism that dominated his music in the 70s.

Above all it was a superbly presented celebration of an endearing and endlessly intriguing personality, in whose music unevenness is part of the package. Not every work comes off. The Fifth symphony is a wonderfully exuberant orchestral showpiece, to which Knussen gave a really stylish finish, but Ariosi isn't totally successful - that sun-drenched Mediterranean sensibility is better represented in other pieces than in these slightly forced exchanges of solo soprano (Carol Farley here) and violin (Ernst Kovacic). Whatever one thinks of the sheer fluency of the orchestral writing in the Eighth, inspired by Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, there's sometimes too much of it; especially in the galumphing scherzo there are passages that overstay their welcome. Yet the BBC Symphony made light of those congested moments, and the exuberance and honesty of the writing, as in so much Henze, triumphs in the end.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: No morality is too high a price to pay

fields.headline: No morality is too high a price to pay
fields.standfirst: The Muesli Belt Peacock Theatre, Dublin **
fields.trailText: It happened in London in the late 80s. Now it's eating Dublin alive - the boom that has seen property prices double and more in the last three years, with semi-derelict old residential areas in the city razed and redeveloped as apartment blocks and multi-storey car parks. Dublin playwright Jimmy Murphy feels bitterly about the little people, the old salt of Dublin town whom he here portrays in an ancient, run-down pub, with its tawdry trophies behind the bar.
fields.body:
It happened in London in the late 80s. Now it's eating Dublin alive - the boom that has seen property prices double and more in the last three years, with semi-derelict old residential areas in the city razed and redeveloped as apartment blocks and multi-storey car parks. Dublin playwright Jimmy Murphy feels bitterly about the little people, the old salt of Dublin town whom he here portrays in an ancient, run-down pub, with its tawdry trophies behind the bar.

Unknown to the dwindling clientele, the dishevelled landlord has sold the pub for a cool £750,000 - and with it the crumbling house next door. Sadly, his sitting tenant of 40 years, a widower and newly retired bin- man, had been planning to buy the house with his retirement package. Stoking the marinated debate is the bankrupt, vodka-alcoholic proprietress of the nearby hair salon, who swears she'll never sell out. A young barmaid, herself hard-pressed to pay the mortgage on her apartment, generally nurses wounds.

There's a lot of sozzled schmaltz in the writing, spiced up with some downright queasy examples of the Dublin dialect, which Murphy gleefully lards onto the dialogue. After the landlord's deal is revealed, the comic and dramatic tone slackens off considerably, into a series of long, maudlin farewells, like wringing a dishrag of every last drop.

Then, suddenly and paradoxically, the stage is electrified by the young developer, who comes to collect the keys and shut the place down. The sheer bombast of Don Wycherly's huge performance, in five hilarious minutes of brutal raze 'n' build philosophy, verbally demolishes every sentiment in the play, and with them, many sacred cows of the Dublin architectural landscape. With punchline after punchline, he wipes the stage with the other characters, sending the audience home cackling and, it has to be said, agreeing whole heartedly with him.

It's a real conundrum - this high-minded humour which devastates the whole moral purpose of the play. Murphy writes from direct experience of underclass Dublin, but one worries about the National Theatre's dramaturgical machinery in bringing a script like this to fruition. Certainly, this one runs aground in both Murphy's and director Jimmy Fay's confused instincts between wild-minded comedy and angry, feeling pathos.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Until March 25. Box office: 00 353 1 8787 222.
